The ingredient list contains no parabens and plenty of well known good performers (glycerin, Shea butter, hyaluronate) .  The only con is that inwish this was in a pump since exposure to oxygen is never good for beauty products.  This is a well formulated moisturizer that delivers hydration without shine or greasiness.

I really struggled with how to rate this product.  The sound quality really is excellent but the installation was definitely buggy. I am thinking this is closer to a 3.5 star product because of the difficulties we faced in getting the system set up and it is still not optimal.We are using this in a larger downstairs room and the system still delivers good quality sound.  At all ranges, the sound is rich and clear and travels through the entire room.  The footprint of this product is small and you are not stuck with a zillion speakers hanging throughout the room.  If installation had gone easily, then this would be a hands down 5 star product. My husband and I worked through this installation together and we ran into a problem with trying to get it to connect to our tv.  After running through the troubleshooting guide, we finally called the Bose customer service.  The customer service was very friendly and helpful.  Our SMART  TV is not brand spanking new but it does have an HDMI ARC input.  We could not get the system to work using the ARC input even after multiple troubleshooting tries with the Bose customer support.  The customer support person was exceptionally patient but could not figure out how to get the system to work with the ARC input.  We finally got the system to  work by running everything through the DVD player which is a less than ideal solution.  So if you have a fairly new tv (less than 3 years old) this will probably work perfectly for you and you should consider this a 5 star product.  If not, you may run into issues like we had and this may be a buggier set up for you.

Both my husband and I enjoy long distance running.  I have used a Nathan for carrying gel pouches and carried a collapsible water bottle but I have found that to be tiresome so I was looking for better hydration options.  Needless to say, I was delighted for the opportunity to test this product.  This product is definitely a winner.  The pockets easily held my galaxy or my husbands iPhone, keys, and gel packs.  The bottles were easy to grab when a drink was needed.  The waistpack was comfortable to wear and didn't move around when either I or my husband used this (even with a full bottle of water).  Neither I nor my husband could find any cons with this product.  Highly recommend

This is the fifth convertible car seat that I have installed over the last 8 years and this one was hands down one of the easiest to use.  Our son is two and a half so this was installed forward facing using the latch anchors.  We recently installed a Diono in our other car and the installation instructions on that seat were an absolute nightmare (although the seat itself was excellent).The seat itself is on the larger side (much larger than the Diono) and probably won't fit 3 across in any but the largest of cars.  It sits somewhat high which means my toddler can see out of the window very well which makes him happier.  Recaro is well known for making seats for racing cars and they are transferring the safety design features of their seats to their car seat line.  This seat should provide superior protection in a side-impact crash (which can be the most deadly).  In the US, seats are not required to be tested for side-impact crashes but this seat has performed well in side-impact crash tests in Europe. This seat has also performed well in independent crash tests. Another nice feature is the no rethread harness.  For most seats, to change the harness height, you have to uninstall the car seat, remove the straps from the splitter plate, and then rethread them into the higher slots. Sound like a pain in the neck?  That's because it is.  A no-rethread harness adjusts with the knob on the side -way simpler! For ease of use, safety performance, and comfort, I am rating this 5 stars.  The material of this car seat can not be machine washed- only spot cleaned.  Recaro recently recalled a large number of seats (the model I tested was manufactured after the recall date).  For some potential buyers, this may factor into their decision so I am including the information here.

This toy is a bit of a 21st century rock'em sock'em robot toy.  In this version, the robots have remote controls and spin (which is actually pretty cool) but the goal is to beat your opponent's robot.  In this version, you also kill a Forest of battery trees -10 AA batteries (negative blow to the environment and the pocket book is why this is 4 stars).Outside of the painful battery costs, this toy is pretty entertaining and kept the kiddos occupied for quite a few hours. The toy was relatively simple for my boys to figure out and so far, we have not seen any signs that the toy will fall apart easily.  The price is pretty high, especially when you count in the cost of the batteries.

I was torn between a 5 star and 4 star rating for this car seat.  Quality and safety wise, this is an easy 5 stars.  It is a highly rated seat in terms of safety.  This does not have the wings that some of the other models have but in my case, that is a bonus.  My child hates the wings. Not sure why because he is 2 and logic usually does not factor into his decisions.  I seriously considered subtracting a star because I found the instructions difficult to follow.  The pictures were in black and white when they really should be in color.  So there was some mumbled curses while I figured them out.  But, at the end of the day, the instructions were a few hour inconvenience while the car seat will be a multiple-year product.  Since the product itself is so good, I will go with 5 stars.  But be pre-warned, grab a nice glass of beer or wine or cocoa to indulgE yourself and settle into and accept the frustration.This seat has the advantage of a narrow profile so it can be used 3 in a row.  The frame is truly made of steel.  It makes for a heavier but way more solid feeling seat.  We have a 2 year old so use are using forward facing with 5-point harness.  This will seat rear-facing to 45 pounds so can be used for extended rear facing but without some of the bells and whistles of the RXT and GXT models (like wings).  This will work for a newborn through pre school or Kindergarden so it truly is a seat that will suit all your needs.  This is a top-rated safety seat and it feels it.

My 8-year -old son is doing a mystery/detective unit in school and this was a great compliment to what they were learning in the classroom.  This is really a science lab kit with a detective twist -lots of experiments for kids to run.This set is probably best geared for kids at least years of age.  The set comes in a case and comes with a guide and a bunch of detective tools (finger printing powder, crime scene tape, magnifying glass, black light, tweezers, notepad for writing crime details).  I really liked that this kit wasn't electronic and that it let my son use his imagination and brain to work through the problems.This is a great set for kids who like to solve puzzles and riddles.  They will have fun and maybe pick up a bit of science.

With the trend towards paleo and gluten-free eating causing many people to eliminate pasta from their diets, the increased interest in spiralizing is spawning many cookbooks. Spiralizers basically turn vegetables into noodle substitutes.  Paradise for veggie lovers and a great gluten and grain free substitution.My family loves vegetables and we look for lots of ways to incorporate veggies into our diet so I was very interested in trying this cookbook.  So far we have tried a handful of recipes and all have been VERY good.  The book organization is by diet type and not meal type so you can't flip to a soup or salad section.  Instead, there are paleo, vegan/vegetarian, raw food, gluten-free chapters.  There is also 3 chapters covering basics, the spiralizer pantry, and getting started.  We have liked what we have tried but the only downside is that there is an awful lot of squash recipes.  I guess there is a limit to what will spiralizer but boy is this squash heavy.

This is a workout targeted for intermediate/advanced exercisers and it is now my new favorite workout program.  I am midway through week 7 and I have gained noticeable definition in my arms , legs, and waist/core (comments from coworkers on my arms:) I am an exercise fan and have been working out for years but I have been holding on to about 6 pounds of post-baby weight for 2 years and I was looking for a program to help me kick up the intensity.  This did not disappoint.First, this really isn't a program for beginners. I would consider myself an advanced exerciser. This year, I have run 2 half marathons and I can do full push-ups, pull-ups, and chin ups.  I found this program difficult but doable.  I began this program able to do a full push-up but now I can do clapping push-ups.  So I am very pleased with my gains in strength and definition.This program requires only weights (light to heavy).  The workouts are all about 30 minutes long and have a warm-up followed by 4 circuits each consisting of 3 minutes of strength, 2 minutes of cardio, and 1 minute of core. There are multiple types of exercises included from body weight only, plyometrics, balancing, static holds, ect. This really does work multiple muscle combinations ans muscle fibers.  There is a lot of jumping and plyo so if you have issues with joints, you will probably want to pass on this.The program is led by Jillian and a group of professional trainers.  There are quite a few I have seen in other programs including Zuzka Light, a personal favorite.  Jillian's banter with the cast is friendly and light spirited and the cast is all superbly fit and strong -definitely enjoyable.So far, I have lost 2 pounds and increased muscle definition.  I am going to do the 21 day fix extreme after this and then repeat this program.  I will update with a comparison of the two programs.

I have yet to jam this shredder, it really will handle up to 12 pieces of papers.  I haven't tried a CD but it will chomp through a credit card.  This really is a powerful shredder that is simple to set up and use.  Instead of long shreds, this shredder is a micro shredder. It creates small confetti like little squares which are much harder to piece together and provide more security.  This shredder is pretty heavy duty (and very heavy) and feels like it should last for a while. The shredder is on wheels which makes moving it simpler. Another nice feature is the removable waste basket.  I have no complaints, I like everything about this shredder.

This toy is just fun.  We set the target up in our lawn and my boys have had hours of fun playing with this set. The bow is easy to use for an 8-year-old, the arrows light up, and the target is colorful and fun- this set is great for little kids.  The arrows stick to the board using suction and stayed on through the round.  So far, nothing has fallen apart so I give this a thumbs up.

I am a fan of anything that will get kids to read and Captain Underpants gets kids reading. This series is crazy popular with the under 10 set-even reluctant readers pick up these books.  So how is this latest installment?  According to my 8-year-old, "give it 5 stars".  He loved this book and read it in one sitting.  I also read it in one sitting.  The story was entertaining-don't expect anything dramatically different with this book (well except for some minor political jabs).  The puns are there, the story is wacky, and there is flip-o-Rama (of course).  If you have a fan in your house, they will love this book.

I suffer from seasonal allergies and was very interested in testing out this model.  This purifier is for smaller rooms and comes with a HEPA filter.  This also has an ionizer option that you can us to increase the air cleaning.  The unit arrived read-to-use with almost no set up.  The manual was straight forward and well written and did provide good instructions and some useful information.I set this unit up in my bedroom.  It runs fairly quietly and provides some nice white noise.  I have been running it continuously and I have definitely noticed an improvement in my allergy symptoms even though pollen counts have stayed steady. There are three settings, high, medium, and low.  I run it continuously in low.  The unit requires a new filter around every three to four months.  This is a nice product at a nice price.

I paired this with a Mac without any issues, it seems to stay paired without any issues.  As we acquire more and more devices, the amount of wires seem to increase exponentially so anything wireless is always nice.The keyboard and mouse have a minimalist design which like more on the mouse than the keyboard. The keyboard is smaller than standard, this is a result of some unconventional placement of keys like the arrow keys.  Since I touch type and rarely look at the keyboard, this is a bit of an inconvenience. Now the mouse I really like. I am a small person and this smaller than average mouse just feels very comfortable in my hand.If you are running an older machine that is not Bluetooth enabled you will need to purchase a dongle.If you are touch type this keyboard may drive you batty.This is a nice but not spectacular keyboard.

I have mixed feelings on this cookbook.  The recipes are great so I am going with four stars.  There is definitely an Asian theme but the author is Asian and writes in the introduction that these recipes are inspired by how she ate and cooked while growing up.  Asian inspired recipes are a huge hit in our house (especially with my 8-year-old son) so that is a selling point for us. The recipes we have tried have been very tasty.  I think this is just trying to take advantage of the huge popularity of CSAs but really it doesn't really fit that well.  There are a lot of unusual ingredients like tomato leaves, radish leaves, or pea shoots.  Well, in the CSAs I have been a part of, I have never gotten tomato leaves because the farmer keeps them on the plant so the tomatoes will keep growing.  This is really a Use All of Your Garden cookbook and would be better suited for gardeners.The mixed feelings comes from the intro and writing stype which I  found a little off putting.  She writes about how she grew up with an immigrant family that always cooked and ate all the ingredients and how they were cooking while their American neighbors were eating boxed mac and cheese and wasting half their produce.  Really?  I grew up eating home-cooked meals and not mac and cheese or other convenience foods.  Many Americans of my generation ate  real home-cooked food with real vegetables.  The whole vibe of the intro felt like she was saying "silly Americans, let my wise Asian culture teach you how to eat real food" which I found somewhat insulting.  The writing as a whole just felt somewhat patronizing to me which is why this is not a 5 star book.

This is a hard case is designed for the iPadAir 2.  It was easy to snap on and connect via Bluetooth. I really enjoy the keyboad, it has made my iPad feel like a small laptop computer.  Since this is being used on my work iPad, it has really increased the usability of the iPad especially when I am traveling.  The instructions say that the battery can go for about 2 years between charges and then it is charged via a USB port.  I have only used this for a month but the battery shows no signs it will need a charge soon.  The only minor con for this is that the case is somewhat on the heavier side.  I really can't think of anything else negative.  My coworkers have eyed this up, tried it out,  and the general consensus is that everyone else wants one.  One of the best keyboard cases I have seen yet.  Definitely recommend.

This is a solid and well constructed bunk bed.  This bed has a maximum weight allowance of 125 pounds so this is really only meant for children through their early teen years.  I could not determine what type of wood this bed is made of but it does seem to be made of some sort of hardwood.  It does not seem to be made of pine or some other cheap type of soft wood.When this arrived, I was really impressed with how it came.  You could drive a car over this and you probably wouldn't damage it.  A lot of care and thought went into ensuring it would arrive without any damage.On the other hand, the instructions were not well done.  There were pieces missing from the instructions and the pictures could have been clearer.  I was tempted to remove a star for the instructions but because the bed quality was so good I decided I would note it in the review so that buyers would be forwarned.  For example, in one place, it indicated that pieces G, D, and E were required.  It left off piece H although piece H was in the picture.  Sometimes they indicated that the orientation was important and in other places they didn't (even though it was).  Since there sometimes could be two ways the orientation could work but only one was correct, this could lead to problems a few steps later.  If the orientation was wrong, you would have to take the last couple of steps apart.Quality-wise, this bed is excellent.  We have put together many pieces over the years and this is definitely one of the better built ones.  We really were pleasantly surprised at how well made and solid this bed is.  I am a bit of a worrier parent and I had no qualms about my child sleeping in this bed.  The pieces fit together perfectly with perfect alignment.  This bed should have no problems standing up to children (this is from a mom of two rowdy boys).  I would expect this to last many years.Overall, I would definitely recommend this bed.  The quality is very good and should last long past when your child outgrows this bed.  If you have a very large child, please not the maximum weight allowance of 125 pounds to determine if this bed will work for you.

This was mostly tested by my 8-year old son who really enjoyed playing with this product.  The removable stock and barrel extender doesn't really seem to add much value and I think some of the other Nerf products shoot better and farther than this one.  My son thought this was cool but then seemed to abandon the extender after a couple of days.  Its a fine product but there are better Nerf guns out there.

Toshiba's Satellite Laptops come in different series. This particular model is their C series which is aimed at the budget-minded consumer who wants a basic laptop without the extra features.  As such, this is a great entry-level laptop for school work or for someone who just requires a basic computer for email and other household tasks.  This is not the laptop to buy if you do graphic design or gaming. Toshiba offers other series with more features for more intensive activities.  Other series are the S (more power and speed, better display), P (their premium line, way more features), L (next level up from C, a few more features), and the CL (designed to be more portable).  This is reviewed accordingly as a basic feature laptop.  For a basic feature laptop, I think they have done a very good job of packaging a lot into this value-positioned machine.  This computer comes with a very respectable 8 GB RAM, 1 TB storage, and a very nice Core i5 processor. This was ready-to-use out of the box and set-up was an absolute breeze.  I set this up for myself and for my school-age son who has been using this for school work and online academic programs.  Very simple set up.This laptop has one USB 3.0 port and two USB 2.0, an HDMI connector, and a DVD  player/burner. Also comes with video camera.  Wireless is only 802.11 b/g/n (not ac).This laptop does not have a touchscreen and the screen quality is really pretty average  The keyboard is not backlit and definitely feels on the cheap side.  I have noticed keys getting a bit stuck under the edges of the keyboard.  Not a big problem but definitely contributes to the cheap feel. I guess if you are going to scrimp somewhere on a value laptop, I'd rather it be the keyboard then the hardware. The cons are mostly minor and outweighed by the pros (good  processor, RAM, and storage) so I would definitely recommend this laptop.  It would be perfect for kids who need a computer for school or for the casual home user.

This is a large (and heavy) printer that takes up a large footprint.  Set up of this machine was pretty straight forward. The instructions were clear and easy to follow and I had no issues setting up the machine.  I set this up to print wirelessly.  Again, instructions were very clear.  I didn't need to install any drivers because this was recognized by all my machines as a network printer.Print quality was ok, not spectacular but not terrible.  I printed a photo as a test and some routine color documents.  I wouldn't use it for routinely printing photos but it is fine for normal household and homework use.  I can't comment on the longevity of the ink cartridges yet or the durability as I have only been using the machine for a few weeks.  If these do not perform as expected from the product description, I will update this review.  The scanner and copier functions worked well but I did not test the Fax.  Overall, this is a nice multiple-functional machine that is good for routine household use.  I would not recommend this if you want crisp high-quality printing but for routine use (which is how this will be used in our household) this is a good machine.

This is a facial cleaner that is meant to compete with the more expensive alternatives such as the Mia.  I have tried a variety of deep cleaners and in my opinion, most of them perform similarly, the extra cost is for the perks.  Overall, this does a comparable job for facial cleaning as the more expensive Mia and the less expensive Olay Pro -X.  The Silk'n offers more perks than the Olay version such as charging station (instead of batteries), more brush options, and more variations for speed.  This has less options than the Mia (only one button to cycle through the speed options and no signals to move between facial zones).  Construction-wise, this feels not quite as well built as the Mia but sturdy enough.  I have only used this for a few weeks so I can't comment on long-term durability.As far as cleaning goes, this performs well.  Extra cost is for the product perks.  Overall, a good cleaner.

My toddler (and my older child!) find this toy fascinating.  My 2 year old has been playing with this for a couple of weeks and really enjoys this toy. Since it makes no electronic sounds, requires no batteries, and builds skills, I like this toy too.  These click and pop pieces are easy for small pudgy hands to grasp and put together.  Each side has either a cup or a ball on the end.  The ball fits into the cup and has to be pushed firmly in until it snaps together, a nice hand eye coordination activity.  My youngest just turned 2 years old and he is able to fit the pieces together so this is definitely doable by the youngest of the recommended age range.  Pieces are holding up to toddler use.  We've been making shapes, letters, and practicing colors together. Great toy!

I have very mixed feelings on this device.  When it works, it is great.  The problem I have been having is that the device keeps disconnecting from my phone.  Often multiple times a day.  A device that is supposed to keep you connected to your phone should stay connected to your phone.  This seems pretty obvious.  I have rebooted my phone and that doesn't fix the issue. So it is hard to give this anything but 3 stars.One of the features that you can download is a fitness tracker.  Well it is very frustrating when it disconnects right before or during your workout and then you lose all tracking of the exercise.  One note, this seems to underestimate the steps you take.  My counted steps and my recorded steps were about 10% off.The device was pretty straightforward to set up.  The app was easy to easy.  If the device was more reliable, this would be a 5 star product.5/2/15. Updating this review and downgrading to one star.  Now this device is failing to hold a charge for more than a couple of hours.  This band lasted just a couple of weeks and now seems to be almost dead.  I would suggest passing on this device.

This is a fun and stylish watch that is also a beautiful piece of jewelry.  The face on this watch is large and I was a little worried that it would overwhelm my small wrist (I am slight to medium framed but only five feet tall) but it looked great. The band also could be worn without needing another hole added so I was pleased.  Materials wise, this looks like a beautiful and nicely constructed watch.  This is not a watch that is made for hard wear. The instructions state that the leather should not be exposed to water other than briefly.  The face is made of mineral so is scratch resistant but not as durable as one made of sapphire.  The watch itself, minus the band, is water resistant to 33 feet so with a different band this could tolerate showers.  What this is is a beautiful fashion piece not a piece for hard wear.

This is the fourth convertible car seat I have used over the years.  This one lacks a lot of the bells and whistles you will find on higher end car seats but it is comfortable and very easy to use.  And to be honest,  extras like the cup holder on my other seat seem to be used to hold crumbs and whatever else my little magpie has decided to collect and rarely used for cups.Any car seat you will find for purchase will meet mandated safety requirements.  All car seats have to meet these safety guidelines and every year, they are safer.  This seat was easy to install and comfortable for my child.  My child seems to prefer this seat to the fancy more expensive seat I have in the other car.  The harness is easy to tighten or loosen.  I can't comment on how well this works for a young baby since I used this with my 18 month old child but for the toddler set, this is a great seat at a great price.

This book is targeted for kids in first to third grade and will probably appeal to more boys than girls due to the subject matter.  The story is about a bug-loving boy, Max,  who gets an old book about bugs.  While peering at the bug island in the book through the book's magnifying glass he says" I wish I could go there" and finds himself transported to bug island (hmmmmm..... I wonder where that plot device came from).  On the island, he finds himself in a world where bugs are in a war for survival against the lizards.  Max uses his big human brain to help save the bugs from the lizards.  The story appealed to my 8-year old boy who read it in one sitting and now wants the next one.  For kids who like war and bugs, this should be a hit.

This bike seat is differently styled than any I have seen or used before.  This sits on the front handlebars so that your child is seated in front of you.  They have a handle bar of their own to hold on to.  I wasn't sure how this would work when actually riding the bike but it worked surprisingly well. It doesn't feel less safe than having the seat in the rear. And just as important, my child loved sitting in the front and being able to see so well.  He keeps begging to "bike, bike. mommy".  Since modeling an active lifestyle is important to us, a product that makes this more enjoyable for all members of the family definitely helps!Instructions were pretty easy and the products seems durable and well put together.  I have had good experiences with this brand so I expect that this will hold up pretty well.  Definitely a recommend.

This is a cute casual watch with a cute band and a classic face. The band is a polka dot canvas.  It probably will only last one season but since the watch face is very classically styled, it would be very simple to pair this with another band.  The watch is reasonably priced and looks great.  There is really no cons to this watch.

OK, its hard to get excited about wiper blades but I was really pleased with these.  Yes, they work and they seem to work pretty well.  What I really liked about them was the convenience of being able to buy both blades for my car in one package.  Installation of these was pretty easy.  I am not one of those people who can fix anything on their car but I had these installed in about 5 minutes. The instructions were very easy to follow and nicely illustrated.

This may have been the most painless set up experience I have ever had with wireless speakers.  Connecting this speaker to my iPad took under 5 minutes and the instructions were unbelievable easy to follow.  There was no need to download a special app and the devices paired immediately with no troubleshooting.  I paired the speaker, started the music playing and it was a little dance party for me and my toddler.  This easy experience engendered quite a bit of love from me as I have had some painful experiences in the past with wireless speakers.  The speakers were small and the battery life seems pretty good, I haven't reached the end of the batteries yet so I can't comment on how long but this isn't a battery eater.  The speakers have a USB port for charging devices.  The sound is pretty good, not as full as I would hope but pretty good.  This speaker has also been pretty much problem free to use, no troubleshooting or connectivity issues.

This is a very affordable K'nex set with multiple design ideas.  My 7 year old son loved this set and happily spent a couple of days working through all 5 designs and then happily making his own creations.  The price point of these would make them a fantastic birthday gift and I will be buying a few of these to use for a bunch of the birthday parties my son has been invited to.  Very pleased with these.

I have purchased both expensive (plus 100 dollars), cheap (around 30 dollars), and in-between non-stick cookware.  Minus differences in weight and quality of the riveting and construction, they all have seemed to last around the same amount of time before the nonstick surfaces ceases to be nonstick (between 1 to 2 years).  Therefore, I really am reluctant to spend a lot of money on nonstick cookware.  For me, this is a good price point for nonstick cookware.  The construction on these is a bit on the light size and I would not recommend this for high heat cooking but as a nonstick set, this is definitely serviceable. I have really liked the little single serve egg pan, its perfect for cooking eggs for breakfast sandwiches.  The nonstick surface performs well enough, some minor sticking if you do not add oil (or make sure the oil coats the pan).  In general, I am pretty pleased with this set and think it would be a good starter set.  One thing that is a bit misleading is calling this a 14 piece set since 4 of the pieces are measuring spoons.

I have been looking for cookbooks like this because both my husband and I work outside the home and we have two small children.  Cooking during the week needs to be quick and easy because the time between walking in the door and toddler melting down is unfortunately pretty short.  This cookbook offers 8 strategies for planning and preparing meals that can be ready to eat quickly (prepare ahead, reheat and eat, bake and serve, fridge to table, shop smart, Sunday cook, crockpot, stock the freezer).  This book also has a hints and tips section for making prep ahead easier.  We have tried a couple of recipes in this book and have been pleased with all.  In particular, there was a roasted eggplant lasagna that everyone in the family (including my husband and toddler loved).  I have been married for 14 years and this is the first eggplant dish that my husband actually liked and the toddler just demolished it.  The toddler also loved the chicken shish kabobs (as did everyone else in the family).  The only real con to this book was that the preparation time for some of these recipes could be pretty long (over 2 hours in some cases).  Since the one thing we don't have  a lot of is time (something many of the potential readers of this could book probably share in common), it would have been nice to see more meals with shorter prep times.  I also wish the section of stocking the freezer was a lot longer.  But for the most part, this cookbook was a win.

This vacuum is targeted as a more budget-friendly version of a popular but very expensive brand.  Honestly, it has a lot to offer and is definitely worth looking at more closely if you need a powerful vacuum but don't want to drop 500 bucks on a vacuum.  First and foremost, this vacuum has A LOT of power.  When I stopped moving this vacuum, I could see a cheerio two inches away from the vacuum being pulled into the vacuum head.  I vacuumed my room just after going over this with my Miele and this pulled up a bunch of new dirt.This vacuum can be used on hardwood floors and carpet.  Turn off the brush (little button near the top) and this is suitable for hardwood floors. Turn on the brush and you can do carpets.  This comes with the standard hose, wand, and crevice tool so that you can spot clean, do edges and corners, and furniture.  This also comes with a pet erase tool (I think this is the only feature that really is specific to a  pet vacuum).  The vacuum head of this vacuum was pretty maneuverable which made it very easy to vacuum around furniture and tables and under things.This did a pretty good job as a vacuum and considering the price, is definitely worth looking at closely if you are in need of a new vacuum.  There are a few things that keep this from being a 5 star vacuum.  First, it is heavy at close to 17 pounds.  Second, the instruction manual was definitely missing key details that made assembly and early use a little difficult.  There is no release button for lowering the handle, just pull down.  I didn't want to break it if there was a release handle so I was pretty gentle and I couldn't get the handle to lower.  Finally figured out that there was no release button and I just pulled down hard and the handle lowered.  The cord does not retract.  I have gotten spoiled by retractable cords and this has a long cord to roll up.All in all, a pretty good vacuum for the price.

I really really really glad that this is not a seasonal specialty because this is probably my new favorite creamer. This product is the non-refrigerated liquid singles with sugar (this is not the sugar-free variety).  I used 2 singles in my morning coffee and it really did have a clean strong taste of peppermint mocha.  This is a stronger flavor than some of their others (hazelnut, caramel macchiato, french vanilla) and you really only need one or two to get the effect.  This is delicious treat for when you would like an indulgence.

There are a lot of things to like about this stick vacuum.  There are also some areas where this could be improved.  I spent a lot of time trying to decide between 3 and 4 stars for this vacuum but I ended up going to 4 stars but it is really a 3 and a half star product.This is a cordless stick vacuum that also contains a handheld vacuum.  It is very easy to remove the handheld vacuum.  This came with crevice and dusting rushes for the handheld.  The handheld did a pretty good job on cleaning up popcorn on the couch and cleaning the car.  The maneuverability of the stick vacuum was pretty amazing, I have to admit I was impressed with how easy it was to navigate my kitchen and dining room with this (one of the features that I feel elevated this to the 4 star rating).  I never tested how long this would operate on a charged battery but I used this for over 20 minutes without running low on power (this long because my toddler decided to help clean and wasn't going to let go of the vac so it kept running).The LED lights are  a nice feature, it makes it easy to see the dirt to clean. The brush roll clean technology is also nice if you tend to get a lot of tangled hair in your vacuum brushes.  I have a lot of long hair and I she quite a bit.  I have spent a lot of time cutting hair out of brushes so I really appreciated how easy it was to clean the vacuum brushes.  This has a reusable filter and no bag, you just dump the dirt in the trash.  All of these features were easy to use and pretty intuitive.Some of the features that could use some work were the suction power and the engagement with the docking station.  Regarding suction power. this did a nice job and smaller and lighter crumbs but it had difficulties with things like cheerios and beans (it did not have difficulties with these items when the vacuum was used as a handheld, only when used as a stick vacuum).  I have a toddler and cheerios are often on the floor so I was disappointed that this had trouble with picking up cheerios and other larger/heavier crumbs.  Another negative was that this can be a pain to dock on the charging station so that the light comes on and it begins to charge.  I often have to reset it multiple times before the charge light engages.  It seems like other reviewers have had problems with the charging/dock station.I mostly really liked this vacuum.  It is convenient and easy to use.  The only complaints were the suction power and the engagement with the docking station.

Scales with BMI information, calorie estimates, and goal weight tracking are extraordinarily helpful for anyone who is trying to lose or maintain weight.  I am comparing this scale with the Ozeri Touch scale, which I have been using for about a year.  They are both priced comparably but they have slightly different features.  Both scales give weight to one decimal point out.  Happily (well sort of) both scales gave the same weight (I wish that weight was a few pounds less but alas at least they were in agreement). Both allow you to program 8 profiles.  The Ozeri gives weight plus percentage fat, percentage muscle, hydration, and bone mass.  The Bowflex gives BMI, recommended calories, and difference between goal weight and current weight.  Both are useful depending on your goals, the Bowflex is probably a bit more useful for those looking to lose weight.  One feature the Ozeri has is that it automatically recognizes you based on your weight so you don't need to select a profile.  With this scale, you have to select your profile.  Both scales were easy to program and constantly gave the same weight.In summary, this is a good performing scale that is accurate.  It is easy to use and reliable.

I confess to being a bit of a conditioner snob.  I typically only use salon conditioners because I have "temperamental" hair (i.e. damaged from coloring and heat styling combined with its naturally tendency to frizz). I tried this conditioner and the Fekkai Prx conditioner and while both were very good, I think the Prx conditioner is a touch better for increasing softness and keeping hair manageable.  This conditioner was on par with a salon conditioner and left my hair soft and manageable and is really a very good conditioner.  The conditioner has a pleasant light scent and is very thick.  I did not notice any increased glossiness in my hair after use but my hair was still soft.  In the future, I would probably just get the Prx conditioner because I think that one is better for damaged hair.  This would be more suitable for finer hair and for hair that is not heavily damaged.

I confess to being a bit fussy about my conditioners - I typically only use salon conditioners because my hair can be a bit "temperamental".  This conditioner is on par with the conditioners you would typically buy in a salon.  Cheaper conditioners are often thinner and don't always do a good job at preventing further damage.  This conditioner is very thick and rich, the scent is light and pleasant, and my fair feels soft and manageable after using.  I have used this conditioner for a couple of weeks and I am very pleased with this (hair still soft and no increase in split ends).  I think this conditioner would be too heavy for fine hair but would be very suitable for hair that is medium textured to coarse.  For reference, my hair is medium to thick, wavy, and damaged on the ends from heat styling and coloring.

If you are looking for one workout that will cover everything, this is worth looking at.  The target group for this is beginners to intermediates.  This requires some dumb bells or resistance bands.  Each segment of R.I.P.P.E.D is covered as a separate section (resistance training (7 minutes), intervals (5 minutes), power (10 minutes), plyometrics (5 minutes) and endurance (10 minutes)).  There is a warm up and a cool down.  Before each segment is an instructional tutorial.  There is an option to play the workout with or without the tutorial. There are beginner to advanced modifications for all exercises and low impact options are presented.The exercises themselves are a lot of solid tried and true standards with some innovative moves fit in. While they claim that you will burn 700 calories I doubt very few people will burn actually 700 calories doing this workout.  Maybe if you are 6 foot four inches and over 200 lbs but most people won't burn that kind of calories with this workout.Cueing on this video could be better.  The instructors can be a little chatty.  These are minor points and I think the overall merits of the workout are enough to bring it up to 4 stars. This would be a good video for someone who only wants to own a few DVDs and who wants to cover everything in a workout.  This is not quite as hard as a Jillian Michaels workout but it is still a solid workout if you are an advanced beginner to intermediate.  If you are looking for something like insanity or p90x, this may be too easy for you.

This is a barre style workout that is most appropriate for beginner exercisers.  There are two workouts on this DVD and the only equipment required is a chair, mat, and a towel.  Both workouts are about 30 minutes and largely focus on the butt and legs.  The movements are gentle and easy on the joints.  Neither of these workouts would be a problem for someone with joint issues.Both workouts use a chair to mimic a ballet barre. Both workouts take you through a standing series on the barre with ballet inspired moves. The burn and firm workout is almost entirely lower body work and is done standing.  The lengthen and strengthen workout has more core work included and more floor work included.Cueing is done well, the scenery is beautiful, and the video is well produced.  This video would appeal to someone who likes Pilates and yoga.  You do not need a ballet background to use this nor do you need to be super coordinated.  The only thing holding me back from giving this 5 stars is the lack of any real upper body work.  The video claims to give you a balanced body which suggests a total body workout.  This is really a lower body and core workout.

This is an adequate but not spectacular slow cooker.  Considering it is made by All Clad and carries a hefty price tag, I really expected a lot more from this product.  It really didn't deliver.  I would consider myself fairly well versed with slow cooking. I use a slow cooker at least twice a week.  Compared to the Hamilton Beach slow cooker that I have been using for years, this All Clad is far inferior.  One thing I didn't like about this is that you can't program this slow cooker for shorter periods of time.  It has a four hour minimum time but I have recipes that only cook for two hours.  I need to set a timer to use this which defeats the purpose of a programmable slow cooker.  This also doesn't come with a temperature probe which something this expensive should have.  My Hamilton Beach slow cooker cost 50 bucks and has a temperature probe and can be set for 30 minute intervals with no minimum.I would suggest passing on this one.

One of the reasons I use a flat iron is because I have 2 crazy cow licks at my hairline that make my bangs go in all crazy directions.  This is the best flat iron I have used for getting right down to the hairline and pulling those suckers straight.  Basically, if you need an iron with a lot of maneuverability, this one does a very nice job.There is a screen that indicates the temperature the iron is set at.  This can be changed by pushing either an up or the down button.  For my hair, which is medium to fine, I set the iron at 180 degrees (the default and lowest setting) and the iron did a great job getting my hair smooth and straight.  These buttons are on the side of the iron.  One potential problem is that these buttons, along with the on/off buttons, are easy to hit with your hands and I have inadvertently shut this iron off at least once in the month that I have been using it.  Normally I would deduct a star for this but I am so happy with how close I can get to the hairline that I can't make myself take off a star.Personally, I love this iron because it makes my crazy cowlicks look shiny and neat (something that my previous flat irons didn't do well).  The only drawback is the placement of the buttons.  Good product.

I have used hot rollers since high school (about 20 years) but I have always used the ones with the wire pins to hold them in.  This set uses clips to hold the rollers.  This took a bit of getting used to but I personally liked the clips much more than the wires.  I use rollers for large waves in my long hair and the clips are perfect for this. I can't get the clips to hold the roller in close to my head, if you like your rollers set that way, this may not be a good set for you.I found these rollers heated up within a few minutes and as expected, set my hair within 5 minutes.  There was nothing fancy about the rollers themselves, they are your basic hot roller with one difference.  Unlike previous sets, the heating rod does not go through the bottom of the roller but through the side.  This means you need to be careful how you grasp them or you could get burned.  Because they sit on their side, this set also takes up about twice as much space as conventional hot rollers so if your counter space is limited, you may want to look at a different set.This set comes with 12 large rollers and 8 medium rollers.  There are no small rollers.  This is another feature I liked.  I never used the small rollers and mostly just use the large ones.These are basic no-frills hot rollers.  They work well and heat up quickly.  On the downside, they take up a lot of room and there is the potential to burn your fingers.

This is not a book I would have typically picked up.  It had a few reviews that were very positive so I thought I would give it a try.  I am very very glad I did.  The easiest way to describe this book was riveting.  The author tells a tight,fast moving narrative that really draws you into the lives of the unfortunate hikers who perished in Russia so long ago.  The story is not familiar to Americans but is apparently quite well known to Russians.  Nine very experience hikers took off on a long hike in the Ural mountains over their winter break.  The goal was to document their hike for the purposes of obtaining certification as elite hikers. This meant that there was a treasure trove of pictures and diary entries that the author used to recreate their final days.  For some reason, on their final day, they ripped open their tent and fled half clothed into the brutal winter night.  Their bodies were found almost a mile from their tent with brutal injuries.  Why has remained a mystery for years.  The explanation the author comes to, which is only possible due to modern research, is plausible.  The author treats the story with care and compassion and fully draws the reader into the story. This is an  all around excellent book.

My oldest son used a Britax Convertable  car seat which we were very pleased with.  Six years later and we were again in the market for a Convertable car seat.  My infant seat goes up to thirty pounds but at five feet tall, carrying 20 pounds of baby plus car seat weight was about killing me.  And, I have a CRV so I had to lift chunky monkey and seat into the car- so time to switch!So how is this car seat? First, let's address installation.  I found this to be similar to the Britax.  I had to push down on the seat to get the latch engaged.  No big deal once I realized that the latch belt needed to be in the proper location for the rear facing option. The manual had fairly easy to follow instructions.  For my son (9 months), the position of the head rest and the buckle were perfect so I did not attempt to adjust these.  Our installation was position 3 rear facing.  This is the most tilted back.  Ther is the option for two tilt positions for the rear facing installation.  It was pretty easy to go between the two positions.This seat is sold on its comfort.  My baby hated his infant seat, he'd scream as soon as he was placed in it.  Obviously at 9 months he is too young to tell us how he feels but i can report that he does not scream when he is placed in this seat. Sometimes he stays happy.  He sleeps well in this seat.  We drove 300 miles (one stop) and he was happy or asleep for most of the ride.  He seems pretty comfortable and happy in this seat.This seat has a nice built in cup holder.  The safety ratings are very good and the seat feels well built.  The only con to this seat is that it is pretty hard to unbuckle.  You really have to press in hard to get the buckle to release.  Pretty minor con and I can definitely recommend this seat.

A good diaper should hold in wetness and "other stuff", should be adjustable without tearing, and should be nonirritating to the baby. I received these and the Pampers Swaddlers for the purpose of reviewing these.  I typically buy Huggies Snug and Dry. I found little difference between this diaper, the Swaddler, or Huggies except that the Swaddlers cost a lot more and had a moisture detection dye.  All diapers do a reasonable job of holding in wetness and "other stuff" although the Baby Dry did seem to do a marginally better job.  None of the diapers tore during use and my son did not develop irritation during use.  I should note that my son does not seem to have a problem with irritation with any diaper except for Luvs (those turned his bum acid red). These diapers were less bulky than Huggies.  These do have a slight scent which I personally think is unnecessary, a poopy diaper is still stinky. Adding a scent does not make the diaper any less nasty smelling and its just an unneeded chemical that can cause irritation to a baby with sensitive skin. I deducted a star for the scent.  I would buy either these or Huggies, depending on which had a better price.  If both were priced about the same, I would go with the Huggies because they do not have a scent.

A good diaper should hold in wetness and "other stuff", should be adjustable without tearing, and should be nonirritating to the baby.  This diaper did mostly well on all counts.  Used overnight, we had 2 times where my son woke up wet in the morning.  There was one "blowout" during the day.  This was over 186 diapers.  All-in-all, not too bad and something that could be chalked up to parental error.  We have had similar results with the Huggies we typically use.  These are a thinner (less bulky) diaper than our Huggies Snug and Dry.  None of the closures ripped on us and our son showed no signs of irritation (although he does not seem to have sensitive skin).  These do have a slight scent which I personally think is unnecessary, a poopy diaper is still stinky.  Adding a scent does not make the diaper any less nasty smelling and its just an unneeded chemical that can cause irritation to a baby with sensitive skin.  I deducted a star for the scent.  These have a moisture indicator strip (goes from yellow to blue) which is not really needed by the time you are in a size 2 diaper (unless you have a monster newborn).  These are nice enough diapers, I liked but did not love them.  These cost a lot more than Huggies Snug and Dry  or Pampers Baby Dry but perform about the same.

This game is geared towards 5 and 6 year olds.  The game comes with 20 blocks and 20 cards.  The goal is to recreate the shape on the cards.  You can do this by looking at the card or by describing the card.  My son enjoyed this game and I liked that it teaches concentration and critical thinking.

Coming of age movies have found a built in audience with teens for years. As far back as REBEL WITHOUT A CAUSE through THE BREAKFAST CLUB and on, the problems faced by teens growing up has felt a similar concept running through them while adapting to the situations faced by each successive generation. So it’s always interesting to see what comes next as we do this week with PAPER TOWNS.Based on the best seller by author John Green who wrote last years THE FAULT IN OUR STARS, this movie takes a look at life through the eyes of narrator Quentin “Q” Jacobsen (Nat Wolff). As the film opens a younger Q tells us about the first moment he set eyes on his new neighbor Margo Roth Spiegelman and immediately fell in love with her. As they grow they start out friends but a chance encounter with a suicide victim’s body changes their dynamic. Q grows into a semi-nerd while Margo (Cara Delevingne) runs with the popular kids, becoming the talk of her generation with the various adventures she has supposedly gone on.Q hangs with his two best friends Ben (Austin Abrams), a cocky little guy who talks big about his sexual conquests which obviously have never happened and Radar (Justice Smith) the only member of the trio to actually have a girlfriend. The prom is coming up and only Radar has a date. This is there life, a situation where all three never take walk off of the path to success or dare to do anything they shouldn’t. That all changes in one night.One evening Q is awakened by Margo sneaking into his bedroom window. She tells him she needs to borrow his mother’s car but he refuses. Instead he tags along with Margo on her “missions”. They begin in a store purchasing items for the “missions” and then begin. Each revolves around Margo taking revenge on her so called friends after discovering that her boyfriend has been cheating on her with another friend. As they go from place to place their doing things which could get them in trouble but having fun at the same time. A moment between the two is shared. And then, the next day, Margo goes missing.As Q tries to figure out where Margo has gone her friend Lacey approaches him to find out where she went as well. Q begins to find clues, the sort that Margo would use to solve the mysteries of life that have always intrigued her. As he and his friends cipher through the various clues Margo has left behind, Q becomes certain that she left them for him to find her. The end result is a road trip but it is the journey that it takes to go on the trip and the trip itself that offers the adventure these friends go on, a trip that changes their lives.The term “paper towns” is one Margo uses to describe life where they all live. It references something mapmakers used long ago, false towns they would place on maps to insure their copyright to those maps. The towns were fake towns that didn’t exist but insured that one mapmaker wouldn’t use the same information from another’s. For Margo it represents an empty life, an empty existence. It also provides the group with their greatest clue.The whole concept of the treasure hunt here makes for a lot of fun in this film. It creates the background story that links together the lives of the three friends, Lacey and Radar’s girlfriend along with Margo into something that explodes their lives from living the mundane existence that they have created for themselves and most likely will carry on till they die and transforms it into experiencing life for perhaps the first time.The young actors here do a wonderful job of bringing life to what could have resulted in nothing more than cardboard cutouts. Each has their own quirks that make them who they are but rather than those quirks being challenges to overcome they are what make each of them special and a necessary part to the journey.The story is one that grabs you from the start and holds on to you until the finale. Not only are these friends going on a journey, the viewer is as well. In the end perhaps each viewer will find themselves looking back in regret for a chance never taken, a journey never traveled. But the truth is that these opportunities for adventure never end. With any luck, those who go on this trip with Q and friends will seek out adventures of their own.

As a young movie fan I spent numerous days and hours watching the classic Basil Rathbone/Nigel Bruce versions of Sherlock Holmes on TV. These movies left a lasting impression on viewers for decades first when they appeared in theaters and then when people like myself discovered them on TV. Those 14 films they made were what we based our knowledge of the character on. For me it wouldn’t be until later that I discovered the books on which they were based.Yes Sherlock Holmes has been with us in one form or another for decades now. But we never hear about what happened later on in life, what happened when Dr. Watson had passed away and Sherlock got older. That is until now. With the new movie MR. SHERLOCK we get a glimpse of what might have happened. It’s a wonderful film that discusses both what happens when we age and what becomes of our heroes. And like those movies that inspired a search for the real Holmes stories my guess is this movie will make viewers seek out A SLIGHT TRICK OF THE MIND by Mitch Cullin on which the movie is based.The year is 1947 and Holmes (Ian McKellen) is retired now, living in a Sussex village and tending to his bee colony. His life is less adventurous and he’s assisted in his home by his housekeeper Mrs. Munro (Laura Linney) and her young son Roger (Milo Parker). A bit on the cantankerous side now, Holmes softens when young Milo takes an interest in helping him with his bees. For a character who based his life on rational thinking with little or no emotion, he now finds himself faced with feelings that have long been buried. His fatherly affection for the young boy whose real father died in the war provide him with the impetus to do more than just get by.While his exploits gained him notoriety due to the literary license used by his chronicler Dr. Watson, Holmes always felt he got things wrong. In particular the one case that has bothered him the most was his last one which he feels didn’t tell the truth. But as he has aged so has he taken on the problems that entails. His memory is fading. The details of that last case elude him. With the friendship of young Milo Holmes is invigorated and begins to recall things he’d forgotten. Before the film ends the details of that last case will be remembered and the reason for much of why he’s become who he is at this point is revealed.What has always made Sherlock such an interesting character has been his ability to perceive the world around him in an analytical nature. And yet at the same time he was rarely able to see his own faults, in particular this lack of emotion. When it did occur it usually resulted in some tragedy and in the case of this film that potential happens with two different incidents, one in the past and one in the present. But this concept that Holmes always considered a flaw was what in reality made him the best detective that he was. While he never showed that he cared, deep down he did.McKellen is magnificent in the role, bringing to life the character at his deepest roots. Not to discredit those who have played the part in the past but their versions were always the man on the hunt, the deductive man of action in search of a criminal. McKellen is left to play a man who is aging whose nemesis is not a human being but himself and his slowly digressing mind and body. He brings to life a character we know and yet don’t know at the same time.The supporting cast also does a fantastic job here. Linney is wonderful as a woman dealing with her loss while at the same time trying to provide for a child she loves dearly. Parker as Roger is an amazing talent for his age and fills the shoes of this boy too young to know the legend of Sherlock Holmes while at the same time having an adulation for the older man who he shares a home with. It could have been played as far too precocious but he does a great job here.Those who are looking for the pace of the recent Robert Downey Jr. films will be disappointed, that’s not what this film is all about. But fans of the real Sherlock Holmes will adore this film. The pacing is slow but the story is what matters. And there is plenty of story to go around in this film. It’s one that fans of Holmes will want to watch more than once. I know I intend to.

This item was provided for review purposes.I was contacted to see if I would be interested in reviewing these headphones and agreed to do so. It’s been some time since I’ve owned a pair of headphones and to be honest I’d always opted for the very inexpensive brands in the past. This was due in part to their being affordable but also because I tend to be far too rough with my headphones. I’m one of those people who accidentally rolls from one part of the room to the other so immersed in my music I forget I have them on.Since the last pair I purchased there has been a dramatic interest in headphones and they’ve gone from a good pair for $20 to pairs that exceed several hundred dollars. I’m sorry but I’m still not ready to shell out that kind of money for headphones. If I worked in the recording industry maybe. But the truth is while I enjoy using headphones quality for the price is more of what I’m inclined to look at when purchasing them. There is also the fact that I am not a sound technician. I am the average Joe on the block looking to see what sounds good. No bells and whistles, no technical equipment to measure frequency and the rest, just two ears to listen.So rather than hook up modulators and the like I decided the best way to determine if these headphones were worth their salt was to try them out with some music. That is what most people will be using them for. And rather than try them on one single or one album (yes I’m old and still call them that) I would try them out on several songs from various styles. Would they hold up to heavy metal but not soul? What about classical or folk? So here is what I found using various songs.“You Shook Me All Night Long” by AC/DC. Great. The bass came through but wasn’t overpowering. Lead guitars were crisp and clear. Vocals came through as intelligible. The drums were fine and the cymbals rang. All in all this song came through perfect.“I Robot” by The Alan Parsons Project. The song starts low and soft and that was there with great mixing back and forth from left to right. Again the bass came through without being the only thing I was able to hear, one of my biggest complaints with headphones and sound systems in the past. As the melody came in all parts of the composition could be heard clearly and clean.  Another perfect sound experience.“Pink Moon” by Nick Drake. The opening guitar chords strummed away and I closed my eyes. I was transported to a smoky nightclub or campus center where I could hear everything as it was meant to be, Drake playing in an intimate setting. The headphones allowed me to go there, offering superb quality sound that brought it all together.“Déjà vu” by Crosby, Still, Nash & Young. One of my go to songs for harmonies, something that doesn’t always transfer well when listening to headphones. One that I listened to on headphones for years. The harmonizing of the four singers combined sweetly through the headset. Guitars solo and background sounded real. The bass was there but not overbearing. Another plus mark for this headset.“Elevate” by Winery Dogs. Great bass on a level playing field with the lead guitar. Bass drum pounding beneath it all. Other drums and cymbals beating wildly and with clearness not usually found in headphones. Vocals clear as can be. Once again a perfect sound experience.“Spring” by Vivaldi. The concert hall came alive. Lows, highs, midranges all came through loud and clear. Violins came through sweetly and the orchestra around them added much support clearly and cleanly.That gets me through the sound experience but what about the rest of what makes a good pair of headphones? To start with on a comfort level these were better than headphones I’ve had in the past. The cushions used allow for maximum comfort without applying too much pressure. They also provided great sound enclosure preventing sound from not only being heard by others but from stopping sound from coming in as well. When your wife comes in and tells you she’s been calling for you from the other room for the past ten minutes you know the sound canceling works better than she would hope for. The tangle free cord was a feature I loved as well having dealt with far too many coiled cords that did little more than wrap themselves up after a single use. Perhaps it would have been nice if it were a little longer but I can take care of that on my own with an extension cord. The case the headphones come in is nice as well providing a protective location for them to reside in when not in use.As I am not a game player and was using these for just listening to music I can’t tell you if the built in microphone on the cord worked well or not. But it seems like most headphones these days require that.My entire experience with these headphones was exceptional. Are they worth the money? At a list price of $79.99 on amazon but marked down to $19.99 I would say they are way more qualified for that sale price. They are quite possibly worth the $79.99 price tag. If you’re looking for a pair of headphones that will fill the bill of what is required for a basic set then this is something you should look into buying.

A copy of this title was provided for review purposes.Let me say up front that your political viewpoints will more than likely determine ahead of time whether you love or hate this book. Honestly, that’s sad. But we’ve become a political world where convenience seems to trump responsibility. Rather than look deeper than a headline people tend to base their beliefs on memes and slogans. If that’s you then you’ll miss something when it comes to this book. You’ll miss a great deal of information but on top of that you’ll miss some great laughs as well. So if you’re interested in both then continue reading.Greg Gutfeld is a commentator, a satirist and a member of the regular panel on Fox News Channel’s THE FIVE. Among the commentators there he is by far the wittiest and the most regularly hilarious member. As host for years of RED EYE, Fox’s late night show, he brought together a divergent group in individuals to talk about the days topics that was enlightening and funny at the same time. As his star has risen Gutfeld has taken his words from spoken to book format authoring four books including this one. All insightful and are worth reading.But this new book is something more important. It’s something that members of the Republican Party need to read, especially those higher up. It also should be required reading for all of the Republican candidates as well during this election year. They could use the sage advice offered here.Gutfeld makes numerous great points in the book but the most important is that if the truth of what the right stands for is to get out there a better presentation is needed to make it happen. What Republicans lack when it comes to speakers that represent them is a charismatic leader who can reach people on a level that doesn’t involve fact filled charts and graphs but just talking to them. The last time this happened was with Ronald Reagan and look how good he did.The book opens with a chapter called “Why We’re Evil” which doesn’t really present that as a desirable description but actually discusses why Republicans have been saddled with that label and done little to counter it with the exception of saying “Nuh uh!” Admitting up front that you will be attacked for saying you are a Conservative, Gutfeld explains how to explain you stance in a way that’s both quick and difficult to refute. That answer, from the book, is “Here is the simple stance to why you are Right: It is a more practical, generous, and compassionate way to live”. The fact of the matter is he’s right or to be more understandable, he is correct. He then discusses how to present you case in a way that doesn’t resort to insults or simply saying I’m right and you’re wrong.Much of what he carries on with discusses the fact that for liberalism to exist it needs conservatism there to allow it to be. As he says “Liberalism can exist only in periods of calm” that “…conservatism doesn’t compete with liberalism, it sustains it.” Safety and security must be a part of our society for there to be the free time to consider much of what liberals have to offer. Well not so much offer as take it from others to offer to someone else. With each word printed in the book he explains this and how both views need one another.But Gutfeld doesn’t let the right off the hook either. As he states in the book “The left is excellent at extolling horrible ideas; the right is horrible at extolling excellent ideas.” Therein lies the heart of the book. While he does lean to the right (Gutfeld says that he’s a libertarian and all things point this direction though I’m sure the left considers him just shy of Rush Limbaugh), Gutfeld points out problems with both sides of the issues. Best of all is that along with the humor he is noted for he presents arguments that are fact based. Sadly that might not matter. My father has told me more than once that liberals don’t want to be confused by facts. Which might be why this book is so important.That’s because Gutfeld doesn’t rely simply on facts. As I said from the start, the book is more about being able to argue persuasively. Eight years ago we had a relatively unknown and unaccomplished nominee for President running who won not based on his abilities and his record but because he was persuasive. It’s what young people today in a world of social media where everything is explained in 140 characters in a tweet expect. This book helps conservatives find the way to do that. And make you laugh.Greg Gutfeld takes a lot of flak from his co-hosts for promoting his books when they come out but the fact is they are enjoyable books to read. They make you think and they make you laugh. As with many satirists from the past, he blends those two things together to make an impression on those willing to look past those memes and slogans, those one worded posters like “HOPE” and extremely edited campaign commercials and find some truth in a world where one side controls most media. Now if we could just get Republican candidates to read this book.

A copy of this title was provided for review purposes.One of the great things about movies is that a subject matter can be sought out by an inventive writer or director and finally get the green light to have that movie made. When that happens, the writer or director can bring to the attention of the world a topic that they may never have heard of before. In the case of THE END OF THE TOUR director James Ponsoldt and writer Donald Margulies bring to our attention author David Foster Wallace.Some may be familiar with Wallace and his works. I am not one of those people. But in watching this film I was provided with a look at the author as interpreted by this team as well as David Lipsky upon whose book the film was made. The author and Lipsky are both brought to life by actors Jason Segel and Jesse Eisenberg in a way that makes them both interesting. When the film ends you may find yourself as I did, searching for information about both men and perhaps seeking out their books.The movie opens with word that author David Foster Wallace (Jason Segel) has just died of an apparent suicide. This causes writer David Lipsky (Jesse Eisenberg) to be contacted to discuss Wallace and to reflect on the time the two spent together. Going back 12 years, Lipsky is an author whose latest book is well received but not doing as well as he had hoped. At a party among friends Lipsky talks about taking on a job at Rolling Stone as a writer and then hears about an author everyone is talking about, David Foster Wallace (Jason Segel), whose new book Infinite Jest is being hailed as the greatest thing currently in print. To see what the talk is all about Lipsky reads the book. Aware of how great the book is, he convinces his editor at Rolling Stone to send him out to interview Wallace.Thus begins a road trip that develops into a friendship between two authors both seeking something completely different and yet identical at the same time. Lipsky arrives in Wallace’s Midwest home in the middle of a snow covered winter, a far cry from the city streets of New York he is familiar with. Wallace is a nice sort who greets him and welcomes him into his home, an unassuming ranch house that’s more everyday guy than talked about literary celebrity. Wallace is a quiet man who lives with his two dogs, wears a bandana around his head and is wary at first of being interviewed.As the two men spend time together their comfort level increases and Wallace ends up opening his world, his life and his mind to Lipsky. Their discussions are fascinating to listen to and you soon discover that behind this sought after author is a man who fears losing himself and his sanity to celebrity. He loves his life the way it is. While Lipsky can’t understand this feeling as he desires notoriety, he comes to realize what it is that Wallace means in his search to retain his own identity.Along the way the pair share stories of their lives and backgrounds as they drive from one location to the next while Wallace completes the last stop on his travels to promote his book. The two bond as they travel until a jealousy seems to take over Lipsky and he begins flirting with an ex of Wallace’s that meets with them in Minneapolis. The rift between the two offers an insight into both with each jealous of the other. This up and down rollercoaster ride of adulation and envy that fills becomes apparent to Lipsky before the end of the film just as the acceptance of him and envy of his lifestyle is shown in the character of Wallace. What they each take back from their road trip makes for a wonderful movie.Both actors bring to life the two men that they story is based on. I’ve never been a huge fan of Eisenberg but when he’s on point he does a tremendous job and that’s what he does here. While his performance is that good it is Segel who surprised me here. Having watched his career for some time in almost always comedic roles, he takes on Wallace with apparent ease and takes what could have been nothing more than a quirky individual and turns him into something more. That he can do so in such a subdued manner makes the performance even more memorable.While watching the film I was reminded of the movie MY DINNER WITH ANDRE, a film that was nothing more than a dinner conversation between two intellectuals filled with a back and forth dialogue. While this movie moves around more than that, it feels the same. It is a film filled with conversations between two characters that holds your attention with every word they speak. In the wrong hands that could lead to boredom but here it grabs your attention from start to finish.Most films these days seem to include little more than explosions and car chases, super heroes or paranormal demons. This movie is about nothing more than two men who start as acquaintances and then become friends, contemporaries who find a common bond in their love of the written word. It’s the type of movie that rarely makes a huge splash at the box office. The nice thing is that with it coming out on DVD perhaps more people will discover the fun they can have while watching it at home.

A copy of this title was provided for review purposes.There have been revenge films since movie began being made. Perhaps the most famous of these was DEATH WISH, the Charles Bronson starring film that had him taking out street thugs to the cheers of movie goers who were tired of being victims of crime. With FINAL GIRL we get a twist on the revenge film nearing what was accomplished in OLDBOY.The film opens with young Veronica being questioned by William (Wes Bentley). Her parents have just died and she seems nonplussed by that fact. With each question William gets to know more about the mind of Veronica and when he finds her suitable for his needs he offers to take care of her from now on. What that need is is to create a perfect assassin, a weapon that can take out his revenge on those responsible for the death of his wife and daughter.Twelve years pass and Veronica (Abigail Breslin) is now grown. We witness her training at the hands of William. A brutal task master when need be, he helps Veronica to learn how to cope with any and all obstacles that might come her way. He takes her shoes when she’s in the woods, he gives her a cocktail of drugs to prepare her for what it’s like to battle under duress and he shows her that a gun isn’t the way to handle things because bullets eventually run out. When he feels she is finally ready, the pair set out on their task.The victims in mind are a predatory bunch. While we might question William’s moral sense early on it becomes apparent why he’s taking the route he has all these years. The group of young men he is about to turn Veronica loose on are serial killers. Four best friends with sociopathic qualities, this group of well-dressed killers will pick a young blonde, invite her to a party and then turn her lose in the forest while they track her down and kill her. While it’s never clearly stated one has to assume one of their victims was William’s daughter.Veronica does some reconnaissance by talking to one of the young men’s girlfriend and understand then that these men have no sense of right and wrong, they are incapable of love and affection. There only joy comes from the pain and suffering they instill in others. She suggest the girl can do better and then preps for her confrontation.It comes easily. The group’s ringleader Jameson (Alexander Ludwig) sees Veronica in the diner they frequent, an angelic vision with blonde hair in bright light, and approaches her. He casually and with an aristocratic air invites her to a party the next night. She accepts and the following night meets the rest of the group. Promising that others are on the way to meet them she goes along and finds herself in the forest with this group of tuxedo wearing young men. She knows what they are. They have no clue what they have gotten themselves into. Their night of “fun” will soon come face to face with William’s weapon of revenge.To begin with no one should take this movie as a reality based film. It is a story plain and simple that is shot in such a way as to be more artistic than one would expect given the material being witnessed. While this could have fallen away into the B-movie category the performances by all involved and the style with which it is shot make it more than that. Directed by photographer Tyler Shields it becomes obvious early on that he has an eye for composition with his choices of light and dark, the framing of his movie in all scenes.
