Let me start out by saying that I'm not a fan of the original 1981 film `Arthur' starring Dudley Moore. There are a number of reasons for this but probably the biggest is that I don't generally enjoy movies with storylines focused on excessive drinking and alcoholics. This is especially true for films within the comedy genre. Having that said, you can imagine that seeing a mediocre 3 star rating overall on the 2011 remake of `Arthur' starring Russell Brand would only reinforce my decision not to view this one.Fortunately I watched the film before checking out its Amazon rating and I have to admit that I absolutely love it! Russell Brand is amazing as the man-child Arthur and while the image of a loveable drunk is not my forte he definitely pulls it off.  I also loved Helen Mirren as Arthur's lifelong nanny and surrogate Mother.  Brand and Mirren play off each other beautifully and their relationship is edgy, witty and poignant.What ultimately ties it all together and makes this a 5 star film for me is the hilarious, laugh a minute dialogue. Just about everything that comes out of Russell Brands' mouth is funny, unexpected and memorable. You know, the kind of material you want to write down so you could use it yourself in the future.  I was already a Helen Mirren fan before watching this film but was undecided on Russell Brand. Now I'm a fan.

'Am I Really a Christian' by Mike McKinley is a concise, insightful, honest and surprisingly refeshing reassertion of the essential core beliefs of Protestantism and the standards by which we can truly know whether or not we are really a Christian. McKinley's straightforward, unapologetic approach to the subject matter leads the reader on a no frills, step by step methodology of self-examination that ultimately leads to a fuller understanding of ones personal, spiritual journey and ultimate eternal destination.Obviously this books target audience is the practicing Christian. It's designed to encourage and enbolden the faithful as well as admonish and reinvigorate those who have become apathetic or fallen away from the faith. 'Am I Really a Christian' succeeds in accomplishing those goals and will serve well as a evangelical tool.*On a personal note let me say that my own personal belief system is immensely different from the one discussed here, however I do appreciate the manner in which the author presented the material and made his case. I guess we can agree to disagree.

After a 32 year wait I finally sat down and watched the 1979 cult film classic 'Monty Python's Life of Brian'. With the wait over I can honestly say I was neither surprised or disappointed, nor particularly amused or insulted. It was in fact pretty much what I had expected. Maybe I just don't get British humor, or maybe it's a problem with the heavy British accents. If I hadn't already been familiar with the religious context on which this satire is based I would have found large portions of the film all but unintelligible. Aside from the translation problem I found the truly funny moments in the story to be few and far between.Memorable Moments:1-The stoning bit was hilarious,2-The singing on the cross was a clever touch and3-All the re-occurring joisting and one-liners between competing Judean liberation groups was amusing and probably the only thing that keep me watching.There were a few other good moments here and there but not enough to persuade me to endure a second viewing. I guess the comedy of Monty Python is an acquired taste that I apparently lack.

The 1999 TNT original film 'Purgatory' is a unique and throughly enjoyable watch. Much like the classic 'Twilight Zone television series a specific time period and a seemingly ordinary place serve as the setting for an extremely unorthox tale. The time period is the American Old West, the place a small, off-the-beaten-path town known as Refuge. It is here that the world we know intersects with another and things are seldom what they appear to be. When a gang of outlaws ride into town they think they've come upon a place ripe for the picking and decide to take over and do as they please. Again, in the town of Refuge things are not exactly what they seem to be.If you're the kind of person who enjoys a good western, a quirky, out of the ordinary storyline and can appreciate a little morality tale as long as it's not preachy than this is the film for you.

I found the film '127 Hours' to be extremely difficult to watch, particularily so since it's a true life account. I began fidgeting early on in my viewing and as the storyline inched closer and closer to the inevitable event I began losing eye contact with the screen, staring down at my dog or getting up and going to the kitchen for another cup of coffee. As I said, this was an extremely difficult watch.Having openly revealed my lack of fortitude to millions you would probably expect me not to recommend this film. Well, that would definitely be true in the case of small children, the film is far too intense and disturbing. Furthermore if this movie was only about the extreme events that occurred in the life of outdoor enthuasist Aron Ralston (played brilliantly by James Franco) for no other reason than pure shock value and financial gain I also would not recommend the film.However there is another dimension to this tale of unbelievable horror that needed to be told. Exactly what is this other dimension of which I speak? Well you could call it mankinds inate biologically induced will to survive, or man's ability to tap into a higher source or divine power in times of desperation, or quite possibly a hands on discourse on the timeless processes of karma and destiny.I made it through to the end by tuning into the internal dialogue going on in Aron Ralston's mind during his unbelievable ordeal. His thoughts, feelings, memories and future aspirations are laid out before the audience. Past, present and future converge and focus on one spot and moment in time and space. That point of convergence being the place where Aron's hand, rock and cliff meet and all that was, is and may yet be hang in the balance. An entire universe of possiblities will be determined by what is about to take place. As Aron so succintly put it, "this rock has been waiting for me my entire life". Yes it has and what he does next will determine everything!Amazing film if you're up for it.

This is a great leatherette cover for my LG tablet. It fits perfectly, folds well, and has two magnets that keep it firmly in place. Of course, there is the tab on the back that allows you to sit your tablet up whenever necessary, leaving it at the perfect viewing angle. For the money, it can't be beat.

My doctor recommended I take Mega Red Krill Oil to help with heart issues I've been having. I was afraid of having to ingest nasty fish tasting pills every day.I'm happy to report that these Mega Red Omega-3 Krill Oil gel caps do not at all taste fishy! When you open the bottle, you get the faint smell of fish, but it's covered up with something sweet, I think vanilla. When you put it in your mouth, you get the slight vanilla flavor. And that's really it, folks. No fishy aftertaste. You'll never know you just took fish oil.Best of all, it seems to be working. My doctor thinks that my issues have leveled out, and it may be in part to the Mega Red. I am pleased and have just come to Amazon to order more (the price here is much, much cheaper than at my local pharmacy).

I recently started making jewelry, especially earrings. I purchased this to organize my ever expanding earring collection.For the price asked, I wasn't expecting something of extremely high quality. That's a good thing, because this isn't the sturdiest of stands. The feet are actually rubber tubing that you slide onto the stand when you get it. I don't have a problem with that per se, but because of that, the stand wobbles a bit. When you go to add or remove earrings, especially the kind with lever backs, the entire thing shakes.That being said, they hold my earrings, and a lot of them. That alone makes it worth the money I spent. However, if you are looking for something sturdy, you might want to consider a different stand, perhaps made of wood.

I purchased this at the recommendation of an Etsy seller to glue a cabochon into the tray of a blank cuff bangle bracelet.It worked great - I let it set overnight and the cabochon seems to be quite sturdily glued into the tray. So it was very effective for what I needed it for. Just one thing to note: It has a very, very fine long metal tip at the nozzle which is designed for fine rhinestone work. The tube does leak quite a bit when you're using it, so be sure to have something guarding your work surface. Also, I found it very difficult to replace the cap due to the long metal nozzle. After a few tries, I got it to go back on, and I wiped away any excess glue from around the cap.I don't know if they have this glue with a nozzle made for gluing larger surfaces, but if they do, I'll be buying it.

I just started making my own earrings and bracelet, and wanted an array of jump rings on hand depending on the size of project I was working on.This is a great kit. It has six different size jump rings and the ring tool to help keep them steady while opening them up. They came in what is essentially a 7 day pill organizer (awesome reuse), which keeps everything neat and organized. I ordered them in silver, and am using them mainly with earring and bracelet connectors. I am not having any problems with them tarnishing or changing color, though if I used them for larger products, who knows?One thing to note... I have not found the ring tool terribly helpful. I'm not sure if I'm not using it properly, but I have found that the rings don't stay put very well. I have had more success using my jewelry tool and a heavy duty cuticle nipper together. That aside, however, I think the rings are a great value and I recommend picking them up.

I was somewhat hesitant to spend $30 on a broom and shovel. Despite my misgivings, I really needed a good sweep set because all the ones I had been buying were always bad in some way: Either the brooms were too short and I got a backache using it, or the dustpan wasn't level with the floor and debris slid underneath it. However, seeing as this was made by Oxo (I'm a huge fan of their kitchen gadgets) I figured I'd just take the plunge.It was a great decision. I love this set! The broom has an extendable handle, which is great because I'm tall. No, the extended handle isn't terribly thick or sturdy, but it doesn't really need to be to serve its purpose. The best part of this set is the dustpan, which not only is nice, large and level with the ground, but the top comb to clean the broom is ingenious! If I only have one gripe, it's that I wish the comb had denser, closer together bristles. I think it would help get the dust bunnies out even more.That aside, however, this is exactly the kind of set I've been needing and I found it worth the extra money.

I know the Onex brand is one known for comfort and fashion. I've always wanted to buy a pair, but never did, until I saw the Brandie dress sandal in red. I was looking for a red slide, and the price was amazing. I was super excited to get them.I was disappointed because they just didn't work. The length was fine, the instep fit well, but the insole was so, so narrow - my foot just hung over the edge, so whenever I walked I could feel it digging into my arch. Additionally, the silver accent part (along the side and the heel) is actually made of plastic, and it arrived a bit scratched up.So while they would have been comfortable if the width had been right, they just didn't work for me. I don't know if narrow is the hallmark of the Onex brand, but I might not order these online again unless I can try them on in person first.

I live in an apartment where the bugs think they are welcome to enter my home whenever they feel like it. You'd think they had a hand delivered invitation they way they pranced in and out! Nervy little buggers. I've especially had trouble with earwigs, all around the inside of my front door. Not anymore, thanks to Ortho Home Defense.I sprayed the odorless liquid outside my apartment (and my neighbor's, for good will). I sprayed around the front door, along the concrete foundation, around the side of the building - anywhere I could think bugs would enter. After the first application, the number of earwigs actually seemed to increase around my door. So, I applied it again to the same places, but used even more spray. Well, that did the trick.I haven't seen nary an earwig or spider since the second treatment. Ok, maybe I did see one spider inside, but I sprayed it and that was that. That sucker was deader than dead, and quick. But I haven't seen an earwig in almost a month (knock on wood).I can always call my apartment community's office and order professional extermination. However, if I'm too busy to wait for them to come, or have a sudden infestation of gross, exotic bugs, Ortho Home Defense works great, and is a wonderful thing to have on hand.

I needed a stapler at my home to keep my bills together in groups. This Swingline fit the bill. It's the same type I have at the office: lightweight, basic and durable. It fits a full strip staples, which was important to me (I don't like those cheap mini staplers). Additionally, I love that it came with the staple remover. I can now save my fingernails by using a proper device to remove them.One thing to note: This stapler is stationary; it does not open flat, so you can't staple bulletin boards with it. It is strictly for paperwork. So if you don't need it for that purpose, this product is a good value and worth the purchase.

Nine West is a brand of shoes that I've always liked. Although they are hit or miss with how they fit me (more miss than hit), these pumps were just what I was looking for, so I took a chance.When I received them, I was satisfied with the quality. The leather is soft, the heel is a manageable height, and the strap fits around my ankle with no problems. However, the cutout part in the middle of the instep, for whatever reason, they dug into my skin. Plus, the design made my feet look weird. Lastly, they were a bit narrower than I would like.So as nice as the quality was, I had to return them because they just didn't work for me.

I used to by the Costco brand of bags, when you could find a box of 90 for less than $20. However, they have gone up in price online (shipping is just too expensive), and I no longer live near a Costco, so I decided on these instead.The price here currently is decent for 50 bags. They are smaller than the previous bags I liked, but that is not an issue since these are the ForceFlex; meaning, they are very strong, they flex, and you can fit more into them without fear of breakage. I have to carry my trash a distance outside to the dumpster in my community, so for me this is essential.I do like these bags and will continue to use them as long as they are available. Highly recommended.

I had such enormous hope for these sneakers. I have been trying for months to find the perfect, well balanced, all around great sneakers for very light jogging, walking and maybe some basic exercise. I'd heard good things about the brand and decided to give it a go.Sadly, these shoes were just not for me. They are very cute looking, and I love the color & design. However, they fit absolutely strangely in a way I'm not used to. The width was great, as was the length. I loved the wide toe box. However, the insole is much, much softer in the heel than the rest of the shoe. Therefore, every time you walk, you can feel your heel (and just your heel) sinking in. I didn't know if this was normal, so I contacted the company via their website chat option. Their representative who responded did not seem to know and seemed somewhat disinterested in assisting me in general. When I asked him if that was normal, he just said "yes", but would not elaborate or tell me why it was, nor did he recommend a different shoe model to me.I decided to give them a go anyway and wore them for 10 minutes outside... just a trip to the mailbox and a quick walk around the block. Within 5 minutes, not only my feet and legs hurt but my lower back as well. So, with great sadness I had to return them.I must say that I know I'm a heel striker, so apparently these are shoes not for people who walk the way I do. Additionally, I have a high arch and there is no arch support (I'm guessing that's due to the zero drop platform). Maybe this these sneakers are perfect for some, but they just did not work for me. I will keep searching for the perfect athletic shoe.

Bandolino has done it again. One of my favorite brands, Bandolino always seems to hit the mark for shoes that are high quality, beautiful, comfortable and relatively affordable. (No, I don't work for them in any way - just a happy consumer).I love these wedge sandals (I purchased them in Navy). They are just gorgeous; the fabric and patent leather look classy and elegant. They fit wonderfully and are quite comfortable. I can't wait to wear them with my new dress.I love these so much, I wish they came in more colors. Orange, red or pink would be perfect for spring and summer. That aside, however, I will just be content with them in blue. :-)

These gloves are exactly as described. The only thing to note is that they have a very strong odor, making them not so appropriate for food preparation. There is also a California Proposition 65 warning on the bottom of the box.

I have been looking for a pair of knee high wedge boots for a while now. I got these AK boots during a great sale. I have many pairs of Anne Klein shoes and I love them all, so I figured I'd be safe to give these a go.I'm glad to say these boots are just what I wanted. They are very comfortable. They are easy to walk in and look classy with pants, leggings, skirts - they dress up any outfit. They stretch in the back, so they fit my larger, muscular calves (17). There were only two things I would change -  if they were real leather, and if they did not have the seam in the front.Otherwise, I really love these boots and they were worth the money spent on them.

Aerosoles has become one of my favorite shoe brands. They are stylish, but comfortable and well made. The Dream Plush Wedge by A2 is no different.These shoes are absolutely wonderful. They are well crafted and sturdy. The insole is highly cushioned, making for a super comfy experience. And the fit - is spot on. The zipper on the top actually works, so you can adjust it up or down to tighten or loosen your shoe as needed (especially helpful if your feet differ in size at all).I absolutely love these sandals, and plan to buy them in more colors.

I really love the way these shoes look. They are absolutely on-trend; very sexy and stylish. I had high hopes for them and couldn't wait to receive them.Sadly, they run very, very small. In most shoes, I wear a size 10 (on the rare instance, a 10.5). I actually couldn't fit my foot fully in this shoe. My heel didn't even come close to making it. I'm not sure if it is the style or the brand itself, but since they are not available in a larger size, they had to be returned. Which is a shame, because they are so nice looking.

I very much like these shoes. They are very nice looking: quality construction and the chain detail gives it some shine and glamour. The fit is as expected, and the cushioned insole makes them very comfortable. I haven't worn them yet for any significant length of time (just around the house), but so far, so good. I think they will prove to be a great find for summer weather.

UPDATE 2: So, I didn't get around to conditioning the leather, but it actually didn't matter. The next time I wore them, they didn't stain my feet. So perhaps it was just the first time. Or perhaps it was extra humid out that day. Whatever the case is, I really do like the shoes and am very happy to have them.UPDATE: I've lowered the star rating from 5 stars to 4 for one reason: they can stain your feet. I have them in black and after wearing them for one full day, the top of my feet are black (from the leather band). They are still very comfortable, and maybe a little leather conditioning will fix the issue. I'm going to give it a try. I love these shoes too much not to.ORIGINAL REVIEW:These are beautiful, seemingly very high quality shoes. The genuine leather upper is very soft and supple, which pairs perfectly with the highly cushioned insole. These shoes are incredibly comfortable, and have amazing support. I imagine wearing these all day with no discomfort. They are rather sexy and feel great on - a rare combination indeed.I can't recommend these shoes enough. I might be buying the other colors in addition to the black I already have.

I don't have the best luck when it comes to slippers. I specifically like the mule style, but usually find them to be too short, or too shallow in the bridge thus hurting the top of my foot.Luckily, these slipper are neither. They do fit a little wide, but I actually quite like that. They are very snug and warm, and fit true to size (see photos I've attached). The heel is more rigid than other brands, giving each slipper more structure, which is a plus in my book. The thick rubber sole makes them appropriate for around the house, or a quick trip to the mailbox. The suede is what causes them to be snug at first, but they do appear to be loosening up. The insole isn't terribly thick, but since most slippers are the same, I'm fine with that.They are to new, so it's early to attest to how durable they'll be overall, but so far, so good. I am pleased with my purchase.

I have been looking for a set of solid silicone cooking utensils for a while. I had several spatulas with the plastic handles, and had trouble keeping the inside (where the rubber fits on to the handle) clean. Even when used in the dishwasher, water would seep in there and cause discoloring/cleanliness issues.I saw that this Ouddy set looked exactly like another set I had been eyeing, but cost $7 less. Why? I can't imagine. The dimensions are the same for them and they both have a temperature limit of 480 degrees. The ratings for this were good, so I thought I'd take a chance.I am very glad I did! These silicone utensils are exactly what I have been looking for. The quality is seemingly very high - thick and sturdy. The red color pops on my counter top (I have them sitting in an empty Arborio rice container with red glass marbles at the bottom for weight). With proper care, I imagine they will last a long while.The one thing to note, at least with mine.. the holes in the spatula had some slight edge overlap with tiny slivers of extra silicone. I took a new nail file and cleaned them out a bit. I doubt it would come off in my food, but I wanted to make sure. Now it's perfect.Overall, I am very pleased with this set and may consider buying more from this brand.

I have very thick, long, wavy locks. It's always been a challenge to keep it healthy, moisturized and frizz free. A few years ago, I discovered that I had a sensitivity or allergy (not sure which) to the silicones that the majority of shampoos contain. I noticed a significant bald spot on the back of my head that, while easily covered by proper styling, sent me into an obvious panic. I was in my 30's, surely this couldn't be happening to me? So, after some research and trial and error, it became apparent to me it was the silicones causing the problems. Once the silicones were cut, my hair grew back.So began an extensive search for shampoos and conditioners that did not contain silicone. I never expected it to be SUCH a challenge! Interestingly,  most shampoos & conditioners available in the US contain silicones (you can tell because the ingredient ends in "cone"), while the majority in the UK, France and abroad do not.I found a couple low end brands that didn't have it. Generally, I found that the scent never last very long and they left my hair really dry. I found a relatively well-known, higher end brand that contained many different types of oils (mainly olive), but that left my hair feeling greasy much more quickly than it should. I was at my wits end, about to submit to a life with shampoos I hated.Enter Elucence Moisture Benefits Shampoo & Conditioner. I am absolutely ecstatic that I discovered this brand. Wouldn't you know it? It's a UK based company. The products smell heavenly (like peaches & cream). They don't dry out my hair, instead leaving it soft, bouncy and conditioned (but not greasy). Best of all, they are silicone free so my hair is immensely healthy!Elucence may be a hard brand to find, and maybe a bit more costly, but it's well worth the trouble and expense. I love it and am already planning my next purchase.

I have always been a fan of sweater dresses, though I've never been able to find any to really flatter me. This one had so many good reviews so I thought I'd give it a try.First of all, let me say the dress looked nice. It appeared to be well made, and it fit great. For me, sadly, I just did not like the pattern of the dress. From the photo online, I thought I would like it, but for some reason it did not look right on me. I think I would have preferred more black and less white.So, although I had to return it, the dress itself was quality and it fit well. Perhaps I will consider another pattern from this brand.

UPDATE:Ok, so I have had this pan since the end of February... almost 4 full months. Sadly, I had to change the 5 stars I had previously given this pan to 2 stars. The reason: It warped. Yet another deep jumbo fry pan that has warped on me. I purchased this pan to replace another one that had done the same thing. This one has popped "up": the spot in the center on the bottom raised up, so any cooking oils/liquids fall to the perimeter of the pan, leaving the middle without any.To anyone who may be wondering, I am a cook and take excellent care of my cookware. This WearEver has never been put hot into cold water (a reason why some pans warp). I always wash it by hand, and use silicone utensils when cooking.I think this is common with aluminum pans. This is aluminum, and my previous pan was as well. I think the thing to do is spend money on an All-Clad (not Limited, but one of their higher end lines), or Swiss Diamond. When I purchased the WearEver, money was tight. However, I'm going to pony up since quality cookware is an investment, and the good ones should last you a nice long while.ORIGINAL REVIEWI needed a new 5 quart pan to replace another "name brand" cooker that had warped at the bottom, thus making it unusable. This one looked nice, and the price was right, so I gave it a chance.So glad I did! Here are the pros thus far:* Gorgeous pan. Glossy, shiny, sexy candy apple red in color. I love the side pouring spouts.* The elegant, shapely handle is dual riveted for strength and designed for proper air flow while cooking.* Helper handle helps stabilize pouring when pan is full* Lid is very well constructed with thick glass with pouring holes in two places* Non-stick coating seems durable and hasn't scratched as of yetI've only used it several times but as of right now, it is holding up well thus far. While it's not terribly high end, it doesn't have the price tag, either. It is a nice pan at a decent price, and so far is worth the purchase. I have included some photos in case it helps, and will update this review if there are any changes.

This is my second ProBake Teflon 16-inch Pizza Pan. The first one has served me well, but when I noticed it wearing down, I decided to buy another one (instead of a more expensive pizza stone).This little pan has not only made fantastic pizzas but I've used it to bake bread, strombolis, scones, biscuits, etc. It works well with no warping. Even without a pizza stone, this pan makes great pizza - even moreso when it's been seasoned a bit. The crust is nice and crisp, and everything bakes evenly.For the price, this is a nice pizza pan that should last you a long while. Very much recommended!

Since I do try to watch what I eat, deep frying is a rare instance in my kitchen. However, once in a while, the need arises and I was in search of a thermometer to monitor the temperature of the oil. Enter Polder THM-515 candy thermometer.Here are the pros & cons:Pros:* Sturdy & seemingly well made of thick stainless steel* Has both Farenheit and Celsius readings* Features "shortcut" readings along the temperature gage, such as "thread", "soft ball", "soft crack", "hard ball", "deep fry", etc. to help with cookingCons:* Due to placement of the pot clip, it will not work if your pot is under 8" high (ie. small saucepans, etc.)* Thermometer takes several minutes to reach desired temperatureSo, while I don't plan to use this thermometer more than infrequently, I do recommend a purchase.

Because I prefer darker ink, I generally use gel ink pens. However, I just needed some inexpensive retractable pens to have throughout my home.These pens are great for the money! They write smooth (no skips so far) and surprisingly darker than I expected. They are comfortable to write with (I have rather large hands). Overall, I am very pleased with these pens. They are quite a value and I may be ordering some more, perhaps in blue this time.

Well, what can I say? This Brownie Brittle is beyond tasty. They are thin, very crisp squares. They look like brownies (complete with flaky crust on top). They taste like brownies (they have honest to goodness chocolate chips in them). Best of all, they are only 4g of fat and 120 calorie per serving.The only problem is they are addictive and you WILL want to eat more than one serving. Luckily, they come in small bags so you can't scarf down 20 servings at a time. That makes you feel somewhat better. Until you look inside the empty bag at only crumbs, wondering where it all went. You may look suspiciously at your significant other, looking for any signs of betrayal. You may go through your child's room, wondering if they stole from your stash. But look no further than the mirror, my friend. You likely ate it all yourself.You have been warned.

Well, being February on the East Coast, I realized that I needed even more blankets than I already own to keep warm. I considered many different brands before settling on this fleece blanket.I am SO glad I took a chance! This blanket is amazing! It's soft, thick, warm and cozy - everything I wanted it to be! It's perfect to cuddle up with while watching TV, or to use at night while sleeping. It doesn't seem to shed much (if at all), which is important to me. I chose to go with the silver color, since it's neutral and will work in any room.I highly recommend this blanket. Nice quality at a reasonable price. In fact, I may order one or two more.

These tights are absolutely wonderful. They fit exactly as they should (the sizing chart is accurate). They are thick, opaque and warm, especially important at this time of year. And there is no control top, which I appreciate because I already have garments for that.The only small drawback, if there is one, is that the waist band is a bit tighter than you might expect. Other than that, they are perfect and I'll likely be ordering more very soon.

My first thought was, how much can be said about a skimmer? Well, surprisingly in this case, a lot.This is an extremely well made utensil. I am surprised by how high quality it is. The stainless steel used is very thick and quite lustrous.The skimmer itself is nice and large at 5 inch round. The mesh is very fine, which will be great for what I plan to use it for (mainly for removing gnocchi from boiling water). The handle, which is half stainless steel and half heavy duty rubber, is very securely welded to the skimmer.Because this skimmer is so nice, I have included some photos. Well worth the money spent - in fact, I'm surprised it is so well priced!

I purchased this knife set at a special sale last year during the holidays. I figured due to the KitchenAid brand name and an amazing price (about 50% off), I was getting a bargain. Now, here I am 3 months into ownership, and I am glad I did not pay full price for them. They have been a disappointment.First, let's start with the good things about it:* The knives are very sharp. They have cut through everything with ease. They are much sharper than my previous set.* Nice block. It is a very attractive silver gray and looks very classy on my counter top.* Triple riveted full tang handle. Not nearly as good as the full hidden tang of my favorite Royal Doulton bread knife, but it's not bad.That being said, these knives stain SO very easily. After almost 3 months of daily use and gentle washing by hand, the have stained. Not even just the rust spots, either. They look like water spots, though I can't imagine how this has happened. Please see the photo I posted of the stains.So even after quickly noticing the inferior quality of this knife set, I chose to keep it because the knives were sharp and I didn't pay too much for it. If you are going to have to pay full price, however, I recommend considering another brand because these aren't worth the money.

I have been through many measuring cups. First, several plastic ones. They all cracked at some point, either the handle or the cup itself. So, I moved on to glass cups.I had previously purchased a similar (but different brand name) glass measuring cup to this one at a local big-box home & kitchen store. After only about one month, I noticed that the red writing on the side was fading off in the dishwasher. Now, after about 3 months, I can barely read the measurement lines.So, I decided to take a chance on this Pyrex cup. I've had it for several months now and I am happy to say that the lines are still nice and bright, even after numerous runs through the dishwasher. It appears very sturdy and heavy duty. I have had no issues whatsoever. Granted, I don't generally use it for anything but cold liquids, but I think that it would hold up to whatever I used it for.All-in-all, this is worth the money. I actually may buy a couple more for when I need back ups while cooking.

I purchased this to make fresh homemade ravioli. I considered buying one of those dual-wheel contraptions, but instead decided on this single version. I figured if I want to cut straight pasta, I can just use a pizza cutter to get the same result.This particular ravioli wheel appears to be sturdy and well made. The wheel moves freely and smoothly. The black plastic handle is comfortable to grip. Additionally, the hole at the end of the handle was an important feature because I hang the majority of my kitchen tools from the hooks on a magnetic knife strip.I'm assuming if this is washed quickly and well maintained, it should last you a while.

This is a great movie that is extremely underrated. I honestly can't understand how this movie isn't appreciated more than it has been.Gripping, well-crafted script; wonderfully acted by a very strong, A-list cast; and wonderful production value. The Blu-ray is pretty much the typical blu-ray transfer, which is always far better than the standard version.All in all, I love this film. I wish more people would give it a chance.

This is a very nice kitchen torch. It seems sturdy and well made. I plan to use it to make creme brulee and baked alaska. A must-have tool for the intermediate to experienced home cook.Note: This item does not come with butane. You must buy it separately.

I absolutely love this foundation. Up until the point I discovered PhotoReady, my foundation never quite blended the way I wanted it to. Now, using this in conjunction with green foundation primer, and a high quality flat kabuki brush, I get the flawless, almost airbrushed finish I'd been wanting. It never feels heavy; coverage amount is moderate (which is what I want); and it lasts all day long.I hope they never discontinue this product. I will continue using it as long as they make it.

I use this silicone basting brush for everything: Oiling bowls for dough proofing; brushing egg wash on pastries before baking; basting whole chickens and turkeys. You name it, this little brush can do it. Just make sure to use light touch when using it on fragile items (like pastry dough) to make sure the bristles don't break through.I always clean this brush in the dishwasher to make sure I get all particles out of the little bristles. It is dishwasher safe and cleans like a dream. Highly recommended, I may buy more!

Cuisinart has a fine reputation for cookware excellence. One of my all time favorite pots, which is about 15 years old, is a heavy duty stainless steel Cuisinart stock pot. I wanted a similar skillet for things like pan frying chicken and scallops, and I took a chance on this pan.I am very happy with this purchase. It is quite substantial, with a nice heavy bottom. This makes it sit evenly on my electric coil-burner style stove. It heats up very evenly (sometimes so fast you have to watch not to burn something!) and, since it's stainless steel, it's great for using the fond in your recipes.I easily and readily recommend this skillet. It will make a nice addition to any cookware collection.

These are great gloves for dish washing. I needed them to go with the Bar Keeper's Friend, purchased to deep clean the bottom of my pans.What I love best about these gloves, aside from the fact they keep my hands dry, is the lining inside. It's soft and fleece like, almost like gloves your grandmother used to wear.Since they are white, they will stain. But at a reasonable price, they will be easy to replace once they become too unsightly.
Super cute! My kids will be looking forward to this every year. They can help out by prepping the candy and filling the cornucopia. Easy, cute, and not messy!

Great releasing of my little donuts! Heavy-duty, never warped, cleaned up easily. Glad it made so many at once, more than double other mini pans. Still fits in the oven easily, about the size of a cookie sheet.  Fills up easily with the corner cut off of a batter filled baggy!

USA made, no hole for the flour to find its way out, small size so it isn't too heavy, no handle to turn and crank to wind up with wrist fatigue, easy for my kids to use. Very sturdy, well made, and super cute! Looks kinda old timey, so I actually leave it out as a little decoration!  Bromwell Industries was stamped on the side, I love it!
I bought this at a big box hardware store, but we returned it. My husband and I were not comfortable with the plastic 'InnoFlex' water lines. We want the braided lines instead

Fits great! Completely covers the mattress top, and the sides go all the way around the mattress sides to have the elastic tucked underneath. We have a memory foam topper that is three inches thick. The top is a soft terry, backed with a NOT NOISY plastic sort of material. My child gets hot easily, but has not complained about it, even in the summer heat.  Seems to be durable, I would recommend this protector, great product for a great price!

We have one of these from many years ago, and decided to buy another for our second vehicle. The new ones unfortunately are made in China, as stated on the back of the cardboard packaging. It also reads about 1-2 psi lower than our original. We are unhappy that the company has outsourced, but we will continue to use this one since the discrepancy is small.

We have this stuck on our fridge, and it works great for knowing what is going on for the month. Two things that you might want to know. 1. RUBBING ALCOHOL. Works great at cleaning it off, we don't wipe dry, seems to scratch it. 2. EXPO superfine markers, you can fit way more into the little boxes than with the included marker. Other than that, it does what it is supposed to!
Works great for my Fire phone, I especially like the compass. I have the whole world rolling around in the palm of my hand!
Hold tight on the back of my Silver Forest of Vermont earrings without being too difficult to get on or off! Would recommend these to anyone with hook earrings.

Didn't give a clean cut, had to file to make it fit, but ended up having to just get a new card. Guess you can't expect much for this price, bad grammar on the packaging would be a dead give away if they had a packaging pic. There were no adapters as listed or eject tool.
Great tight fit on our Amana washing machine! Heavier duty than original parts, highly recommend.
Fit our Amana washer like an original part, helped quiet it significantly. Not a thin whimpy aftermarket.

Great for my apple shape! No buttons, loops, or zippers means a smooth front and no muffin top. Rise is a teeny bit higher than the Paley; relaxed, but not loose in the thigh.  Comfy and stretchy, great color that doesn't fade to quickly. Love Jag jeans in general, but these are definitely my favorite!

Smells great, like a Luden's coughdrop! Doesn't taste quite as sweet, but does taste very good! We usually use the raspberry lemon, and this was a nice change. This is a tad sweeter since it doesn't have the lemon flavor, but I really enjoyed it. My kids like it too!

We bought this as a birthday gift for our daughter, she was thrilled to get it, but quickly became disappointed. The hair falls out with even an adult brushing it gently, she has no feet, the boots attach to her legs with a ball/socket joint, and the barrettes and really hard to open and close, again, for an adult. One of the only positives she has mentioned, she stands on her own unlike Barbie. She also likes the hair, but there is a huge bald spot in the back of the head(intentionally), and the hair clips are pretty, but frizz and fall out easily. Won't be investing much into more of these.

I just have to say that these fit so well, and are so easy to install!  They have rigid, yet fairly flexible sides, that do not to buckle over and let dirt get down the sides like our WeatherTech mats in another car.  The grip on the back is amazing, and really hold so they don't slide around under your feet.  The upper side is textured just enough to not be slippery, and they are definitely waterproof.  They fit with limited space between the original curve or the car floor and mat, just enough to make them easily maneuvered into place.  Wish we would have saved our money on the WeatherTech mats we purchased for our other vehicle and bought these instead!

Whole family enjoyed this thoroughly! I have three kids, 8, 5, and 2, and we were all captivated.  It has a wonderful twist, where as in the original there is the Rat King, this is Nazi's (as bears in her imagination).  The little girl is her own heroine, along with her brothers, mother and a friend.  She 'visits' her father in a POW camp(though it's a dream), and helps him keep hope and faith.  It's a great way to introduce young children to history, and it isn't too graphic or scary(and my kids can be a little overly sensitive, we watch mostly just Veggietales).  The one tense part is a close up of the Nazi bear's sharp teeth, but young Clara is triumphant.  The dancing is wonderful, the costumes beautiful, and the storyline caught me completely off guard in the best way!  I am sure that this will be a yearly family favorite, and I would recommend this to ANY family!

Decent weight for the fabric, though my daughter still needs to wear white underwear underneath, which is expected.  All of the seams and hems have held up for the last month of wear, it's great quality. They are a great cut, I usually have to take the waistband in on bottoms, my daughter is tall and skinny, but I didn't have to for these. They have enough room for her to grow into as well! We look forward to more of these!

A little on the thin side, but for the price, it's just right. Very soft, colors are bright and we haven't had any bleeding.  We have had it for a few weeks now, it is used for a bath towel almost daily, and it is not unraveling or busting at the hem. My daughter loves it, and for the price of $10-15, I would definitely buy this again.

Still the same great white chocolate flavor and smoothness of the original. The new bar is simply thinner and easier to break than the old square. Another plus is that it melts faster! Before, two thick rectangles in a square was 1 ounce, now it's four thinner rectangles that make an ounce. It also contains no hydrogenated oils like other brands, which was my biggest  draw. Cocoa butter is the second ingredient behind sugar, with a little milk and flavors. We used ours to cover pretzels and make peanut clusters. Was great not having to wait as long for it to melt, since I have children working with me.  Great product, and I will buy this brand again in the future!

Writing a fundraising letter is easy. Lots of people do it every day.Writing a GOOD fundraising letter - one that grabs the donor’s attention, touches her heart, and motivates her to give - now that’s hard work. And it happens a lot less often.Jeff Brooks (disclosure: a longtime colleague and friend) has been writing the best kind of fundraising for many years. He knows what sets fundraising copywriting apart from every other kind of writing. And fortunately for us, he’s willing to pull back the curtain on the counterintuitive world of fundraising to help you focus your fundraising where it should be focused … not on your organization, not even on your cause … but on your donor.Jeff takes the guesswork out of writing by explaining how to tell a story effectively, how to build a compelling offer, even what to do when a problem feels too big to solve (“How can my $25 cure cancer?”). Along the way, you’ll learn why fundraisers write in that style that makes English teachers cringe, why humor and symbolism almost never work, and how to defend your work to your director, board, or client.Jeff is a great writer, but also (and also) a great teacher. Whether you’re new to the discipline or have been in the field a long time, I’ll bet you will learn a lot from this slim book, and gain a new appreciation for the value of your work. I know I did.

I was skeptical about both the quality and the comfort of this shirt, and was pleasantly surprised. It's still just a basic blue T-shirt, but as such items go, it's not bad at all. One thing I was concerned about was that the high percentage of polyester in the construction (40%) might make this feel like the plastic-y shirts I wear for working out - fit for purpose, but not something I grab just to get dressed. But in fact, this shirt doesn't feel a lot different from many of the 100 percent cotton T-shirts I have. This is on the thinner/lighter side, but so are many of those other, often more expensive, shirts. If you're looking for something like this, don't be spooked by the price or the fact it's not a name brand. There's a certain beauty in a plain ol' American T-shirt (defined as a T-shirt worn by Americans; this item is actually made in China), and this shirt has that.

I have to admit I don't get the horological fad of both men and women wearing huge clunky watches. I wear this two or three times a week, and honestly, the most noticeable thing about it is its weight. It is certainly an attractive watch, but not one I've made a regular part of my daily routine.I would point out a few problems. The watch face is white, with gold Roman numerals and gold and silver gears. The hands are also white with gold edges, which means the hands do not stand out against the face at all. Threading the band is complicated - at least it was for me. I worked on it for some time, though my wife wants me to point out that once I handed it to her, she figured it out instantly. "Instantly." Also, because of the large metal parts and hinge in the clasp, the band does not lie smoothly against the wrist was would other types of bands. The fit is always slightly distorted (and uncomfortable) because of a roughly inch long piece of metal against the inside of your wrist. Finally, because this watch mechanism is an "automatic self-wind" that depends on the wearer's movement to keep ticking, if you're like me and only wear the thing once in a while, you'll have to reset the time a lot.This watch isn't going to replace my iPhone as my principle time-telling device: Even when I was wearing this, I found myself taking my phone out of my pocket to find out the time (though granted, that may just be because I'm out of practice wearing a watch). This is an ornament - like all expensive watches, or watches that want to look expensive, are - and as long as I keep that in mind, it's satisfactory enough.

Since I have a beard, a tube, can, or jar of shaving cream or soap tends to last me a long time. That's a good thing in this case, because I like this foam-free shaving cream a lot. Like the name says, the fact that my face isn't covered in suds or lather makes it much easier to negotiate the beard line or other places I want to get right by sight, instead of just by feel or muscle memory. I found the scent light and refreshing ... not nearly as strong (or as long-lasting) as many other shaving products. And, being AHAVA, it's no surprise this stuff leaves my skin feeling good too. On the whole, this is a very positive addition to the medicine cabinet.

The Jam Trance Plus is a decent Bluetooth speaker, no better or worse than any of several others in our house (though not as good as the Amazon Echo, I should mention). The lights are a nice plus, especially in a darkened room or on the back porch at night. I am a little disappointed that the lights do not flash or pulse in synchronization with the music being played, but I didn't lower my rating for that because that was never a feature it claimed. Battery life is quite good. On the whole, this is a serviceable wireless speaker with a little bit of extra pizzaz if you need it.

Most of my portable listening is done through one or another pair of fairly decent earbuds, or, when I need quiet, an old pair of Bose noise-canceling headphones. While there's nothing intrinsically wrong with these Panasonic cans, I haven't yet found a use case where they would replace either of those other options. The sound quality is decent, but lacks the immediacy and clarity of either in-ear or cover-the-ear models. Real audiophiles probably won't be impressed, but for casual listening to music or podcasts, these may be good enough. One thing I do sort of like about them is their vaguely old-style, 1940s-esque styling. I feel like I should be wearing a 50-missions cap with them. On a practical level, though, these are definitely third-string.

Although not explicitly intended as a companion volume to editor Sonja Tiernan's 2012 biography Eva Gore-Booth: An image of such politics, I think that's how this impressive collection functions best. Certainly my copy of the biography now includes, next to mentions of or quotations from Eva's writings, my annotations of the relevant page numbers in the Political Writings. Making those connections would have been easier had this book listed the writings by title in either a table of contents or an index (many are sub-indexed under media type: "articles by Gore-Booth," "pamphlets by Gore-Booth," etc.), but they are listed chronologically under large umbrella topics.This book would be impressive enough if it were just a collection of Eva Gore-Booth's writings: Since many of those works, particularly from Eva's early years in trade-union activism, were topical pamphlets not intended to have a long lifespan, finding those works and reprinting them here is itself an achievement. But the book includes a useful introduction, and each of the three main parts includes the editor's scholarly review of the content and context of Eva's work. As the frequent appearance of Tiernan's own name in the listing of "Selected Works about Eva Gore-Booth" at the back shows, Tiernan must be the preeminent expert on Eva's life today. This book isn't just an appendix to the biography, but an important addition to the historical record in its own right.

Like many people, I imagine, I came to know of Eva Gore-Booth through reading about her sister, the Irish revolutionary Constance Markievicz. I think Countess Markievicz a very interesting historical figure, but for reasons I still can't quite define, I find myself fascinated by Eva Gore-Booth. Sadly, while probably about a dozen biographies of the Countess have been written in the last 80 years, there appear to be only two treatments of her sister's life at any length: 1988's dual biography Eva Gore-Booth and Esther Roper: A Biography (Valient Women Series) by Gifford Lewis, and this book by Sonja Tiernan. This latter book is a remarkable book, and was completely worth the eagerness with which I waited for it to come through the door. I recommend it highly.Eva Gore-Booth is unquestionably a challenge for the biographer. Unlike her sister, who loved to put herself on center stage figuratively and literally, Eva by temperament as well as health tended to keep herself in the wings. While active in, and indeed central to, many of the causes most important to her, that nature often caused her to be overlooked at the time, and forgotten since. Compounding the difficulty, Eva kept her private life very private indeed, and many of her personal papers were destroyed or returned to her family following her death. Even after the impressive and thorough degree of research Sonja Tiernan did to prepare this biography, then, Eva remains something of a cypher on the personal level.In that earlier biography, Gifford Lewis states that a further reason Eva is often overlooked is because of the alleged difficulty in describing, or as we would say today, "labeling," her relationship with Esther Roper. Eva and Esther met in what sounds a lot like a case of love at first sight, and remained together until Eva's death thirty years later -- indeed, they remain together still, buried under a common headstone in a London churchyard. Lewis argues at some length that the two were friends, collaborators, each other's inspiration ... "life partners" in every sense of the term except the physical. Theirs was a "passionate," even "ecstatic" friendship, Lewis says, but they were emphatically not lovers. At considerably less length but with compelling logic, Sonja Tiernan says "yes they were." This may be a question we never get an answer to, but personally I find Tiernan's argument more persuasive.Where this book really shines is in the analysis of Eva's public work: her life as a union organizer, suffragist, feminist, and antiwar activist, as well as a poet, artist, and religious and sexual reformer. In all those fields, although she was a tireless worker and excellent organizer, Eva's principal tool was her pen, and Tiernan analyzes both Eva's deeds and her words in satisfying detail (I strongly encourage you to read this book with a copy of The political writings of Eva Gore-Booth, which Tiernan edited, by your side: Nearly all the works quoted in the biography are printed in full in the latter book, and are definitely worth reading). I was particularly interested in Eva's work in opposition to World War I and in support of conscientious objectors (readers also interested in this topic should check out Adam Hochschild's To End All Wars: A Story of Loyalty and Rebellion, 1914-1918, a well-told history of British opposition to the war, although -- perhaps in confirmation of challenge I described above -- Eva's name does not appear in its pages). The other topic I was particularly intrigued by was Eva and Esther's work with Urania, the journal they founded to promote feminism and "unconventional views regarding sexuality and gender" (p. 227). One of my standards for measuring the worth of a book is how many other things that book inspires me to read. My to-read list is a lot longer now as a result of this biography -- starting with trying to find a decent copy of Eva's Collected Poems. (I'm just not sure if I can trust all these $15 reprint volumes.)I hope this book and the Political Writings succeed in bringing a bit of attention to the life of Eva Gore-Booth. She deserves not simply the reflected light of her acclaimed sister, but a spotlight of her own in the literary, political, and social history of both the UK and Ireland. Sonja Tiernan, in turn, deserves thanks for reminding us of that.

I handed this case off to my wife for her to use on her iPhone 6, and her verdict is much like that of other reviewers here: The leather is a nice touch, giving a sort of sophisticated look to the phone and a comfortable enough feel in the hand, but it doesn't add very much protection to the unadorned phone. But how much protection you really need depends on your use case, I guess, and so she's pretty satisfied on the whole. The case fairly soon started to show some wear on the lower corners, and that continues to be the most visible sign of use. But she likes the bright yellow, which stands out nicely when you're looking for your phone across a room or in a dark briefcase. It's not exactly armor, but maybe that's not what everyone needs.(Edited a couple of months later to add: My wife has now officially retired this case with the ruling, "It looks okay, but the materials wear out too soon and look bad as they do." It's hard to disagree. After about five months of use, the leather is separating from the plastic case all along the left side and on the upper right corner. There are scuff marks all over the back, and the "ullu" logo on the back is faded.)

There are a lot of things I like about the iPhone 6, but one of my favorite improvements is that it no longer spontaneously crashes when the battery meter reaches 20 percent or so (a "feature" of the iPhone 5 that was not unique to me). That makes an external battery case like this one less essential for daily use, at least in my case, but still a very good thing to have for travel or other long days away from a plug. The brushed black finish is pretty sharp to look at and comfortable to hold, although obviously the battery adds noticeable weight. I have several external batteries I use from time to time with my iOS devices (I'm a particular fan of the Jackery Bar Premium iPhone Charger & External Battery 6000mAh - Portable Charger and Travel Charger for iPhone 6 Plus, 6, 5, iPad Air, iPad Mini, Samsung Galaxy S6, S5 & Other Smart Devices (Orange) ), but there are many arguments for a battery case versus a separate recharge unit. Users with a need for extra power for their iPhone 6 ought to take a look at this option.

I bought this book and the second title by the author, I admit, because I was intrigued by the idea of a murder mystery series set in Sugar Land, Texas, a community just south of my home and where I've spent a fair amount of time. (The fact that the author, like me, lives with "two badly behaved pugs" also helped.) What kept me reading, though, was the well-crafted story and an ending that didn't give itself away too soon.One of the intriguing things about this book was that I didn't actually like our narrator Walker "Bear" Wells very much. There was a lot about how he related to other characters that I found unpleasant -- and not in a curmudgeonly-but-ultimately-endearing way like, say Inspector Morse. The fact that other characters called Bear on this behavior from time to time helped, though, and reassured me that first-time novelist Stephanie Jaye Evans hadn't fallen into the trap of creating an idealized superhero as her lead character. Bear is a very fallible man.The other thing I found interesting is that Bear is not really attempting to solve the murder in this story. He's content to let the Chesterton-reading Detective Wanderley do that. Instead, Bear keeps -- as the back cover blurb puts it -- finding himself and his family wrapped up in the mystery. There's a lot more I could say about this, but it could cross the line into spoilers.One final point to note, since this is "A Sugar Land Mystery," is how nicely the author captures the atmospherics of suburban Houston -- which is to say, there basically *are* no atmospherics. Fort Bend County is the most ethnically diverse county in America, and this shows up in a few ways on these pages. But readers from other parts of the country who might expect a whole lotta Texas flavor here may be disappointed -- the front-cover blurb from Susan Wittig Albert about "down-home Texas twang" notwithstanding (I would recommend the pre-sword and sorcery Tres Navarre novels of Rick Riordan, set in San Antonio, for readers looking for that sort of thing; start with Big Red Tequila). Detective Wanderley sports an admirable collection of boots, and Bear himself is practically royalty, having once been a starter on the University of Texas football team, but on the whole Sugar Land is pretty standard-issue suburbia, and that in fact is reflected here quite accurately.As usual, my to-read pile is pretty huge, but I'm looking forward to getting into Safe From Harm (A Sugar Land Mystery) as soon as I can, and then keeping my eyes out hopefully for a third title in the series.

Although I've been a fan of Will Thomas' from the first time I picked up the initial Barker and Llewelyn novel in 2006 (shortly after I met Thomas and his family, entirely by coincidence, in a London pub; in the interests of disclosure I'll say I haven't been in contact with him since), I hadn't realized quite how much I'd missed the pair until the second or third chapter of "Fatal Enquiry." After that, I pretty much read straight through to the end with minimal interruptions. Readers who've been drumming their fingers waiting for this latest addition to the series will find a lot that's rewarding here, and a lot that pays off the wait. But as many other reviewers have suggested, there is something different about this Barker and Llewelyn title that makes it, in some key ways, a big departure for the series.As I've noted in most or maybe all of my reviews of earlier Barker and Llewelyn books, Will Thomas' standard approach is to put us in a setting that's probably relatively recognizable to most mystery readers -- late-nineteenth century London -- but then carries us into much less familiar segments of that era's society -- Irish revolutionaries, Chinese immigrants, London's Jewish community, and so on. (Of course, being Scottish and Welsh respectively, Barker and Llewelyn are also outsiders to a fair degree.) "Fatal Enquiry" has very little of that occasionally unsettling blend of familiar and unfamiliar. That's because in this book, Barker and Llewelyn are not master and student trying to catch their criminal prey, but are themselves the prey, marked for destruction by Barker's oldest and most dangerous foe, Col. Sebastian Nightwine.I really liked the way the premise of the story was introduced in chapter one, with Barker's police friend Poole coming to tell him a VIP had requested Scotland Yard's protection from a potential attacker ... the attacker being Barker himself, with Nightwine the VIP. After that, Barker and Llewelyn's world collapses around them ... quickly, disorientingly, and by this series' standards, quite violently. Characterization sometimes felt a bit too ... "too." Barker and even Llewelyn a bit too superhuman, Nightwine a bit too Moriarty, with his fingers on every lever of power. The one "character" who came out beautifully well-defined and evocative was, as always, London itself.I think we learn more about Barker in this book than in the rest of the series put together. Readers following the series will want to read this one for that reason alone, I think, but even with my reservations noted above this is a good entry in an excellent series. I've found Will Thomas' work to be the Lake Wobegon of mystery series: all the books are above average. By that standard, even a title that some may find disappointing is still worth reading. It's definitely enough to make me start drumming my fingers waiting for the next one.

NOTE: SLIGHT SPOILERS AHEADCritics cited on various other websites seem to have dismissed "Jo" as a collection of cop-show clichés. I don't think it's quite that simple. Certainly creator/writer/producer Rene Balcer, writer and showrunner of the original "Law & Order" and other parts of the L&O universe, and his team made use of some familiar (and useful, and largely successful) building blocks from L&O days. I might arguably describe that as lazy writing, but not, on that basis alone, as bad writing.I'm an L&O fan, but I was attracted to this by the fact that my favorite actress, the magnificent Orla Brady, plays the Anita Van Buren/Don Cragen role as "Commissaire Béatrice Dormont." My first thought was that this would be "Law & Order: Rive Gauche." It wasn't quite that, although the familiar elements mentioned above range from the wisecrack at the fade into the opening credits, to the detective estranged from his adult daughter in part because of his own demons and addictions, to the Ell-Tee with lessons hard-won from years of sobriety. There were probably many more. Episode Six nods at the L&O universe with a guest appearance from Sam Waterston (not playing Jack McCoy). I imagine nearly everyone who knows L&O was hoping, as I was, they could contrive to get his character and series regular Jill Hennessy's into a scene together. Episode Eight, which turned out to be the final one of the series, places the show entirely within the L&O universe with the appearance of a well-known recurring character from one of the spinoffs.I didn't have a problem with the plots, but I did find the dialogue surprisingly wooden sometimes. Tom Austen's lines in the earlier eps, especially, often seemed very awkward (again, this isn't about his performance, but about the writing). Some critics evidently said the show didn't do enough to highlight the Paris scenery. I thought, on the other hand, it did a good job of demythologizing the City of Light and making it a city of actual people.For me as for some others, the big question mark was someone's decision to have all of these allegedly French people (with the exception of Jean Reno, who really is French) speak in terrible, flat American accents. Having to listen to Orla Brady swallow her natural Irish accent in order to deliver lines like "Well, you need to get up there and show `em how it's done" or "This two-bit drug dealer..." while sounding like she was from Akron or something was one of the true crimes in each episode. On the other hand, Jo had a memorable bit in Episode Five: "He was looking at her the way a man looks at a woman. He's the warden. He should be looking at her the way a grocer looks at oranges." Even Lenny Briscoe couldn't have gotten away with a line like that.Be sure to note the wonderfully atmospheric score by Danish jazz artist and composer Thomas Hass Christensen. Reminiscent of Miles Davis' minimalist score for Elevator to the Gallows (The Criterion Collection) ("Ascenseur pour l'échafaud"), it really helps set the mood for the series.On the whole, I liked "Jo" and thought future series, had there been any, could have had a lot of promise. This is a weird little satellite orbiting on the outer edges of the L&O universe, but it was not in the least an unpleasant place to visit. Even though only eight episodes were made, it's good to know we'll always have Paris.

This book is the 1994 publication of the scripts of three plays that premiered together in London in March, 1993. To quote the Times Educational Supplement review that forms the foreword to the book, "'A Love Song for Ulster' chronicles the history of a family from the arranged marriage between John, a stolid, decent Protestant, and Kate, a beautiful, tempestuous Catholic free spirit..." At the premiere, Kate was played by my favorite actress, the magnificent Orla Brady (Mistresses, Proof), while Brendan Coyle (later Masterpiece Downton Abbey's "Mr. Bates") played both John and their son Boyd (the playwright specified that both roles should be performed by the same actor).Kate is a wife and mother, and as the TES review says, the trilogy is the story of several generations of her family. But the family is also metaphor for the history of Northern Ireland from the partition to the then-contemporary peace effort. Each family member or supporting character essentially stands in, as best  I can tell, for various Ulster populations and/or political opinions. John and Kate's house -- all three plays are set entirely within the house's walls or near exterior -- becomes a representation of Northern Ireland itself, with Kate's children and various outsiders battling for control. I was particularly moved by the central relationship between John and Kate themselves: two people who, although forced together against their will, eventually develop mutual respect and even love, only to have what they built fought over and destroyed from both inside and out. It's ambitious storytelling, and from the reviews printed on the book cover it sounds like it was well received. Certainly I found the story compelling. I don't know if "A Love Song for Ulster" is ever performed anymore, but I'd enjoy a chance to see it -- particularly if the original cast were to reprise their roles.

I don't know about "tranquility" or islands of serenity or any of the other cosmic virtues claimed for this water bottle, but I can absolutely attest that it performs its function of holding water admirably. The top unscrews in two places — a wider mouth just above the top of the soft blue lining, and then a smaller one just below the circular handle. That makes this easy to fill with ice and liquid, and then easy to drink neatly. The ring on top makes this easy to carry, and the bottle is somewhat insulated too, so drinks stay cold. The bottle is a bit wide for many car cup-holders, which is a minor complaint, but otherwise I like this bottle a lot and use it almost daily. And since I'm drinking water and not caffeinated beverages out of it, maybe it's making me more tranquil too? Hard to say.

I watched this for free last night on Amazon Instant Video, and I still think the price was too high. To borrow, with apologies, from the previous reviewer of a decade ago, even if you like Mia Sara, you will not enjoy this film.Mia Sara became my favorite actress a long time ago, and held that position even as she became, to use her own phrase, "mostly retired," her work became more sporadic, and someone else ascended rapidly to become what I could call "my favorite actress who isn't mostly retired." As consolation, if any were needed, Mia has also become a favorite poet: google the phrase "Mia Sara Writes" or take a tumbl with "where to find Mia Sara" and I think you'll be favorably impressed.Sadly, there was not much favorable or impressive about "Shadows in the Storm." Reviewers on IMDB describe this as writer-director Terrell Tannen's attempt at a neo-noir, and that seems accurate to me. He didn't succeed, though. The plot matches the broadest description of a noir plot, that being the story of a man who makes a bad decision and then is helpless to prevent the consequences of that decision from destroying him. And the setting in the California woods did remind me of parts of Out Of The Past [HD]. The near-constant darkness and rain worked too. But unlike the typically convoluted, even indecipherable, noir plot, I figured out what was up here very, very quickly. I expected to be squicked by the idea of a romantic pairing between 21-year-old Mia Sara and 51-year-old Ned Beatty (see also 28-year-old Mia's character being sent to seduce 62-year-old Michael Caine in Bullet to Beijing), but it did make sense in the context of the plot, while their one un-graphic and un-sexy sex scene only lasted about 20 seconds, which seemed true-to-life for a man in Ned's condition. And there's at least one plot hole in the resolution that even someone with eyesight as bad as Thelonious Pitt's (yes, that's Ned's character's name) should have been able to see through.Still, Mia is luminous -- not only herownself, but because for most of the movie she's in white sweaters or dresses that seem to glow in the murky woods or interiors. When she suddenly appears in a black leather jacket in bright daylight, you know something has changed. This was a tough movie to watch for several reasons -- and also to listen to, O bad '80s soundtrack entirely disconnected from the mood of the film. At one point late in the story, Mia's character is sitting in a motel room watching the noir classic D.O.A. -- specifically, the scene where Edmond O'Brien is told "You're already dead." Sad that that should have been the most dramatic moment in this film.

This is a great-tasting hazelnut syrup, especially given that it's sugar-free. I find the hazelnut taste is much stronger than the tastes of other Torani syrups (I have coconut, chocolate, raspberry, and a couple of others), and so a much smaller pump serves the same purpose. As part a home coffee bar or even a cart or cafe, this syrup is a great option to have around.

On the morning after George P. Bush scored a decisive victory in the Republican primary race for land commissioner in Texas, and when his father Jeb is already showing up in some polls as a frontrunner for the 2016 GOP presidential nomination, it's clear that the Bush family's place as America's preeminent political dynasty is as secure today as it has ever been. That makes "Family of Secrets," even though it's a few years old now, very far from (to use a Clintonian term) "old news." In fact, it may be getting more important.Russ Baker is an experienced and perceptive investigative journalist, and is very aware -- as he notes in his final chapter -- that in exploring the "powerful forces" surrounding the Bush family he is skirting the bounds of "conspiracy theory." Some would say, and have said, he crossed those bounds. But he has amassed some pretty powerful evidence behind his revelations. Going well beyond the popular images of George H.W. Bush ("Poppy") as the genial but ineffective and out-of-touch preppy and his son as the bumptious, inarticulate "decider" whose strings were pulled by Cheney and Rumsfeld, Baker also doesn't settle for what you might call the next-level of Bush "revelations" ("Prescott Bush ran businesses for the Nazis," etc.). Instead, he covers a remarkable amount of ground across three generations, showing how the Bush family, and Poppy in particular, were and are central to political and business interests that have dominated the American state for half a century or more.By coincidence, I was reading "Family of Secrets" more or less simultaneously with Stephen Kinzer's outstanding The Brothers: John Foster Dulles, Allen Dulles, and Their Secret World War. Although the Dulles name appears only passingly in "Family of Secrets" and the Bush name, from what I recall, not at all in "The Brothers," the two families have a lot in common. Each occupies that spot on the Venn diagram where big business interests, U.S. foreign policy, and the world of intelligence, espionage, and covert action converge. Almost a decade ago, in reviewing Tom Wicker's marginal George Herbert Walker Bush: A Penguin Life (Penguin Lives Biographies), I wrote "George H.W. Bush strikes me as an interesting historical figure whose legacy (like J.Q. Adams' or William Howard Taft's) will be seen as coming from someplace other than his years in the White House." I'm now convinced by Russ Baker that Poppy's primary legacy -- aside perhaps from his raft of children and grandchildren -- will be his integration of electoral politics and intelligence tradecraft -- an integration that affects, and to some degree explains, so much of the nature of the modern American state. In fact, many of Baker's most important discoveries concern Poppy's long and intimate connections with America's intelligence elite -- long predating his brief service as CIA director.In that final chapter I mentioned above, Baker writes that he thought of titling this book "Everything You Thought You Knew Is Wrong." Not many people like books -- or the writers of books -- who threaten their certainties in that way. I encourage you to take the risk and give this book a close reading ... not only for what you'll discover about America's past, but even more critically, because of what it means for our future.

Whatever it is I'm doing sitting out in my back yard during the spring or summer, it's clearly not the "art of outdoor living" as portrayed in this book. The many different homes and estates shown here include some truly remarkable examples of architecture, landscape-engineering, furnishing, and the blending of the three to take advantage of — or create — luxurious and welcoming surroundings. While not perhaps as immediately practical as some more downmarket homes might be (in the sense of "Hey, that's something I could do myself"), there is definitely a fair amount of inspiration here for the reader who seeks it. Or if you'd rather just look at beautiful pictures of built environments, this works for that, too.

I find it slightly hilarious that the box instructions for using this on hair say something like "apply from middle of strand to end." Given how short my hair is, application is kind of an all-or-nothing affair. I'm finding that about a quarter-pump, or even slightly less, is a great amount for keeping hair neat and under control without looking like I got into either my dad's Brylcreem or my son's "sculpting gel" (disclosure: Dad didn't use Brylcreem, and I don't have a son). I've also used this as a beard-treatment, and while my beard again might be too short to get the full "nourishing" benefit, it does at least smell nice.And finally, I also use this as a moisturizer from time to time. Obviously — since it's an oil — it will leave a more "oily" feeling on the skin than the moisturizing lotions I currently use from Dove or Aveeno. When once again used sparingly, though, this oiliness is noticeable only to the touch, not to sight. And again, it does smell nice.I don't use this on either hair or skin on a daily basis. More like a couple of times a week. So think even a two-ounce bottle will probably last me for some time. Given what a nice and versatile treat this has turned out to be — particularly for keeping hair under control when needed — that makes the price much more palatable than it would be if I was burning through this quickly.

Amazon's recent decision to set a time limit on Vine reviews means a clock is ticking behind you as you read. For I think the first time, I'm posting a review of a book I haven't finished yet. So far, "Wilson" is a very readable look at the life of a man who few today remember was, and certainly seemed to think of himself as, a Southerner. Although he served as governor of New Jersey, as well as president of Princeton, and so is sort of officially remembered as being "from" that state, Wilson was in fact born in Virginia and raised in various parts of the South -- including spending the years of the Late Unpleasantness on the CSA side of the lines -- and studied at both Davidson College in North Carolina and the UVA law school, although he left both before completing his studies. Author A.
