Scott Berg is doing a fine job showing how Wilson's early years in the South, as well as the influence of his Scottish and Scots-Irish ancestry, shaped the man, both in general terms and on race relations and other specific issues.As president, of course, Wilson has much to answer to history for -- I'm far from the only person to see his decision to embroil the US in World War One as central not only to sowing the seeds for the second war, but indeed for the red and brown revolutions that followed WW1. He is thus, arguably, the man most responsible for the sanguinary course of the rest of the twentieth century. Wilson's messianic sense of himself is only beginning to show so far, though it is interesting to note that Berg's chapter titles ("Ascension," "Eden," "Sinai," "Disciples," "Gethsemane," and so on) as well as his decision to head each chapter with a Bible verse, seems suggestive of more than simple Scots Presbyterianism. Even if I'm not reading this as quickly as the invisible forces shaping the Vine program might prefer, this is been pretty rewarding so far and I'm looking forward to what comes next.

As a relatively recent convert to the virtues of safety razor, tub of shaving cream (Taylor of Old Bond Street Sandalwood Shaving Cream Bowl, 5.3-Ounce is my pick), and badger brush, I'd been looking for a small travel brush to carry with me on my infrequent trips. This little tool from Baxter of California is a fine choice. The way the brush screws onto the case to form the handle is clever, while the fact that the lid securing the brush inside the case has a hole on top to help drying and air flow may be downright ingenious. The first few uses reveal a certain badger-y scent to the bristles, and I've noticed one or two falling out into my tub of cream, but both of those are standard for any badger brush and not excessive in this case. And the smell of course diminishes with use. Be sure to dry the brush thoroughly after use and I expect to get a lot of use out of this. It's definitely going in the overnight bag or suitcase now.

"Triumph and Tragedy" may be something of a cliché in book-titling (at least it seems that way to me), but "My Promised Land" is one book where that descriptor is really deserved. Author Ari Shavit does an excellent, and moving, job describing how, as he sees it, the triumphant accomplishments of Zionism and early Israeli independence have been squandered by Israel's tragic turn to becoming an occupationist, imperial state. The "anyone who..." endorsement may be equally clichéd, but I believe anyone who is interested in Middle Eastern politics, Israel, or the Jewish people and their history could find much food for thought here.Shavit weaves a great many strands together in these pages, so it's hard to summarize all he discusses in his review of Zionist settlement in Palestine. His profiles of Jewish settlers, pioneers, entrepreneurs, and others who helped build the young nation create a complex but informative picture of what it means to be Israeli.At the same time they were tilling the soil, draining the wetlands, and building new lives in a new land, however, the settlers all too often overlooked or ignored the Palestinian inhabitants, Shavit argues. In fact, the line some Zionists used, "A people without a land for a land without a people," wasn't even remotely true. As the book progresses, Shavit introduces us to more and more of these Palestinians -- including Palestinian Israelis -- and the dimensions of tragedy underlying the triumph begin to take shape. In many ways, the centerpiece of the book for me was the chapter "Peace, 1993," describing the time that year when Shavit brought a 70-year-old Palestinian friend back to the site of Hulda, his ancestral village destroyed in the 1948 war. Before then, Shavit recounts, Jewish and Palestinian residents shared a respectful, if not intimate, coexistence. Then, during the war following the Israeli declaration of independence, the Jewish army shelled the village, driving out his friend's family and all the other residents. "It is precisely here," Shavit writes, "...that the Jews crossed the threshold between the commune's olive groves and Jamal Munheir's fields and entered the forbidden. For the first time in eighteen hundred years, Jewish soldiers employed a large, organized force to take another people's land.... Here, by the old well of Hulda, we moved from one phase of our history to another, from one sphere of morality to another" (p. 251).As I said, the scope of Shavit's work -- drawing on his decades as an active journalist -- is quite broad. Interviews range from Palestinian refugees like Jamal Munheir to leading Israeli writers, politicians, and scientists, including some of the ones who created Israel still-officially-nonexistent nuclear weapons. More than anything else I can recall reading, "My Promised Land" made clear the dueling forces in Israeli history and society -- the pioneer spirit contrasting with the contemporary desire for less work and more play, the contrasting dreams of Ashkenazi and Sephardic Jews coming to their promised land, the idealism and the realism, the desire to create a new world and the inability to escape history. Yes, triumph and tragedy.

Like other reviewers, I've been charmed by the idea of silicone baking products, which seem futuristic, practical, and in more ways than one flexible. But even apart from all the things you need to do to prep a silicone bakepan for first use, it seems like an awful lot of adjustments need to be made to make this particular petite loaf pan really useful. I'll note how many reviewers aren't even using this to make cakes or loaves of bread, but rather are making soap. For the more casual baker who doesn't want to deal with the ambiguities of working with individual "cavities" this small, I'd recommend using a more traditional pan instead.

We already had a similar in-car charger from another retailer in use in our car, but this Belkin unit beats it hands-down and immediately became something we got into the habit of using almost every time we get into the car. As other reviewers have mentioned, both plugs in this Belkin charger work to charge iPhones or iPads, whereas on our other unit, only one does. Also, the other unit came with a charging cord that's something like 12 feet long, which is a little ridiculous for in-car use. The much shorter Belkin cord seems much better suited for this use, long enough not to be constricting, but not so long as to become a nuisance. Because of where the charger is plugged in, I don't get to enjoy the cool blue light that much, but even that is helpful when I do need to unplug a cable or just reach into the storage area where the plug is located. Until USB ports replace cigarette lighters as standard equipment in cars, an item like this will be useful and even necessary. Belkin, not surprisingly, has got it right.

I set this air cleaner up in a badroom that's probably larger than intended for it (the description says "ideal for small rooms"), and in which the primary pollutant is a superabundance of pug fur. But even there, a quick check of the filter shows that this little machine has been cleaning the air and, thus, making breathing a little easier for person and pug alike. We don't smoke or have a problem with pollen in the house, so you can't always tell what difference something like this is making. But even when unclean air isn't a big issue, a handy filter system like this does seem to make a difference.

This isn't a comprehensive history of Texas baseball, or even of the Texas League. As the "greatest hits" phrase in the subtitle and mention of "episodic chapters" in the description might suggest, this is instead a collection of short, readable chapters about some of the milestone events and memorable characters in the history of the league. It makes for fun dipping-into for bedside reading or, maybe, during commercials or between innings. It gets a little bewildering trying to keep track of team names and league arrangements (the "Complete list of Texas League teams [1902-]" list on Wikipedia is impressively long, and this book goes back well before 1902), but as a print equivalent of just sitting around and telling baseball stories, this book definitely has something to offer the Texas baseball fan, or the fan of Texas baseball.

Two comparisons. probably pretentious, come to mind for how to describe "Class A: Baseball in the Middle of Everywhere." One is to Elgar's "Enigma Variations," the orchestral piece in which variations are developed on a theme "not played." In the case of "Class A," what's not played is baseball. Author Lucas Mann describes minor-league baseball as an institution in Clinton, Iowa, and charts its impact on players, fans, and the community, but there is almost no description of actual baseball games. Now, I don't have a problem with that per se: I think it's an interesting way for Mann to have framed his work, and also saved him the problem of trying to describe -- and us the tedium of having to read about -- a whole season of Class-A baseball. Still, anyone expecting this to be a book "about" baseball and baseball games is likely to be disappointed.The other comparison is to the work of George Plimpton, in that Lucas Mann makes himself very much part of the story he's telling. In this case, he isn't a ball player, though he has personal experience as a high school player and lifelong fan. Instead of reportorial objectivity and distance, Mann makes himself part of the Clinton fan community (especially the serious fans known as the "Baseball Family"), and -- though he never quite succeeds -- also tries to be buddies with the players, managers, and coaches. This leads to a lot more personal reflection, personal insights, and recounting of personal history than you're likely to find on, say, the sports page. It also made it difficult for me to get beyond about page 200 of the book.Clinton, dwarfed by the local ADM plant that evidently fills the air with pollutants, struck me as a depressing sort of place, the town a shadow of its former self. Minor-league baseball has some of that air about it too, with the arrogance and self-assurance of players on their way up contrasted with the desperation or resigned inevitability of those on their way down or, maybe worse, not on their way anywhere. Even the team name, "LumberKings," derives from a long-gone era in the town's history. The managers are once-promising players who years after their own brushes with stardom, as Mann memorably puts it, still wear pants with elastic waistbands to work every day. Even the play-by-play announcer dreams of getting out of town the way the better players get to. Baseball brings some life into the community, but also seems to add to the cloud of desperation. Its an interesting balance, and even though I never entirely connected with Lucas Mann or the people or place he was describing, I do admire his attempt at describing it.

I requested this item pretty much solely for one reason: to use as a wifi repeater here in my office, where my iPhone and iPad often lose their connection with the wireless router on the other side of the house. I can't comment on the other functions this device can perform, but I can note that as a repeater, it works pretty well. Setup was complicated a bit for the reasons other reviewers have explained, most notably a heavy use of IT jargon in the installation and troubleshooting documents. But once I navigated through that (and a minor security-settings issue that was my fault, not the device's), I did get a strong signal that my iPhone and iPad latched onto immediately.The problem then became that my laptop, which is also in the office and on the wifi network, began to generate "self-assigned IP address" errors and dropping its connection. None of the several solutions offered on the Internet fixed this for long. I will note that the TP-LINK's box says the product "is designed for use with tablets, smartphones and handheld game consoles," so maybe the laptop put too heavy a load on the device? I don't know about that. But I've since hit on the substitute idea of using this as a wifi repeater for when I'm in the backyard with one of my devices -- no laptop there. I plugged this into one of my house's exterior outlets and again, it worked great with my phone. I do not leave it plugged in outside all the time, obviously. Only when I'm outside myself and need it. But that's a use case where this fits the bill just fine. Maybe I'll bring this along next time I travel someplace and see how it works as a router.

As the product page here notes, Photoshop Elements has gone up to 11 now (har har), so this specific title may not be as useful as it was five years ago if you want to keep up with the latest iterations of the software. At the time, though, I found it useful to dip into from time to time to figure out how to do one thing or another. The problem was, as neither a photographer nor an artist, I didn't really have the motivation -- or the need -- to become a Photoshop ace, and so wasn't interested in putting in the time it would take to get the most out of this book. Instead of a basic tips-'n'-tricks list, the tutorials contained here really do allow you to get under the hood of the program and really start doing some interesting stuff. It wasn't what I needed, exactly, but I could certainly see powerusers-to-be getting a lot out of it, and that seems like enough of an endorsement to me.

It may be true, as Daniel Cappello notes in the introduction to this attractive and useful book, that "schools outside the Ivy League, including the so-called 'Ivy Plus' universities (such as Stanford, Duke, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the University of Chicago), actually provide a more rigorous scholastic experience than their Ivy counterparts." Nevertheless, the Ivy League, he argues, retains "an unquantifiable distinction factor that eludes empirical educational value and worth. ... To some extent, the old-school idea of the Ivy League continues to define it, and is one that Ivy Leaguers still cling to. It is also one that looms large in the popular imagination." It's this "old-school idea," the "unquantifiable distinction factor," that Cappello attempts to define for the Ivy League colleges. He paints what struck me, as admitted outsider who's paid but brief visits to only three of these campuses, as fine individual portraits of eight very different schools, yet also shows what they have in common -- what sets "what might be seen as one of the most successful and singularly American brands" apart from other schools.Cappello starts with the Big Three: Harvard ("the Ivy's Ivy"), Yale ("the classic Ivy"), and Princeton ("the preppy Ivy"). He then moves on to Brown ("the hip Ivy"), Dartmouth ("the rugged Ivy"), Columbia ("the urbane Ivy"), Penn ("the entrepreneurial Ivy"), and finally Cornell ("the Ivy for every man"). Each chapter is colorfully illustrated with an assortment of historic and contemporary images, including campus landscapes, portraits of alumni and current students, and classic athletic programs. His text not only describes each school's history, but also its current character and distinctiveness. Among the topics I found particularly interesting were his discussion of Brown as what someone else described as "the daycare center of the Democratic Party" and preferred school of Hollywood and Euro-elites; Columbia's close ties to neighboring Harlem; and the "discreet, almost philosophical nonchalance" of Yale and its students. Readers who, like me, are interested in the "Ivy League" style of dress, and have studied relevant books like Ivy Style: Radical Conformists, Take Ivy, or The Ivy Look: Classic American Clothing - An Illustrated Pocket Guide will be pleased to know that Cappello hasn't stinted in this area -- particularly in the chapters on Yale and Princeton.Again, though, I return to the beautiful photos. This could easily be described as an Ivy League photo album, and you could certainly browse it as such. But then you'd miss the very good writing that goes along with the colorful and well-chosen images, and that would be a shame.

In "Tipsy in Madras," Matt Walker and Marissa Walsh take the several pages about drinking sprinkled through The Official Preppy Handbook ("TOPH") and expand the idea to an entire 200-page book. The pastel design on the cover even recalls the red and blue madras pattern on the original. While this is clearly derivative of the original ... who cares? "Tipsy in Madras" is an entertaining, well done, and also quite practical look at the lost world of preppy imbibing.Like TOPH's famous "Preppy Value System" of consistency, nonchalance, charm, and the rest, Walker and Walsh propose some preppy-drinking guidelines, including availability (ie, did the drink exist in the '80s?), archaism (did it exist *before* the '80s?), efficiency ("the drink with the fewest ingredients is the preppiest"), and so on. As they describe various drinks, they helpfully include information on who drank it then, who's likely to be drinking it now, how to accessorize, and more. It's often these suggestions that are the funniest part of the book, but it's all pretty good. Whether you want to re-live those long-lost days at cottage, campus, or club during the Reagan administration in book form, or are looking to recreate them more energetically with a few carefully-selected bottles, finding a copy of this and adding it to your bookshelf isn't a bad idea at all.

When my wife and I left the New York City area for Texas early this year, I knew there would be things I'd miss and things I wouldn't. Pretty much at the top of my list of things I wish I was still in town for is the Ivy Style exhibit at the Museum at FIT. So I eagerly awaited what I hoped would be the next best thing, the publication of this book. Now I'm of mixed opinion. Parts of this book, like the curate's egg, are excellent. Other parts are quite good if not as obviously relevant to the topic. Then there's what felt like filler.Importantly, this book is not "about" the FIT exhibit: There are many beautiful photos from the exhibition, but not enough to make up for not having been there. "Ivy Style" the book is meant to accompany the exhibition, and cover the topic in near-academic style. There's some serious analysis going on here, a long, long, *long* way from The Official Preppy Handbook.The centerpiece of the book is a wonderful interview with Richard Press, grandson of the founder of J. Press and himself a former president of the business. His words more than anything else laid out the fundamentals and evolution of Ivy style. Bruce Boyer's excellent chapter on the intersection of jazz and Ivy in the 1950s is fascinating and important reading, while Masafumi Monden's look at "Ivy in Japan" highlights where the flame is perhaps burning most brightly today. Patricia Mears' historical overviews tie things together well.Other chapters were more problematic for me. Peter McNeil's "The Duke of Windsor and the Creation of the 'Soft Look'" was an interesting look at one of the great icons of classic men's style, but despite the author's efforts seemed only tangentially related to Ivy style. The next chapter, "Ivy Britannicus" by Christopher Breward, was similarly interesting but even less relevant. (To repeat, both chapters are worthwhile reading on their own; I question their inclusion here.) Bruce Boyer is an excellent author -- I admire not only the chapter mentioned above but also his book about my particular idol, Fred Astaire Style. Yet the chapter here consisting solely of excerpts from Boyer's Elegance: A Guide to Quality in Menswear, especially a very, very long section on tweed, felt like filler. And, apart from Mears on the birth of Ivy style, this collection of excerpts is indeed the longest chapter in the book. Throughout, one more pass by a copy editor would probably have helped: There are more than a few errant apostrophes, for instance, and an egregious description of Alan Flusser as a "menswear doyenne" (p. 165).There's one final problem with "Ivy Style," one that guaranteed I couldn't give the book more than four stars: As other reviewers have noted, the typography is bad, bad to the point of near-unreadability. A small, sans-serif typeface printed in medium grey on glossy stock pretty much ensures illegibility, and it sure did here. Captions and endnotes are tinier still. These layouts may have looked pretty to the designers at FIT and Yale University Press, but I hope the authors protested against the abuse their words were forced to endure. My eyes certainly protested at trying to read them.On the whole, though, there's a lot that's satisfying about "Ivy Style." Certainly, the book and exhibition is probably the first time (and maybe the last?) that this style of dress has been blessed by such substantial curatorial attention. For devotees of the style, this is essential reading despite its flaws (overlooking illegibility is a pretty big "despite"). Historians of fashion or socio-economic signifiers could get a lot out of it too. Like Ivy style itself, this book won't appeal to everyone. But those who see the virtues of the style will appreciate the virtues of the book, too.

I've been a Dallas Cowboys fan pretty much since childbirth. Landry, Staubach, and the late-'70s team roster were icons of my childhood. Even today, I remember the combination to my gym lock by recalling the Cowboys players who wore the relevant jersey numbers. Watching the great documentary "Full Color Football: The History of the American Football League" (sadly not yet available on DVD) a year or two ago, however, turned me into a partisan of the old AFL, and so, despite knowing the outcome of the drama, I found myself rooting for the success of Lamar Hunt and his Dallas Texans in the "ten-gallon war" to be Big D's marquee sports franchise. That's how entertaining and engrossing this fine book by John Eisenberg is.The mention of "Full Color Football" is not entirely coincidental. Eisenberg's earlier memoir, Cotton Bowl Days : Growing up with Dallas and the Cowboys in the 1960s, landed him a spot in front of the "Full Color Football" cameras discussing the Cowboys-Texans clash. It was that experience, he writes, that convinced him there was a book in that story.And what a book it turned out to be. Eisenberg relies on interviews he conducted for the earlier book as well as new research and interviews, and so while there are lots of football games recounted in these pages, there is also an insightful, and inside, look at what was every bit as much as business war as a sports one. Lamar Hunt and Cowboys owner Clint Murchison are the central figures in what must have been a peculiarly Texas-style feud. The two men had very different personalities and styles, yet each was a recognizable *type* of Texas millionaire of their era. The two men were able to drink whisky and eat steaks together (Hunt once famously leaped out of Murchison's birthday cake, which Murchison found hysterically funny) while each simultaneously plotted to bankrupt the other, or at least drive him out of their mutual hometown. For some time, it was by no means clear which team would ultimately claim the heart of Dallas fans: The Texans had by far the better record in the early years, but the Cowboys faced tougher on-field competition in the more established NFL. As I said, even knowing the outcome, it was a pretty absorbing story.This book could easily have been longer: The discussion of the AFL-NFL merger proposal seemed to come almost out of nowhere, and after that the rest of the story felt a little rushed. But Eisenberg's emphasis is on the years when the Texans and the Cowboys battled for the hearts and wallets of Dallas' football fans, each trying to establish pro football in a land where the college game was unquestionably king, while also trying to smother the other team in its cradle. On field and off, it's an entertaining read. I recommend it especially to my fellow Cowboys fans, but more broadly to Texans, football fans (and there's admittedly a pretty huge overlap there), and fans of a fine story well told.

"The Horseman at Midnight" could be described as a cowboy novel, as a modern Western, or a hymn to vanishing rural California. And it excels as all of those. But I see the book as primarily a novel of bloodlines, of lineage, and of how the relationships and influences that move back and forth across generations affect a man and color his life and choices. Author Jameson Parker's novel works on the most basic and essential level: it's a very good story. But it's that deeper level that makes this a book I'll remember for a long time.When elderly horse trainer Matt Sullivan describes a horse to Grady, he almost invariably does so by recounting the horse's bloodline. "A lot of people believe, and I guess I'm one of them, that when you breed a horse, the qualities you're going to get come from the grandsire. And granddam too. But it all skips a generation," Matt says. "Maybe it's the same with humans." Similarly, nearly all the characters in this book are shaped to some great extent by the influence of their father and grandfather. Matt and Grady are the most obvious examples, but we see it in ranchhand Mike and druglord Antonio too. Late in the novel, police officer Isaac Sullivan, Matt's son and Grady's father, meditates on families destroyed by drugs, kids who see their parents' lives of addiction, violence, and crime and follow in their footsteps, and wonders "When will it ever stop? Three or four generations down the line, like in the Bible?"Yet if we're shaped by our bloodlines, we're not slaves to them. When Mike refuses to take part in the drug-fueled debauch of a young girl, his decision saves his life. But later, he makes a different decision, and the consequences drive the second half of the novel.Book titles don't happen by accident, and I've been wondering what "the horseman at midnight" means. The obvious answer is that the horseman is Matt. But interestingly, the one instance of the word in the text -- thank you, Kindle search function -- describes, not Matt, but the great love of his life, Patty ("she was a hell of a horseman," Matt says). The one time action takes place at midnight, it's when Matt and Grady make the grisly discovery that ratchets up the tension for the rest of the book. Later, reflecting on his new relationship with his grandson, Matt wonders whether "his profound happiness in this moment had been preordained by a sequence of events that began when a slim young woman [Patty] rode a little dun filly into an arena in Fresno." In Parker's American Riff, all the major characters are men, but the story is set in motion by the long-ago actions of an influential woman. Here, too, almost all the characters (including a "boogery" yellow horse who plays a big part in the story) are male, but Matt wonders whether life is unfolding as it is because of what a woman did decades ago. Is the title horseman Patty?I'll stop the amateur lit-crit there and spare you my other theories (#2 involves Paul Revere). The key point is that while "The Horseman at Midnight" really is a great modern cowboy novel and all those other things, I was most affected by Parker's exploration, celebration, of how love and family entwine through generations, and how we're shaped by the lives of people we barely had a chance to know. As Matt continues to reflect in the moment of "profound happiness" quoted above, "there was, for once, only this moment of joy, as if some generational schism had been briefly breached and all, in both directions, father, grandfather, deceased great-grandfather and beyond one way, son, grandson, unborn great-grandson and beyond in the other, as if all were united in a small, sweaty boy in an old-fashioned Nevada-style Stetson..."

When I reviewed the Seagate Slim 500 GB USB 3.0 Portable Hard Drive STCD500100 a few weeks ago, I mentioned that I'd like to try the one terabyte model to use as a secondary backup for our iMac. Now that I have indeed tried this product, I need to say my initial suspicions were correct. Like the other, it's easy to use, functional, and entirely up to basic functions like routine backups.Unlike the other drive this one is not designed to work with Macs from the start -- it's formatted for Windows work. Maybe I should have read the specifications more closely? But it was the work of just a few minutes to reformat the drive for the Mac (there is a discussion of how to do this on the Seagate website, so clearly they don't mind), and after that it was easy to make this work with the Time Machine software on the Mac. I'll be storing this in a secure location away from the computer, and bringing it out once a month or so for regular backup work. It's not the most demanding work to put an external hard drive to, but it's important and this drive is admirably fitted to do it.

At the dedication of the Soldiers' National Cemetery at Gettysburg in 1863, keynote orator Edward Everett spoke for over two hours. Abraham Lincoln then spoke for barely two minutes. Later, Everett wrote to the president, "I should be glad if I could flatter myself that I came as near to the central idea of the occasion, in two hours, as you did in two minutes."Out of interest or necessity, I've read a lot of books about nonprofit fundraising. Books for writers and designers, books for nonprofit staffers and board members, books for volunteers or one-person shops -- but like Everett at Gettysburg, none of those books, some quite long, have come quite "as near to the central idea" of direct-marketing fundraising (some haven't come anywhere *close* to as near) as Jeff Brooks has in the brief but powerful "The Fundraiser's Guide to Irresistible Communications."Now, here is where I disclose that I know Jeff Brooks. In fact, we've worked together for some sixteen of the last 20 years, usually with him as creative director on projects where I was the writer. But this is a completely uncompensated endorsement. And what my vantage point lets me tell you is that the "real-world, field-tested strategies for raising more money" Jeff discloses here are the real thing, empirically verified by thousands of mail packages, e-mail appeals, radio specials, and other fundraising tools he has employed and mastered over the years.Most of those other books go into more detail, with appendices of sample letters, chapters on creating a marketing schedule or long-term donor maintenance. But none of them capture the *spirit* of effective fundraising, or convey that spirit quite as entertainingly, as Jeff does. So much of what makes good fundraising effective is counterintuitive. The good fundraiser has to set aside her preferences about what looks best, or sounds best, or is the "right" way to describe a problem or a program or a solution. Instead, she must be willing to inhabit the mind of the donor, and be able speak to that donor in a special, even unique, way. Many of those other authors resent that fact. Jeff celebrates it. There are lots of great lessons in these pages (as I said, I've been doing this for years but my copy of this book is still filled with underlining and notes -- just like a good appeal letter!). But the most important lesson may be that whether we're in-house or work for a partner agency, we as fundraisers have the privilege of helping donors build the world they want to live in. Embrace that lesson, and put it to work in the ways Jeff describes, and your communications will be irresistible too.

"The Last Jeffersonian" is a biography, but it's a biography with a purpose: This is author Ryan Walters' attempt "to point out what we in the conservative movement, as well as the nation as a whole, can learn from" Grover Cleveland, a president contemporary historians have consigned to the memory hole (p. xvii). Walters argues Cleveland should be honored not only as "the last Jeffersonian," or the last great president, but as "perhaps the greatest statesman in American history" (p. xix).Instead of telling Cleveland's story chronologically, Walters moves topic by topic, showing how Cleveland was a man of remarkable honesty, hewing faithfully to consistent Jeffersonian principles of sound money and noninterventionist, nonredistributionist government, an opponent of class warfare, but a consistent friend of the taxpayer. In 1887, for example, Congress appropriated funds for relief of drought-stricken Texas farmers -- an act that would hardly get a second glance today. Cleveland vetoed the bill, writing, "I can find no warrant for such an appropriation in the Constitution, and I do not believe that the power and duty of the general government ought to be extended to the relief of individual suffering, which is in no manner properly related to the public service or benefit." Rather than being burned in effigy, Cleveland was praised. Even the Houston Daily Post, in the heart of the afflicted state, called it "a very proper veto" of a "clearly unconstitutional" bill (p. 34). Following the veto, private charities stepped in and ultimately raised over $100,000 in private donations (in 1887!) to help the farmers, "more than ten times what Congress [had] sought to appropriate."On the international stage, Cleveland again stuck to a Jeffersonian line that seems sadly foreign (so to speak) today. In 1893, for instance, the American planters and other interests who dominated the economy of the Kingdom of Hawaii (whom Walters oddly calls "outlanders"), backed by the American minister resident and American Marines, overthrew Queen Lili`uokalani and established a provisional government. Benjamin Harrison, the equally-forgotten president sandwiched between Cleveland's two terms, rushed an annexation bill into the Senate, but couldn't get it passed before Cleveland's reelection. Cleveland withdrew the treaty, sent a fact-finding mission to Honolulu, and ultimately decided the coup was an improper exercise of American power. Though he originally argued "the only honorable course for our government to pursue" would be restoration of the monarchy, he eventually backed away from that and settled for recognizing the provisional government. When Hawaii was finally annexed a few years later, Cleveland wrote "As I look back upon the first steps in this miserable business, I am ashamed of the whole affair" (p. 114). Walters paints Cleveland as an opponent of imperialism and "nation-building" (he opposed early efforts to get the US involved in the Cuban revolution) but an advocate of the Monroe Doctrine and a believer in a strong national defense.Refreshing as Cleveland's focus on honest republican governance, noninterventionist foreign policy, and sound economics are (what modern politician -- save one -- would describe taxes as "extorted," as Mayor Cleveland did in 1882?), it's when Walters begins to apply Cleveland's example to today that I, as I imagine many of Jeffersonian persuasion might, had to part company. The author rightly chastises modern neocons for the warfare state, an aggressive foreign policy, and their devotion to "war as a means of national policy to destroy tyranny and forcefully impose democracy around the world" (p. 124). Yet he falls in line with them in portraying China as the Next Threat, even noting that "George W. Bush did very little to confront China" (p. 122). We cannot "allow a thuggish regime like Iran to possess nuclear missiles [or] send warships to our coastline" (p. 159), Walters writes, though it's apparently okay for us to send warships to China's coastline -- a policy that resulted in the April 2001 Hainan Island incident, which was in fact one of America's most serious confrontations with the PRC in decades. "Quod licet Iovi...," as William F. Buckley used to say.Where I really have to question Walters' interpretation of the Cleveland model, though, is in his discussion of how war should be waged once it becomes inevitable. "We must no longer allow silly and unwise Pentagon lawyers to determine how our men and women fight," he writes, "nor rely on the restrictions of international rules of conduct written by European bureaucrats," which I take to be a reference to the Geneva Conventions. "We must fight," he concludes, "as we did in the days of World War Two" (p. 161). FDR and Truman, he writes approvingly, "did what was necessary to win ... [and] concerned themselves first and foremost with the overwhelming destruction of an enemy, which generally precludes further aggression, as we saw with both Germany and Japan." It's hard to imagine that "the last Jeffersonian" would endorse the immolation by fire and radiation of hundreds of thousands of civilian noncombatants. But then, I also didn't expect to encounter the phrase with which Walters begins an earlier paragraph: "Dick Cheney, a man I greatly admire..." (p. 158).Walters looks to the Tea Party to return conservatism to a more Jeffersonian line, writing that "if [Cleveland] were alive today, he would certainly join the grassroots crusade of action against an overbearing federal government" (p. 162). It's always problematic to speculate how a historical figure would react to contemporary events (a lesson conservative admirers of Winston Churchill could also learn), but it is instructive to note how the Tea Party reacted when the opportunity arose this year to support the most Jeffersonian major-party presidential candidate in several lifetimes. They embraced Mitt Romney instead.Oh well. There will be plenty of time to re-read the historical sections of this book before 2016 rolls around.

I have a modestly-sized collection of what you could broadly call "New Age" music, and I generally put it on when I need to create an environment conducive to concentration and moving the cursor to the right. "What's Real" from Silentaria fits into that New Age category too. But when I put "What's Real" on, I found myself concentrating as I desired ... and then realized I was concentrating on the music, and not on the work I thought I would be doing. On the whole, I think that's a good thing, because it shows how complex, interesting, and even involving this music is.Although "What's Real" as a whole can be called New Age, there's actually a lot of genre-bending happening here, and that makes individual tracks harder to classify. Some are meditative -- I remember thinking during one such track, "At this point, Kitaro would have dropped in a soaring electric guitar solo; I'm glad Rixa White [the mind behind Silentaria], didn't." But then, another track (particularly "Deceived") will be full of those very electric guitars. Electronic, acoustic, sounds from nature, and even voices -- both natural and computer-generated -- weave together in a complex tapestry.The project's website says "Silentaria is inspired by the Wholeness and Emptiness philosophy." Unfortunately, Googling the Wholeness and Emptiness philosophy mostly returns pages saying "Silentaria is inspired by the Wholeness and Emptiness philosophy." I'm sure there are levels and angles at work here that aren't entirely coming through to me. It's certainly an intriguing concept album, and one that will repay more listenings, whether for setting an atmosphere or as something to really dig into.

I had never heard of "Gentry" before some of my favorite style bloggers began discussing this book a few months ago. But that's hardly surprising: Gentry ran for only 22 issues between 1951 and 1957. But what a run! Positioning itself as "A Guide for the Civilized Male," Gentry is far, far from your stereotypical 1950s men's magazine. This book serves best as a monument to the vision of the magazine's founder William C. Segal -- a man interesting enough that Ken Burns has turned his camera upon him (Seeing, Searching, Being: William Segal - Three Films By Ken Burns). But there's also a lot of just plain interesting reading here for the "civilized male" (and the women who love them?) in 2012 and beyond.In its early years, "Playboy" magazine (Playboy was born roughly in the middle of Gentry's run) was known for promoting Hef's vision of bachelor culture -- not just women, but art, jazz, and a stylish pad. But Playboy seems positively parochial compared to the range of interests of the Gentry man -- interests which, I hasten to add, do not include prurient photographs of women, at least not in this book. If the Playboy man was a swingin' young bachelor, the Gentry man could have been his wealthier, better educated, and probably married older brother, a man of more diverse tastes, more widely traveled, and more comfortable in his preferences with less need to impress others with his hipness.With sections devoted to "Style," "Home, Cars, and Travel," "Food and Drink," "Sports," "Art and Culture," and the still-valuable "What Every Man Should Know," this book covers a lot of ground. And it does so not only by reprinting words, but by recreating the original layout as those articles appeared in Gentry magazine. You come away from this book with a strong sense of what the magazine must have been like. For aficionados of classic men's style, a bygone approach to journalism, students of the era, or guys trying to get a handle on the era their fathers or grandfathers grew up in, "The Gentry Man" has a lot to offer.

Firstly let me say that the build quality on this camera is top notch. Now it is made to be an indoor camera, so do not expect it to be placed outside. It will not withstand the elements for sure just based on the seams in the plastic. It is however built very well for an indoor camera and comes with the mounting hardware to either flush or swivel mount it to the ceiling.It comes with everything you need to get started, whether you decide to install the software on a PC or if you decide to download the free Hootoo app for your phone (the route that I chose). The instructions are clear, concise and had me up and running in very little time.What can I complain about? Well, the only thing that really got to me was the length of the power cable. It is only about 3 feet long, which I know can be made longer via an extension cable, but I feel it should be at least 6-8ft long depending on where you mount it. As it stands I will either have to install an outlet on the ceiling or run some form of extension from the existing cable.I really love that this camera captures in several qualities, with sound and has the ability to use infrared to give you night vision. It really works! I would suggest this to anyone looking for an indoor solution to their monitoring needs, whether it be for baby monitoring or otherwise.

4:44 Mins I received this item to test and review, so made a short video talking about it.Upon opening the package for these headphones, I was greeted with a nice, hard-side canvas zipper case which held these headphones along with the accessory package included. The included accessories seem to be of decent quality, and I like the inclusion of the 3.5mm to 1/4 inch adapter. I am not totally sure what the stereo to L/R mono adapter is for, but it's included anyway!As far as the build quality on the headphones, you are looking at a mostly plastic build with "metal" looking accents. Mind you, the plastic construction looks nice but I have had other headphones in the past constructed like these that broke at the earpieces prematurely. I will not pass judgement on these yet, but will update here if I do see the same issue arise. The headband is well padded, and these really feel comfortable being worn for long periods.These are designed to offer the user an immersive listening experience while also giving them the capability to have active noise canceling when they need it. As far as sound quality goes, these are on par with most BT headphones. I used the ultimate headphone test to check the specs, and was able to get a 20hz to 18khz frequency response range, and the treble side did break up a little as it got up into the 17 to 18khz range. The overall sound was not bad though, and music/talking came through boomy, being heavy on the bass.The active noise canceling feature is switchable, which I thought was cool because it means you don't have to use it if you don't need to. This function worked as expected and I am not sure what else to say about it honestly.Using these as wired headphones works quite well too, and offers the user an option if the batteries are running low. Speaking of battery, I used these for several hours straight out of the box without getting a warning, so I am thinking that the claimed life on these is not too far off. I will make sure to respond on here if that turns out not to be the case.Overall I would say if you are in the market for a decent set of noise canceling headphones, and want the bonus of having BT connection then these are not a bad choice.

6:09 Mins I received this item to test and review, so made a short video talking about it.Upon opening the box on these, I was immediately impressed with how nice these headphones looked. The metal padded headband, metal accents, super padded ear muffs and the really nice ribbon cable were all nestled nicely in a really sturdy zipper case. Once I removed them from the packaging I noticed how positively the earpieces stayed in place, allowing for 90 degrees of movement but holding firm wherever I placed them. The adjustable headband also has very resistive, independent motion to extend these headphones out for large heads like mine. The adjustments are even delineated to give you an idea of how far you have adjusted them.The included 3.5mm ribbon cable is tipped with metal plugs on both sides, and a small 3 button remote on one side. These buttons work perfectly on my Macbook Pro and iPhone 6s Plus to control volume, ffwd/rwd, play/pause and phone answer/release.Now let's talk a little about sound quality. I use the Ultimate headphone test website to see how headphones perform, and ran these though the same gauntlet to gauge how they sounded. The company claims a 20hz to 20khz frequency response range and I was easily able to achieve that using the test site. The spectral flatness was good, with a little more tendency towards the bass frequencies. All frequencies were clear to my ears and the drivers seemed pretty well matched up. The Bass Shaker test did not phase these driver either. The only oddity I got with them was during the center vs twisted test where the sound used for the test caused a little bit of a rattle sound in the headphones. In real use (hours of listening to music of all types) I did not experience this rattle, but I thought I would mention it anyway.Overall I would say if you are looking for a good set of cans that are affordable, you can't touch anything in the price range that is better!

3:16 Mins I received this item to test and review, so made a short video talking about it.Think of this as a way to charge many of your USB items in one place. That is enough for me to love this item.The idea is that it will detect the item attached to it and output the proper amperage to charge it at an optimal speed. Now, keep in mind that the unit is limited to 10A per the manufacturer's specs, so if you have several high powered items attached the charging will slow down.The build quality is nice with the outside being mostly soft-touch plastic and the ports mating tightly with all USB cables I plugged into it.Overall I would say if you are looking for a way to intelligently charge up to 6 USB items at once then look no further!

2:52 Mins I received these to test and review, so made a short video talking about them.I have been wearing a metal wedding band for 11 years now, and I have not had much issue with it (mainly because I work behind a desk). While these do not look like metal bands, they have a nice look and will serve the intended purpose well. There are no obvious seams on these bands and the grey one almost blends in enough to not get questions in an office atmosphere (I got questioned quite a bit with the black one).They fit true to size for me (I am a 10 and the 10s work fine), but YMMV.Overall I would say if you are looking for a safe way to wear a wedding band this is a great choice.

2:20 Mins I received this item to test and review, so made a short video talking about it.This is without a doubt the most comfortable wedding band I have ever worn. This should be obvious because it's such a soft material compared to METAL, but I wanted to state it anyway. 7:07 Mins I received this item to test and review, so made a short video talking about it.This is yet another entry into the tempered glass screen protector market, and I feel that its quality is right on par with many of the other out there. So, I just received this today, and it is a wonderful tempered glass screen protector...However, the one thing that I was most excited about with this protector was the addition of the invisible circuits allowing touches at the top to be registered by touching the bottom of the phone.Well, that function works, but not exactly as I had thought it would. One of the most important things to be was being able to return to a previous app when moving to another one. That touch is usually done at the top left of the screen, and I thought that the protector would register there but it does not. It registers just below that, and for instance in the browser opens up the address bar and pops the keyboard up. Now that is convenient but not what I expected. I guess I was confused by the description, so I just wanted to make sure I posted here my finding in case anyone else was in the market. Honestly, for the price it's a great standalone glass protector. The hidden circuitry just adds a nice bit of convenience for a large phone.

3:47 Mins I received this item to test and review, so made a short video talking about it.These earbuds are another in a long list of available options when looking for Bluetooth headsets. The inline remote provides you with control over your phone's music player and also allows you to answer phone calls on the go. The cable is a bit lengthy, but has an adjustable piece on it that allows you to shorten it if needed.As far as sound quality, they sound really good for the money and using the Ultimate Headphone test, the 20-20Khz rating proved to be true as well.Overall I would say that if you are looking for a sporty Bluetooth headset and you like the color scheme, then you have nothing to lose with these.

3:56 Mins I received this item to test and review, so made a short video talking about it.In a market filled with choices, it is often hard to differentiate Bluetooth headsets among manufacturers. This headset seems to buck the trend a little and provide the user with a unique way to interface with it.Instead of having the controls mounted on the earpiece or inline, this unit goes for a "necklace" style approach that puts the controls on an "amulet" on your chest. Basically there is a magnetic closure point that sits on the back of your neck, allowing the cables from your ears to fall behind your head, and then another set of cables coming from that magnetic area come around the front to form the necklace.I have to say that I was impressed with implementation of this design, and think that this company has created quite a unique product here. The earbuds themselves are very comfortable and provide a good balanced sound. The magnetic closure works very well and in the time I was testing never opened without me wanting it to.The micro USB charging port is located on one side of the magnetic portion and the other side is the battery. There are 3 buttons on the amulet that allow for volume/track changes and play/pause/phone answer and release functions.

They are suspended directly above the driver on a touch sensitive panel. Just underneath those buttons is a dark color cone that protrudes downward towards the driver which lights up like a slow heart beat while the speaker is turned on. The "pulsing" signal speeds up when an incoming call occurs.Speaking of calls, the sound quality on call is great, I am heard well and I can hear callers just fine. The range is like any other speaker, around 30 feet and the output on this thing is LOUD.Overall I would say that if you are in the market for a nice looking and sounding BT speaker then look no further!!

They limit the output to 85 decibels when using the BT connection, meaning that your kid's ear should not get damaged while listening with these headphones. The looks are really nice, and I could easily see kids at just about any age up to mid teenage years using them. They will even fit my fat head, although the muffs are too small for my huge ears...The battery claims to get you 10 hours of use, which is right around average for BT headphones, but one cool thing is that if the battery runs out you can use the included 3.5mm aux cable to pump sound through without using battery power. The mic picks up my voice well and I can hear the caller on the other end very well. 3:56 Mins I received this item to test and review, so made a short video talking about it.In a market filled with choices, it is often hard to differentiate Bluetooth headsets among manufacturers. 6:49 Mins I received this item to test and review, so made a short video talking about it.I have not had a ton of experience with RC boats, so I cannot speak from a position of authority. Please see the video for proof of that. The included stand is really cool for keeping the boat on a shelf when not in use, and it actually looks really cool sitting up there! The included nose cones are really nice if you happen to have rocks or logs that the boat may run into.One really neat feature about this boat is that it will not work unless it's in the water. There is some sort of way that the system senses water pressure in the cooling system which makes it power on. The trim controls on the remote are super helpful if you want to get more throttle sensitivity or correct the steering on the boat.Overall I would say that this is a really cool little boat that will give you lots of fun on the water!!

3:40 Mins I received this item to test and review, so made a short video talking about it.This pair of BT earphones are one of the better looking sets that I have reviewed....and I have reviewed quite a few! The body is made from some form of aluminum alloy and the ends are a really nice, brushed silver color. Also included are a Micro USB cable for charging and a nice mesh bag to store everything in. I took them straight out of the box and put a few hours on them without charging and they are still good to go. 5:12 Mins I received this item to test and review, so made a short video talking about it.Firstly, I wanted to say that I am not a big fan of bulky cases, so I went into this review a bit biased against this offering. That said, I believe that this is the nicest, best looking version of a waterproof case that I have reviewed yet.The body is very slim considering the protection that it offers and installation could not be easier. I did the water test with the case containing a piece of paper only to make sure there were no leaks and then put it on the phone to "wear" it for a few days. Again, I am not a big fan of bulky cases, but this one is certainly slimmer than many other waterproof cases.The design of the front is nice as well since the plastic continues further onto the front than some others. The buttons are still very easily actuated and the unique twist-style button for the mute switch is really cool. The door on the bottom which covers the lightning port is tight, but still fairly easy to open when needed and all cables I tried fit into the port just fine. There is a screw on gasket covering the headphone jack, and an extension which screws on at that point to allow waterproof usage of earphones.The worst part about this case in my opinion is the front screen cover. Most all waterproof cases use it, and I just don't like the feel. There can also be a rainbow-esque oil slick appearance under the protector where it touches the screen. However, this is true of all waterproof cases I have ever tested, on up to the most expensive.Overall I would say if you want a really sleek looking, but protective waterproof case then look no further!

4:37 Mins I received this supplement to test and review, so made a short video talking about it.First I want to say immediately that this is no miracle pill. It is advertised like it's the popular drug from the film "Limitless" but it is certainly not that....at least not when I took it.What I can say is that I did get a boost with respect to focus, drive and mental state while using this supplement. I quickly ramped up to using 3 at once as I generally have a high tolerance to things, but would suggest that anyone taking these follow the instructions to ensure you are using the proper amount for you.At the end of the day this is a non FDA approved dietary supplement, so make sure you know what you are putting in your body (the ingredients are here on the page) and give them a shot if you are looking for a boost in the brain department.

6:20 Mins I received this item to test and review, so made a short video talking about it.Let me preface everything I am about to say with the fact the I am a total new when it comes to drones. I have always thought that they were cool, but never ventured into learning about them much. When GPTOYS wanted me to test and review one, I just had to check it out.Well, I was not at all disappointed with the flying capabilities of this little guy. I guess I should say "little" as it measures almost 16" across at its largest point (with the blade guards installed). The entire body is made from a really thin, lightweight plastic and the 4 motors are also quite light. There are cool LED lights on the underside and on that neat looking red directional indicator on the top.Included in the package was the remote (Which looks super high tech, lol), two batteries (supposed to give you 8-15 minutes each per charge), a USB charging cable (had to use tape to keep the end together), 4 extra props, a 4GB micro SD card (for the built in camera), a USB card reader, and a screwdriver for working on this thing.I did not use the remote full capabilities whatsoever. I literally took this thing out and started trying to fly it. It was rough going at first, but after a few minutes I started to catch on and could get the drone going pretty much where I wanted it to.As far as the camera is concerned, the quality of the video could be alright as long as you are flying straight an not panning to fast. I found that it was quite jerky while I flew it, but that could have been more about my flying skills than the camera itself.Overall I would say that this is a great way to get into drones without dropping a lot of dough. The company has parts listed in the manual so it appears that you can get replacements as you need them so I see no reason to give this one a shot if you are in the market.

2:45 Mins I received this item to test and review, so made a short video talking about it.Firstly, I have to say that I am drawn to thin, minimal cases. I really like the style of the iPhone, and don't want to put a case on it, but am realistic to the fact that I am not the most careful person and have dropped my phones many times. There are thinner cases out there, but this one is a great balance between protective and slim. The soft touch plastic back is complemented with patterned sides that offer an immense amount of grip. The buttons are not raised on this case, and are smooth to be differentiated from the patterned areas. There is a good cutout for the mute button and it is easily reachable. The camera cutout is precise and looks quality against the phone.The logo is not overdone in my opinion is striking against the black color.The only negative I have on this case is the top part (when looking down at the screen) is made from a glossy style TPU. I wish they had carried the soft touch plastic all the way around the case as I feel it looks more quality than that glossy stuff. However, this is just a personal opinion and I can still say that this is one of the best compromises I have found yet for a slim case that actually does some protecting!

3:53 Mins I received this item to test and review, so made a short video talking about it.I was a bit skeptical on this case as I usually do not like multiple pieces being attached to the phone. When I was given the opportunity to test this case out, I was intrigued.Let me say that I am impressed with how precisely the cutouts are done and just how form fitting this slim plastic case is. The fact that it covers the entire rectangular area on the front of the phone is really cool and makes the transition from the case to the screen less "bumpy".Overall I would say that if you are looking for a case that will provide a little protection and keep the phone looking pretty darn sleek then check this one out!

2:57 Mins I received this unit to test and review, so made a short video talking about it.There are a ton of different bluetooth headsets on the market right now, so choosing can be difficult. 1:37 Mins I received this item to test and review, so made a short video talking about it.This is a very convenient cable! That's the biggest draw for it in my mind as you can use it to charge, pass data and add USB items via OTG (if your mobile device supports it). The ribbon cable is sturdy and very rubbery feeling, and the ring for hanging on your bag is equally rubbery feeling. While the full sized USB port is not in use it can store the other end of the cable to keep it more compact and easily carried. The plugs all fit tightly into the devices I tried (Nexus 7, Samsung Galaxy Tab 8, Galaxy S6 Active and Kindle Fire) and all worked as they should. I was able to read flash drives to the devices that had OTG capabilities as well.Overall I would say if you need an OTG adapter why not get this instead so you have the versatility of a charging and data cable if you need it!

4:26 Mins I received this item to test and review, so made a short video talking about it.When I received this camera in the mail, I was just amazed at the build quality. The all metal body, heavy duty mounting plate and arm and the very well made camera module were all very impressive. Speaking of wifi, this unit comes with an extended range Wifi antenna to give you enough boost to catch your home network with ease.Also, you can access this camera via your mobile device on Hootoo's camera app. This app will let you check the footage from the camera and also pan/tilt/zoom the camera to see what's going on all around.I could easily see this being used for business purposes or for the very security conscious home owner.Overall I would say that this is a very nice IP Surveillance camera that you should look into if you want something tough!

Gok (Masako Nozawa) and Vegeta (Ryô Horikawa) must protect Earth from the resurrected Frieza and his army of soldiers.

When John Connor (Jason Clarke), leader of the human resistance against Skynet, sends Kyle Reese (Jai Courtney) back to 1984 to protect his mother, Sarah (Emilia Clarke), from a Terminator assassin, an unexpected turn of events creates an altered timeline. Instead of a scared waitress, Sarah is a skilled fighter and has a Terminator guardian (Arnold Schwarzenegger) by her side. Faced with unlikely allies and dangerous new enemies, Reese sets out on an unexpected new mission: reset the future.

Riley (Kaitlyn Dias) is a happy, hockey-loving 11-year-old Midwestern girl, but her world turns upside-down when she and her parents move to San Francisco. Riley's emotions -- led by Joy (Amy Poehler) -- try to guide her through this difficult, life-changing event. However, the stress of the move brings Sadness (Phyllis Smith) to the forefront. When Joy and Sadness are inadvertently swept into the far reaches of Riley's mind, the only emotions left in Headquarters are Anger, Fear and Disgust.

Alien Isolation could have, and should have, been a better game than it is. Like most others I loved it... for the first ten hours. But unlike most others (only fifteen percent of those who start it ever finish AI) I played it through to the end. Twice! The good things about AI are that you'll have to think to survive its challenges.  It's definitely intense and immersive. And whoever did the artwork hit a home run.  There are moments of beauty in AI.  But along the way I learned a few things....1. There are bugs in the program!  LOTS of bugs. I played AI using the Xbox 360 so I can't speak for the other systems but this thing has bugs galore.  I'm trying to figure out if the programmers didn't have time to fix AI's many bugs -  or were just incompetent.A. In Mission 14, "The Descent" the ladder in the Apollo Core refused to raise into position and allow Ripley to climb down into the reactor - even after reloading from the previous save point. I had to play the entire mission over from the start. This is a very difficult mission too and it took way over an hour to replay it.B. In my second go at AI the flashlight quit during Mission 12, "Synthetic Solution" and never worked again. This became a problem later on.C. Also in my second go, while climbing out of a floor duct Ripley was jumped by the Alien, who hadn't registered on the motion tracker (more on this later). I pulled her back into the duct as fast as I could, but the Alien made the "prepare to die!" screech... then the slaughtered pig squeal - and Ripley didn't die. ???Strange....However, the floor panel I needed Ripley to exit was now DOA. I crawled her around through the duct work to the opposite side of the room and was able to exit a floor panel there - and discovered the Alien had left the building. Where shortly before it'd been a killing field I was now able to walk her around with complete impunity! The sound fx channel died too - though the music soundtrack was still playing. However, when I saved at the next save station things returned to normal again.Strange....D. When you killed one of the human antagonists, if they had a revolver it would be left floating in mid-air over their dead body.E. In Mission 10, "The Trap" there were large machines in a room, that only partly loaded. They just sat there... winking spectrally whilst Ripley sneaked around trying to evade the Alien, which is hot on her heels in this mission.F. If you think Ripley's carrying a specific weapon, e.g. the flame thrower, you might want to think again: because when the Alien comes screeching towards her you may find the revolver popping up in her hands instead of the flame thrower. This will  happen whenever she acquires a new weapon; the weapon you thought she had gets pushed down the weapons queue and the new acquisition takes its place. But the controller is so touchy it often will select the item next to the one you thought you were selecting. Whatever the reason, you have to check her "weapon of the moment" frequently to avoid an ugly surprise.G. In Mission 18, "Tomorrow, Together" during my second play through, Ripley's arms caught on fire and she ran around this way for 6-8 minutes. While it was pretty funny it interfered with game play because I couldn't see well through the flames whenever her arms were raised.Unfortunately, it's just a buggy game. If you look into the various glitches reported by AI players you'll see and hear some pretty weird stuff.Along with the bugs in AI, YOU... GET... ROBBED!Some of the reviewers here have mentioned that aggravation - and they're right. For example, the motion tracker will suddenly not alert you to the Alien that's lurking directly ahead. Oops! Time to re-play the last ten minutes....  Proponents say it only registers motion, therefore the Alien must not have been moving. Well, the Alien was far behind Ripley a few seconds ago - now all of a sudden it's howling down the hall towards her.  And Ripley gets eaten again. And again... and again... and again....... Oh well, what's another hour or two of life wasted?In my opinion the way the Creative Assembly team scalds its customers by arbitrarily changing their game's rules is the worst thing about AI. Worse even than the bugs. Sometimes the tracker works... sometimes it doesn't. The Alien that was behind Ripley a few seconds ago is now ahead of her - or is it still behind her... or above her... because the motion tracker has gone MIA.Should you send Ripley into a duct to hide and the Alien comes in after her you might as well throw a Twinkie at it as use the flame thrower. And there are times when just a short blast from the flame thrower sends the Alien scurrying; yet at other times you can unload on it for three or four seconds and it still kills her.The game sticks it to you like that. The Alien pounces with no warning. And let's say you learn to retreat down a hall pointing the flamethrower backwards, because the Alien attacked Ripley from behind the last three tries; it'll then attack from the opposite direction... or drop down from an overhead duct. And there's only minimal auto-save in AI, so when Ripley dies, and she dies a lot, you have to replay from your last save point - which may take half an hour if you're new to the game.One point about the save stations: stop and check the floor map often - both to see where Ripley is and where various objects of interest lie. The most important objects of interest are the save stations - which look like phone booths of old. If you miss one, or God forbid, more than one, it means that when Ripley is killed you'll have to replay everything from your last save point.  Depending on how many save stations were missed it could easily add another hour to your replay time.  Save as often as you can.  If you save on entering a room remember to save when leaving the room - or AI will make you pay for that oversight.Lest I forget - when you do have to replay a section after Ripley is killed, or when the game moves from one mission to another, the reload can take over a minute.Then there are the slow moving Working Joes... who become world class sprinters when closing the last few feet. Similarly, the Alien closes whatever the distance in milliseconds. When you're trying to hoist the flame thrower into position to blast it, Ripley goes into slow motion. You'll do better holstering it, turning to face the alien, then unholstering it to try to get a blast in before it kills her.  I swore a lot playing AI.  Probably more than I did my time in the Navy. I woke my wife up one night swearing at it - and she was fifty feet and two closed doors away.And be forewarned about unreliable game guides. None of them by themselves are much help. What I learned to do was use three guides: the VGFAQ walk through, available on Youtube; the floor maps at Steamcommunity.com; and the Primagames walk through. All of them at once.  But even then there are places where you get disastrously bad info.  I had to stop play several times and figure out what went wrong.Once you become familiar with the game you'll do best just following the path cursor. The path cursor is a bar at the top of the motion tracker screen. It moves around, pointing out the direction you need to send Ripley. But it doesn't always work and will often ignore rooms full of stuff Ripley needs to build up her inventory. And it sometimes leads straight into an ambush.I have to marvel at all the good reviews given to AI. I can only assume most of them are by people who haven't played it through to the bitter end; or even more than the first few hours. I played it through twice - forty to fifty hours total - and liked it less the more I played it. I started out thinking, "What an awesome game!" But after completing it the first time, reckoned it just three stars. After my second play through, (and that was on "easy") I decided that because of the Hollywood chicanery, programming bugs, weak script and the lame grand finale, (with comically indestructible and homicidal Aliens swimming through outer space, still trying to kill Ripley) that when all's said and done, it's a two star game.I really wanted to like AI. I even played it through twice hoping this would resolve some of the aggravations I experienced the first time. Unfortunately, it wasn't to be. For me at least AI was a long, grueling, frustrating slog - with no payoff that justified the pain.  When it was over I felt like someone who'd run a marathon only to find out their paperwork got lost.

Well made and robust (fake) two-stage suppressor.  It weighs two and a half pounds - which will take your MAC-10 to over ten pounds with a full clip.  But it looks very cool on the MAC and arrived within a few days.

We've had ours for five years now and it's always started and got the job done.  But I do yearly spring maintenance on it and discovered it has some design flaws.1. The mounting bar for the shaft pulley guard is situated directly over the crank case oil bolt.  It was a chore to change the oil because of that stupid oversight. I fixed the problem myself but it should have been noticed and addressed before it got out of design.2. The bigger problem.  The gas tank is plastic - molded in two halves.  During the third year the two halves separated somewhat - with a crack of about 1/8 inch finally developing at one end of the seam.  It spilled a lot of gas and you couldn't fill the tank all the way up because it'd leak out a cup or more of gas onto the bed. Even at half full or so it still leaked quite a bit at first. If I hurried I could just barely finish my lawn before it died.  Eventually I sunk eight small wood screws through the lips of the upper and lower halves - which pulled the seam back together.  That eliminated most of the leakage problem but I still can't top it off.3. There are sharp edges here and there which you have to be aware of or they'll nick you. You shouldn't have to be warned about stuff like this.Other than these problems it faithfully starts, runs, mulches and mows like you'd expect.  But considering our Toro's problems and looking at all the negs here I don't think we'll be buying another one.

I think it's safe to say Nick Drake was a musician of genius.  Five Leaves Left came out when he was only 21 years old. An amazing effort for someone so young. FLL is an album that appeals on different levels: lyrics, voice, guitar work. Unfortunately Drake never had a producer worthy of his gifts and some of the songs on FLL sound as if they were recorded in someone's apartment.Lyrics. Drake's lyrics are refreshingly literate, mature and unpretentious for a 21 year old man of that time (1969). His meanings are often obscure, but he comes up with good lines and you are given things to think about. He references nature a lot, in a traditional hippie way, but even here he's restrained and matter of fact. A shadowing melancholy is apparent in FLL.  By the time of Pink Moon it had become very apparent.Voice. Drake has/had an elegant, soft, velvety and recognizable voice. He even sounds English. Posh English as a matter of fact - which he was, his family being of the posh class. His range is very limited however, probably not much more than an octave; and you won't hear any dramatics from him. I suspect this was one of the reasons his albums had such limited appeal while he was alive. But his voice was a nice though understated complement to his guitar playing.Guitar. Simply put, he was beyond good on the guitar. His songs revolve around that fact - and he knew it. His voice had its limits, his lyrics were thoughtful but in an understated English way.  His guitar was the star. Particularly his use of unusual modalities and chord progressions.  This isn't immediately apparent but a few bars into River Man and you find yourself saying, "Oh, that was well done!" That was his main genius: to find a guitar line off the beaten path and explore it well. His words and voice were like leaves floating on the bubbling stream of notes pouring out of his guitar.  He was technically gifted too.  Drake's playing is clear, clean and rhythmic. Finally, he could sing while playing his complicated guitar lines. No small feat there.As I mentioned earlier his producer (and back up musicians) for the most part did him no great favors. If you listen to Drake playing alone he sounds better than with all the strings, saxes and flutes thrown into the mixer. He would have benefited greatly having a producer who knew how to make his music rattle the china now and then. Had FLL been a Nick Drake solo effort I'd give it five stars. But the uninspired producing and accompaniment drag it down.Given that he was such an accomplished singer/songwriter at only 21 you just have to wonder what Drake might have achieved had he not fallen into the mire of depression that put an early end to his song.

As of this writing, our  Oster electric kettle has worked and looked great.  The kettle boils quickly and the beautiful blue light adds a nice zen to to our daily coffee.When working night shifts, I like to turn off the kitchen light and watch the water come to a blue boil in the dark - as my soul resigns itself to what lies ahead.However I foresee some issues that'll probably develop down the road... or one's existential path in this case:1. The beautiful blue light will probably have a brief journey.2. The on/off thumb switch appears frail and needs to be treated contemplatively.3. The plastic lid/switch assembly will deteriorate over time - then disintegrate back into the void from whence it came - fulfilling the destiny of all complex systems.But that day has not come yet and for now my wife and I are as serene as two peas in a pod.
This fife has a  sweet, warm tone.  I bought the Smart fife at about the same time and found this one the better of the two.  It's almost $6.00 cheaper as well.

Not too bad.  It has a nice woody tone  - but very airy.  I recommend the Yamaha fife.  It's cheaper, sounds better and you won't have to draw a breath every few seconds.Some here said the finger holes are too close. It's a fife, not a flute; the holes are no closer than on any other fife.

While mine didn't go flat like some of the folks here have reported, it did require constant re-adjusting to keep it positioned properly under me. This caused the fabric to shift to where the zipper was on the bottom instead of the back.After three hours on it last week I went running and my butt and thighs hurt so badly I had to head home within a minute. The next morning I awoke with a loud, sharp pain in my butt. It was only a spasm and passed after I rubbed it a few minutes, but that was the last straw.I'm trying out layers of bubble wrap now.

I'm sure these would be considered "premier" quality sheets in China, but in America they're only "adequate".Here are the issues I uncovered with this set: 1. The piping you see in the accompanying photo is only on the pillow cases.  The top sheet just has a plain old stitched seam.  Not a deal killer, but kind of deceptive. 2. The pillow cases are short.  They should be about four inches longer to cover the pillow ends.  Plus there's some kind of inner flap in them.  If the flap were bigger it might cover up the pillow ends; but it's too small to do the job there.  As things stand, all the flap does is demand to be tucked under when the pillow is put in the case.3. Although the sheets are advertised as "1800", this too is a deceptive sales gimmick.
