They might be 600 count at most.  4. Furthermore, there were noticeable production run oil stains on the set I got.  These were fairly small and washed out after a couple of washings but were another reminder that quality control isn't really on the list in China these days.However, they are a nice color (brighter than the "Calla Green" in the photo), fit pretty well and are soft and comfortable.  The price wasn't bad either.If they hold up for more than 100 washings they'll have been worth it.

The Schecter Stiletto is just a beautiful bass - both to look at and to hold.  It feels smooth and satiny in a way that makes you want to run your hands over it.  The satin gold hardware is very fetching too.  It has a high dollar look for a mid range priced bass.  Imho, whoever designed it hit a home run.And at 7.7 lbs. it's the lightest of all the basses I've owned.  The difference is something you appreciate immediately.Mine arrived ready to go, with the action set low with no buzz.  The round wound strings that came with it were fine, but I like flats and bought some GHS strings to put on it.  These were the second set of GHS strings I've put on an instrument and I have to say I'm very impressed with them. In both cases the action seemed to be lower than before.  It plays easily - like one of those fabled basses at Ebay that supposedly play themselves. The frets were all cut properly with no ends sticking out.  The neck is small and thin; about like an Ibanez.  And being satin finished too, like the rest of the bass, is very fast.  I have medium sized, squarish hands and for me it's a blast to play.I'm happy with my Stiletto's sound too.  It has a smooth, melodious tone that goes from a deep, sonorous bass to high, bright treble with no hiccups anywhere that I can find. I'm really impressed with how much treble you can squeeze out of it.  The pots are smooth and silent too. Everything about this bass is smooth and attractive in my opinion.  If I had to find fault with it the only thing I could come up with is that it's too pretty to take on the road.If I were allowed to keep only a couple of my basses, the Stiletto would be one of them.Update, September, 2015: I like the Stiletto even more than I did at first. There have been no problems at all with it. I'm playing it more than any of my other basses now.

Not long ago you could find great stuff made in China.  I've got lots of nice things around here that were made in China.  Unfortunately, those happy days are fewer and further between.  There's been a change over the past couple of years: nowadays you're taking a gamble when you buy something made there.  This fireplace tool set has been a rude reminder of that fact.  If I'd known beforehand it was made in China, I wouldn't have bought it; or at least paid so much for it.The set looks very nice when viewed in the photo here, but it's been a disappointment. To start, the broom is disaster.  It won't stand up to the rigors of even one fireplace sweeping without falling apart.  The bristles fall out of the head just from waving it. They break easily too.  And there's some sort of tiny, stem-like plant matter that falls out, leaving a copious mess that must be vacuumed up.The tool stand isn't straight either.  As it stands on the hearth, mine leans about 5/8's of an inch out of plumb.  I'm going to have to work on it to make it stand up straight.  Call me old fashioned but I don't think you should have to work on things you buy new.The handles too are welded to the shafts in an indifferent manner and there are some angles at joints where things should be straight - but aren't.  More work....When seen from ten feet away it looks good enough; but if you're someone who likes to use your fireplace I recommend you pass on this set.
Nice, crisp sound.  But let me add a caveat: you'll have to mount this on a separate stand.  It'll jingle every time a drum, cymbal, etc. is struck if you don't.

After Life is a fast and easy read that contains much helpful and comforting information.  However, author Michael Brown is clearly a devotee of Medjugorje and his reasoning is suspect at times as a consequence. There are many passages wherein he cites Medjugorje.The Medjugorje apparitions are a series of supposed apparitions that began taking place in the former Yugoslavia some thirty years ago.  Many odd claims have issued forth from the mouths of the so-called seers.  Some of them much at variance with Catholic doctrine.  As just one example, Brown claims on pg. 11: "Heaven is an incomparable joy, and one day most of us will reside in it."This is pure Medjugorje.  But Jesus, numerous popes and countless saints and doctors of the Church have said the exact opposite: few will make it.  As just one good example I could use: "Indeed a multitude shall be saved; but compared to the multitude that is damned they will seem to be only a few." - St. John Vianney.I could go on a long time with similar quotes from other saints, popes and doctors.Still, for the most part the book is good and towards the end Brown grows very eloquent. I'd like to have given After Life another star but were it not for the final beautifully written chapters I don't think it'd rate four stars.For those interested in better treatments of our after life destinies I'd recommend, The End of the Present World, by Fr. Charles Arminjon; and Purgatory, by Fr. F. X. Schouppe.

And not just "for the $$$".  It looks, feels, plays, and sounds better than basses I have - and have had - that cost a lot more. So, in this case I actually got more than I paid for.  This can happen when you're buying a guitar or bass these days.  You don't have to go for the big name brands to get a great  instrument.  And there are some really nice budget friendly basses that'll do everything the high dollar ones do. My Fender and Ibanez basses my look a little cooler, but I'm grabbing for the Yamaha most of the time now. It's lighter, sounds just as good if not better, and is sweet playing.The split p/up configuration is adaptable and has the balls to go wherever you want it to. The p/ups are very meaty for such an inexpensive instrument.  They don't need to be replaced at all.  The strings were fine but I stuck some Dean Markley cryo's on it. They sound good and stay in tune better than others. I've noticed I rarely have to tune this bass - unlike my Fender basses, which require it every time you pick one up and then several times afterwards.  A Leo Quan Badass II bridge is next on the list.  The neck is nice and smooth and fairly thin - about like an Ibanez - and fits my average size hands well.Some have said this is a great starter bass.  I totally agree.  But it's a great bass for advanced players too.  I'm not a professional musician but I'm confident it would hold its own on stage.  It's solidly built too and feels like it would stand up to life on the road.If I have any complaints it's that the fret ends could have been finished better.  They're ok and they won't chew up your fingers but you can feel them a little when you're playing.  Especially down close to body.As with many items made in China it's important to be aware of the quality control issues there. Given that this is a Yamaha you'll probably do ok buying it here.  And Amazon has a good return policy. But you might want to consider buying one from your local music store just to make certain you're not getting a Chinese lemon.Hope this review helped.

With all the warm fuzzy "I'm OK, you're OK" stuff emanating from the Vatican these days, The Apostolic Digest is like a much needed glass of cold water for Tradition minded Catholics wondering what's going on and why things today don't square up with what the Church has said and done for millennia.The Apostolic Digest assembles quotes from the Bible, hundreds of popes, doctors of the Church, saints and blesseds on a host of subjects: "Catholic Church the Only True Church", "No True Miracles Outside the Church", "Baptism of Desire Insufficient", etc, to demonstrate the ancient and authentic Catholic teachings.Michael Malone was only a lay Catholic but this work is one of the most valuable books on Catholic truths I own or have ever read.

I was very disappointed with this Dragunov SVD.  It looked great but was thinly made and the accuracy was poor.  There was a problem with the feeding too: I routinely had to take the magazine out and clear the jam. Some people seem to like it - which says there are quality control issues in the Chinese factory that makes them.  Quality control is a real issue with stuff made in China. If you're like me and there's even a one in ten chance that you're going to get a lemon then you probably should pass on this one.

I bought People Who Knew Jesus hoping it might be the one, with a similar sounding title, I regret not buying back in 1987. I should have saved my money.Within *one page* of opening this book I began finding errors such as: "How could an uneducated man like John, described as unlettered or even illiterate in the Acts of the Apostles (4:13) create the highly sophisticated literary and spiritual masterpiece represented by the Fourth Gospel?"In Acts, Sts. John and Peter were brought before the Sanhedrin and accused, among other things, of being "uneducated" men; not "illiterate" as the author claims.  Sts. Peter and John were very knowledgeable about Jewish scripture. "Uneducated" in this sense means they hadn't studied in a rabbinical school - and the rabbis at their trial were accusing them of this.On the very next page we find this gem: "The evangelists were not eyewitnesses to Jesus' life."Except for St. John, and almost certainly Sts. Mark and Matthew; and not unlikely, St. Luke as well. Those familiar with liberals' interpretations of holy writ will recognize the ploy: attempt to undermine the historical foundations of the bible - especially the New Testament. Once this is successful, everything becomes open to debate.On the next page there's this dreck: "Eventually what began as a Jewish movement became Gentile Christianity, and since the victors write the history, "The Jews" - especially the Pharisees in the Synoptic Gospels - become the enemy and are represented as seeking to kill Jesus."What Sommerville attempts to do with that bit of nonsense, and elsewhere in his book, is shift the blame for Jesus' death from the Jews to the Romans: actually calling the Gospels "anti-Semitic" along the way! Yet, when He was brought before Pilate, Jesus specifically stated the greater sin was that of the Jews. The Romans definitely crucified Jesus - but only after Pilate, who'd repeatedly tried to release Him, was howled down by a bloodthirsty Jewish mob whipped into a riot by the rabbis. "He came unto His own and His own received Him not."Sommerville also denies the doctrine of Original Sin, declaring it the result of St. Augustine mistranslating some key words in St. Paul's Letter to the Romans; and that the Catholic Church has perpetuated the error ever since. First, St. Augustine spoke Greek very well. He mistranslated nothing. And even if he had there would have been such an immediate uproar he'd have been forced to correct it. In any event, although he remains influential to this day, Catholic doctrine was never decided by St. Augustine.Sommerville isn't stupid and it's clear he actually studied his subject in depth and detail. Yet he commits numerous unforced heresies on just the first three pages of this tome.  After even an hour's worth of reading one begins to grow tired at the rapid pace of them all. He's not an ignorant man - he's consciously deceitful.It should come as no surprise that this anti-Catholic heretic taught philosophy for many years at the "Catholic" colleges, Fordham - and Xavier of Cincinnati....I'm only a layman but I could easily have written a much longer review on all the errors spewed in just the first twenty pages of People Who Knew Jesus, but vita brevis.  Rather than waste any more time (and precious shelf space) on this repugnant book, it's going into the circular file tomorrow.

Well made, heavy duty cotton. The service from California Beach Store was fast and friendly.  They definitely exceeded the norm.  My only complaint is that the image has been expanded from the original and is pixelated as a result. If you stand closer than six to eight feet it becomes kind of blurry. They may want to decrease the size of the image to remedy that.
It looks good but it's made from *very* lightweight fabric.  I doubt it'll last long.  It's not worth $20.00 + $2.50 s&h.  Maybe $15.00... total.

This jacket looks like it cost a lot more than it does. It's well made too. The only qualifier I'd add is that you buy two sizes up from what you normally wear. I'm just under 5'9", 158 lbs, and the *large* is tight - I can't wear anything thicker than a light shirt with it.  But it looks great!Update: Bought the XL and it fits really good.  So good that I bought the khaki colored version too.
I got this as a birthday present from my wife. I've seen others that look much like it going for 4 or 5 times as much.  It's very cool looking, isn't heavy and the links don't snag on my wrist hairs.

The Airsoft M1928 I got here at Amazon is well made, with tight tolerances, very accurate with a high muzzle velocity, holds close to 450 bb's in the magazine and looks pretty much identical to the real deal. The squirrels that were tearing up my back yard got an ugly surprise one recent morning!  If you're having trouble making a decision about which Airsoft AEG to buy I can definitely recommend this one.  It's much more gun for the money than the Airsoft MP40 that I bought at the same time.

This Airsoft MP40 looks cool and spits bb's out like a house on fire; but it is barely accurate and the folding stock and upper and lower receivers have *a lot* of wiggle in them.  There's really no justification for that. The instructions that come with it are like a bad Chinese joke: "Caution! Inspects whether installs the arriving". I bought an Airsoft Thompson M1928 at the same time. The Tommy cost about $40.00 more but it's well worth the extra $$$.  It is more accurate, has better muzzle velocity, holds a ton more bb's in the mag, looks better and is much more tightly made. If you're trying to decide between these two, I definitely recommend the Thompson.

When I first listened to Off Duty I liked it, but maybe not as much as some of 480E's earlier stuff: The Album, Nocturnal, Round Three....  But I've listened to it many more times now and like it better with each listen. It's now become one of my favorites - maybe *the* favorite.Generally speaking, Off Duty has a somewhat cooler, more thoughtful vibe to it than the other 480E cd's - and Rob Deboer's bass playing is more muted than it has been in the past; at least in some songs. But it still has nice, strong melodic lines and plenty of those spacey 480E effects you love to hear. It will probably have the strongest appeal to more cerebral chill fans. But that could be said of all of 480E's catalogue: everyone I've known who likes them strikes me as being pretty smart.I was listening to Off Duty a couple days ago and my son, who's also a fan, dropped by and asked what I was listening to. I told him to guess.  After a few seconds he knew who it was - even though I've got tons of cd's of every kind of music. 480E just has a distinctive sound. It's hard for me to say which of their cd's is my favorite because they all have a different mood. Off Duty is something that would go well with a glass of Canadian Club, falling snow and a picture window with a good view for any UFO's that wander by.As always with 480E, you don't have to wait long before the music incorporates a spacey new sound or heads off in an interesting direction.  One of the things I've always liked about them, apart from the cool jazz is the attention to detail they put into their productions. Even their first effort, The Album, was mature and polished. Off Duty won't disappoint anyone here either.Special mention must be made regarding the addition of flutist Bill McBirnie to the line-up: a wise decision in my opinion.  McBirnie is a fantastic jazz musician whose clear and fluid playing nicely accentuates the cool and intelligent flow in Off Duty.Strongest tracks (imo): The Walker, Sandbar, Vaporized, SpunWeak tracks: none

My relic'd SS, M35 isn't as well done as the M35 winter camo helmet I bought from IMA, and it cost twice as much!  The paint job and aged patina aren't nearly as good as they are in the pic shown here either. From 10 feet away it looks ok, but any closer and it's obvious that it's a re-creation.  My helmet is almost entirely brown with at most ten percent of the feldgrau showing through. And the liner has what look and feel like multiple little scabs rather than leather age spots. All-in-all a disappointment given my expectations of quality and the nearly $200 I dropped on it.

Cool looking and well made size 68, M35 helmet that'll have your friends wanting to try it on.  Camo scheme is flat white paint, sprayed over spruce boughs and needles, with a feldgrau base. Mine looks a lot like the one in the picture. The liner is comfortable and sturdy.Unfortunately, what you see here isn't what you'll get. The helmet IMA sells is a *low profile* helmet. What this means is when you put it on a table and measure the distance from the table to the front visor, it's only 15/16".  Real German WW2 helmets have a visor that's 1 1/2" off the table. In order to accomplish this the skirt was shortened.  The differences become apparent when you compare one of these helmets to the real thing.

The first thing you need to realize when you learn you've got bed bugs is that you don't have a battle on your hands - you're in a FULL BLOWN WAR.Bed bugs are very tenacious insects and they show signs of climbing the learning curve. You're going to have to annihilate them or they'll come back. Getting rid of them involves work and commitment. Fortunately, once you finally get rid of them, they're loathe to return. Diatomaceous earth will get the job done but if you want to succeed you have to be smarter and more persistent than the bed bugs.I first learned we had bed bugs when I saw something like a brown pill bug, but a lot faster, charging at me across the sheets. I squashed it and it exploded in a dime sized blood stain. I realized to my disgust that we had bed bugs - and that was the reason for the small red marks on my wife's and my arms and legs. We had what I'd consider a small to moderate infestation - maybe 200 bed bugs total (for every full grown adult you see there are about ten smaller ones in various stages of development). We learned a few things along the way:1) Forget about pesticides. PESTICIDES DON'T WORK WITH BED BUGS! Bug spray doesn't work. Bug bombs don't work. Pesticides just drive them into hiding... for a while.2) Alcohol kills them, but only a few at a time. The survivors scamper off into more remote hiding places. Extreme cold kills them too but has to be applied in such a way that none are missed. Heat kills them VERY well. Bed bugs can't stand temps above 115 F for more than fifteen minutes. Exterminators are now using 200,000 BTU heaters to heat houses, apartments and rooms to 140 F for an hour. Bed bugs can run but they can't hide from heat. But thermal extermination is expensive and doing an entire house can cost over $5,000. Diatomaceous earth kills them too. It's the cheapest way to get rid of bed bugs - but you have to be thorough, persistent and systematic. DE won't kill them immediately as it's not a pesticide. It takes a couple days to start working - and it takes a while to get them all.3) You're the bait! Bed bugs love us and take great risks to suck our blood. Many of them die in the effort. They're most active between the hours of three and four am but they'll change their schedule to whatever yours is if need be.When I discovered we had bed bugs I bug bombed and sprayed them. But it quickly became clear that while they didn't like it, it wasn't killing them. That's when I finally understood we had a lot bigger problem on our hands than I first thought - our own personal hell.  Fortunately for bed bug sufferers the Internet has lots of information about how to fight them. Maybe too much.  After a day spent studying the problem I came up with a plan: diatomaceous earth.Diatomaceous earth comes in two grades: pool grade, which is poisonous to people and pets; and FOOD GRADE, which is the stuff you want to use. It's very light and powdery, about like flour. It contains tiny, glass-like shards that work their way into the soft spaces of insect exoskeletons, cutting them up and causing them to dehydrate and die. Bed bugs don't seem to recognize it as a mortal danger and once it gets on them they can't get it off.We dusted diatomaceous earth all around the bed, on the mattresses, underneath the bed and in the bed frame screw holes and any crevices, on the headboard, rails, legs and everywhere else. Then I dusted behind, inside and underneath the bedside tables and dressers, along the baseboards, in all the drawers, etc. Everywhere a bed bug might hide. Trust me, they're very good at hiding and if you make life hard for them around the bed they'll move their base of operations to a further corner of the room and bide their time.We also put plant pot saucers filled with diatomaceous earth under each bed leg. This is real important because once you've defeated the ones hiding in your bed the only way those lurking elsewhere can reach you is by passing through it. As much as possible turn your bed into an island surrounded by an ocean of diatomaceous earth.Use double sided tape around all the bed legs, on the headboard, etc. They won't try to cross it and will in fact turn back around as soon as they encounter it. What you want to do is create choke points that force the little buggers to have to pass through diatomaceous earth in order to get at you.Mattress covers for the top and bottom mattresses. These are very important. Bed bugs like to hide in mattress seams - and in the hidden recesses of box springs.  Leave the mattress covers on for a long time too because they can live up to a year without feeding; and check the covers periodically to make sure there aren't any holes or tears they can climb in or out of, because they will definitely find them.  Also, if you've got anything: dust ruffle, sheets, blankets, bedspreads, etc. that touch the floor, take them off because bed bugs can and will use them as an avenue to get to you.Light colored sheets - to see them better. The nymphs are light tan colored, tiny, and a lot harder to see than the adults - which are 3/16 of an inch long and dark brown. Dark sheets show up the little ones better. Light sheets show up the bigger ones. Also, after nibbling on you they poop little black spots. If you see these showing up on your sheets it's a good sign of bed bug infestation.  I went with light green sheets which worked well as I could see both adults and nymphs, and any poop spots. Dark sheets hide their poop stains, so avoid them. Also, it's a good idea to wash your sheets daily for the first week or two because these things are laying eggs like crazy.We got everything out from under the bed and put ALL our clothes, bedroom stuff etc. that bed bugs could hide in, into black garbage bags, then sealed them and put them out on the back patio to heat up for a couple hours in the summer Sun. Black garbage bags absorb the Sun's rays and turn the insides into an oven. I measured the temp inside and it was 132 F! If it's cold when you learn you have bed bugs you could probably use a blow dryer on low setting. You just have to get the temp in the bags up to 115 F for fifteen minutes.  Eggs take longer to kill but they can't survive 115 F for more than an hour. The more heat you create the faster they die.Vacuum your floors - 3-5 times a week for a couple of weeks or more depending on how many there are. You want to suck up any eggs that have fallen to the floor or any bed bugs that are crawling around. Concentrate on the spaces under and around your bed and base boards. If you've got hardwood floors it'll make your job easier as there are fewer places for them to hide and you can see them, and signs of them, better. Also, if you have a canister type vacuum it'll give you an idea of how many you're killing. Re-apply the DE as necessary. I used a paint brush and turkey baster. DE's very powdery and floats like dust but it doesn't take much to cover a large area.  Some have complained about how dusty it is, but ask yourself this: what would you rather have to deal with, a little dust or bed bugs?Even after all this we were still getting bitten - though much less. We found a few hiding between the new mattress covers and killed them. A few days later we were bitten again. Taking the bed apart we found a half inch hole in the mattress cover surrounding the box springs. It had some little black poop stains near it. The bugs that'd been trapped inside found the hole and came out to feast. We sealed it with some scotch tape.We next found some crawling up a table lamp cord and marching across the bedside table!  I've no doubt they were headed for the sheets that were brushing against the table. I moved both bedside tables a foot away from the bed then thoroughly dusted the table tops, cords, electric receptacle boxes (which they use as hideouts), etc... but we still got some bites - though less than at any time in a month. We then took the bed apart and using a flashlight, magnifying glass and dentist's mirror, searched every nook and cranny.  Sure enough, some were hiding in screw holes. We'd already treated the bed frame and screw holes with diatomaceous earth, but it hadn't stuck to the tops of some of the screw holes... and that's where they were hiding. I killed these and we put the bed back together.About a week went by without any bites but we were still suspicious and took the bed apart again. Lo and behold two adolescents were hiding in a small worm hole in one of the slats. I killed these and prayed we were finally nearing the end our disgusting problem. But just to be sure we took the bed apart and thoroughly inspected it weekly another four or five times. By now we were familiar with every nook and cranny of our bed.  We also checked all possible hidey holes around the bed. All told we spent around a month and a half in our bed bug war and the mop up missions... BUT WE WON THE WAR! And we've been bed bug free since September 2011.We didn't think we'd ever get bed bugs but we learned better. They're everywhere now. If you're waking up with unexplainable red marks, and/or your sheets start showing little black spots, you need to ACT FAST.  At the first sign of an infestation take your bed completely apart and INSPECT EVERY INCH OF IT: mattress, frame, inner box springs, headboard, legs... everything. A flashlight and magnifying glass are helpful here. You may be shocked at how many you find. You can vacuum them up and/or squash them with paper towels.  Squashing them is messy but hydrogen peroxide will clean up any blood stains. Toothpicks work well on the ones hiding in crevices and holes. You'll learn to be impressed by how cleverly they hide. Don't go light on the diatomaceous earth either - this really is total war.Once you've cleared your bed of them the ball's back in your court. But you can still pick up eggs on your feet and carry them back into the bed - thus the importance of vacuuming religiously.  If you go a week without getting bitten it shows you've made progress, but the war ain't over yet. Many are still lurking around, so you need to keep checking for them. If you go a month without getting bitten you've probably won the war but it's a good idea to leave some diatomaceous earth in the plant pot saucers under the bed legs, and along the baseboards too, for several more months - in case some are still hiding out.  And inspect your bed a few more times too, if only for peace of mind.I might add that if any of your family, friends or visitors report bed bugs at home - or at work - you should immediately buy some diatomaceous earth in anticipation of when they show up at your place. Pre-emptively dust your base boards, especially in the bed rooms, because they use base boards as highways and hideouts. Most of them stick pretty close to the bed but for some reason some go solo and you can find them anywhere in your house.I can only surmise that the people who neg diatomaceous earth are less intelligent and/or persistent than bed bugs. Or maybe they're exterminators. Who knows? Diatomaceous earth is a real deal killer for exterminators if it's used properly. It just takes a while to get them all.The key to defeating bed bugs is to understand you're up against a wily and resourceful adversary who's not going to leave without an ugly fight. A hit and a miss doesn't work with them. The sooner you get started the better because the more there are the harder they are to get rid of. If you decide to go with diatomaceous earth you learn their habits and hideouts. You make life at your place dangerous for them and kill them off by percentages in a series of running battles until all are gone. There may be multiple battlefields: your bed/mattress, framework, under your bed, the baseboards, bedside tables, chairs, blanket boxes, behind picture frames, electric boxes, loose wallpaper, lamps, dresser drawers and everything that's in them, closets, curtains, etc.  Like I said, the main thing is to first get them out of your bed and turn it into an island sanctuary; then go on ruthless search and destroy missions for any others.Remember... you're the bait!  But by using yourself and your loved ones as bait you'll lure bed bugs into a diatomaceous deathtrap. It's a great feeling to be able lie peacefully in your bed again without worrying if you're being silently stalked.

I bought this book at the urging of a friend who trains with Wes Cole in Tulsa and has lost weight using his method. My problem's not really fatness or unfitness. I just seem to hit a wall where I can't lose any more weight, hard as I try.  Willpower's good, but only to a point: it can help you lose some weight but it won't keep it off.  What makes me think this book will work is that Cole's program is greater than just losing "x" number of pounds.  It involves developing healthy dietary, exercise and mental *habits* that'll help you get into better shape and health - and keep you there. Thus the title: Healthy Habits.At the core of the Healthy Habits program, and something that makes the book unusual in my view, is a series of four "cycles" as Cole calls them that last about six weeks each.  Each cycle incorporates a program of diet and exercise to burn flab and build up stamina and strength. On completing a given cycle, you take a self test that lets you know if you're ready to move on to the next. The cycles are slowly progressive - you gradually build up habits you can use in the next cycle.Cycle one is mainly about the importance of getting rid of refined sugar from your diet, and how to do it. Americans are hugely addicted to refined sugar and the average person eats about 150 pounds of it a year. Unfortunately, it has no nutritive value whatsoever and gets stored in your body as fat. Worse still, it leaches out essential vitamins and nutrients that you need to function. I'd heard refined sugar isn't good for you but never realized before just how contrary it is to good health. Basically, you'd do better starving because refined sugar's worse than nothing. After a lifetime spent eating it we don't even realize how addicted we've become. Not only that, sugar's a hidden ingredient in lots of foods, even those that are touted as healthy. Manufacturers slip it into all kinds of stuff. Cole goes after refined sugar like public enemy number one.  He tells how to eliminate it from your diet and gives a list of sugar alternatives with their relative merits. Interestingly, it seems that once you beat your sugar jones, it starts to taste bad - even to the point of making you nauseous.The fitness component to this cycle involves doing stuff that you already enjoy doing. This is an important point with the book: you don't have to kill yourself doing stuff you'd rather not. You can burn lots of calories doing things you actually like to do.Cycle two is about eating healthier, and getting the right balance of proteins and carbohydrates in your diet. Recipes for healthy eating are given. The fitness component involves expanding on your exercise routine.Cycle three is about eliminating certain fats from your diet entirely while reducing others; and decreasing your sodium intake. Along with refined sugar, there's lots of fat lurking in our cupboards. The book discusses these in  some detail (especially Trans fat and partially hydrogenated vegetable oil), and ways to purge them from your diet. The reader's encouraged to read food labels to see just how much hidden sugar, fat and salt their food actually contains.  Here I think the book could have been improved by giving some examples and instructions for reading food labels, but it's not hard to learn. More recipes for healthy eating are given. The fitness component discusses upper level activities like group sports, charity runs, etc.Cycle four gives instructions about calorie counting - and its importance for people who really want to be slimmer. The first three cycles were about losing weight while becoming fitter, this cycle is about keeping the weight off and keeping fit. The simple math is that if you want to lose weight you must burn more calories than you take in (to lose a pound a week you need to burn 500 more calories a day than you eat). To maintain stasis it's necessary that you eat no more than you excrete.  Apparently lots of people can't wrap their brains around calorie counting, but the way Cole describes it it's really not hard, just an acquired skill you'll be able to do in your head before long. There are sites on the Internet that do much of the grunt work for you. The fitness program of this cycle offers types of advanced exercise regimes.For me, Healthy Habits was a very fast read. Especially given that it's a weight loss book. Cole has an accessible, conversational style; like he's lifting weights next to you in the gym. There are lots of interesting observations based on his experience as a strength and conditioning trainer that make sense. One thing he repeatedly emphasizes is the importance of group exercise, be it  jazzercize, Judo or jousting.  Solo exercise routines rarely endure - as all the dusty Bowflexes and Nautilus equipment in America's garages attests. There are just too many interruptions for you to concentrate on exercising properly. Plus, humans are by nature social beings. The four Healthy Habits cycles seem to me very reasonable. You build up over six weeks until you're ready to graduate to the next cycle.  And if you fail to pass one of the self tests in order to graduate, you just back up a couple weeks and proceed again.Update, Oct 2012: I've completed all the cycles spelled out in Healthy Habits and IT WORKED!  I'm holding in at an average of 156 lb's now.  One thing I learned from the book is that although I wasn't over eating, my sweet tooth got the better of me about once a week and I'd demolish anything sweet in sight. That seems to have been the key for me.

I got this kneeling chair a month ago and have come to the conclusion that it's just an uncomfortable ride and there's no way around it. I got mine because of low back pain that was exacerbated by the old chair.First: the padding in the kneeler is inadequate at best.  The wooden frame makes itself known after just a few minutes and after an hour my knees are screaming. I'm not all that big either - 5'9", 165 lbs.  It'd probably be more uncomfortable for people bigger and heavier than me. Also, my aching knees are continuously sliding forward on the kneeler and I have to wiggle back up every couple of minutes. This is because the kneeler nearly parallels the floor - it needs more of an upward angle but it can't be adjusted.The seat has problems too. It's pretty hard and in my case at least needs to be a little more parallel to the floor - but it can't be adjusted either.  The back rest is adjustable but it has only three settings - none of which fit me. There's a high/low adjuster underneath the seat that I've monkey'd with a dozen times but to no avail.  It just trades one discomfort for another. My back pain has let up somewhat, but now my knees hurt and are growing callouses.  Getting up to walk after an hour or two in this thing has me feeling like I'm 90 years old.In a nutshell here's what's wrong: we're not all the same size!  To make it comfortable the kneeler and seat need more padding and some way to individually adjust them. In my case the back rest is pretty much useless, except as a head rest when using the chair as a recliner.If you're anywhere near my size I highly recommend you not buy this.  Shell out the extra $$$ for a better kneeling chair. One that you can personalize to your body... with thicker padding. It hasn't been too expensive a mistake but I'm looking for something else.

I bought How to Avoid Huge Ships as a companion to Captain Trimmer's other excellent titles: How to Avoid a Train, and How to Avoid the Empire State Building.  These books are fast paced, well written and the hard won knowledge found in them is as inspirational as it is informational.  After reading them I haven't been hit by anything bigger than a diesel bus.  Thanks captain!

This little drum auger does a good job on small clogs that are halfway close to the drain.  But here's the caveat: it comes with a thumb screw (which secures the snake when the drum is spinning) that screws into a cheap, very easily broken plastic nut.  Click on the pic and it'll expand the image where you can see it better. The thumb screw/nut is the achilles heel of this thing.  Be very careful: don't overtighten the thumb screw or it'll split the nut. And if you're using an electric drill to power it don't let the thumb screw bang into anything when the drum is spinning - as that'll break the nut too.  If the nut's broken it's pretty much useless. Your only recourse then is to pull the snake out of the drum, jam it down the drain with your bare hands and hope you get lucky.  What I learned to do was replace the thumb screw with a half inch long round head machine screw and then use my fingers to tighten and loosen it.  Now the screw can't be overtightened; and if it hits anything while spinning it's only a glancing blow.Also, when using a drill keep the drum pretty close to the drain because the snake can tangle itself up if there's too much exposed.  Manually advance the snake a few inches at a time until hopefully your drain starts flowing again. It's a great feeling to see the water go swirling down!

Koyaanisqatsi made an artsy splash when it came out in 1983, but for reasons now lost I couldn't make it to a showing.  Twenty seven years later I finally got my wish.I wanted to like Koyaanisqatsi, but was forced to realize it hasn't aged well. Godfrey Reggio shows a very good eye for dramatic shots, but then works them to exhaustion.  The time lapse scenes of people scurrying around like harried ants grew wearisome after two minutes, let alone ten.  The movie's metaphor of modern life as a hotdog highway, with people as the hotdogs, was soon made abundantly clear, but Reggio seems uncertain of his audiences' intelligence and just pounds this thought into their collective skull.Likewise, Phillip Glass's score became an exercise in repetition that eventually began to grate on my ears.  To be fair Glass captures the atmosphere of the movie and the repetition in the score is a faithful reflection of the cinematography. Given the singularity of Reggio's vision he had no other option.Koyaanisqatsi would have been great as a fifteen minute short subject; but like having a guest who overstays his welcome, I was relieved when it was over.

...but not this time.  Thirty years ago I couldn't wait for the next installment of Shogun to appear on tv.  Perhaps times have changed, or I've changed, but whatever's changed, thirty years later I wonder why it was so wildly popular.Frankly, the script was wooden.  After hearing Richard Chamberlain say, "Thou art beautiful and I love thee!", or "Hai, Toranaga-sama!" for the hundredth time I was about ready to do something more productive... like grab a beer and watch the cars drive by.  The dialogue just came across as stilted; particularly in the interactions between Chamberlain's (Blackthorne/Anjin-san) and Yoko Shimada's (Mariko) characters.I realized Richard Chamberlain is just not a good actor.  His emotional depth and breadth is very limited.  Granted the role was probably a difficult one to pull off, and he was given some pretty lame lines, but Chamberlain wasn't remotely up to the job.  His facial expressions ran the gamut from A to B: A. Perturbed look... eyes narrowing.  B. Flinty smile.The interactions between Chamberlain's Anjin-san and the Jesuit priest, Father Alvito, are absurd.  Their relationship see-saws between invective and admiration without any explanation; and the dialogue between them verges on farce.  Curses of, "You heretic!" and "Damn you to hell, priest!"  are interspersed with scenes of gum swapping cordiality.Another thing: Lord Toranaga (Toshiro Mifune) would perform a bizarre dance before his men in which he'd wave a fan at them while stamping his foot and shouting, "Heeyit! Heeyit! Heeyit...!"  No explanation was given for this.  One assumes that in some mysterious way it put his samurai into a fighting mood.Lastly, it would have been nice had English subtitles been used during the Japanese segments to help the viewers sort out some of the action.The good things about this movie were:The Japanese actors (especially Toshiro Mifune) who all came across convincingly - at least when compared to the European actors. The sets, which were beautifully done; and the costumes, which were beautifully done.  One qualifier here: the Jesuits in Japan did not wear saffron colored robes, they wore black robes as they always have.Finally, the director of Photography, Andrew Laszlo, did a fine job - both indoors and outdoors - of capturing the drama and poetry inherent in such a story. In spite of the opening scene with the shadow of the cinematographer's helicopter shading a 16th century ship, IMHO he was the secret star of Shogun.
Our's had less than 30 hours of play on the cd when the laser module pooped out.  Other than that it was nice.

IMHO, when a movie resorts to the cheap scare - people jumping out, accompanied by loud blasts of discordant music - it's time to move on to something more productive.  This amateurish conceit must have been used half a dozen times in Shutter Island.  One would expect better from Scorsese.  The good acting and gothic sensibilities of the movie were weighed down by plot holes and a "surprise" ending you could see coming long before it arrived.

I have to give this five stars for the following reasons:(1) Solid Teak: This stool is SOLID. It weighs 24 pounds because the genuine teak is so heavy.(2) Design: The Asian design (with the curved bench top) is the most comfortable stool you can find. In addition, the triangular base provides maximum support in all planes for considerable weight and shifting weight. The legs, being solid wood (instead of just legs) are perfect for moving the stool around when you are sitting on it and still maintaining stability.(3) Height: The height is perfect for using around counters in the home, or, other places. I bought this because I need a stool that provides proper height for using microscopes and working at my potting bench in my greenhouse. This provides the perfect height for using it on most counters between 30" and 34" in height (most home counter heights).(4) Water resistance: Since this is made of teak you can use it indoors, outdoors, wet or dry. I have to admit I am not fond of the finish (because it will fade, peel or wear over time). I would rather have had an unfinished stool so I could treat it with Tung Oil. However, this finish will look good for years out of doors (even with exposure to UV and water), or, it will look good indefinitely if you just use this indoors.

I have to give this item five stars.I have a modest sized greenhouse (about 200 square feet.  It is imperative that I provide moisture throughout intense dry summers in the Southwest, with high UV from high altitude sun.  In addition, even with sunshades, the temperatures in my greenhouse will reach 127 degrees (F) in mid and late summer.  It is imperative that I provide both moisture and cooling for plants I keep in the greenhouse year round (and cooling for myself).First of all, whoever designed this had on their thinking cap.  All of the material are of either stainless steel or high strength molded polypropylene.  The polypro is highly UV resistant, heat resistant and strong.  It will stand up to the rigors of outdoor UV, moisture and temperature extremes.There are no nozzles to clog.  The mist is emitted from the fan blades themselves.  This insures that the mist is propelled away from the unit (up to 20 feet) to avoid uneven moisture accumulations around the unit.You can control the amount of flow easily by just regulating the amount of water you are feeding to the unit (I bought the direct feed model).This model is very, very economical.  It only draws about 1.8 amps.  Most of the power for the unit comes from the water pressure if you purchase the direct feed model and just hook it up to a hose.  In addition, it only consumes about 3 gallons per HOUR (on its maximum setting) of water.This model will easily humidify 600 square feet, and, cool 300 square feet.  I can leave all of the windows open in the greenhouse for ventilation and this still provides adequate cooling and humidification for my plants (and for me).The direct feed, portable model can be moved fairly easily (to your house in the winter for example).  All you need is a faucet, an outlet and bracket to hang the unit.

Notwithstanding its minor shortcomings, this pan is perfect for making yogurt or cheese.First, it is made of stainless steel.  This is a pre-requisite for preparing foods that involve gestation of bacteria.  This is easy to clean, it is easy to sterilize and it is very durable.Second, the aluminum encapsulated bottom is what you need for careful temperature management.  Aluminum is a soft metal (like copper) so it conducts heat very well.  Applying heat to the bottom, from any source, the heat will spread quickly all across the bottom and a little way up the side.  When making yogurt and cheese, you have to hit 110 degrees fairly accurately and this helps you do that with a small amount of heat from either a gas or electric stove.Third, the handle is of rolled stainless steel, which means it is hollow - that means the handle will stay relatively cool even if you are heating the contents of the pot to a high temperature.Fourth, the heavy glass lid is ideal for protecting contents from accidental contamination - it allows you to see the contents if it is covered, and, the lid has a small (nicely grommeted) hole in it to relieve steam and allow insertion of a thermometer or temperature probe so that you can monitor the temperature of the contents.Fifth, the price is fantastic compared to other forms of a pan.Sixth, the pour spouts on either side of the pan are very accurate and allow you to pour small amounts into small jars or other containers without any spill or mess.Seventh, this is a large pan and allows you to easily make up to two quarts of cheese or yogurt so that you don't have to make multiple batches.I shopped around, and bought this and I am glad I did.

This is not food or fertilizer.What this is, is a live culture of the four basic types of micro-organisms that are necessary for plant health, growth and maintenance.I agree with the other reviewer.  The company that is marketing this has done a very poor job of providing users with the information they need to use this effectively.All plants need four types of micro-organisms around their root systems to extract and store nutrients (such as nitrogen) from the soil.  The four types are:  fungi, bacteria, protozoa and nematodes.  There is a complex interaction between these microorganisms, and plants, to maintain healthy soil.  Teaming with Microbes: The Organic Gardener's Guide to the Soil Food Web, Revised EditionThis culture provides all four types of micro-organisms.This culture is most useful when you are trying to re-establish soil structure (after heavy fertilization or use of chemicals, or drought, or augmentation with compost, etc.)  It will re-introduce the necessary micro-organisms into your soil that plants need to extract basic food from the soil (nitrogen and carbon, especially).  Just as we need pro-biotics in our digestive system to digest food, plants need these micro-organisms to "digest" raw materials in the soil into forms that the plant can assimilate.  This concept is known as "bioavailability."Couple of pointers on using this.  First, if you are smart, you will culture this yourself before using it.  When I received it I examined it for live organisms under a micro-scope.  It is a live culture.  I cultured it in two disposable petri dishes just to make sure.  It yielded a substantial culture within ten days.To use this, you want to add about 40 ccs (two tablespoons) to a gallon of water, and, just water your plants around the base so that the water and the micro-organisms get into the root system.  You can also use this to inoculate your plant roots when planting or potting them.  If you are planting or potting flowering or fruit bearing plants or trees, you should also consider inoculating the root system with a small amount of mychorizzae (a benign fungus that vastly increases root system efficiency).  Mycorrhizae Inoculant (Earth Ambrosia/Earth Nectar) - 32 OunceThis stuff is expensive so, to stretch it out, I culture my own after I've bought the bottle.  I use a 250 ml erlenmeyer flask.  I add about 100 cc of ordinary water, 75 cc of the stuff in this bottle, and about 75 cc of ordinary molasses or sugar.  I let the flask sit in a warm (not hot) place for a week or two and the result is about 8 ounces of the stuff in the bottle - which is enough for adding to four gallons of water.  (You don't have to culture it yourself - you can just buy the stuff and use it straight from the bottle, but, I don't like paying this manufacturer because they rip you off on the shipping fees, and, don't offer any support).Get this stuff into the root systems of your plants and it will help them maintain a healthy root structure so that they can draw nutrients from the soil.I use it because I have some of the worst soil in the world and I need to bio-activate it after adding iron and organic material (compost) to it.

This film has very, very little content.  It is mostly conjecture about Einstein's relationship to his wife and their relationship.  In addition, the production and filming are accurately described as "amateur."The premise of the film is that Einstein's first wife was the real discoverer of his theories of special relativity and space-time.Mileva was a physics student with Einstein.  He married her, and, during their second year of marriage, after the birth of his son in 1905, he published his four *now famous) papers on physics.It is clear in history that Mileva edited his papers before he submitted them to Max Plank.  However, her own correspondence and journals show that the seminal ideas in Einstein's papers were inspirations that he had entertained long before ever meeting Mileva.If you like revisionism, then this is a interesting speculation based work of entertainment.

Actually, this tender is made by Honda, not Yamaha.The package in this listing includes a variety of connects for the battery terminals.  You can switch out the connects so that you can use this with just the terminal clamps, or, in my case, fastening the o ring connectors directly to the battery terminals for a permanent installation.I've used this tender for over five years.In that time, I have had it almost permanently hooked up to my tractor battery, and it has performed flawlessly the entire time.This was designed for maintaining marine batteries, so, the waterproof feature means I can leave it outside, unprotected, on the tractor.I wired it permanently to the battery terminals so that all I have to do is plug it in.If I really deplete the battery on the tractor (heavy starting in cold weather and heavy use of lights on the tractor) it will take about a day or day and a half to charge it back up.If I am just using a normal warm weather start on the tractor battery, it only takes about a half an hour, at .8 Amps, to recharge the battery.The unit is fairly compact, and, even with long cords, tucks up neatly under the tractor seat.In all, given its reliability, quality, waterproof case, and, the requirement for almost zero maintenance, this tender is the best bargain.

I've used this tender for over five years.In that time, I have had it almost permanently hooked up to my tractor battery, and it has performed flawlessly the entire time.This was designed for maintaining marine batteries, so, the waterproof feature means I can leave it outside, unprotected, on the tractor.I wired it permanently to the battery terminals so that all I have to do is plug it in.If I really deplete the battery on the tractor (heavy starting in cold weather and heavy use of lights on the tractor) it will take about a day or day and a half to charge it back up.If I am just using a normal warm weather start on the tractor battery, it only takes about a half an hour, at .8 Amps, to recharge the battery.The unit is fairly compact, and, even with long cords, tucks up neatly under the tractor seat.In all, given its reliability, quality, waterproof case, and, the requirement for almost zero maintenance, this tender is the best bargain.

This is the best cookbook I could find for the recipes that my Mom used to make.This book is a pretty comprehensive treatment of Czech delights using natural and original ingredients.I've tried other Czech cookbooks, but, this one gives you the directions and instruction needed to handle natural foods and prepare the dishes in a way that provides the real Czech flavors and dishes that I learned to love from my parents.

This economical device is a great investment.I'd give it five stars if there was a way to shut off the timer once you have initiated power to a device.  As it is, the minimum setting is for 1/2 an hour of power, and, once you start the timer, there is no way to shut it off without pulling the timer out of the socket.Other than that, this little device is a real power saver, especially on high consumption electrical appliances like heaters and fans.

I really enjoyed reading this book.People have searched for the Lost Dutchman mine in the Superstition Mountains for over 100 years.This book brings to life the "old dutchman" himself - Jacob Waltz.  This is important because Wells provides a colorful narrative of Waltz, and the people he knew.  This provides some fascinating context for the book's discussions of the many people who have searched for the Lost Dutchman Mine.The book has dozens of photographs of the actual area surrounding the Superstition Mountains, as well as the Tonto National Forest and the Old Apache trail.At the end is a complete bibliography, and, a helpful listing of websites (with working hyperlinks) for additional information for anyone visiting the area.This book is an easy read and very enjoyable.

I give these five stars because:(1)  The wooden handle is slightly more flexible than nylon, hence, it is more comfortable for repeated use.(2)  The price is fantastic.(3)  The wavy blade edge makes it easier to sculpt hedges.(4)  For the money, this is really well-made.After looking at scores of these, I think these are the best buy and the best shears you can buy.

I agree with the other reviewers.  These ladies are wonderful.The cooking sequences in these episodes demonstrate time-tested ways of cooking fine cuisine.  It includes a lot of handy tips that you might not otherwise know.  For example, when adding cream to melted chocolate, make sure the cream is room temperature; or, put tomatoes in boiling water for one minute to easily remove the skin.Jennifer Paterson was born to missionary parents in China.  She travelled all around the world as a chef for the privileged class of people who hired her.The other lady was a barrister (trial lawyer) until she was 34 years old and took up cooking, around the world, as a passion.This show isn't just about cooking, it is about all of the wonderful scenery, sources of fresh dairy, produce and meat available in rural areas, and, the best that England has to offer in the way of traditions and style.

I was impressed with the quality of the design of this sifter.First, at 4 cups, it's just about the right size for any baking or cooking.Second, the bottom of the sifter is slightly funneled so that you have a good chance of getting the sifted material into a one cup (or larger) measuring cup.  (I think this is great since the secret to most recipes is to sift the material many times - this is especially true for soufflets and cakes).Third, the stainless steel makes this a snap to clean, and keep clean.  It also doesn't allow flour or powdered sugar to stick to it so much that you can't shake it or knock it off with a few raps of your hand).  The stainless steel is heavy compared to the ones I looked at in the supermarket.I'd give this five stars except for the chintzy revolving shifter mechanism, the chintzy crank handle and the wooden knob.  I actually really like the wooden knob, but, it won't stand up to the dishwasher.In all, I'm pleased with it.

This little book (it's about the size of a stack of 3x5 index cards) has many of the favorites my Mom used to make.However,(1)  The recipes are "Americanized" and call for ingredients that are not the original natural ingredients from Czech recipes.  (For example, the "Dumplings" recipe calls for "potato flakes")(2)  There are really only about 100 recipes - much of the booklet is fluff about Czech traditions, maxims and culture.I found myself looking elsewhere for authentic and original Czech recipes and finally purchased the Kindle version of this book.  The Best of Czech Cooking (Hippocrene International Cookbook Series)On the positive side, this little booklet is spiral bound and lays nice and flat on the counter while you are cooking or baking.  It is compact so that it is easy to use while you are cooking.  The covers are of a waterproof material so that this will survive enthusiastic cooking environs.l

I'd give this documentary five stars except for the poor quality of the soundtrack (the music is obnoxious and drowns out the commentators and the narrator - there are no subtitles).This documentary is very, very well-written.  It covers many of the moral, political and military issues of the time.  The re-creation of the battle scenes is some of the best that I've viewed.  The re-creations give you a real sense of the hardships and tragedies endured by the troops.The documentary seems to be fair and balanced, exploring the views and beliefs of both sides in the conflict (North and South).  The well-written narration illuminates many of the historical forces that shaped the world-shaking conflict.  For example, much of the brutality visited by the North on the South, at the end of the War, arose simply because everyone was despondent over the War and wanted it to end.  As the CSA still had over 150,000 troops in the field at the time of Appomattox (Lee's surrender), the War could have continued indefinitely.The documentary accurately points out the terrible attrition on both sides of the conflict (over 500,000 died on both sides) and the drastic efforts of leaders, on both sides, to try to end the conflict by decisive battles.There is a balanced, and erudite exploration of the moral and legal issues of slavery in the South.  There is also a very-well written episode on the efforts to reconstruct the South after the War, and, the political battles fought over the issue of whether to punish the South for the insurrection.In all, this is one of the best documentaries I've viewed on the Civil War.This makes an excellent background for understanding the political events which are the focus of Steven Spielberg's recent film: Lincoln

This is a great innovation for baking.I bought this to make Czech Rakvičky (which is one of the items shown in the photos).This is a hybrid between a metal pan and a silicone mold.The advantages are that the silicone mold for the bars is flexible.  Once you have finished baking, you can easily pop the bars out of the pan from below.  The silicone is a non-stick surface and you don't have to worry about toxins from scratched teflon coatings.  The bars come right out without having to use any kind of coating on the inside of the molds.In addition, the silicone mold has a rigid metal ring around it, with metal handles, so that when you are carrying the pan to the oven, or taking it out, you don't have to deal with the silicone flopping all over the place.  The metal rim around the silicone mold holds the assembly rigid so that you can easily carry it.I use Chicago brand for all of my baking and their quality is excellent.

I grew up in Cleveland amid many different nationalities.This little book (it's about the size of a 3x5 stack of index cards 1/2 inch thick) contains all of the favorites that my Mom and grandmothers used to prepare.There are about thirty five Kolachky (that's how we spelled it and pronounced it) recipes that include all of the favorites from my childhood, including Icebox kolaches, Potato Kolaches, Old Czech Kolaches, Cottage cheese kolaches (my favorite), sour cream kolaches, nut kolaches and a host of different fillings that can be used for variety.In addition, there is a special section for coffee cakes, sweet breads, fried breads and rolls.There is also a special section for poppyseed coffee cakes, cakes, rolls and even a poppyseed torte.Some of my other favorites include Prague Whipped Cream Tarts (Rakvicky), Apple Strudel, Rice pudding.At this price you can't go wrong.There are, in all, over 150 recipes.

I remember watching this series when it was a broadcast program on NBC in the 1960's.The series is a compendium of actual war footage of Pacific operations during WWII.  The series documents, step-by-step, the comeback of the Pacific fleet and its campaign to Tokyo.  It includes raw footage of U. S. Marine beach heads, and, U. S. Army involvement in the Pacific.  Much of the footage in this documentary was not released to the public during the War.Most of the film is composed of footage of actual battles, the commanders of the operations, and the men who fought so valiantly to bring peace to the Pacific Basin.The film is scored with the Emmy award winning music of Richard Rogers and Robert Russell Bennet.  The score is one of the high points of the DVD series.  Victory at Sea.  The music has become one of the benchmarks of American classical music.Unlike many of the historical films produced about the war in the Pacific, this series underscores the hardships sailors encountered in the drive to Tokyo.  The footage does not spare us from the grim realities of the War, but, accurately portrays its horrors and the incredible courage of the sailors who faced long odds.It is difficult to find a more detailed and accurate account of the war in the Pacific than this series.

I live in the semi-arid Southwest of the U. S.Humidity is usually down around 10-30% most of the years.  In the cold, during the winter, the air is even dryer.  These provide soothing relief for a dry throat, or even a sore throat.These drops come in convenient packaging, and, if you buy three of them, they are economical.  I can keep one package in the car, one at home, and one at the office.The taste is very pleasant (I love Wild Cherry) and the soothing quality of these drops is very high.  Ludens has been making throat lozenges ever since I can remember and their excellence shines through in this product.

I have to agree with the reviewers who found this DVD to be somewhat limiting.There are some great CGI reconstructions of the Parthenon as it existed in ancient times.  However, except for that, much of this DVD focuses on modern Greece.  Much of it is little more than a travelogue.The photography is beautiful, but, there was little footage of the ancient Greek structures for which most people seek out documentaries on Greece.In all, I would not again pay the price for this DVD.  It's worth watching if you can view it on a one-time basis, economically, through rental.  Greece: Secrets of the Past (IMAX)

I bought this because it seemed identical to an oil can that my father used in the 1950's.To my pleasant surprise, this can is manufactured with the same made-in-usa quality as the ones my father used.Here are the reasons I like this oil can:First, it is made of heavy gauge metal.  I don't have to worry about leaking oil all over my car or tractor because of cheap materials that won't stand up to an honest working environment.Second, it is made in the good-ole U. S. of A.Third, the bottom is both crimped and welded so that this can will still hold oil if I drop it, accidentally run it over, keep it on my tractor where there is significant vibration and shock, or use it in demanding work situations.Fourth, the trigger mechanism is driven by a heavy gauge spring.Fifth, being made of steel, instead of plastic or cheap metal, if I dent it, ding it, drop it, or stress it, it won't break, and, if something on it does break, I have a chance of fixing it instead of having to throw it away.The paint on the outside of the can is thick metal enamel and it was primed before it was painted.  This is a can I can keep outdoors, in handy places where I need it the most, without having to worry that it will corrode beyond usable limits.This can is made the way "they used to be made."

I was really pleased to find this album on Amazon.My family originated in Prague.  When I was young we shared many Czech carols at Christmastime with my grandparents and family.This album is a classically arranged collection of authentic Czech Christmas carols.  The accompaniment is by prominent Czech classical musicians and vocalists.Each of them are beautiful, and, well-performed.  The arrangements are not only professional, they are delightful as well.All of the Carols are in Czech, and, the vocals are performed by native Czech speaking performers.The quality of the performances on this compilation is very, very high.  The quality rivals Der Wiener Sängerknaben (Vienna Boys' Choir) collections.Czech music and culture faded into the background after WWI.  We lose sight of the fact that Prague was THE center of arts and sciences, in Europe, during the renaissance.  This album is a reminder of centuries of Czech music that have delighted those in search of the Christmas Spirit.The title means:  "Czech Christmas Jewels"

Four and a half stars.There are a lot of reasons to give this binder five stars.First, it is a definite improvement over previous vinyl binders because it uses a non-stick vinyl.  The vinyl cover will no longer absorb ink from the pages of copies.Second, the ring mechanism is also an improvement.  You need very little pressure on the tab in order to open and close the rings.  However, the rings are still rounded and tend to bend the pages a little when the rings are full.Third, it has four transparent pockets - two on the inside of each cover.  These are great for including cd-roms, DVD's and index pages.Fourth, it is easy to slip a cover sheet on the outside of the front cover so that you can easily label the contents.  There is also a transparent strip on the side of the binder that is transparent so that you can easily insert a spline information paper on the side.Fifth, the binders are relatively lightweight.I would have given these five stars except they are not as "heavy duty" as I had hoped.  When they are full of paper (they will take almost a full ream) they tend to bend.However, I think this is still the best binder out on the market today.

I have owned two of the 3TB Hitachi drives for over a year.  They are quiet, reliable and inexpensive per TB.I purchased this as a third drive for my Apple Mac Pro.  The access (read speed) is seamless on my Mac Pro.  For my main drive, I am running a 300 GB Intel SSD which is, of course, very fast.  I recently moved by iTunes library to the Hitachi to free up about 50 GB on my SSD.  Once I moved the music library for iTunes, there was no noticeable difference in the access speed for the Hitachi from the access speed for the music on the SSD.The read speeds are everything I expected and the drives have performed flawlessly and reliably for over a year.In addition, while running the SSD and three of these Hitachi drives, there is almost no noise from the cabinet from the operation of the drives.  The entire assembly of drives (an SSD and the three Hitachi drives) consume less that 150 watts of power, so their are also very energy efficient.

This book should be mandatory reading for any history classes, law studies and political science curricula.Professor Maine (of Cambridge) wrote this treatise in 1867.  It is a documentation of how ancient laws (especially from ancient Greece and Rome) have influenced our modern societies and systems of law.One of the most illuminating chapters contains his brilliant analysis of the American system of government just after the civil war.Professor Maine points out that the US system of government is based almost entirely on Roman Law.  Many of the important ideas in our seminal documents, such as the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution, derive from the Roman "Jus Gentium."  [The "law" of the People]  The Jus Gentium was the law which Rome used to rule over its empire.  It was designed to guarantee certain rights and freedoms to the people of the empire, notwithstanding their diverse cultural, economic and religious differences.Prof. Maine points out that just as the Romans ruled over the diverse nations and cultures, of the ancient world, by imposing the Jus Gentium upon them, the federal government in the U.S. governs the diverse cultures, economies, religions and geographies of the several states of the Union.He is the only historian who realized that the principal premise of the Jus Gentium was the basis for the U.S. Constitution.  The principal premise of the Roman Jus Gentium was: "omnes homines natur æquales sunt,"  [All men are created equal]  Maine, Henry Sumner (2011-03-17). Ancient Law Its Connection to the History of Early Society (Kindle Location 1094).  Kindle Edition.He points out, brilliantly, that Thomas Jefferson, and most of our founders, were scholars of ancient law and implemented the principles of ancient law in the founding of our country.As this was written just after the American Civil War, Professor Maine's insights give new meaning to President Lincoln's most eloquent Gettysburg Address:  "Four Score and seven years ago, our fathers brought forth onto THIS continent a NEW nation conceived in liberty and dedicated to the proposition that: omnes homines naturâ æquales sunt." [All men are created equal]  . . . . that these honorèd dead shall not have died in vain, . . . and that the 'Jus Gentium' [translated by President Lincoln as: 'Government of the people, by the people and for the people'] shall not perish from the earth."

This series is one of the finest treatments of Western Art and Art History that is available in multimedia.  It is a series that appeals to both experienced art historians, and, persons who want an introduction to art history.This second episode focuses on the cathedrals and churches constructed in Europe from the tenth century (Romanesque period) to the High Gothic period.  It shows how the Middle Age architects used the Roman principles of architecture and engineering, and how they refined Roman building techniques, to create the extraordinary cathedrals and churches of the Middle Ages.  This episode not only focuses on the cathedrals of France and Spain, but, also on the Norman spread of Romanesque architecture to England.  In appreciating this episode, it helps to have viewed the first episode in the series:  The Classical Ideal, but, it is not necessary to view the first episode in order to appreciate this one..The episode focuses on the development of the High Gothic cathedrals in Chartres and St. Deny (in France) and the perfection of the High Gothic cathedrals in England after the Norman conquest.The series then continues, in the next episode, to show the extraordinary contributions that Italian artists made to art and architecture during the Early Renaissance period.  The Early RenaissanceI really enjoyed watching this series.  I own the DVD set, but, found that Amazon's digital download provides better resolution for HD tv's than a progressive scan image from the 1989 DVD set.  Art of the Western WorldMichael Wood (see below) has taken a unique approach to art history in this program.  Instead of telling a story of art with arcane analysis, he presents a series of presentations by art experts that explain Western Art, from the Greeks to present day, in the context of the historical realities in which the Art developed.This series follows a companion book of the same title (although the book is not necessary for viewing the DVD).  ART OF THE WESTERN WORLD From Ancient Greece to Post ModernismI highly recommend this series as an excellent overview of Art History in the West that allows us to understand, not only Art, but, its origins.For those of us who have viewed Michael Wood's documentaries, he needs no introduction. For those of us who haven't, here is a brief summary: Wood has produced over 100 documentaries in this thirty year career as a journalist, scholar and broadcaster. Each of them brings history alive. Much of his focus, in his documentaries, is on dispelling myths and misconceptions about history. His documentaries are scholarly, yet fascinating to even the average viewer. He is a Fellow of the Royal Historical Society, the Royal Society of Arts and the Society of Antiquaries. He is a governor of the Royal Shakespeare Company and a Pro- Chancellor of the University of Staffordshire.Trivia: Wood's charismatic presence on the screen and his looks are appealing especially to women. He was humorously dubbed "the thinking woman's crumpet" by British newspapers.
