This is absolutely true for Konrad Wolf's movie, which attacked censorship in a totalitarian State.In the movie by Konrad Wolf `Goya or the hard way to understanding', based on the novel by Lion Feuchtwanger (centered on Goya's private life), the artist is the direct target of the Holy Office's Inquisition, because of his paintings and diabolic etchings.In `Goya's Ghosts' by Milos Forman, the painter is a kind of neutral observer or helpful middleman between the Holy Office and the family of an innocent victim of the Inquisition and its bestial `question'.However, the message of both movies is crystal clear and highly relevant today; first of all, no inquisitional powers with armies of spies and laws propagating denouncements; and, secondly, no torture, because unbearable pain forces totally innocent people to confess anything asked for, which is then considered as the ultimate proof of their guilt by their barbaric interrogators.The play of the whole cast in Milos Forman's movie is simply fascinating, but it is not fully convincing in Konrad Wolf's film.All men and women of good will should view these remarkably courageous masterpieces.

J. M. Coetzee has always been an ambitious writer, tackling head on major human problems, be those on the individual or on the societal level.‘The Childhood of Jesus’ is in this way not an exceptional Coetzee book, albeit (again) a controversial one, directly (by what it says) or indirectly. It treats recurring themes in his work.First of all, this book is written in impeccable prose, and is a far cry from his Beckettian beginnings.The basic story is very simple: a man is looking for the mother of a very young boy (not his child) in a foreign country that is well organized for the integration of all foreigners who arrive at its shores. Those foreigners should, however, all be ‘washed cleanly’.On the individual and family level, the boy is an exceptionally intelligent human being. He is helped, protected and loved in an exemplary way by his surrogate parents. Are they better, or fitter, than natural ones?Being clever and (therefore) rebellious, the boy has big problems in the existing educational system.On another level, the foster father is a great fan of the frugal diets based on grain in his new country.On the societal level, the foster father becomes a longshoreman, unloading on his back vessels full of sacks of grain, real ‘bestial labour’. He proposes to mechanize the process with a crane. But, the crane is badly handled and hits him. Does this crystal clear image mean that technical progress is a curse for mankind? Because, it destroys jobs, because it makes men idle? As stated in the book: ‘I would not dream of disparaging the work we do. In the time I have spent here I have experienced nothing but comradely love. Imagine having to spend your days on a public bench with nothing to do.’ This is Kropotkin revisited.The grain silos are infested with rats. But those are left alone. A peaceful cohabitation with wild animals (rats) wasn’t a blatant success in the course of human history.The country has also a ‘nurse’ solution for man’s sexual drive.However, the main problem for the surrogate family is the education of the young boy. Being stubborn, the school administration is obliged to put him in a camp with a special regime for difficult children. Will the foster parents, ultimately, accept this authoritarian measure, or will they leave their new fatherland and search for a new utopia for their foster child?‘The Childhood of Jesus’ is a typical Coetzee book. However, as an introduction to his work, I would begin with less ‘utopian’ novels, like the masterpieces ‘Foe’ or ‘Waiting for the Barbarians’.I also highly recommend the movie ‘Disgrace’ by Steve Jacobs, based on J.M. Coetzee’s (also controversial) book and with a sublime John Malkovich in the main role.

Oswald von Wolkenstein is a very original composer, even though he borrowed most of his melodies from colleagues, be they anonymous or not.Word-sounds are an essential part of his music, not only in order to create onomatopoeia, like C. Janequin, but to generate wordplays and to express his message in a memorable way.The textsThis recital covers a very wide range of themes. It contains a hunt song (7 - Tally-ho, companion), a drinking bout (9 - Let's make a lot of noise), a spring song with onomatopoeia (5 - May covers the earth), a dawn (lovers split at dawn) song (13 - Awake, my treasure), a war song (15 - At them), a quarrel between a farmer's wife and her maid (11 - Get up, Maredel), a song about his personal problems (16 - Through Barbary: `my prince is angry with me, because of the envy of wicked people), songs about physical love (4 - Joyfully: `mouth kissing mouth, tongue on tongue, breast on breast, belly on belly, skin on skin pressing eagerly all the time') and (8 - You, my heart's own: `her proud body removes all my sorrow'), a call for God's help (3 - He who hovers above us: `may He help me to fend off all my enemies') and, ultimately love (lament) songs (12 - Cruel lover, where have I lost you), (10 - Ah, this yearning, suffering) and (1 - A nobleman of high birth: `my longing and lamenting never swayed you').The musicThe melodies are mostly simple monophonic lines with sometimes rudimentary counterpoints. Some songs are very rhythmic, like the drinking bout (9), the spring song (5), the quarrel song (11) and the (16 - Through Barbary) which has also an Arabian flavor.The most original part of Oswald von Wolkenstein's scores is the word-sound-music combination, which generates a declamatory, theatrical style. Some of his songs (7, 12) are really short theatre plays, while (11) can be seen as the quintessence of a German operetta.All songs could be sung or played at weekly markets or on Sunday morning after mass by folksingers.The recital is magnificently sung and played by the New London Consort under Philip Pickett.All texts are translated in English, French and modern German.This CD, with its excellent introductions by David Fallows, Pia Ambrosh and Giampiero Bernardini, is a must have for all lovers of classical music

Gabriele Cassone is the Italian Maurice André,His trumpet playing, here together with the virtuoso organist, Antonio Frigé, is simply glorious.This trumpet/organ recital contains some well-known pieces like the voluntaries by J. Stanley, but also rarely heard very appealing scores by Italian composers, like G.M. Trabaci, G.P. Cima and G. Pietragrua.The Voluntaries of the English composers M. Greene and J. Stanley shine by the fantastic echo plays between the trumpet and the organ.This Nuova Era CD published in its magnificent ‘Ancient Music Collection’ is a must have for all lovers of classical music.

This recital of religious music from the 15th century (and before) by nearly unknown composers and written down in `The Old Hall Manuscript', reveals a certain link in the history of Western music between the Gregorian and secular music.Nearly all the texts are catholic classics. The music is not very sophisticated: plainsong melodies with little rhythmic variations.The two songs which stand out are 22 - Are post libamina (At the altar after the libation) by Mayshuet (Matheus de Sancto Johanne) and 25 - Post missarum solennia (After the solemnity of the Mass) (Anon.).Song 22 is remarkable by its text and music. The text is an outspoken reflection on music and singing. A song should be `sweet harmonies, highly lyrical, with a joyful tone'. In the second part of the text (which is not sung on this CD), Mayshuet strongly admonishes singers: they should not seek `vain glory' and certainly not if their `skills fall short'. They should not be `mercenary men (who) change the best gold into base metal and sweet perfumed flowers into nasty smells. Such singers think not about God the man. You, hypocrites, you have never heeded the Holy Gospel.'Song 25 is less original: `we will with sweetly fluent voice sing songs requesting God the fount of all good things.'Both songs shine by their rhythmic variations: voice singing together at different tempi (fast and slow).The songs are brilliantly interpreted by the Hilliard Ensemble.All texts are translated in English.This CD will mostly appeal to all those interesting in the history of Western music.

This CD contains excerpts of other recorded recitals by the New London Consort.Of course, this collection of Medieval and Renaissance music is splendidly played and sung by Philip Pickett's group.But, a comment like `a performance with words appear on the original recordings' is simply not acceptable. The folder doesn't even mention the individual performers (C. Bott).Moreover, trying to find the texts on Internet, like those of the Carmina Burana songs, is a hell of a job.All those interested in this kind of music should (are forced to) buy the original recordings.

The complete scores of the Italian madrigals on this CD have been assembled from different libraries by the musicologist Wolfgang Boetticher, who wrote a fine introduction for this CD. We can only fully agree with him: Lassus' genius provided `magnificent madrigalian images of ecstatic poetry' by Petrarca and other poets, `with detailed musical word-painting'.The textsThe madrigals, `Ben convene', `Ove d'altra montagna' and `Spent' è d'amor' are lover's laments, while in `Al dolce suon', the poet sees light at the end of the tunnel of his misery.For the French/Latin songs, `Lucesit jam o socii' is a drinking song, while `Voir est beaucoup' is a social exhortation: `to see is much, to keep quiet about it even more'.`Praesidium Sara' is a wedding song and `Bestia curvafia pulices' a curse of the flea (all words begin with the p of pulex (flea)).The texts of the four motets are, besides the glorification 'Gloria patri', far more important. `Beati pauperes' and `Beati pacifici' are excerpts of the Gospel of Matthew (5/3-8 & 9-12 - the Beatitudes), with `Blessed are the peacemakers for they will be called children of God'.`Da pacem, Domine' prays for peace, and `Domine, quando veneris' asks the Lord when he will come to judge the world?The MusicThe scores on this CD are all sublime masterpieces: magnificent sound waves with brilliant imitations, heavenly (de)crescendos and astonishing word-paintings. A few examples: `Ahi mi' in `Solo n'andrò' or `quiete fui' in `Praesidium Sara'.The singing is simply glorious and sublime, one of the best (if not the best) ever of Lassus' music.This CD is a must have for all lovers of classical music.One caveat: the texts are translated only in German. Translations on internet generate, however, acceptable results.

This eminent recital contains 11 appealing transcriptions for flute and harp of very well-known melodies by, among others, Bizet, Massenet, Debussy or Rimsky-Korsakov.But, the real highlights of this CD are the rarely heard original pieces for harp solo by Auguste Durand (Waltz op. 83 and Chaconne op. 62) and by Edmund Schucker (Mazurka op. 12).The recital ends with a dazzling transcription of the Tritsch-Tratsch-Polka by J. Straus Jr.A beautifully played CD. Highly recommended.

This is an astonishing CD, as the music, as well as the texts and the interpretation is concerned.M. Posch and M. Ambrosini point out in their excellent introduction that, the troubadours (of the southern part of Europe) were, in general, not wandering minstrels like the `trouvères' (of the North of Europe), but often held high social positions in society.The textsThe subjects of the songs, written in the `langue d'oc' (Provençal) or Catalan, are mostly ideal love, but also political (war), bawdy and religious themes.We see idealized love in the songs of Berenguier de Palou: 1 - `So much I love': `So if ever am held in your arms, so that both of us are of one mind' and 7 - `Such a lady': `noble and fair in demeanour'.Of course, love rhymes with sorrow and loss of liberty: in 11 - `When I see the lark move' by Bernart de Ventadorn: `she has brought death to me'. But, in 3 - `Now I can be satisfied with love' by Peire Cardenal: `Nor am I her captive nor her bond-slave, but I have escaped from her'.Love themes are mixed with war (the crusades) in 5 - `It is fine to sing' by Raimon de Miraval and in 12 - When the days are long in May' by Jaufre Rudel.Another aspect of love is `making love': in 9 - `Praise, now' (Anon.) `you shall not pass a day except on your back, so the abbot says'; or, in the alba song (a couple at dawn after a night together) 6 - `the birds were singing' by Ramon Lull.No wonder that some asks for mercy: in 10 - `Humble, sinful, accused and penitent' by Guiraut Riquier: `I have wasted my time in sinning. I seek mercy, mother of Christ'.The musicAll the songs and the instrumental pieces shine by their beautiful monodic melodies, as do the intimate (5, 10) as well as the more expansive laments (11, 12) or the fiesta exuberance about sex (9).The interpretation of the songs by the late Maria Dolors Lafitte is simply formidable as is the playing by Oni Wytars and the Ensemble Unicorn.Rarely has early Western music of the 12th and 13th century been served so admirably.All texts are translated in English.A must have for all lovers of classical music.

This CD is a perfect introduction to Renaissance music with its broad range of Italian and English madrigals, French chansons, Spanish ensaladas and German Lieder, of which many are highlights of 15th and 16th century music.All the pieces are gloriously sung by The King’s Singers and masterfully played on original instruments by The Consort of Musicke under Anthony Rooley.However, there is one caveat: there are no texts of the songs.Of course, if one is interested in some particular songs, one can find the texts (and eventually also their translations) more or less easily on Internet.So, all in all, five stars for the singers and players, one star for the publisher.

The piano works on this CD are all masterpieces, with their evocation of impressive changing moods, natural sounds and a shocking political event.As R. Schulz notes in his excellent introduction, for L. Janáček `notes mean nothing at all, unless they are steeped in life, blood and nature. Otherwise they are like playthings, quite worthless'.The piano sonata 1.X.1905 `From the street' is a dramatic musical evocation and reflection on a brutal political murder with a bayonet of a man who took part in a demonstration calling for a second Czech university. One hears the shuffles and the killing by a bayonet stab, followed by deeply emotional mourning.The piano pieces `On the Overgrown Path' can be situated, musically speaking, between F. Liszt's `Années de Pélérinage' or E. Grieg's `Lyric Pieces' and C. Debussy's piano suites like `Children's Corner'. They are pure musical expressions of human sentiments and life sounds.`In the Mists' is an imposing `impressionist' suite of 4 complex movements, while `Tema con variazioni (Zdenka Variations)' is a brilliant stylistic exercise.This recital of music by a very much underrated composer is magnificently played by Rudolf Firkusný.A must have for all lovers of classical music.

This CD is a perfect introduction to the music of Josquin Desprez. It contains religious as well as worldly works, with some of his generally best known scores, like El Grillo (7), Petite Camusette (9), Scaramella (5) and `La déploration de la mort de Johannes Ockeghem' (13).The textsThe texts of his religious songs are classic ones, like Ave Maria, Veni Sancti Spiritus, De profundis clamavi, in te Domine speravi. They are praises or calls for mercy and/or help.In `Absalon, fili mi' King David mourns over the death of his rebellious son.The songs about love are pure laments. In (8 - Mille Regretz): `I have such great grief that one will see shortly end my days'. In (10 - Je Me Complains): `I don't have news of him'. In (11 - En l'ombre d'ung buissonet): `I won't love you a grain'. In (12 - Je ne me puis tenir d'aimer): `Receive your friend when he is half dead'.The musicJosquin Desprez's religious music and love songs here are characterized by slow tempi and imitations, perhaps too slow for modern ears.However, in `La déploration de la mort de Johannes Ockeghem' those imitations turn into impressive mournful sound waves.Other highlights of this CD are `El Grillo' (7) with its bright onomatopoeias, together with `Scaramella' (5) and `Petite Camusette' (9) with their appealing rhythmic melodies.This recital is magnificently sung by the Hilliard Ensemble.All texts are translated in English, French and German.Highly recommended.

This splendid album seems to be focused on the religious part of Lassus’ work. But behind the religious varnish (7 – There once was a nun) one can find worldly themes of vital social relevance.TextsThe lyrics deal with nothing less than the cardinal themes of war and peace, life and death, love and aging, the powerful and the helpless, the rich and the poor, justice and injustice.War and peace: In 2 - Ad Dominum 'those who hated peace attacked me, a pacifist, without reason’. 'In 21 - Respicit Dominus: 'the wicked one is a prisoner of his own misdeeds’. In 20 - Veni, Sancte Spiritus 'you, who assembled all people in the unity of faith'.Life, death, love, old age : In 15 – O wine, wine is life. In 3 - Open deliciarum 'all delights of the world will soon come to an end. Death, sorrow and fear invade everyone'. In 9 - In ultima hora 'in the last hour all will perish'. In 13 - Passan vostri triomphi: ‘reigns come and go'. In 18 - Hola, Caron: ‘Love has killed me’. In 12 - Il grave età: 'the burden of old age is accompanied by pain, darkness and terror'.The powerful and the helpless: In 1 - Magnificat: ‘he has put down the mighty from their thrones and exalted the lowly’. In 10 - Deus, which seeds: 'God be the refuse of the poor’.In this world full of bloodshed and misery one can become desperate: 8 - Timor et tremor: 'Fear and trembling have beset me’. But, one can also see a glimmer of hope: 6 - The cold and somber night: ‘the day unfolds its brightness and adorns this grand universe.'MusicLassus’ songs shine through their extraordinary polyphonic sounds (1, 2, 3, 8, 9, 10, 12, 20, 21), their brilliant imitations (2, 3, 6, 8, 12), their beautiful melodies, including the instrumental pieces (11 - ' Susanne un jour' in an arrangement of Giorgio Bassano and 14 - S'io fusse), and their musical interpretations of words and phrases. Some examples: 'tuba' (10), 'exaltavit’ (1), 'fugimi' (5), 'confundar' (8), 'risus' (9), 'mors, dolor’ (3).In (1), 'morietur’ is followed by a silence. In (13) the trumpets announce the Last Judgment. Song (4) is a beautiful lament; Song (7) a sarcastic parody of religious music and song (6) an admirable description of a sunrise.This CD, whose texts are translated into 4 languages (French, English, German and Dutch), also contains a piece of 3 students of Lassus.The songs and instrumental pieces are interpreted and played magnificently by the Capella Sancti Michaelis and the Currende Consort under the direction of Erik Van Nevel. In one word, a sublime CD.

This splendid CD presents Flemish composers who had the Habsburg dynasty as patrons. Besides well known composers, it contains rarely heard music by J. Vaet, J. Regnart, C. Luython and L. de Sayve.The songs have mostly religious themes, but also worldly ones.The textsThe religious texts arethanks (20 - I will sing unto the Lord, because he hath dealt bountifully with me),wishes (19 - He that hath clean hands and a pure heart shall receive the blessing of the Lord),prayers (18 - Out of the belly of hell cried I, and thou heardest my voice), (6 - Stand by me in pain), (1 - Make me poor soul, one with you). (2 - I do not wish, think or strive for anything but what is salutary for me), (4 - Hail Queen, to you ascends our call of exiled children of Eve).But, the most astonishing text of all is the litany `Litania Deiparae Virginis Mariae' (8) with `ivory tower, dripping honeycomb, sealed spring, well of living water, vessel that bring us bread from far away'.Also, captives don't sing (16 - we hanged our harps upon the willows.)While the Lord is the savior in the religious songs, in the worldly ones he is replaced by `the wine God': (14 - This wine rids you from all sorrow.)The songs about love are mostly laments: (7 - How could a heart live without pain when it remembers times of joy that can never return), (10 - You are fiery enough as a lover, my beautiful goddess, only not very faithful), (11 - that ruthless wild creature), (12 - An oppressive sorrow turned me to a senseless stone), (13 - Could I have but enjoyed your beauty for still longer, or else not at all).But, at least one man is happy that his love story is over: (9 - I sing, delivered of sorrow, of sweet and much loved liberty).MusicP. de Monte's music is a mixture of noble, slow, melodic sound waves created by voices and instruments (1, 2, 19, 20). The melodies and imitations in his laments (12, 13) create an atmosphere of real sorrow.A. von Bruck's drinking bout (14) impresses with its lively rhythm, while his (15 - Christ has risen) shines through its melodic line.Other highlights are the sound waves and imitations in (8) by J. Regnart, the remarkable mood of (6 - Adesto, dolori meo) by A. Utendal), the pure melody in (17 - Canzon) by C. Luython and the splendid sounds in (21 - Hodie Christus natus est) by L. de Sayve.This recital is sublimely played and sung by the Currende Consort and the Capella Sancti Michaelis under Erik Van Nevel.All texts are dutifully translated in 4 languages (English, French, German and Dutch)This splendid CD with some very rarely recorded tunes is a must for all lovers of classical music.By the way, there is another version of Psalm 136, 1-4 (here nr. 16) by Boney M.

This astonishing compilation of Italian, Spanish, Judeo-Spanish and Arab-Andalusian music, mostly written by anonymous composers, is a rare find.As E. Enrico notes in his excellent introduction, the music is a reflection on the exploration of new lands, on the defeat of the Moors in Granada, on the expulsion of the Jews and on the consolidation of the power of a catholic monarchy.The textsThe songs capture the spirit of adventure in the mappamundi (world map) songs (1, 16, 17, 18), of the Fall of Granada in (2) `Viva el gran Re Don Fernando' and (3) `Una sañosa porfía' (a furious conflict) by J. del Encina, of the forced conversion of the Moors in (4) `Improvisationes on Tres moricas m'enamoram' (I fell in love with three Moorish girls) by Diego Fernández, and of the expulsion of the Jews in (14) `El paso del Mar rojo' (crossing the Red Sea). `Ah, el novio no quere dinero!' (Oh, the groom wants no money) is a Jewish wedding song.The excerpts of the `Palace Song book' commemorate the Fall of Baza in `En memoria d'Alixandre' by J. de Anchieta. There are also religious (7 - Ay Santa Maria) and worldly songs. The latter about traditional themes like love in (12 - `Pase el agoa' - Cross the water) and in (6 - `Nunca fué pena mayor' -Never was there greater pain by J. de Urreda), or feasting in (13 - `Oy comamos y bebamos' - Today let's eat and drink) by J. del Encina.MusicAll these songs and instrumental pieces shine through their splendid homophonic melodic material, their adequate rhythms, vivid for victories or slow like for the haunting exodus lament (14). Arabian and Turkish influences mark the Judeo-Spanish songs (14, 15) and the instrumental piece (5) with its B'tayhi -M'saddar rhythms (slow with slight increases in tempo).The songs and the music are sublimely interpreted by the Waverly Consort using traditional instruments.All texts are translated in English, except (10 - En Memoria d'Alixandre) for which even the Spanish text is not available (and difficult to find on Internet).This splendid CD is a must for all lovers of classical music.

This magnificent CD is a real discovery. It contains, besides music by P. Rogier, pieces by not well known composers, like G. de la Hèle, G. van Turnhout, P. de Manchicourt and M. Romero (Mathieu Rosmarin).The textsThe main themes are religion and its worldly counterpart love, with their praises, prayers and torments.The religious songs are excerpts of the mass by P. Rogier `Philippus Secundus Rex Hispaniae' composed on notes derived from the vowels in the title of the mass (! Schoenberg is not far away; but it was already done by Josquin Desprez before);There are also praises like '10 - Regina caeli' and `17 - Laudate Dominum' both by P. Rogier;and prayers/torments: `deliver me of eternal death on the fearsome day of judgment' in (16) by M. Romero; `have mercy on me' in (2) by G. de la Hèle and in (11) by P. Rogier; `let your ears be attentive to the voice of my supplications' in (8) by P. de Manchicourt.The Lord is replaced by the loved one in the worldly songs of praise: `to look into eyes that are so divine' (15) by M. Romero; `I saw my precious girl, like a dove' in (9) by P. de Manchicourt; `even when I am dead, my spirit will remember you' in (5) by G. van Turnhout; and `love follows beauty' in (12) by P. Rogier.Love's land is also sown with torments and sorrows: `I take pleasure in cruel death for you have wounded me" in (4) by G. van Turnhout and `her beautiful eyes were every day a new burden' in (14) by M. Romero.Therefore, P. Rogier gives perfect advice in (13 -Lal Amour): `to live free of worries, flee from love if it is not requited'. `Physical love' is a main aspect of worldly love (not of spiritual love): `if he was too sleepy the right recipe would be to take a lover' in (7) by P. de Manchicourt and `my behind (not my `bottom', as in the translation) signals that you'd better be off' in (6) by P. de Manchicourt.The musicThe highlights of this recital are the appealing melodic lines of (5, 8, 13), the rhythms and imitations in (6, 7, 10, 14, 15) and the beautiful sound waves of (16, 17).The recital is magnificently sung and played by the Currende Consort and the Capella Sancti Michaelis under Erik Van Nevel.All texts are translated in 4 languages (English, French, German and Dutch).This rare find, with an excellent introduction, is a must for all lovers of Renaissance music.

This splendid CD contains the highlights of A. Willaert's (recorded) French and Italian songs and their remarkable texts.The textsThe most astonishing song is (1) `Qual dolcezza giamai', where the sweetness of the songs seduces the senses and the souls of those who hear them. `The air becomes serene, the sea is calm: Love reigns here.' In other words: music is love.The main theme of the other songs is love, all kinds of love and its torments.Eternal love in (17): `even when I am dead your spirit will remember me.'Pure love in (5): `Let's be merry, my darling'.Jealousy in (12): `because you are jealous, you are always near me.'Laughing out loud in (23): the mad little woman, she does nothing but laugh'.Sorrow in (9, 16, 22): `here I am now with only the wind in my hands.'A tryst in (20): `come without fear and don't bother to knock'.But also venal love, notwithstanding (2): `Love is neither beautiful nor to be cherished if it is obtained with money.'In (3) `In the market of Arras': `Girl, listen, you'll get some money'; in (8) `Nasty old hags set an ambush'.Yet, not everyone agrees to have full physical contact: in (19) `her friend gave her a kiss and ardently desired to play Love's games, but she replied: go water your violets'.Music(16) `Once I had a neighbour' is A. Willaert's most beautiful song (here intabulated by G. Abondante) and a highlight of Renaissance music, with its sublime melody and splendid timing of pauses.Other songs shine through their pure melodies (3, 7, 19) or their rhythmic melody (20, 23). There is also no lack of humor (15, 19, 23).The pieces are sublimely sung (with extremely comprehensible pronunciations) by K. Van Laethem and splendidly played by the Romanesque group. They caught the perfect rhythm and intonation of some of A. Willaert's most recorded songs: (8) `Vecchie letrose' and (15) `Cingari simo'.This magnificent recital, with also works by other composers, is a must have for all lovers of Renaissance music.N.B. the introduction contains some errors: `The versions for solo voice and lute of `A quand' a quand'haveva una vicina' and of `O mio bene' are intabulations of works by the Spanish vihuela player Diego Pisador' should be as follows: `The version for solo voice and lute of `A quand' a quand'haveva una vicina' is an intabulation by the Italian lutenist Giulio Abondante and the version of `O mio bene' an intabulation by the Spanish vihuela player Diego Pisador.' The original compositions are by Adrian Willaert.

This heavenly recital of songs and instrumental music of the Italian Renaissance contains compositions of well known composers, but also of not very well known or even anonymous ones.The textsThe themes of the songs are love, life and death, the woes of the world and music itself (7 – ‘I wouldst that you a song might sing’ by A. Scandello).The love songs are mostly laments, like 9 – ‘I cannot thee abandon’ by P. Cesena, but also stories of happy encounters (18 – ‘I shall return twice daily’ by P. Azzaiolo) or mighty outburst of happiness in 4 – ‘a thousand upon a thousand times each day I wouldst thee leave so sweet returning be’ by C. de Rore. As M. Materassi tells in his excellent introduction, this last text has been heavily parodied (supposedly, because people asked themselves: why not more?).The woes of the world and death are the subject of 1 – ‘I lived as an eagle’ by S. Lando: ‘midst plaints, sighs, pangs and pains go I forth all my life consuming and like a swan then shall I die singing’; in 13 – ‘Oh my sweet life’ by A. Willaert: ‘I suffer like snow beneath the sun’; in 3 - ‘The husband’s death’ by P. Cambio: ‘the husband’s death do I await. But I fear that I first shall die’; and in 6 – ‘Happy, contented spirits’ by V. Ruffo: ‘how parting doth us burden of such a lovely shepherd’.Music – HighlightsThe two instrumental pieces by anonymous composers, (2 – Canario) and (10 – Pavana della ‘La Battaglia’ inspired by ‘The Battle of Marignan’ by C. Janequin), shine through their expressive melodies.The pieces (7) by A. Scandello and (18) by F. Azzaiolo impress by their vivid rhythm, while the songs (3) and (11) by P. Cambio stand out with their changes of rhythm.The song (1) by S. Lando has a sublime melodic line.The interpretation by Roberta Invernizzi and the Academia Strumentale Italiana is simply sublime.This CD (all texts are translated in English) is a must have for all lovers of Renaissance music.

This sublime recital contains many highlights of the French chanson of the Renaissance with beautiful melodies, sensuous evocations, brilliant imitations and echo plays and true laments.ThemesThe themes are love, eating and drinking (10) combined with prayers (17, 18), nature (3 - bird songs), and the most important theme of all, peace (23).The songs about love are mostly laments, like `nothing but bitterness, spite and torment all their life for poor, weeping lovers' (20). But, there are also high praises for the loved one, like `my sweet pleasure, my sweet dove' (21) and, of course, of the delights of `physical love': `then I made her lovely body dance, the dance of the happy hop' (16) or more scabrously: `your behind shall serve as a trumpet' (5).HighlightsFor the songs about love, `So long as I am in my prime' (8) by C. de Sermisy and `Good day my heart' (21) by Lassus shine through their beautiful melodies.Sorrow drips from `It is nothing but bitterness' (20) by C. Le Jeune and from `Beautiful one, who holds my life' (15) by J. Tabourot.Suggestive rhythms and imitations evoke physical love in `Come now Perrette' (5) by C. Janequin, `God's truth' (16) by Vassal, `A young monk' (25) by Lassus and `Margot, tend the vines' (12) by J. Arcadelt.`The song of the birds' (3) by C. Janequin displays bright onomatopoeias of bird songs. C. Janequin's work was considered by J. Huizinga as a symptom of the `decline' (of the Middle Ages), while, in fact, it constitutes a return to nature from the spiritual (after)world of religion.`Beauteous are crystal' (23) by Lassus tops them all with its appealing melodic line and its all important message of `Beauteous peace alone adorns the world'.All the French texts are translated in English without any censoring, although popular trivialities are converted into a more `respectable' vocabulary.This eminent recital is sublimely sung by the Scholars of London. It is a must have for all lovers of classical music.

This album is a compilation of Renaissance music magnificently sung by different choirs, but mostly by the Huelgas Ensemble under Paul Van Nevel.It contains music by well known composers (Josquin Desprez), but also by less known names (Costanzo Festa, Serafino Dall’Aquilano).Unfortunately, the producer committed a deadly sin by omitting to publish the texts of the songs in the accompanying comment. Fortunately, they can (more or less easily, with a translation) be found on the internet.HighlightsOf the instrumental pieces, the frottola by F. de Lurano (8) shines through its beautiful melody.Another frottola ‘Quando ritrovo la mia pastorella’ (When I meet my shepherdess) by C. Festa is also a melodic highlight, yet not a moral one: you can make love to me, but only for money.Other highlights are the pure melody in ‘Tu solus qui facis mirabilia’ (You alone can do wonders), the onomatopoeias in ‘El Grillo’ (the cricket) or the beautiful sound waves (imitations and echoes) in ‘Miserere mei, Deus’, all by Josquin Desprez.But, by far the best part of this CD is the astonishing canon for 36 voices ‘Deo Gratias’ by Johannes Ockeghem. This sublime short composition alone is well worth the very modest price of this album.Highly recommended.

This magnificently sung recital contains some not very well known gems, like ‘The Willow Song’ and the arrangement of the folk song ‘The Turtle Dove’ by R. Vaughan-Williams, ‘O magnum mysterium’ by G. Gabrieli or ‘O for the wings of dove‘ from ‘Hear my prayer’ by F. Mendelssohn.And then, there is, of course, ‘Spem in alium non habui’ by T. Tallis, one of the astounding eternal highlights of western music. The King’s College Choir’s interpretation is simply outstanding.A must have.

This is a well-made, heavy duty cord.I am using it to feed power to my Level I EVSE for my electric vehicle.I feed 12 Amps through it 12 hours straight almost every night.  Never gets warm.  Plugs are good quality on both ends.  It lives outside all the time and I don't see it having any issues being outside.They tell you not to connect an EVSE to an extension cord because in order to do it safely, you have to have a specific, minimum gauge of wire in the cord AND you cannot exceed a maximum length.  Most people do not understand this, and if you do it wrong you can easily set your house on fire, damage the charger, etc. Rather than explain all that, they just say don't do it for liability reasons. This IS the correct gauge for a Level I EVSE as long as you do not exceed the 25 foot length of the cord.

I was looking at this for the dog area.  Like everybody else, I'm trying to get my dog to "mark" somewhere different than his favorite spot.  You can get plastic versions for less money, or something that is basically made out of real, heavy-duty pipe fittings for hundreds of dollars more.This "in the middle" product is fine for what it is.  It just has to look real from across the yard and survive the elements.  If you inspect it closely, you will find that the metal is not real thick and the welding is rough and not particularly well done.  You cannot notice any of that from a distance.  It looks completely genuine out in the yard.I did carefully clean it (it arrives kind of filthy), got some clear coat spray paint and put several coats of that on it before I installed it in the dog run.  I also dug a little hole a few inches deep where I wanted it to go and filled the hole under the base with gravel to promote drainage, then filled the entire inside of the hydrant with gravel to stabilize it and keep it from getting knocked over in the wind.  I assume the (likely cheap) paint would not survive the elements and the "use" by the dogs very long otherwise.I imagine that with those extra steps it should survive outside a few years before I'll have to repaint it.  I suspect that it would fall apart pretty rapidly if you allow the paint to start peeling.  There is not a lot of metal there to loose any to rust.So yes, it is relatively cheaply made in China and the quality isn't amazing, but it is good enough that you can make it work with a trivial amount of additional work.  It isn't going to fade and crack because it is made of plastic, so I think it was a good decision to spend a little more for a metal version.  If you don't want to maintain this, you could get a cheap plastic one and replace it when it inevitably falls apart.  But that seems unnecessarily wasteful to me.  I'd rather just buy this and paint it every few years to keep it looking good.
These seem decently well-made.

This product should be called "Giant Volume Knob" because that is what it really is.  The description is so vague I wasn't sure whether I was getting a foot pedal that you used to switch back and forth between headphones and speakers like a guitar foot pedal or something.  That isn't what you get.The thing is about the size of a hockey puck in person and you will want to find an accessible place for it on your desk.You plug your headphones into a jack on the side of the hockey puck.  Then the black cord connects to your speakers and the green one connects to your computer's speaker or headphone jack.The entire top of the hockey puck is one big, physical volume control knob.  You end up setting it up so full volume flows out of the computer, then you adjust the volume level you actually want using this big knob, which is way easier than hunting for the setting on your computer.  No more getting your eardrums blasted out when you accidentally put on headphones with the computer volume all the way up.There is a nice switch on the side of the hockey puck that toggles between outputting the sound to your headphones or the external speaker.  You never have to plug or unplug your headphones again.  Nor will you ever have to mess with your sound settings on the computer again - instead you now have this awesome, big honking physical knob on your desk.Since constantly unplugging and plugging in your headphones puts wear on them, it probably means your headphones will last a little longer, or at least they will ultimately fail in some other way.The instructions are so bad you might as well not even look at them.  Fortunately, I just told you everything you need to know to set it up correctly.The product itself seems sturdy and well-made.  It doesn't feel like it is going to go skating around your desk or fall apart immediately.I am glad I spent a little more to get this vs. some of the cheaper options out there.  Once you realize that you are going to be using the knob and the switch constantly, you will be glad you got something that is pretty solid and seems well put together.I didn't really get that I was getting something that both controlled the volume and allowed me to keep everything plugged in constantly.  It is a big upgrade over awkwardly plugging things in and unplugging them constantly.  Assuming it holds up, it was well worth what I paid for it.
What an awesome little flashlight this is.  It is solidly made and gets really bright for its size.  Runs on regular batteries.
These are handy for short trips.  They keep your medicine segregated and fit easily into your toiletry bag.

There are a lot of sketchy USB power packs out there.  This isn't one of them.It is a quality product that is solidly put together and works well.  I recently used it on an extended camping trip and it kept all of our phones and such powered up without any issues.  There are LED status indicators letting you know how much capacity is left and it even has a convenience flashlight built into it that would probably last weeks.If you are trying to figure out what size to get, here is a little help.  You can get little tiny chargers that are barely larger than a lipstick and basically have enough zip to maybe charge your phone once before they die.  Most of them only charge at the slower 1.0 Amp speed.  You can move up from there to chargers that are about as big as a deck of cards.  Some of them will charge at the higher rate that iPads and many modern phones prefer and some of them have enough zip to power up your iPad once or your phone a couple of times before they die.This is a significant step up from those smaller sizes, without an enormous increase in size and weight. Now you are looking at something that can recharge an iPad more than once or a typical, modern smart phone numerous times before it gives out.That said, this 16,000mAh size is just about as big a portable USB charger as you would want to actually carry anywhere.  It is small enough that it could live in your carry-on luggage without weighing you down too much.  It is a bit much for hiking unless you are going on a multi-day trip and really really need this much juice.The sweet spot for something this size is extended power outages, international travel in situations where you don't trust the local grid or there isn't one, etc.  It is not something you would want to carry around every day in places with a reliable grid.

This fan runs either on USB or AA batteries.  On USB, on High, it puts out a slight breeze.  Enough to be pleasant if you are a foot or two away.  But forget sticking this any distance away, it just doesn't have enough zip.Weirdly, if you pull it off USB and let it run on the batteries, its speed increases noticeably.  It puts out a bit more air and gets significantly noisier.  There is not much difference between low on batteries or high on USB.The noise from it on USB is not perfectly even.  That is annoying in a very quiet space, but not noticeable otherwise.So this is a fairly marginal desk fan that gets buy in like an office situation where you already have A/C and all you want is just a little air movement.  But even in an untaxing environment like that, it just gets by.If you are seriously hot or expecting this to do something useful somewhere where there is no A/C and you really want a stiff breeze - keep looking.

I have had this cooler for a couple of years now and been very happy w/it.  It just came back from a 5 night camping trip.  We started out with 12 of those little bags of ice you get at the store and the cooler was full of food/drinks etc. on top of all that ice.At the end of the trip with temps in the 70s all week, there was still some ice left and the milk was still good.  I imagine in blazing heat or direct sun it would still survive a few days, although probably not 5-6.The only downside is the size and shape.  It is a good bit taller than the usual size/shape and so it may not fit in the trunk of your car.  I have a full-size pick up truck with a cover.  I can't put this in the bed with the cover closed - it sticks up too high.  If you are putting it in an SUV it will probably work, or if you want to put it in the back seat it will likely work, but it will not fit everywhere because it is so tall.  So take the dimensions and measure where you want to put it before you buy it to make sure it will fit.Minor downside is that the drain isn't completely flush with the bottom and so it is almost impossible to get 100% of the water out while it is full of stuff.Mine has held up pretty well and has been used a lot.  I am actually on here trying to find this same cooler in a lower profile design for my truck, that is how much I like it.

My wife and I each have a work phone and a personal phone.  Then we each have kindles, and we have an iPad.  That is a lot of stuff to keep juiced up.  This small thing, plus a few short cables, helps to keep everything juiced up without creating a mess of charging spaghetti all over the kitchen counter.  It does seem to charge the devices that can take higher amps faster, although we've not tested that carefully.

Good for a Paperwhite Kindle.  Fits easily with room to spare.  If you prefer not to have a case on your kindle or tablet but want something cheap to protect it when traveling, this is a good choice.  It is just a little neoprene case, it isn't hard-sided or anything, so it will just protect from modest impacts, scratches etc.
well made and doesn't leak.

This is a well-made flashlight that throws an absurdly bright light at its highest levels while also using regular, AA batteries.The benefit of this flashlight is that now you don't have to fool around with expensive lithium cells or powerful but slightly dangerous rechargeable batteries in order to get a flashlight that is powerful enough for almost any real need with this.  It throws a nice wide pattern and on high it feels like it is lighting up the whole woods in front of you.I wouldn't hike with it - it weighs too much.  But for walking the dogs in a rural area after dark, where you want to be able to reach out and see whether that rustle in the woods is just a deer or is actually a bear or Sasquatch, it will definitely do the job.I went with the natural light version just because I hate that stark, unnatural looking "cool light".  It definitely does make colors look normal and more natural than some of my "cool light" flashlights.  If you are worried about the fact that you'll lose a few lumens over the other version, trust me, you won't miss them.

This is a cleverly designed candle lantern.  The candles sit in little retaining cylinders with springs underneath them, so as the candle melts, the flame stays in exactly the same, ideal spot.  The flame is protected by glass so it works even in moderate wind and the three candles are apparently powerful enough together that you could eventually boil water by placing a container on the flat metal top of the lantern (although I have never tried that).  But while this design is clever, it is running on a technology that would be perfectly familiar to Benjamin Franklin.In today's modern world, is something that runs on candles practical?  Not really.  You can get an LED lantern that is smaller, lighter, more durable, gets much brighter, doesn't use expensive candles, and has no fire hazard associated with it.But I just returned from a five day car camping trip, and I barely used my big LED lantern, while this thing got lit every single night.The LED lantern got relegated to helping me do dishes or other task-based duty where I needed a lot of light.  But then it got switched off almost immediately in favor of this lantern, which ran from dark until bedtime.The harsh "cool" white light from a modern LED lantern just cannot compare with the pleasant, warm, soothing glow of this lantern.  I used this in conjunction with a few of the smaller UCO tea light lanterns and it made my campsite such a pleasant place after dark.  Hiking around the larger campground after dark, I saw LED lantern after LED lantern, and there was really no comparison in how much nicer my campsite was than those who had fallen for the latest technology.You go camping because you want to enjoy yourself.  This is a small luxury item with an absolutely huge payoff in ambiance.  This is one of the best things I bought for the most recent trip, and it is definitely coming with me on future adventures.Yes, you could also use it as an emergency light source, provided you put up enough of the relatively expensive, special candles it takes.  But it is probably not the most cost-effective way to handle that situation.  If you are just looking for a utilitarian light, buy an LED lantern and some extra batteries for it.  This is a lantern to use when you want more than just lumens out of your light source.  In that role, it absolutely excels.I would definitely buy the little protective neoprene sleeve for it.  Even then, it should be handled carefully.  The candles last a good long time, but buy them in bulk, they are much cheaper that way.

These are the "GI water bottle" size, now made in sturdy plastic.  When you handle these, you realize that the government spent some time thinking about the ideal size/shape for a water bottle.  These are easy to handle, easy to fill, easy to drink from and can be tucked into the side of your pack or carried on your hip with an appropriate carrier, etc.The only thing wrong with them is the same thing wrong with all of these water bottles - they weigh a lot in comparison to the cheap, disposable water bottles that can be had for a fraction of the price and are durable enough to last through many many refillings.You also have to be careful about maintaining them - which basically means keeping the cap off when they are empty, so mildew etc. can't form on the inside which would then be hard to clean because of the narrow opening.  But as long as you rinse them out after you use them and store them with the cap open, they work great.

I used these on a 5 day camping trip, in situations where the ambient humidity was often 90% or more.  Unlike my small microfiber towel I was using as a washcloth that I could never get dry, these things were dry EVERY MORNING.  Even when it rained the night before and they had been soaked by rain and only had a few hours of dry weather to dry out, they were dry enough to use comfortably at 6AM.When you get them, the fabric feels kind of weird, like it won't be absorbent enough.  But in practice it works just like a regular towel would.  They didn't get smelly after five days either.These weigh so little you can even carry a nice big, bath towel sized one with you without any meaningful weight penalty.  I also keep a smaller one in my day pack just for wiping off sweat etc. because the weight penalty is so trivial there is really no reason not to have a towel along.Sometimes you buy stuff on Amazon based on the glowing reviews and it turns out that the hype was BS.  This isn't one of those things.  If you are looking for a camping/hiking towel, just stop looking and buy these.  You won't regret it.

I like these - they are comfortable and have decent-sized pockets.  They are very lightweight and dry quickly.They do have the included underwear sewn in like a bathing suit.  So basically you must wear these commando - they are quite uncomfortable otherwise.I use them for hiking and they are ideal for that purpose.  No binding or chafing, even after very long hikes.

I used this on an extensive hiking/camping trip.  It was great.  I never worried about the kindle getting ruined and it works really well with the Kindle.  It even has the magnet catch so when you open it, the Kindle turns on automatically.  You cannot charge it in the waterproof sleeve obviously and the kindle is a little hard to get in and out of it.  So I think of this not so much as an everyday cover as something for traveling/beach/camping/hiking etc.Fortunately, the kindle paperweight lasts a long time on a single charge if you turn off wireless.  So this can easily work for even a long trip.

I bought a couple of these to put around the campsite.  Boy they are so much nicer than an LED lantern.  They burn well even in moderate wind.  I had no trouble with them even in winds that made them difficult to initially light.  They also burn cheap tea light candles so they cost almost nothing to run.They do get extremely hot in use - I would never use them in a tent or near anything flammable without very very close supervision.  When packing them - I wrap them in a towel because the glass lanterns could break otherwise.  But I like the clear glass version of these because they give off the most light.

I put this in a tent to protect the floor from our cot legs.  It now has wear spots where the legs crushed/destroyed the material.  So while it looks nice and catches dirt and isn't too heavy, it also isn't particularly sturdy.  I imagine any heavy furniture you put on it will damage the material.  It did protect the tent floor on a 5 day trip, but at the cost of permanent damage to the mat.  I may try to find a spot to use it where nothing heavy sits on it, but I am disappointed in the build quality of this.

I bought this for camping and hiking.  At first I really liked it.  It is not overwhelmingly huge like a lot of the G-shock watches and has a lot of nice features.  I particularly liked the barometric pressure trend graph.  When you are out hiking with no cell service to check the weather forecast, this will give you a hint as to the likely weather for the next few hours at least.Unfortunately, it did not fully survive its first, short camping trip.  The inside of the glass fogged, showing that the waterproof seal has failed.  The watch still works, but a sports/outdoors watch that is not waterproof is essentially useless.  At this point, you have to take it off if you want to wash your hands with it.  So much for 100 ft water-resistance.To be clear, this went on a few moderate day hikes and was never abused or subjected to any rough treatment.  It hasn't even picked up any scratches yet it is still so new.  The waterproof seal died with less than 30 days worth of time on my wrist.The motto of Spovan, the company that makes this watch is "To Be Great".  That motto is accurate, although not in the way they probably intended.  It could be great in the future, but it sure isn't now.So do yourself a favor - if you are thinking about trying to get a knock-off G-Shock watch to save a little money instead of a real one, learn from my bad experience and just suck it up and buy a watch from a manufacturer with an established reputation that knows what they are doing.  For this watch to fail after such a short time is inexcusable.

It is nicely constructed, but I didn't find it terribly comfortable once it was filled up with a cell phone, set of keys, wallet, and the usual hiking necessities like a headlamp, simple first aid kit, small pocket knife, etc.  I found it rode better on one of my hips than in the small of my back once it had a little weight in it.  Basically,it feels ok when it is about half full or less, but if you expect to fill it, you may be disappointed in this.I've decided I just don't like fanny packs that much and am going to a small, light backpack instead.  Better a mostly empty backpack than one of these completely full.

Water tastes AWFUL coming out of this thing.  I have filled and replaced it twice with fresh water and it still really tastes like drinking a chemistry set.  I am leaving it sit with full water for a while hoping it will improve over time.  But for now this thing is NOT GOING on my next trip because I would have to be near death to want to drink from it.The construction of it is fine - it seems sturdy and doesn't leak.  But color me disappointed that they can't seem to make it out of things that don't leach disgusting chemicals into the water.EDIT:  After the third water change, I just left it full outside in the hot weather, hoping the heat would eventually cook off whatever was making it taste so nasty.  It took over a month, but the taste issue has finally receded to the point I can use it.  So do not buy this unless you can put in the time/effort required to get the nasty taste out of it.  My guess is that it would have taken even longer in cold weather.  I don't know about using hot water in it, but if you don't melt it, that might work too.
It is a hat.  You put it on your head.  You are warm.  It is comfortable and seems to be well-made.

A flat, clean surface for preparing food, eating, etc. is not exactly something you find in nature very often.  While obviously an unnecessary luxury, it doesn't add a horrible amount of weight to your pack.  After dinner, it even goes into my tent at night as a mini bedside table for my glasses, book, flashlight, etc. (except in bear country).It is very nicely finished and very solid when you put it together.  There is no flex in it - it really is rock solid.Think of it like a TV tray that can be dissembled - that is about the size it has when it is together.  It definitely makes eating in the back country a little more comfortable.Two things I really don't like:(1) there is lettering on the top of the table and a QC look up code.  Both are permanently attached to the table - you cannot remove them.  That is ugly and really mars the otherwise pretty brushed blue metal finish. That is something I would care a lot more about if this wasn't just a piece of outdoor gear.  As it is, I can live with it.(2) the ends of the little feet that hook into the table are sharp and it takes some effort to assemble/disassemble the table.  So you have to be careful every time you take it apart or put it together not to scratch yourself.  You also have to be kind of careful putting it back into the little storage sack it comes with to make sure you don't rip the sack or scratch the table.  The design would be better if there were rubber caps covering the bare metal of the ends that clip into the table.  Once it is assembled, the sharp parts are hidden and it works great.

These are nice, sturdy and functional.  They are comfortable to wear even when hiking in rough terrain.They fit the Nalgene canteen perfectly.The only rub is that you don't really want to get the canvas fabric wet, since it will take a while to dry.  So I fill the canteens at home, dry the outside, and then put them in the covers before going hiking.  Take them out to refill them too.

There is a reason these are notably cheaper than the other bottles like this on Amazon - the quality is poor.  Spend more money and get something of better quality.  The "stainless steel" on one rusted almost immediately - I have had lots of other stainless steel water bottles and never had one rust in normal use and certainly not within the first few uses.  So either the steel isn't stainless at all or it is of such low quality that it might as well not be stainless.It wasn't enough money to bother to return it.  But I wouldn't buy this again.
Bought two of these.  One of them leaked at the valve and had to be replaced.But after that, they seem to be holding up fine.
These are nice.  I use them to store sleeping bags and such when they aren't in compression sacks.  Quality seems fine.

I like it - the quality seems excellent.  The compression sack it comes with is high quality and it compresses down to a very small size.  It is fairly thin and fairly light, but does have decent heat retention.It is not some miracle however.  Think more like the performance of a single, heavy wool blanket without anywhere near the weight of one.It claims it would keep you comfortable down to 45F.  That is bunk - at least if you are sleeping in a t-shirt and boxers.  Think more like 55F if it is the only thing you are using to stay warm at night and you aren't wearing heavier clothes.So I think this is either (1) something you use by itself in the summer, letting you save a lot of weight vs. a traditional bag; or (2) in conjunction with a lighter weight summer bag to stretch that bag's performance into the shoulder seasons.I'm 6'4" and I wish it was a few inches longer.  It basically just covers me on the long side with no slack.You should probably not store it long-term in the compression sack, and there is no larger bag included with it.For what it cost, it was a good purchase.
It is really bright.  It seems very warm.  It seems to be well-made, like everything Carhartt makes.  I am a big guy with a large head and it fits me fine.

I spent a while looking at the various choices for one of these heat reflective blankets.  What I wanted it for was for camping in cooler weather, to reflect heat back up from underneath me without having to drop big bucks on a big, heavy, zero degree sleeping bag.So that means I wanted it to be lightweight, tough-enough to hold up, and most importantly QUIET.  The little Mylar emergency blankets rattle horribly and those blue plastic tarps aren't much better.  Why I picked this one over some of the cheaper alternatives is that the backing isn't basically that same plastic material they make blue tarps out of.  Instead it is fabric.It isn't completely silent, but it definitely doesn't crinkle and crackle so much when you lay on it that it will make you insane.  The weight is also pretty decent - the tarp outside of the package weighs 320 grams on my scale.  It also packs down to a fairly small size pretty easily.  As for durability, time will tell on that.  It isn't super thick and so if you don't care at all about it making noise, maybe you'd be better off with one of those versions made out of the blue tarp material, but for what it is, it seems to be pretty well made.  I think it should work well for my planned use and it is big enough to not only go under my sleeping pad but basically become a kind of floor across a good chunk of my tent.  Definitely room for both my sleeping bag and gear to sit on it - protecting the tent floor.  Although the fabric is folded over at the corners to give double thickness at the grommets, I would probably not use this to make a shelter with unless it was a true emergency - it really is more of a blanket than a tarp.I can't comment on colder weather performance yet (it is June when I am writing this).

This works as expected.  It powers my camera just fine.  However, when you try to shoot video with it - it introduces unacceptable levels of hum into the audio.  For still work it would be fine.  However, it is not great for video, which is the primary thing I bought it for.I will keep it because I also use this camera for astrophotography and it should be fine for that as well.But the only way you can use this for video is if you are capturing audio externally or adding it in post, etc.

You can go buy a $20 compass or you can spend a bit more and get this.  You should spend more.This thing is very cool.  It is very accurate, dampens quickly and lets you shoot accurate bearings very quickly once you get the hang of how to use it.  Yes, it isn't the lightest compass out there, but that is because it is built like a tank.  The whole thing is just extremely high quality.  Given that I am just a hiker and backpacker - I expect it will last me the rest of my life, easily.  Given what a vital piece of kit a compass is - I am perfectly ok with the weight/size/quality trade-off.I agree with the other reviewers that there is really no need to spend more for tritium.  If you are thinking this will work like the luminescent hands of your wristwatch - glow very dimly for a few minutes and then go out, you are in for a nice surprise.I hit it with nothing more powerful than a hiking headlamp at close range for a few seconds.  It glowed so brightly you could read the entire dial.  It stayed that way for several minutes.  Eventually the glow lowered down so you can only see the glowing bits - but that includes everything you need to use the compass, including being able to read bearing numbers off the dial and even shoot new bearings.  It stays like that for 20-30 minutes at least.  And that is after just a few seconds of light.I also checked it using the red LEDs on the headlamp.  They will not make the compass light up like a Christmas tree the way a strong white light will, but you can even charge the glowing bits with a red LED to avoid ruining your dark adaption.I can understand why the military would need a tritium one - it means you can use the compass without showing any light at all.  But I am struggling to imagine any realistic civilian situation where this one wouldn't work at least as well.  So I think you can get this safely and save the extra cost of the tritium one.

This is a good set of silicone pot holders.  They are a bright, cheerful orange in person.They are not hard to wash off or clean.  The design has a lot of texture to help improve grip, but it does not result in a bunch of nooks and crannies that are hard to keep clean.  They are a nice upgrade from cloth pot holders that need to go into the clothes washer if you spill anything on them.They do a good job at not transmitting heat, even though they aren't super thick.  They flex easily so they go around pot handles easily.  They have a good grip, so you can use them as small trivets and the pot won't slide around on top of them.

This is a nice camp knife.  It is light enough to take backpacking, comes already very sharp and has a good, comfortable handle.  The blade is big enough to be useful for a lot of tasks, without adding a lot of weight.The fire starter in the handle works just fine.  There is a nice edge on the back of the knife designed to work with the fire steel and so it throws a considerable shower of sparks.  I've used it to light fires, light my cookstove, etc.  It twist-locks into the handle securely.  You aren't going to lose the fire starter because it fell out of the handle.Mora knives are high quality and this is no exception.  It is stainless steel so maintenance is a bit easier than with a carbon steel knife.The sheath locks the knife in securely, and I like that it is bright orange so it is unlikely to get lost in the woods or down inside your pack.I don't like that the sheath isn't reversible - I'm a lefty and so if I wanted to wear this knife, it would either be backwards or on the wrong side.  A minor inconvenience for a utility knife like this.I see this as an inexpensive, high quality companion knife to a larger blade, saw or axe if I have to do more serious work like batoning wood, chopping, etc. while out in the woods.  Although I suppose it could be pressed into that role in an emergency, the blade isn't that long and it really isn't designed for that kind of work.  It is more the knife you use for cutting paracord, light wood working, etc.

See my reviews of the other two Arkansas stones in this system (Soft Arkansas and Hard Arkansas) for a more detailed review of the entire thing.This is the last of the three stones.  The stone feels almost mirror smooth when you run your finger over it.  That is how fine the grit is.  You bring knives that are already pretty close to done to this stone as the last step.Here is where the scary sharp edge that will cut paper like butter gets laid down.This is the most expensive stone, but also the most important one.  If you are going to go to the effort of free-hand sharpening a knife with stones and honing oil, spend 15-20 minutes or more working on just one knife, the thing ought to come out as sharp as a razor.  Almost any sharpening system can get a blade reasonably sharp.  You are making the extra effort to get to something even better.This is the stone that gets you there.What it does for your knives is just amazing.  The first time I used these stones, I wanted to practice my technique with a junky old kitchen knife that was dull as anything and basically worthless.  I managed to get it decently sharp with the other two stones - sharp enough that no one would have considered it dull.  I could have left it that way and used it and it would have worked just fine.But instead I gave it a few minutes on this stone.  It is now the sharpest knife in my house, by a wide margin.  The boost this gives to the final edge is really quite amazing.

I discuss the entire system of these three stones in the first review (see "Soft Arkansas" by the same company).The bottom line is that I am very impressed with how well these three stones work.Some people say you can get the Soft Arkansas, skip the Hard Arkansas and go straight to the Black Arkansas.I guess that depends on how much you value your time versus your money.  I do think that the Hard Arkansas has value, because it means you'll spend less time on the Black Arkansas stone because you've used this intermediate grit.  It is also where I would start with a knife that was already in ok shape.If this stone cost as much as the Black Arkansas, I'd probably agree with the folks who only use two stones and just recognize I'll need more time for each knife.  But given that this isn't nearly as expensive, it is a nice time saver.  It is the one you can omit if you have to, but I wouldn't.After all, these are things you buy once, take good care of, and pass on to your kids.  They should last effectively forever if properly handled and oiled.Could you just use the Soft and Hard Arkansas stones and skip the final, extra fine step?  Yes, in theory you could.  But your knife is only going to be acceptably sharp after you use this. It isn't going to be dull enough that it is hard to work with or unsafe, but you aren't going to get that amazing, razor sharp edge that comes from careful, free-handed sharpening if you stop at this grit.The Black Arkansas is where the really amazing edge gets laid down.  That is why this is the least important of the three stones in the system.  It is still worth having, but the one place to cut if you just can't swing all three stones right now.

I had heard about how good Arkansas stones are - but had never tried them before.  I finally took the plunge and bought the full set of these.  The whole set is expensive, but I think these are totally worth it for anybody who wants a really high-quality edge.  I am very pleased with my purchase.This "Soft Arkansas" is the first or most coarse stone in the series.The order in terms of grit goes:SoftHardBlack SurgicalI don't know the precise grit equivalent for each stone, but here is where I'd rank the Soft Arkansas: it is where you start when your knife is pretty dull but still has an intact edge.  If the edge has rolled or is otherwise damaged, even this first stone is fine enough that it will take you a while to set it right.  You could do it, but it would take a while.  I'd use a coarser, diamond stone to clean up serious damage, then start with this once the worst of the damage was put right.  This stone is more for fixing an intact edge, not really for setting a new one.It takes a small bit of skill - but honestly, it isn't all that complicated a system to use if you have reasonable mechanical skills.  Just go on YouTube if you want to learn the technique and have never sharpened free-hand before.  All you really do is set the appropriate angle with your hand and then draw the blade across the stone, alternating strokes on each side of the blade.  You don't really have to worry about whether your angle is 23.5 degrees or 24 degrees, you just have to get close to your desired angle and be able to repeatedly hold the knife that same way with each stroke.  That is really all there is to it.Eventually, you will feel that the resistance of the blade lessens ever so slightly on each side - that is when you check the edge and maybe move up to the finer grain stone.  Repeat that process with the hard Arkansas and Black Arkansas and you will have yourself a razor sharp edge that can slice paper easily.Having never used the system before, I dug into the back of my kitchen drawer and found the most bedraggled, beat-up, ugly old kitchen knife.  Something that I wouldn't really care about ruining.  That old piece of junk is now easily the sharpest knife in my house, by a wide margin.While the results are outstanding, you do have to embrace the craft aspect of this.  I actually find sharpening knives with these stones to be very relaxing and zen like.  It takes a while, but that just makes the result seem all that more worthwhile.  If you expect to go from butter knife to scary sharp in 2 minutes, this is not for you.  If you are patient, these do an AMAZING job on your knives, but they require some time.You do need honing oil to use these stones.  You wet the stone with honing oil, then use honing oil again to clean the stone after you finish with it.The stone is large enough that it can be used with larger blades.  I even sharpened a machete with this stone, just to see if it could be done.The little wooden case is simple, but perfect to hold the stone in while you are working and keep it protected in storage.  It was also very well packaged when it arrived - these things are expensive and they are very careful to do everything they can to make sure it isn't broken in shipping.The only limitation in using Arkansas stones that I'm aware of is super high-end Japanese knives.  Some of those super-high end Japanese knives are so incredibly hard that they can't be sharpened on these stones.  I guess those need either diamond sharpening or Japanese wet stones, but that is a whole other level in cost and complexity.  These stones will serve you for basically every other kind of smooth edge you'll encounter - carbon steel, stainless steel, etc.

In person, this is a pleasant, earthy brown color.  It works fine as either a large pot-holder or a small trivet.The material is very flexible, not hard or rigid at all.  So it can wrap around the handle of a pot with no problem.  As a trivet, it will work better than a regular pot holder both because it is large, and because the design sits very solidly on the table - it isn't slippery or going to move on you once you put it down.  Nor does the hot pot want to slide around on top of it.  The material has just enough grip to work well.We just started using these newer, silicone pot holders.  Honestly, once you have tried these, you will want to retire all your existing, fabric pot holders.  Why do you want a pot holder that needs to go into the clothes washer if you spill food on it?  With these newer materials, you can just wipe any spills off with a sponge, and the thing is good as new.  They protect against heat at least as well as the cloth ones and they are just easier to use.This is a handy little thing, I don't regret buying it.

This is a nice, long 30 pin apple cable.  The cable itself is solid and well-made and it is long enough that you can actually use your iPad while it is being charged up.  I find that it will come out of the charging port on the iPad occasionally when you are holding the tablet horizontally and watching movies on it.  I don't think this is a flaw with the cable, more just that the 30 pin connector is designed to release easily when pulled, and it is very easy to do this when moving around with the tablet in your hands, plugged in.  However, the idea that you can actually now use the tablet while keeping it plugged in and charged up is so novel, you are still way better off with this vs. a smaller cable.

This is a good little iPad charger.  I like that it has two outlets that will each charge at up to 2.1 amps.  It seems to be well-made.It is not super-tiny, although the plugs at least fold into the body for storage.So if you are traveling with your iPad or tablet and need a bigger charger of some kind - it is fine, and will also charge your phone, letting you take a single power brick. For a recent model iPhone, it charges them fast, too.But if you are only traveling with your phone, I would take the regular little iPhone charger and leave this at home.  It is a little bit bulky - that's the price you pay for having 2 outlets that can each charge a tablet.  It isn't enormous or anything, but it is noticeably bigger and heavier than the little iPhone charger cube.

This is a cool little thing.  It seems to work reasonably well as long as you understand the inherent limits in this technology.All of these things measure the temperature of your forehead, and then extrapolate a likely internal body temp. from that reading using a simple algorithm.  That is never going to be as accurate as directly measuring the temperature using a traditional thermometer.This unit tries to compensate for the limitations in the process by taking a whole lot of individual measurements in a fraction of a second and then averaging them out.  What it then displays is the average of these multiple readings.  In theory, that should make the readings more repeatable by minimizing the impact of a single bad reading.In practice, this will normally tell you what you really need to know at home.  Does the patient have a temperature or not?  If the patient does have a temperature, is it getting worse or better?  That basic monitoring is what this is good for.  If you expect it to be dead on, within less than a tenth of a degree of the patient's actual temperature - you are going to be disappointed.Nobody should be under any illusion that this will completely replace your need for a traditional thermometer.  It seems to read within maybe .3  a degree of my traditional thermometer most of the time.  It largely is repeatable - it doesn't come up with the exact number every time, but it is fairly close.  But every now and again it seems a bit off - maybe you aren't aiming it correctly, the forehead is really sweaty and wet, etc.  So, if you point this at your child and it says they have a 106 fever, you need to go get a regular thermometer and confirm that rather extraordinary reading before running off to the hospital.  Similarly, if the patient is obviously feverish and you get a weird reading saying it is below normal, dry their forehead and try again.  You should never just blindly trust this - it is a useful, convenient data point that works well when you are monitoring temperature constantly, particularly with a sleeping, sick child.  If you use common sense and understand the limitations of the technology, this is a nice thing to own.  But it is not magic.

Used this repeatedly with a flu, and it seemed to work just fine.  It gets a reading fairly quickly and the results it gets seem fairly consistent/repeatable. It will float around a few tenths of a degree, but that is to be expected.It comes with a little hard plastic case to protect it.  Fine, simple, cheap product that I will use for a few years until the battery inevitably dies on it.  I am not really sure the battery can be replaced or whether it is essentially a disposable thing, but the manual says the battery is good for a few hundred readings.

I haven't used this a lot,  but it has been working fine for me so far.It is a reasonable trade-off in terms of the size/capacity issue.  You can get a huge power pack with a huge battery that will give more charges than this, but then you have to carry that around.  Or you can have something much smaller that can't really fully charge your phone from zero but might give you a few more hours.  This is sort of in the middle between those two choices.  It has enough battery capacity that it should about fully charge a iPhone 6plus from zero, so it will give you a considerable amount of additional run time without being too huge.I gave it to my wife who is constantly forgetting to charge her phone.  Now she has a full charge in her purse without carrying a brick around.  It is good for that kind of application - stick it in purse, a briefcase or something like that.  It is a little bulky to go in your pocket regularly, more like something you can add to a bag without weighing it down much.  It could be a backpacker reserve power supply just because it has a nice amount of power without being too enormous.There is no real indication of how much zip it has left - just a light that turns red when it is charging, green when it is fully charged.  So basically, you use it - you should charge it.  It comes with decent cables, an apple lightening cable and a micro-usb, so it should work with basically any newer phone and the construction quality looks fine - it should hold up for a while.

This works fine and has reasonably good range between the sender/receiver.
