The sender has a screen showing the temp & humidity too, so if you put it on a porch or something, you get an extra outdoor thermometer/hygrometer.  The display is big enough that you can read the large numbers for current temp and humidity across the room.I am, ultimately, not a huge fan of the display design.  Basically, you get a lot of data for each station - current temp, daily low and high (or - if you want- an all time low and high), and the same current, low and high information for humidity.There is no way to make the humidity display into a second temp. temp display for the outdoor station.  So that means you have one of two choices to see the info.  A manual mode where you actually have to press a button to move from station to station, or a cycle mode where it constantly cycles the display between all active stations and the home station every few seconds.It turns out that the constant, automatic cycling of the numbers between inside and outside makes the display a bit distracting.  I would not put this on my desk in my direct line of sight while in that mode, for example.  If you just want a static display of indoor and outdoor temp, this is not for you.  If you can put it somewhere where the cycling of the numbers isn't annoying, you'll get a lot more information out of this unit despite its relatively small size.  So that is the trade-off with this unit.For me, it is fine, I put it where I wouldn't have to look at it constantly and could just consult it whenever I wanted to.

Expensive, but it works just fine for audio.I have one older car that only has a CD player in it - no aux in.  So to play music/book tapes through my car's audio system, I have one of those little FM modulators that plays through the radio.  Not awesome but it works ok.  But a recent upgrade means the old, 30 pin connector no longer works with my new iPhone.  This did the trick.  Don't need to buy a new FM modulator, so I am still ahead vs. what this cost.
This is a good quality cable, thickly insulated.  The connectors are fine.  It seems to send the signal reliably in my experience.

UPDATED:  The review below is of the original item I purchased.  Sling, in its infinite wisdom, has decided to materially change the terms of our prior deal.  They are now installing mandatory adware on the viewing software.  So you pay once for the hardware, and now, all of a sudden, if you want to actually use it - you have to put up with display advertising.  This was never disclosed to buyers at the time of purchase, and they installed this adware onto my computer as a supposed routine "software update" to the player software. I already paid the full retail price for a version that didn't require ad-support.So basically, this is like when you get a free game for your phone then pay extra to get the ads removed, only in reverse.  I already bought the ad-free version at full price, but now I get bombarded with display ads every time I want to use the product they sold me.  Guess how excited I am about that?  Excited enough to bother to come here and warn anybody thinking about buying this device to just steer clear of it.Basically, this is a disreputable, corner-cutting company with no respect for its customers or the most rudimentary sense of business ethics.  It is too bad, this was a good product, the company is just managed by rapacious scum-bags.UPDATED AGAIN:  I have learned to open the player and then minimize it while the pre-roll ad plays to no one.  Then flip it to full screen.  Just forget about the mode it used to offer, to play in a corner while you worked or surfed the web.  But the player is so badly coded that at least half the time, the pre-roll ad crashes it or keeps my Slingbox from connecting properly.  So I cannot NOT RECOMMEND this product strongly enough.  The sooner the people who run it go out of business, the better.  Maybe some competent people will buy the assets out of bankruptcy, but that is about the only scenario where you should put down your hard earned money for this product.  I paid well over $100 for this, and wouldn't pay $25 for it now.-----I had the original Slingbox, the gray one shaped like an over-sized Kit-Kat bar.  I loved it - it turned every computer in the house into another TV and also beamed my cable out to my little cabin in the mountains that otherwise would have had no TV at all.  The power supply died on my original Slingbox eventually, then the replacement power supply died again a few years later, so I finally decided to upgrade to this thing.There are plenty of resources out there about how a Slingbox works and what it does already.  This is a review for people already basically familiar with the idea and just trying to figure out whether this new model would work for them.Upsides:  Within my home network, using current generation devices and a high quality, modern wi-fi router (apple), I get an excellent, full HD picture on both my Apple and Windows 7 or newer devices.  The remote responds quite quickly and it is really does turn your computer into an entirely viable, second HDTV.It also works well over wifi on my phone, using the extra-cost software.  Again, inside the network in my house, the picture is perfect.It uses the component cables, avoiding the nonsense that sometimes occurs with an HDMI signal coming out of a cable box. The picture it makes using component cables is fine and so this is definitely the superior way to go.Outside my network - the quality varies.  And I have FiOS internet, which gives me 50mps upload speed, about the best upload speed you can get outside of Google fiber.  On my phone with AT&T LTE, it has a pretty good picture.  On my DSL line running about 1.5 Mps out in my rural cabin, it is only marginally better than the SD signal pumped out by my old, Kit-Kat Slingbox.  I would go so far as to say that if you aren't expecting 3-5Mps both from your transmitting location and your receiving location, you are probably no better off with this vs. the original, gray slingbox you can still buy on Ebay.  If you want to watch in HD, you need the bandwidth at both the transmitting and receiving location to handle that.  This does seem to be a little bit more efficient in encoding video than the older box, but it is not going to work miracles. Also, understand that it will chew up your limited data plan mighty fast if you hope to use it over your phone.  It is really a wi-fi only thing except in limited circumstances.Downsides:(1) Compatibility with older stuff is non-existent.  It will not work at all with my Slingcatcher, or my old Apple laptop that ran just fine with the Kit-Kat Original Slingbox.  It uses new and different software that must authenticate the Slingbox over the web.  Carefully check the operating system requirements etc. because if everything isn't fairly new, it may very well not work with this new Slingbox.  That is kind of disappointing - one of the advantages of my older Slingbox is that it worked universally everywhere - old computer, new computer, all of them could be made to function as a spare TV.  This new one, not so much.(2) The Roku compatibility is kind of a joke.  It isn't a true client.  Instead, you use your cell phone or tablet to suck down the signal and then forward it on to the Roku.  You use the cell phone/tablet to control the remote source because the Roku remote is too simple to really control a cable box.  The whole thing is kind of klutzy and inadequate.  Do not buy this expecting that it will deliver a great, seamless experience to your bedroom HDTV through the Roku.  It does work, but it is far from awesome.(3) The company that sells these things is pretty shameless about ripping you off.  First, they charge you for the box, then they charge you extra for the cell phone software, and even more if you want to put it on your tablet vs. your phone.  The only free software is for computers - everything else is a stiff, additional charge.  I think it is like $20 for the iPhone software and another $20 for the iPad or something along those lines - same for Android.  So add $40 or whatever the price is for your mobile device(s) software and then decide if you still want to buy this thing.  They know a lot of people aren't going to factor in the cost of mobile device software when buying this - they will assume that all the software you need to use the device is included with it.  Most people won't read the fine print.  It is borderline deceptive how they sell some of the enabling software as an extra-cost add on.  So buy this with your eyes open as to the total cost.

This performs basically the same way every other oil-filled electric radiator does.  A resistance element heats the oil in the radiator, which then heats the room.  Just like a traditional radiator - there is no fan, so it makes almost no noise in operation.  It also has the advantage that the heat level stays quite even over time.  Because everything is contained within the metal of the radiator and the radiator itself never gets dangerously hot, it is a very safe form of heat - it is pretty much the only kind of electric heater you can safely run while asleep, while not in the room, etc.  The downside is the same as every other oil-filled heater - it takes a while for a radiator like this to heat up a room.  No fan means it relies on natural convection currents to heat the air.The advantage this particular unit has is that there is an electronic timer built into it.  So you can set two different times for it come on and off per day.  We use this in the bathroom, so it comes on in the AM long before we get up, and clicks off before we go off to work.  Then again at night it runs a little bit so it is pleasant in there when you are brushing your teeth before bed.  It isn't on when it isn't needed, you don't come into a cold bathroom in the morning, you won't forget to turn it off, etc.If it loses power or you want to wheel it between rooms, the program settings stay in memory for ten minutes.  It comes with a quality cord and plug - always something you want to be mindful of with an electric heater.  I felt it after the unit had been running flat out for well over an hour and the cord was still absolutely cool to the touch.There are little colored, LED lights to let you know what is going on with it - a light showing it is powered, that the heat is on, and that the timer is on.Below the lights is a very small, basic LCD screen that you use to set the timer and clock.  The screen is not back-lit and the symbols etc. on it are quite small.  So setting this thing isn't particularly fun - think setting an old-school VCR with a tiny display at an angle that isn't terribly convenient.  You basically have to squat or kneel down in front of it, or do it while sitting in a chair - you can't see the screen from any other angle.  You need to set the time of day, then the start time and stop time for when you want it to go on and off.We did have to program it once or twice, tuning it to come on early enough to make the bathroom warm at the desired time, then we haven't had to touch it in weeks.  It just works quietly in the background and you can forget about it.You can get a cheaper model without the timer, or you can get one with a mechanical timer that is likely easier to set, but is probably not going to last as long as this one.  In my experience, whenever you buy mechanical timer for lights or appliances, the mechanism almost always wears out in a few years.  The cheap little motor that drives the gears dies or the cheap plastic gears break, etc.  On the other hand, this one is digital, and so it shouldn't suffer from the same kind of wear that seems to inevitably kill a mechanical timer.This is good for somebody with a regular schedule who wants the heat on every day at the same time.  It is probably too much hassle for somebody who would have to constantly reprogram the start and stop times to fit changes in their schedule.  You can turn the timer on and off easily - there are big buttons for that - so you could have it run automatically during the week and then turn it off so it doesn't run during the weekends, or while you are away, etc.  We do that all the time with no problem.  But if you want to change the start and stop times - that is like programming a VCR and so you are just not going to want to do that very often.Overall - I like it.  It does exactly what I wanted it to do and has performed flawlessly since we got it.  The only thing I don't like is setting the start-stop times and the clock.  The cheap little basic LCD screen with no back light seems like a throw-back technology that wouldn't be out of place 20 years ago.  I can see that as a way to keep the price down, but this isn't exactly a cheap heater.  For what it cost, it probably should have a nicer, easier to use programming screen.

This thing is huge, but it seems to work well.  I am using it to maintain the settings etc. on two hydroponic vegetable gardens in the face of our frequent power outages.  It will run a 160 watt load for well over a half hour according to the display.  That gives me plenty of time to get the lights unhooked, and with those off it should maintain the settings and run the little circulator pump for hours.

I needed a case for outdoor stuff - hiking in the backwoods, skiing, and occasionally out on the dive boat for scuba.  Something you could use safely even in questionable weather.  There were no reviews on this thing, but I gambled and ordered it.I am obviously not going to test whether the thing is waterproof by throwing my brand new phone in a bucket of water, but it looks promising.  They even include a special adapter that you can screw into the headphone jack that has an o-ring on it.  So you can use headphones while keeping the moisture seal in place.  Or you just have a gasket that keeps everything closed up.  If you are looking for protection from rain, snow, etc. it should be just fine assuming you put the phone in it correctly (discussed below).The fingerprint ID thing does work through the seal, and you can access the touchscreen just fine through the clear film on the face of the case.  It even has a little flip up stand so you can watch movies or whatever on it.  The sound is also fine, you can hear it through the case.  I even took some flash pictures with it just to test it out and they look fine.There is a somewhat hard rubber ring that goes all the way around the outside. That provides both the seal and the cushion on the edges  It isn't real thick and probably provides ok protection against drops, but I am sure a bigger, more bulky case would provide additional drop protection.  But then you'd have a huge case - a major disadvantage given how big the iPhone 6 plus already is.It does have a nice amount of material above the screen all the way around, so if you lay the phone screen down on even rough surfaces, the screen is well-protected.Downsides:  Nothing major.  It is a little hard to get the phone in and out of it.  There is a little indent on one corner that you can stick a coin or key in to pry the two halves of the case apart (or just pry with your fingers.)  Then you have to very carefully go around and pry apart the entire top half of the case.  Putting it back together is the same way - you drop the phone in after making sure the silent switch on the case and phone are in the same position and then very carefully go all the way around and make sure every little clip between the two halves of the case has snapped into place.  It won't be watertight if you don't snap every snap into place all the way around, so this is something you have to pay attention to.It isn't complicated to do - but you probably wouldn't want to do it 100 times a year.  I think it is fine for the occasional ski trip or hike.  The screen is protected by the clear plastic film which should be fine for most purposes.  But I probably would want something heavier covering the screen if I was going to just throw the phone into a backpack with other stuff that could scratch or rip that film.  Again, it is all about bulk vs. protection.  This is the case to get if you want a case you can take out in the rain, snow, boat etc. with decent drop protection too.  If you want the super-bulletproof case that makes the phone as thick as a brick but keeps the phone safe from extreme abuse, go elsewhere.There is a little thing to slip a lanyard through on one corner.  I kind of wish that there was just rubber on that corner to provide more drop protection - it would be better if the lanyard hole was somewhere else on the case, but that is a small thing.For what it cost, it seems a good value and quite well-made.  I can recommend it without hesitation.  I ordered the safety orange one just to make it easy to see if I ever drop the phone in the woods or snow.  My phone now resembles a small, square road cone.  So you might want one of the more conservative colors if you are using this as your only case and work in an office, but it is a good color choice for the outdoors.

This is a nice, thin leather case for the 6 plus.The front is leather with nice stitching all around the edge.  It is just thick enough to provide some protection and stays in place with a small magnetic catch.  The best thing about it is that you can put the 6 plus in your front pocket and it is still very slim - while still being protected from whatever else in your pocket (keys, change, etc.).  It provides enough protection for typical office workdays etc. and it looks nice and professional.The color in the picture is pretty accurate, it is a very dark brown.  The workmanship seems good for something in this price range.  I am sure it will not last forever, but looks likely to hold up for a reasonable period of time.  The phone clicks into it securely in a way that makes it unlikely to come out.There is a little pocket in the front cover that theoretically you could stick your driver's license or a credit card into.  But don't buy this expecting it to replace your wallet.  First of all, the cover uses a magnetic catch, meaning there is a good chance that the magnet in the cover will wipe the information on the mag-stripe of your credit card.  It might be ok, but seems like a bad idea to store your credit cards a half-inch from a magnet.  Even if it doesn't wipe your credit cards, the pocket is small and is not going to hold multiple things anyway.It does have a stand feature, you sort of unhook the bottom of the case and then the back folds so it presents the phone at an angle.  You can fiddle with the angle a bit to get it right.  The 6 plus is actually big enough that you could watch video on it, so this is a nice feature to have.  I've already tried it out and it works fine.

Yeah - your fears are confirmed.  Unless you are actually on active duty somewhere, you will look like a total goober wearing this.  It is just as ugly as you think it is, when you get it in person.So what.  It works.  It keeps you dry and is so much better than those cheap, semi-disposable ponchos.I bought two of 'em and keep one in the truck now.  If you need to stay dry and don't want to spend a fortune, get this.If you want to be fashionable,  then go buy something else.  But you aren't going to get anything as well-made as this for such a low cost.

Color me not impressed.  You take the unit out of the box and then you have to assemble the glass pitcher yourself.  The whole thing is enormous - it looks from the pictures like it is about as big as coffee maker - wrong.  You are going to need a lot of counter-space to house this beastie.  For scale, the glass carafe is easily 3x the size of a typical coffee maker carafe.Next weird thing: there is no actual on/off switch anywhere on the unit, just a breaker reset on the front of it.Basically, it boils the water, the steam rises into a condenser where it is cooled back into water by a little fan using the ambient air to cool the coils. The condensed water drips down into the glass pitcher.  Rather than run on a timer or somehow sense that there is no water left in the unit, it is supposed to boil dry then the breaker trips off as the base gets too hot.  That is how it shuts itself off.  This does not seem like a particularly sensible design to me.  It is basically designed to deliberately get very hot, when the temp rises too high in the base, it SHOULD stop before it catches itself on fire.  Not a design I am particularly comfortable leaving run when I'm not home for example, and this is supposed to run for hours on end.  It will take several hours to distill a full pot of water.Unfortunately, the little breaker on mine was defective, shutting off the unit after it ran for 10-15 minutes, instead of the 4 hours plus it was supposed to run.  I checked everything over repeatedly, went through all the trouble-shooting steps in the manual - nothing helped.  It was tripping off like it was overheated when there was still 95% of the water unprocessed.So now I have to go return it.  Next unpleasant surprise.  Even for defective units, you get to pay the shipping back to the manufacturer and this thing is big and heavy.  My guess is that even slow shipping this monster back is going to cost me $40 or more.  Doesn't really seem right that I have to pay anything out of my own pocket for shipping when I got a defective unit.  If there was nothing wrong with it and I just didn't want it - ok, but I didn't get a working unit and now I am out of pocket a fair bit of money due to a manufacturing defect.  Yes, I could have looked at the fine print on the shipping policies from a third party purchase, but I didn't and now I got burned. I have had occasional, defective products from Amazon, and they seem to always treat you right, sending somebody to come pick up the thing to make the return process painless and easy so you'll come back to them again in the future.  Not so much for some of these third party sellers, apparently.  If that makes you hesitant to buy this particular item - good.It isn't particularly loud in operation and there is nothing otherwise objectionable about it.  The steel cylinder inside looks relatively easy to clean, although it cannot be immersed in water and would probably be a lot easier to clean if it didn't boil dry each time.

Not much to say, it is a styptic pencil.  I like that the plastic case it comes in has a ventilation hole in the top of it so if there is any wetness left on the pencil, it will dry inside the case.  Seems to work as well as every other styptic pencil I've used.

For the price, these are not half-bad.  The bass response is excellent, maybe the best bass I've ever heard in little ear buds.  So whatever they did to squeeze decent bass out of tiny headphones, it worked.There are two penalties to be paid, however:(1) the mid-range and high-end are not as well reproduced as the bass.  It gives a somewhat odd bass bias to the music - like you are listening to a very good set of headphones for the bass parts and a decent but cheaper pair of headphones for the rest of the music.  Or the equivalent of the bass bias being tuned up just a little too high on the stereo.  So if you are looking for highly-accurate, neutrally-balanced headphones, these are not for you.(2) These don't really sound great at low volume.  It seems like you have to feed enough power to them to "wake them up".  You don't have to crank it to painful levels, but anybody who wants to listen to stuff at very low volumes a lot is probably not in the target audience for these.They are pretty sound isolating and I found one of the interchangeable tips fits my ears reasonably comfortably.  Cannot comment on durability yet.You really don't need to spend a fortune on headphones to get excellent sound quality.  For example, my old-school Koss Porta-Pros absolutely blow these things out of the water across the board.  But those goober-looking things live at home.  For getting a little groove on while riding the subway or working out, these are fine.
Solid, well-made.  Easy to clean.  Keeps water w/ice cold a very long time when sealed up.  Stores plenty of water.

Understand what you are getting here.  Although marketed as a "survival knife", this is definitely not a knife I would choose to take into the wilderness as my primary survival knife.  It is too small and the quality of the steel is unknown and almost certainly suspect at this price.  When it arrives, it is about as sharp as a butter knife.  The case is cheap and likely would not hold up long in sustained, heavy use.None of that matters.  It sharpens up reasonably well, it is a full tang knife that is unlikely to break in normal use, and it is dirt cheap.So it is perfect for those situations where you'd like to have a little utility knife available but don't really expect to need/use it much.  For example, this one got sharpened and oiled and is going into the trunk of my car along with the flashlight, jumper cables and so on.  It is ideal for those kinds of limited applications.In other words, if you don't expect too much going in, you will be very happy with this knife.

This seems to be a well-made product.  I like the thick elastic at the wrists that will keep out the wet/cold and make sure that even if you are working with your arms raised, no water will come running down your arms.  The snap buttons aren't quite as easy to get fastened/unfastened as a zipper, but the design with the overlapping flaps makes sense when you look at it in person.  It is designed to hold up and last a lot better than a zipper, while keeping water out much better than a coat with regular buttons or snaps.  It just takes a little more time to do up or undo the alternating snaps.  I imagine I'll be getting a fair number of years out of this.  Have no illusions about when/where you will wear this - it is for those days when it is absolutely pouring and you need maximum protection.  It is definitely not a casual coat that would also be good when it rains.Here is help for people trying to pick the right size.  I'm a 6'4" guy with broad shoulders - normal build - neither thin nor fat.  When I wear a dress shirt, the dimensions are 17 x 37 and so I normally have to wear XXL T Shirts and/or XXL-Tall for most stuff like this.  I bought an XL Tall based on the reviews here and it fits just fine.  So even for large guys like me, the advice in the other reviews to knock it down a size is a good one.  It seems like the idea in the sizing is if you plan to wear a heavy coat and then put this on top as a protective shell, buy the same size as you normally would.  If you are not planning to do that - follow the advice of the other reviewers and knock it down a size from what you'd usually buy.

I was a little wary of buying this - an unknown brand, no reviews of it.  But when my big gas pressure washer conked out and I needed to get a project done immediately, I gambled on this.  It cost about as much as renting a big gas one, so if it worked once and survived, I figured that I was ahead.I'm an experienced user of pressure washers.  I have had 2 electric ones and finally moved up to a gas one, so I am well aware of the gas/electric trade-offs as well as what to look for in a pressure washer.First impressions - it seems reasonably well put together.  As expected, it is mostly plastic, but it doesn't seem too cheap anywhere.  The power switch is solid, the gun is nothing amazing, but it doesn't feel like it will immediately fall apart, the pressure hose looks ok, etc.  There is a nice long cord with a big GFI on it.  It comes with a little velcro thing to keep the pressure hose neat, a hook for the electrical cable etc.  You can store the detergent bottle and so on right on it and the unit is quite compact for storage.  Unlike a lot of these things that resemble a giant wad of spaghetti in your garage - this one can neatly store away.  That is a big plus for something that is going to spend most of its life in storage rather than in operation.The connection for the pressure hose on the front of the unit is all metal, another good sign.  The garden hose connection in the back is plastic and you put a rigid, filter quick connect onto it.  That is not so great.  Now there is big piece of rigid plastic sticking 6 inches out the back in a way that it could easily snap off if you aren't careful handling it.  If something is going to protrude that far out it really should be reinforced with metal.  That's going to require some attention when moving the unit around - definitely not a great design.  You'll want to unhook all that immediately after every use.So I put it all together following the directions.  It took maybe 10 minutes or less to get it ready to go.  First test was the aforementioned time-sensitive project - a big deck that had been neglected and the solid stain was peeling off all over the place.  It needed to get pressure washed in preparation for re-staining. That meant blowing off the stain that had bubbled up or peeled, while just cleaning rest of the surface where it still adhered properly.  So it is the kind of job that requires a fair bit of power as well as precise control.So off we went.  First nice surprise - the motor is very quiet in operation.  This is undoubtedly the quietest pressure washer I've ever used.  Unlike my gas one, no need for hearing protection running this thing.  It is not silent, but it won't annoy the neighbors 4 houses away like my gas one.  It doesn't sound like a cheap, crappy pump when it is running, either.Power is, as expected, ok.  It has enough zip when you turn the adjustable nozzle all the way up to easily strip off peeling paint and, if you are not careful, dig a nice gouge into the wood.  But the power is tightly focused on a very small area when it is on full power, meaning it takes a long time to clean a big area.  This is where a gas powered pressure washer shines - it can just push a lot harder meaning a much bigger swath of water with same pressure  - greatly speeding up the process of cleaning big areas.The head adjusts the power rather than having a series of tips for various pressures.  The tip system with a gas pressure washer is definitely better - it gives you more precise control.  Although this has adjustable power, in practical effect, this thing has two settings - all the way up (what you need when blowing off mildew, loose paint, etc.) and a sort of mid range that is sort of "garden hose +" setting that would be good for washing your car or lighter cleaning jobs.  When you are using it high pressure mode, you must pay very close attention to what you are doing.  Unlike the gas system where you basically have to be an idiot to do damage to the work surface if you are using a low pressure tip, here all you have to do is get a little too close.  Every electric pressure washer works this way - they just don't have enough zip to give good cleaning performance unless they are all the way up and the water is concentrated into a pencil-thin stream.  Anybody can get the hang of it, it doesn't require any particular skill - but you have to stay on the ball.It cycled on and off smoothly and provided consistent power in operation.Eventually, it got the job done just fine.  It probably took me 2-3x as long as it would take with a big gas pressure washer, but it ultimately did a good job.  I also felt all around it after extended use and the outside wasn't hot anywhere.  This is the first electric pressure washer I've owned that didn't get very hot after extended use. I take that as a promising sign for its future longevity.It also needs essentially no maintenance as long as you can put it inside somewhere where it won't freeze.  The manual specifically warns you that the pump will retain water and will be destroyed if it isn't purged before putting it somewhere below freezing.  Apparently, you can buy some kind of antifreeze and pump it into the pump if you have to store it someplace cold, but since it is so compact, it should be easy to store inside somewhere.  The whole thing is about the size of a canister vacuum cleaner when it is ready for storage.There is no question that if you are using a pressure washer regularly or you are doing huge jobs, you need to step up to a gas one and steer clear of all these little electric ones.  The electric ones just take a very long time to do big serious, heavy-duty cleaning because they don't have the power.  The gas ones are expensive, they require a lot of maintenance, and they will occasionally break down and need servicing, like mine.  But if you are washing an entire house before painting it, or have to regularly clean a 300 yard driveway, gas is really the only way to go.On the other hand, if you plan to use your pressure washer a few times a year, at most, and none of the projects are huge (annual deck cleaning, patio furniture washing in the spring, washing your car) this would be a fine choice.  This is a weekend warrior grade thing, and for that intended use, it is definitely not half bad.I have no idea how long it will hold up, but it doesn't seem to be obviously badly made - I can see it lasting a few years.  Eventually, these things all die - if you expect one to last a decade you are going to be disappointed.  But it doesn't give me any reason to think it won't last a few seasons and be handy for the smaller jobs where my big gas one is a bit of overkill.For what it cost, I think it was a good value.  It gets a thumbs up from me.

OK.  This thing is cheaply made and the mechanism is probably not going to last forever.Nevertheless, I like it more than I expected to.  In a dark room, it has plenty of power and really fills the room with a soft, diffused light.  It is basically a bunch of colored LEDs with different colors and you push the single button to cycle through the various modes.  You can get red by itself, green by itself, blue by itself, and a variety of different mixes of those colors.  There is like a disco mix version that just changes the modes continuously.  That is definitely not relaxing.  I find the green one is the most soothing, while the blue is nice but blue light is really not great for trying to go to sleep.It automatically turns itself off after an hour.  There is no way to adjust how long it stays on, it always turns off after an hour.It has a speaker for your phone, so I guess you could use it to play white noise for an hour, but the quality/cost of this thing is so low I have never even bothered to try the little speaker.  Buy it for the light alone.It has a short power cable that terminates with a USB port.  It comes with a little AC adapter but you could run this off a computer or something, it is nothing but a few LED lights and a very small motor, so I imagine it consumes almost no power.Things I wish it had:(1) The ability to set and remember a particular mode.  You have to cycle through all of them to get the one you want each time. It is a one button interface.(2) A brightness/dimmer.  It is pretty bright in operation - not perfectly ideal as a night light just because it throws so much light.  it would be better if you could dim it a bit.EDITED:To say it won't last forever is an understatement.  After about a month or so of regular use, it started to jerk instead of running smoothly.  The jerkiness completely ruins the effect and makes it annoying instead of soothing.  I assumed it needed lubrication so I unplugged it and set it aside until I had time to fiddle with it.  Finally got a chance to diagnose it tonight.  Not a lubrication problem.  The little post connected to the motor that rotates to move the lens has either bent or worn an uneven hole in the part it connects to.  Everything is just cheap plastic at that central connection point so as it operates it will naturally wear and fail.  The design is inherently flawed - the post that drives the whole assembly and is constantly under stress should be made of metal, and so should the thing it works against.  It probably would have cost all of 1 cent more to manufacture a version of this that would have run reliably for years, but instead they went super cheap and so it is headed to a landfill after a very short life.I spent half an hour trying to figure out how to fix it because I liked it so much.  But learn from my experience, just don't buy this.  You will come to really like it, and then it will fail.

These are ok - they work fine.  Basically, it is 9 little plastic bags filled with water, and they are designed to flex so they don't break as they are frozen and then melt.  They are thin and each compartment is relatively small, so the sheet is somewhat flexible even when frozen, meaning you can wrap it around whatever you are trying to keep cold.  They are good for small lunch coolers or wherever you really don't have room for a bigger, heavier ice pack.The downside is that there really isn't a lot of water in the bags, so it is not a huge amount of ice.  So don't expect one of these sheets to last very long.  In a basic, soft-sided cooler, after about 3 hours, they are normally completely melted.  So they are fine for like keeping a lunch cool for a few hours, but they are not going to be useful for anything more than the most light duty use.  Don't expect these to replace those big blue ice packs - they just don't last that long.

These arrive as flat sheets, you soak them in water and they swell up.  They don't leak or make a mess, the gel inside locks the water into the little compartments once they are soaked in water.  I particularly like that they are quasi-flexible so you can sort of wrap them around stuff in a cooler.  The cubes themselves are rock solid ice, they don't flex, but the fabric they are connected to makes them somewhat flexible when frozen.I also have some of those blue flexible thermos sheets.  They basically just encapsulate water in flexible plastic, while these mix water and some kind of gel inside the compartments.  Those blue sheets are thinner than these, but that means they don't stay cold as long.  I prefer these, overall, to the blue ones.  They seem to stay colder quite a bit longer and the fabric on the outside of them seems to make them sweat less on whatever it is they are keeping cool.

A new computer purchase made me finally upgrade my wireless network.  I have FIOS and the Verizon router that comes with the FiOS service is poky.  I was not looking to get an Apple router at all, at first.  I read a bunch of the reviews in the tech press that dinged this router for only having 3 wired ports, and lacking some of the features of other high-end routers.  The tech gurus complained that it was too highly priced for its limited functionality.  I am no Apple fan boy, so I was planning to steer clear.Then I started reading the consumer reviews of the Asus, D-Link, Netgear routers recommended in the tech press.  Repeated reports of unstable, beta level firmware, abysmal support and problems with disconnects seemed extremely common with all the competitive routers out there.  That sounded really bad.  I soon realized that I really don't care very much about the features this thing doesn't have.  All I really want from a router is (1) rock-solid reliability and (2) high transfer speeds even when I am relatively far away from the thing.  I'm not interested in my router, I don't care about my router, I just want it to work so I can forget all about it and go on with my life.So far, this router delivers in spades.  I have configured a number of wifi networks over the years, so I knew the drill.  I set aside a whole evening just to set all this up, turn off the old wifi from the FIOS router, etc. I actually needed about 5 minutes.  Plug an Ethernet cable from the FIOS router's LAN ports into the WAN port on the Airport Extreme.  Plug in the router. Airport utility automatically pops up on any late-model Mac.  Name your new wifi network and password.  Done.  It took me longer to find the setting in the FIOS router's configuration page to turn off the old WiFi network than to set up this router.  If you have Verizon FiOs, you can't get rid of the FiOS router entirely because it feeds your cable boxes.  So you need to let the FiOS router handle addressing.  I thought that would be a pain, but it was very easily handled.  The whole setup process is about as simple and straightforward as possible.Once in operation, the range is outstanding.  I have a big house and I put it in the basement and it reaches everywhere, giving me every bit of the FiOS speed even when I am far away from it.  It never drops the signal, I've never had to reboot it.  It just works.Do yourself a favor, just buy this unless you really really need some of the features this doesn't have.  Install it, then forget about it.  If you never have to think about it again, it is doing its job.

It is small enough to be very easy to carry, but big enough to hold a fair bit of stuff.  It seems very sturdy, it is comfortable to wear, the straps are good with good adjustments and so on.I bought this for carrying spare clothes when riding my bike.  It was critical that I could keep everything clean and dry even if it pours rain or it is 100 degrees outside and I'm sweating like crazy.  This does the job.  It will easily swallow a pair of big sneakers and a full set of gym or street clothes with a good bit of room left over.The only penalty is that there is no zipper.  Instead, you roll up the top, then strap it down with two clips and a velcro strap. Means it takes a tiny bit longer to get in and out of the bag vs. a regular backpack.  If you really don't need the water resistance and are going in and out of your bag constantly, this might get annoying.  Also it is very much designed for serious day-pack hiking, with a lot of extra straps and clips beyond the two shoulder straps to help keep it secure and comfortable on your back.  I use mine for 30 minute bike rides and so all those extra hiking straps are a bit of overkill for me.  I was basically needing a college backpack that was waterproof, not a hiking day pack, but I can't really ding it for having more features than I need.  I would certainly not hesitate to take this on a long day hike - it is very comfortable to wear, with nice padding in the back and thickly padded shoulder straps.So far it has been perfectly waterproof, but I haven't given it a torture test yet.  But I expect it will do fine.  It seems to be very well made and very well thought out.  You can just tell in the little touches that whoever designed this knew what they were doing.

I bought some cheap solar post lights.  They looked nice at first, but fell apart within 2 years.  So I was looking to upgrade to some better made ones.  Pulling these out of the box, I was largely very pleased.  The glass is a little less colorful than in the picture, but the solid wood base is nicely done, the glass and the leading all looks very good.  There was some excess caulk or sealant of some kind on the glass of one of them, but nothing serious.Unfortunately, just like the cheap lights I bought a few years ago, these include cheap, virtually worthless Ni-Cad batteries.  Ni-Cad batteries do not tolerate long storage and complete discharge well.  These show a manufacture date well over year before I received the product.  Predictably, they died almost immediately.  They actually didn't even live long enough to get installed on the fence post.  I'd unpacked these and sat them in the sun and then didn't get to the installation for a couple of days.  They failed before I could even install them.  So off to the hardware store to buy some fresh, NiMH batteries.  The new batteries are about 4x as powerful as the ones that were provided, do not contain Cadmium and are likely to last several seasons before they die.The way you change the batteries is that the flat black piece on top of the light pulls off, and that top contains the solar panel, the batteries and the two little LED bulbs that light up the glass at night.  There is no rubber seal or grommet where this top piece meets the top of the glass part of the post.  It looks virtually inevitable that in a vigorous storm with wind driven rain, some water will get under the cap.  Once water gets in behind the glass, there is no place for it to drain out.  I am going to have to keep an eye on this.  I expect I will somehow have to drill a weep hole in the back side underneath to let water out from inside the glass area.  It should weather normal rain just fine, but I am extremely skeptical it will stay water tight in really severe weather without a gasket.In operation, it glows very softly, mostly a sort of creamy white color with little bits of the yellow color to it.  It doesn't look at all bad, but it would look better if it were more the color of the picture instead quite so white.  It also could be a fair bit brighter.  Do not expect this to provide anything more than a decorative touch.  It is just not bright enough to light up a path or walkway.So this is a better made and much more solid light than the one it replaced.  But expect to change the batteries before you even install it, the actual color in operation isn't as warm as the picture suggests, the design may not be entirely weatherproof, and it doesn't throw off a whole lot of light.  This may sound like I am panning it - but I am not.  You need to understand that most of these solar post caps are just unmitigated garbage - badly made and likely to fail almost immediately.  This one is far from perfect, but it is much more solidly made than all the ones I looked at in the home center or the ones I previously bought on-line.  I think I can make this one work, and it doesn't seem likely to fall apart in a year or two.One final note - DO NOT glue this to the top of your fence post.  Even though it seems to be better made than a lot of these things - it will inevitably fail at some point and then you'll have to replace it.  Drill two small holes into the wood base, then attach to the post with weatherproof screws.  I used small brass ones that are totally unobjectionable.  That way you can replace it easily when the time comes.So if I were redesigning this:(1) replace the crummy Ni-Cad batteries with fresh, NiMH batteries.(2) more LEDs - it definitely needs to be brighter.(3) rubber seal or grommet of some kind where the top attaches to protect the inside from even severe weather(4) make the glass more colorful.  It doesn't look like the picture in operation - too white.

It is a nice looking little thing, looks just like a retro fridge that has been shrunk down.  It would look better if there wasn't a stupid, big company logo on the front of the door, but it isn't bad.  There is a reason why the only picture is with the door open.In operation the fan is not quiet and not horrible either - sort of in the middle.  If fan noise bothers you this isn't the one to buy, but I don't find it too annoying.  It is just white noise.It is a thermoelectric cooler, which means it is far less powerful in operation than a regular fridge.  I gave it a torture test the first evening - put 4 pony bottles of tonic water into it. They all fit standing straight up and they were at room temp.  A few hours later they were definitely colder, but not yet cold enough.  Left it overnight and in the morning they were frosty cold and perfect, but that was probably 12 hours later.  They probably got cold enough to drink well before I checked on them. But the basic point is this - the thing takes a long time to chill stuff that isn't cold, but it has enough zip to cool stuff down eventually.  There is no fan that blows cold air around inside it, it is just a metal plate in the back that is constantly made cold, absorbing ambient heat and exhausting it out the back.  It works, it just takes a while.What I like about it is that it is tall inside, you can easily get a big water bottle into it.  It will also fit a typical frozen lunch entree into it, but not flat, standing up.Here is what I think this is good for:  mini-fridge in your office to keep a bottle of water cool, your frozen lunch frozen until it is time to microwave it, or a couple of sodas cold.  Because it is a thermoelectric unit, it can only lower the temp. a maximum of 20 c or 36F.  So at 70F, it drops the temp inside to 34F - perfect for a climate-controlled office.Here is what it would not be great for: a cooler that gets knocked around in the car or for camping and so on.  There is a little recessed handle to carry it, but I just don't see it being made sturdy enough to take much abuse.  In particular the door latch mechanism appears fairly fragile and will probably be the first thing to break.  If that happens, the fridge is done, because the handle is what you use to pull the thing tight shut.  You close the door, then have to pull the handle out to get the door to seal tight.  It does come with a car adapter and an AC adapter, but I expect I will never use the car adapter for it.This is something you stick under your desk or put somewhere else and just leave it be.  If you are gentle with the handle, it will probably last a while.  Everything else seems reasonably well put together.  The AC adapter is large, and it gets a little bit warm in operation, but nothing scary.  The AC adapter draws a maximum of 1.5 Amps at 120v - that is 180 watts.  So it isn't going to bankrupt you or blow the circuits in your office to run this thing, but it certainly isn't going to be as energy efficient as a small, regular fridge.  The cables on the AC adapter are correctly sized for the current they pull, neither the AC wire going in nor the wire running to the fridge were even warm after 18 hours of continuous operation.There are two sets of vents on the back, inlet vents in the recessed handle and a fan exhaust vent a few inches below.  With the inlet vent and the exhaust vent so close to one another, this thing needs some open space behind it to get rid of the waste heat.  So make sure you aren't planning to stick it flush against the wall or tucked into a cabinet without any venting behind. I think if you give it 6-8 inches behind and at least that much above (heat rises), it would be ok.  You need to give it enough free air behind it so it doesn't end up sucking in the very same hot air it just expelled.For what it cost, it seems a good value.  If it lasts it is a great value.  Eventually all of these thermoelectric coolers will fail, it is inherent with the technology that they don't run for 15 years like a regular fridge.  But if this survives a couple years it was worth what I paid for it.  If you want yours to last longer, turn it off when it is empty and run it only when you are trying to keep stuff cold.  There is a switch on the back to turn it on and off.  You can also flip the switch the other way and it can keep stuff warm, but I've not tried that.

The bracket that holds the thermometer is made of metal.  The thermometer itself is made of plastic.  The housing and the top and the bottom too.  However, the top and bottom of the thermometer look to be made of metal - it is very convincing.  To the point I had to tap on it to make sure it wasn't metal.You can pivot the arms to adjust the angle and then also spin the thermometer itself to get it positioned perfectly.  You need to be looking straight at it to read it - reading it from the side is not going to work.  But if you are facing it correctly the column of mercury is thick enough that it is easy to read.  I have mine mounted on a screened in porch about 2.5 feet from the glass door onto the porch and I can easily read it from inside.  It seems to be pretty accurate.The downsides?  It comes with very cheap screws which are probably not even galvanized.  So I replaced the screws with two brass screws and used those to mount it.  I would expect the screws would rust in a year or two if you don't get better ones to mount it.I imagine it will last a good while in the protected location of my screened in porch.  But I'd be worried about the fake metal finish not holding up somewhere where it is more exposed to both weather and direct sunlight.  You should mount this thermometer (or any thermometer) in the shade and away from where it will get a lot of direct exposure to the weather.I am knocking off one star for not making clear that the whole thing isn't made of metal - and for the cheap screws.  But it looks very nice in person and so I am basically satisfied.

This box is good-looking and keeps your watches neat.  It is well-made and I expect it to hold up.  The little pillows you wrap the watch around are flexible so they accommodate various band lengths pretty well.  I like that it keeps my solar watches charged through the clear glass window and lets me pick a watch before I even open it.  I have 8 watches in it and it looks ok.  You can order it even if you don't have 12 watches with the expectation that you'll probably get more at some point.  It doesn't look funny when it isn't completely full.

I cannot say I love the menthol & caffeine feeling on my scalp.  It tingles which I guess is supposed to wake you up or something.  This may actually work a little better than intended - what really wakes you up is the knowledge you need to be careful with it and make sure you don't get any in your eyes or even on your closed eyelids.  I was going to stop using it because of that.  But it performs very, very well if you have oily hair that is difficult to get looking decent without having to do wash, rinse, repeat.  I wash my hair once with this, don't repeat, and it still looks good all day.If you hair is dry or even not very oily I wouldn't buy this - it is powerful stuff that really cleans your hair super thoroughly.  But if you work construction and your hair is often filthy or you have oily hair - go for it.  Just make sure you don't get any in your eyes.It seems to be stronger than most shampoo I've tried.

This is a good little unit.  You have to master the process, there is no getting around the fact that there is some skill involved in pouring out just the right amount and then using the little wooden dowel to evenly spread the batter quickly right to the edge.  So just assume you are going to wreck some, spill batter over the sides and so on until you get the hang of it.  But it doesn't take forever to figure out how to do it correctly.  Within a few batches you get the hang of it.  It makes lovely crepes and is pretty easy to clean up after.  I have seen these very same units in a few crepe restaurants - they are definitely up to snuff.

The batteries they come with are garbage and need to be replaced immediately.  They look ok and work well for a year or two.  But the cheap construction catches up to them eventually.  I had a pair and one of them had the top snap off in the wind.  Now it won't stay on and has to be replaced.  If you paid maybe ten bucks for these I'd be ok with them being essentially disposable.  But they cost like they are better made than they are.  I would not pay more for these vs. the ones that are cheaper.

It is a simple pizza pie plate, fits exactly into my Breville oven just like the crummy black one that loses its finish.  It is plain aluminum, not non-stick at all.However, it arrives with no separate box, just loose in the bottom of the Amazon box and it had a bunch of scratches and swirl marks and such in it.  Some scratches are probably in transit - others suggest poor quality finishing.For something like this - it is going to get scratched up anyway and it was cheap.  But if you don't want something that looks like it has already been used in a pizzeria for a few years when it comes out of the box, you may want to look elsewhere.In fact, it looks like a scaled down version of exactly the same kind of metal plates they use in most pizzerias.  So if you know what those look like - you know what to expect if you buy this.

This thing is indeed made from real wood and the corner brackets and rod that holds down the napkins are all metal.  When it arrived, it was kind of filthy so I had to scrub the whole thing with Murphy's Oil Soap.  After I finished cleaning it, it looks fine.  It has little rubber feet so it won't scratch your table and the metal pole is heavy enough to do the job of holding down the napkins.I wouldn't rate it as an outstanding, quality product, there are some scratches on the wood on the base where nobody would see them once the napkins are in place and the finish isn't exactly perfect.  But it gets buy just fine for what it is - a basic, wooden napkin holder.  If I had spent $50 on it, I would be a bit disappointed, but for what it cost, it is just fine.  I am not sure about how "rustic" it is - it would go fine in a rustic cabin, but just as easily in any mainstream decor.  It is a plain, simple wooden napkin holder.  It does take up a fair bit of space because the napkins lay flat instead of sticking straight up.  I wouldn't want it on a really small table.  But outside of that it would be hard to imagine any place where something made out of wood would look ok but this would look bad.

It seems reasonably well made - the ends click in securely and it transmits the digital signal just fine.  Only caution:  When they say "6 feet" they mean 6 feet between the very tip of the end of the connector on each end, not six feet worth of cable with connectors attached.  So the actual cable length is more like 5'6" or so.  Because the connectors are kind of long and there are two of them - it felt short enough that I actually measured it to make sure they sent me this one and not the 4' one by accident.For a monitor in the middle of a large desk and a laptop sitting on a table right next to the desk - this worked, but only just.I would definitely buy this one and not the smaller one unless you are planning to have the computer literally right on top of the monitor.

This really does deserve all the praise it gets.  It is an outstanding knife - better than anything I've ever used before.  You do need to respect it - it is seriously sharp.  But this was and is the perfect gift for my serious cook wife.  She loves it and so do I when I use it.

I never ran this through the dishwasher but the finish started to flake off after about 2 years of regular use (we cook all kinds of stuff on it, not just pizza - it fits the oven perfectly).  So I came onto Amazon looking to buy the replacement for exactly the same problem everybody else on here seems to be reporting.  So I decided to look elsewhere.  There are 13" pizza pans without the nonstick coating available elsewhere on Amazon.  Just make sure you buy one without handles or edges that stick out because they will not fit the Breville oven otherwise.Do not use a pan that has started to flake off the non-stick finish at all.  The stuff that makes pans non-stick does not belong inside your body.  If you must use the one you have until a replacement arrives, cover it with aluminum foil first.

I actually bought one of these by accident, meaning to buy the much more expensive one with the replaceable battery and light.  When I realized my mistake - I thought it would be going back immediately because there was no way this little guy would be beefy enough.  Wrong.  This thing is awesome.  It can push even big screws with ease, and has plenty of power for the kind of routine little drilling/screwing projects a homeowner is normally going to encounter.  The battery lasts a LONG time between charges and doesn't run down in storage.  I am stunned by how good it is given how little it weighs.  It is so easy to handle - it weighs probably 20% what my old ni-cad drill weighs and the power is similar.  The fact that the battery isn't swappable has been no issue so far.Yes, this is not a drill for a professional contractor who needs to shoot 1,200 screws a day.  But this ought to give you a sense of where the line is:  I still own a corded, 1/2"  hammer drill and I still pull it out from time to time.  But basically unless I am using a hole saw to cut a 6" hole through something, or need to bore a big hole through a 6x6 for a heavy carriage bolt or something like that - this is more than up to the task.  This little guy is the drill I reach for probably 95% of the time now.I like mine so much I just bought another one for up at our cabin in the mountains.  It is just so handy to have around, once you have one you really don't want to be without it.As far as I can tell, the only downside is that the battery doesn't seem to be replaceable.  When the Lithium Ion battery does eventually die, you will probably have to replace the whole drill.  But for what it costs, that isn't a deal breaker.

I used to buy the mint flavored versions of these, but my dogs like these more.My dogs are obsessed with cheese and will come running if I open the cheese door on the fridge hoping to get a bit of cheese from me.  These make them almost as happy as getting real cheese.  YMMV, but if your dog loves cheese like mine - give them a try.BTW, these treats are made in the USA according to the package.  So you shouldn't have to worry about what is in them.

I believe in the power of consciousness archaeology. The most significant application in this book is the practice of letting go.  This involves fully experiencing a painful situation and having the ability to let it go.  This is difficult for me to do.  The vices of rejection, denial and arrogance prevent me from letting go. I also believe that I can raise my consciousness by showing kindness and maintaining a sense of humility.  Freeman believes that each person possesses an inner genius.  I agree with this completely. Being a genius simply means having an insight in a particular area.  I have discovered that over the years that I am a genius in networking.  I meet new people constantly.  I have the ability to create new work opportunities for myself because of my ability to network with different kinds of people.  I think that everyone has the power to network.  I try to help people to create or expand their own networks.  I believe in the value of surrendering my own beliefs every and then.  This helps to keep my mind open to new avenues.  I will read this book periodically to remind me to surrender my beliefs and to let go of my negative emotions. These practices will help me to stay mentally and spiritually healthy throughout my life.

The shirt fits me perfectly. I am a big Earth Wind and Fire fan, so I love to wear this shirt.  I celebrate their musical legacy by wearing this shirt. This black shirt with the gold emblem is stylish and easy to match with my black jeans and other clothes.

There is a good balance between faster tempo songs and the slower tempo ones.  There are lyrically moving songs on this album as well.  I love "Heartbreak Song" It is a excellent dance tune.  Some songs are lyrically inspiring like "Invincible".  This is a song that will make young girls feel better about themselves.  The title song is a reminder that a person's faith in people can be restored after being damaged.  "Piece By Piece" is a song that I listen to for inner strength when I need it. "In The Blue" is the best song about how friendship that transcends time.  This song resonates with me.  I think it is because I have several true blue friends that I have grown up with. "Second Wind" is another gem of a song.  It touches me because I believe that anyone can get a second wind.  "Second Wind" is the kind of song that motivates me not to give up on anything. "Run Run Run" is a superb duet with John Legend.  I never thought I would hear these two very different voices singing together on a song.  I love the piano playing on "Run Run Run" by him.  I also enjoy John Legend's soulful voice paired with Kelly.  This is an entertaining album by Kelly.

My favorite song on this album is the title track.  It combines great lead vocals and mind blowing guitar playing.  The lead vocals make me feel peaceful.  The electric guitar playing mixes well with the vocals.  My other favorite song is "Trouble". This song has such an infectious beat.  It makes me want to march or do some exercises or something.  "I'm So Sorry" and "Friction" are two songs that keep me on the edge of seat.  These two songs will help me to release some anger and tension when it comes up.  "I Bet My Life" is a song that resonates with me. This song touches me because I am always putting my life and trust in other people.  "Shots" and "Hopeless Opus" are two songs that remind me to forgive myself for any personal mistakes I have made in life.  The lyrics of these two songs really touches me.  I love the way Dan Reynolds sings.  He has the ability to sing a fast or slow song equally well.  "Smoke and Mirrors" is a very enjoyable album from Imagine Dragons.

Graphic design is a fascinating subject.  I would like a job in creative design because of this book.  It would be so much fun to do something creative.  Creative Anarchy is about breaking the rules of graphic design to create something unique.  I work for a theater company part time, so this information could be very useful in my work right now.  One important rule of graphic design is that type is everything.  I learned some new words that will help me to understand how to use type in graphic design.  I learned that kerning is the space between two letters in a single word.  I learned that tracking is the spacing of all the letters in a single word.  I will remember these words if I ever get the chance to design a poster for my new play in April. There is a picture of a poster advertising the Shakespearean play Othello.  The first O in Othello is at the top of the poster.  The other letters are in a descending diagonal pattern that covers the entire poster. The display of the letters signifies  the descent that Othello experiences in the play.  I hope to create a poster that is memorable for my future plays.  Another rule of graphic design is to use a grid.  I aspire to write a book of my poems. I  want to write an autobiography some day too. I could use a column grid.  This kind of grid works perfectly for books that combines words and pictures together.  I learned a few things the use of color in graphic design.  I learned that hue is the name of a color.  I learned that tint is the lightness of a color.  I learned that shade is the range within a particular color.  I hope to get the chance to create a mural some day.  I could use my knowledge of color to create a spectacular mural.  I learned so much from reading Creative Anarchy.  I can not wait to apply some of the things I have learned in my work and personal projects.

The title of this book drew me to it.  I did not know anything about the Aurora Borealis.  I want to learn more about astronomy and about the different stars in the sky.  The message of this book is that stealing is wrong.  I really appreciate the lessons that Carole P. Roman includes in all of her books.  There is a picture of a monkey with an eye patch.  I think this picture is very neat.  Every page has a colorful picture on it.  Every page seems like a beautiful painting to me. I love this book very much.

Fribbet The Frog and the Tadpoles is a great book for children. It teaches kids how to accept change in the family.  It teaches kids that having siblings can be a fun experience.  I love the colorful pictures of the green frogs in this book.  Every page is filled with bright colored pictures.  It makes this book so much fun to look at and read.  Carole P. Roman uses the human example of Captain No Beard and his sister Cayla to show that having a sibling can be enjoyable. I enjoy this book very much.

The Crew Goes Coconuts is an excellent book for children.  It teaches kids the importance of not teasing anyone. This book also aims to teach to look for the good in everyone and to accept them.  Another message of this book is that everyone is special and has something to offer.  I love the alliterative names in the book. There is a  Mongo monkey There is also a Fribbet the frog and Linus the lion. The names gives the words a poetic quality. This makes this book easy to read. Every page has a colorful animal that is fun to look at for kids and adults.  I like this book very much.

I love to visit Portugal.  Until I have the money and time to do so,  this book is the next best thing.  This book highlights some of the best things about Portugal.  I learned that Portugal is located on the Iberian Peninsula. I learned that Portugal is close to the country of Spain.  I love any book that expands my knowledge of geography. I love to visit the Azores islands.  There are a chain of nine volcanic island in Portugal.  I could see marine animals like whales and dolphins.  I have never seen this animals up close. I would love the chance to see these animals with my own two eyes.  I would love to celebrate Carnaval and eat a sausage and melted cheese sandwich with tomato salsa  Carnaval is celebrated this month in the countries of Portugal and Peru.  The pictures in this book are colorful and fun to look at.

I would love to visit Scotland some day.  Since I do not have the time or money to do that, this short book is the next best thing. This book highlights some of the special things in Scotland.  I learned that Scotland is made of over 700 islands.  I am an avid sports fan.  I would love to see the Highland Games as a fan in person.There is a colorful picture of men doing a log toss in the book.  I love to see Loch Ness lake .  I have always been curious if the Loch Ness monster really exists. Scotland has some of the most beautiful castles and golf courses.  These are things that I would to see as a touristI am always interested in different foods. I would enjoy eating potato muffins. They are called tattie scones.  There is another fish stew called cullen shink.  I have never heard of this before.  It is a stew made with haddock fish, potatoes and onions.  This sounds very delicious to me.  I really enjoy the information presented in this book. This is an excellent book.

I find any book about neurology to be fascinating.  The title of the book comes from Alice in Wonderland.  It is often difficult to get a patient out a rabbit hole when they are diagnosed.  Dr. Allan Ropper is a clinical neurologist at Brigham and Women’s Hospital in Boston.  His job is to listen to his patients and diagnose their problem and decide what to do.  Clinical neurologists save the lives of patients but they also helps patients to end their lives too.  Ropper devotes two chapters sharing about Lou Gehrig’s disease or ALS affects the lives of two different patients.  One male patient with ALS is able to type on the computer with his knee.  He can still engage with the community and meet people.  The other patient is a female.  Her quality of life is not that good.  She cannot communicate with other people and is bedridden.  The difference between the quality of life between these two people are striking.  Dr. Ropper decides to humanely end the life of the female patient by removing her breathing tube so her breathing stops.  He does so at the request of the patient and her family.Some of the stories in this book are scary.  There is a story about a woman who has an ovarian teratoma in her body.  A teratoma is a tumor that contains cells from different parts of the body.  This tumor causes her to have hallucinations. Her hallucinations stop after her ovary is removed.  I learned that 6,000 people suffer a stroke in the United States.  There is a story of a young woman who suffered a series of strokes because of a chiropractic treatment.  I did not even know that this could happen.  This patient received blood thinners to stop future strokes from occurring.  Ropper also treats a man with amnesia by giving him medication to raise his blood pressure and anticoagulant medication.  The diversity of Ropper’s patients and their  conditions makes this book interesting.One of Allan Ropper’s former patients is Michael J. Fox. He has lived with Parkinson’s disease for over twenty years, but he still continues to work and even plays golf.  He has created a foundation to find a cure for Parkinson’s disease.  Michael J. Fox is proof that a person can live a full life with a neurological disease.  Ropper briefly discusses another patient that suffers from tremors, but he concludes that this patient’s problem is Lyme disease.  I am not studying to be a doctor, but I learned that it is important to get the correct diagnosis in order to receive the appropriate treatment.There is no information in this book about how to prevent brain disease from happening.  I would have liked some information about this.  I can only do what I believe is healthy for my brain.  I have to continue to do things like learn new things.  I have to continue to eat healthy and exercise regularly.  My brain will be disease free if I keep doing these things.

I love to watch football, but  I am unable to play because of a physical disability. Still, I never even thought about the values a person can learn from playing the game until I read this book. Mark Edmundson articulates these values in this book.  He played two years of high school football in Massachusetts.  The values that he learned in those two years have stayed with him for more than forty years. He is now a professor of English at the University of Virginia. He finds examples from poems, books and his own personal life to illustrate the values he picked up.  He uses the example from Homer's poem The Iliad to show examples of character.  Achilles is the brave impulsive warrior in the poem.  His personality is similar to the football players who risk their bodies playing football.  There is another character in the Iliad named Hector.  Hector is also a fearless warrior, but he possesses the ability to show tenderness off the battle field.  Achilles does not have this trait in him.  I never read the Iliad, but I am inspired to because of Edmundson's brief explanation of the characters. Character can also be developed through effort and hard work. Edmundson lifted weights and exercised daily to become a contributing member of his high school football team as a linemen.The sport of football is also about learning how to deal with loss. Edmundson shares his personal experience of dealing with the death of his sister at a very young age due to a stroke.  It is healthy to mourn after a family member dies.  But, It is also necessary to move on with life after the grieving is done.  This is what a football player should do after a loss.  They should move on after reflecting about the loss.I learned football that instills faith in a person.  I am not a very religious person, but I think the practice of praying before playing a football game is good.  A football player may pray to have a good game and not to get injured. It also makes sense that a football player says a prayer to play to the best of their ability to help the team to win. I never thought about the connection between football and faith before, but Edmundson makes it sound logical and important.There is another poem in this book that I really like.  The poem is entitled The Bee by James Dickey. This poem is about a how a father finds the strength to save his son, who is  desperately  trying to escape from a bee sting by running into traffic.James Dickey musters up courage from playing college football at Clemson University.  I never even knew that James Dickey wrote poetry.  I like the subject matter of this poem a lot. I never thought a person could learn so much from playing football. I never thought that  qualities of a football player could be found in literature either.  I enjoyed this book very much.

Anthony Ant Goes To France is an imaginative book. It is targeted for children, but  it appeals to readers of all ages. My young nephew really enjoys looking at the colorful pictures.  Every last word in one sentence rhymes with the last word in the next sentence, which gives this book a poetic quality making it easy to read. I would love to visit France someday.  Julie Bettendorf makes me believe that an ant and a lady bug could enjoy the beauty of France. This book is like a guide book for tourists interested in visiting France.  I would love to visit the beautiful flower garden.  I would love to tour the Louvre and walk inside Notre Dame Cathedral.  I would also love to walk down the Champs Elysees to see people walking their dogs.  Anthony Ant Goes To France is a very enjoyable book.

Smart Cuts provides examples of people who have achieved success by doing things to accelerate the career.  I have never even heard of Sonny Young, but he is a musician now known as Skrillex . He started his career wanting to be a singer, but he discovered a talent for being a music disc jockey.  He used those skills to create his own version of music called electronic dance music.  This passion led to career as a record producer for pop star Lady Gaga.  I am also inspired by the achievements of D’Wayne Edwards. He possessed a gift for drawing.  This led to a career in designing shoes.  Edwards now runs his own shoe design academy named Pensole footwear in Oregon, where he now teaches students how to design sneakers.  I have heard of a shoe design academy before, so I found this story to be very interesting.  These two men remained active in pursuing their individual passions.  They were able to able to elevate their talents into successful careers.  Some ideas in the book resonates with me personally. I can relate to having a mentor and being a super connector in my job.I work for a theater company called Playbuilders in the state of Hawaii. Our play about the homeless problem in Hawaii received the highest award for best overall play of the year last week.  I am not the most talented actor, but I have a theater mentor that helped me to learn my character and memorize my lines.  My theater mentor is very important to my development.  She pushes me and encourages me to improve on each individual performance that I do.I am involved in a new play. This play is about the history and people of Waipahu, which is a town close to where I live.  My role in this play is community organizer.  I have to locate people who live a specific community.  I need to find out if they have a story they are willing to share, and then I have to connect them to the playwright of this play project.  I have connected five people to this play project so far.  Meeting different people is a fun way to learn how to get into character when I am on stage, because I believe that every person has a different perspective about a specific subject.  It is neat to read a book that contain so many concepts that resonate so strongly in my life and work.

This is a great album from Spoon.  I like the variety of songs on this album.  "They Want My Soul" and "Do You" are two lyrically meaningful songs for me.  These tunes forces me to reflect on my place in the world and how my life is going.  The lead vocals of Britt Daniel is superb here.  "Outlier" is the purest rock song on the album.  The tone of this song just oozes energy.  This song is about living life on the edge.  "Inside Out" is a slower paced song.  I think this song features a harp playing.  This is a kind of song that makes me forget about all my problems.  I also like the song "Rainy Taxi".  I don't know why this song is entitled Rainy Taxi, but I like it.  I think this song is about the conflict that happens between two people in a relationship.  This song has a groovy tone.  Jim Eno provides a surge of energy on the drums on this song.
