Merriman relates in several parts that while the Communards were being butchered, life in Paris otherwise went on as ususal, as if nothing were happening.The account of the Central government's retaliation is written in an exciting and engaging style, occasionally reminding the reader of the sad, inevitable outcome. Such is the pace and the detail of the battle is that the author places the reader there.The great benefit of Merriman's work it that it relies on French sources for which English translations are not available, as well as other available English resource material.This book is highly recommended for anyone wanting a deeper understanding of the Paris Commune.

For those interested in Easter philosophy and religion the writings of Swami Krishnananda can always be counted on to provide important perspectives and insights. SK was trained in Western philosophy and has a great ability to explain the tenants of Indian philosophy and religion in terms intelligible to Western readers. In this book, SK summarizes the important points of the major schools of Indian philosophy and religion.What is noteworthy about this book is that the Swami provides a detailed analysis of the Purusa Sukta, the mantra in the Rg Veda that explains the creation of the manifest universe. An explanation of this Sukta has been the subject of entire books; authors have declared the importance of this Sukta without giving an adequate explanation of its meaning. In the space of a few pages the Swami analyses this Sukta into five levels and provides what is the most complete explanation of the meaning and importance of this Sukta concisely and with the focus of a master. These pages alone are worth the price of this marvelous book.This explanation of Indian philosophy is basic enough to benefit the beginning and has enough insights to benefit the reader familiar with Indian philosophy.

The specter of global warming has risen from mere scientific speculation to how best to find a political or societal solution. This book is a significant contribution to the conversation. It posits that the solution may not be political, societal or even scientific, but one of attitude. Through a daring, plausible,  interpretation of the most ancient surviving writing in world literature, the Rg Veda, Murthy demonstrates that the earth is a dynamic organism, intimately connected with the entire surrounding universe.Murthy begins with his interpretation of the Rg Veda. He begins with the geographical and geophysical interpretation of the Vedic deities. This interpretation is not so far-fetched. As Murthy reminds us, the “Veda” in the Rg Veda means “knowledge.”  The Rg Veda is a book of knowledge, not simply a philosophical or religious tract. Therefore, according to this interpretation, • Indra becomes the cause of precipitation and earthquakes, after the numerous reference in the Veda of Indra as “the bringer of rains” “the Thunderer” and “the shaker of the earth.” • Agni, becomes the geothermal field in the earth. • The Maruts and Vayu become the Winds and the weather respectively. • Varuna is the gravitational field. Murthy arrives at these appellations from a detailed discussion of mantras from the Rg Veda. In a similar fashion, Murthy examines the earth’s relationship with the planetary system and constellations. Notably, the Adityas represent the twelve houses of the zodiac. After this analysis, Murthy arrives at a ten-point exposition, a summary of the Vedic view of the earth which affirms its divine origin and sacred constitution. This book will change your perspective on the environment and ecological matters and is highly recommended.

To anyone not familiar, John Cleese is a founding member of the Monty Python Flying Circus and went on to have a productive career as an actor and director. Whether you know him or not, this, his autobiography, should be picked up and read and enjoyed, if not to get inside the mind of a great comic, then to enjoy a good read.Anyone who has seen John Cleese on talk shows know that he is a great raconteur. That witty eloquence shines on every page. There is a personal style to this memoir. His memories are not written in a vague first-person narrative. He writes in a lively style, with aplomb and grace. It is as if he is sitting right there at the dining table or in the parlor room, reminiscing, one-on-one, of the past.Many celebrity memoirs are throw-aways, self-serving narratives written with an agenda by a ghost writer because the subject has fame but never had a formal education. More often than not with a remarkable selective memory, these autobiographies are northing more than a mere recitation of events which have not been wiped out by age or other factors.This autobiography is different. Cleese delves deep into his life memories, and in hindsight looks back at those peoples and events with the acquired wisdom of the present, putting those events in an accepting context. At many times, it more resembles a meditation of a life than a simple autobiography. It is all done with a comic, reserved English reserve we have all often seen in some of his characters in the Circus.And what an amazingly literate memoir this is!  Anyone familiar with Monty Python sketches will know their facile use of language for comic effect. Cleese displays his skills as a wordsmith throughout his remembrances.I can’t remember the last time I enjoyed a book so much.

Peter Dale Scott has written many books about the Deep State at work in the U.S. government. Scott depicts American society as structurally and inherently schizophrenic. Just as there is the public government and the deep government, and ordinary events and deep events, there are two dominant forces permeating United States history: One egalitarian, believing in fairness, inclusion, and free expression, and the other militaristic and exclusionary, which is only interested in social control.According to his thesis, there are two levels of government, one the government the public is familiar with, with a Senate, House of Representatives, a President, which enact laws. The other government operates on a deeper level — thus, the “Deep” State — and consists of the national security apparatus, armed forces, and intelligence agencies.  The thesis in Scott’s present book is the glue that binds these desperate forces together — many times in a symbiotic manner —  are the monied elements in Wall Street and their interests for acquisition of global resources (oil, etc.), often working with other major capitalistic countries such as Saudi Arabia and Japan.Of all of Scott’s books — any one of which are highly recommended — this present release is perhaps the most coherent, cohesive analysis of the different levels of governance at work in our society today. Scott examines the significant deep events  — those “mysterious events” which involve some level of criminal conduct such as murder with the elements of the deep state — from the last fifty five years — such as the assassinations of JFK, MLK, RFK, Watergate, the October Surprise, Iran Contra, BCCI — and establishes a clear convergence between these events and the persons and interests involved in them, leading to the institutional and constitutional changes enacted after the occurrence of 9/11.That monied, capitalistic interests drive American domestic and foreign policy is nothing new. And Peter Dale Scott is not some wide-eyed conspiracy sensationalist making hair-brained, half-baked, or screwball theories of deep events. What sets Scott’s book apart from similar books is that every assertion, every conclusion, every connection of persons, places and events are referenced, footnoted and fact-checked. Roughly one half of the book consists of endnotes, many of which themselves feature pertinent and important discussions augmenting the main text.It all makes for compelling reading.

I will admit it: I am a great Takashi Miike fan. He is one of the most interesting directors today, definitely the most versatile. Even when making a conventional genre movie, he produces a film which will stand out from the rest.This movie, Shield of Straw, is a good example. At first glance, it is your typical chase movie. It is the story of the transport of a sociopathic killer who the rich relation of one of his victims has offered a billion yen reward for anyone who kills him “legally.” That means the sociopath’s killer must be either the State or the State’s representative; in other words, the police officers charged with transporting him to the authorities. The price on the sociopath’s head is so big a price that everyone’s loyalty and duty is challenged.But “typical” usually is not in Miike’s lexicon. This movie is in a way Miike's variation of the essential plot to "3:10 to Yuma." Sure, there multi-vehicle chase scenes, explosions, and shooting. The first part of the movie has a magnificient mult--car pile-up. This is not a typical chase because the movie is supported by an excellent script (not a cookie-cutter plot), real dialogue (not corny cliches),fully developed characters (not one-dimensional caricatures found in too many movies), and real drama.This movie is more assessable than your average Miike film. He is famous for employing non-linear, hyperlink, story-telling, forcing the viewer to pay attention and watch the film. The story-telling here is simply and directly told in a totally linear fashion.At least currently the movie is not available in NTSC format, so in order to vew this movie a region-free DVD player must be purchased. This movie is a good excuse to buy one.

The I Ching certainly is one of the most obscure, cryptic and mystifying texts in world literature.Its real meaning is lost to the ages, and it probably will be impossible to divine its intended purpose and meaning.Fortunately, ironically, the most cogent explanation of the I Ching comes from this father and son team, Richard and Hellmut Wilhelm.This collection of lectures consists of the combination of two separate books, Change: Eight Lectures on the I Ching by Hellmut Wilhelm and The Constancy of Change, by Richard Wilhelm. Both titles are contained in this one book.Hellmut’s lectures consist primarily on how the hexagrams should be interpreted, interspersed with a discussion of their philosophical foundations. Hellmut’s lectures contain extensive quotations from commentaries found in Richard’s original translation. Richard’s lectures contain mostly philosophical ruminations concerning the issues and inspirations of the I Ching. Richard’s lectures assume familiarity with the meaning and function of the hexagrams, and therefore may be too advanced for the general reader.Hellmut’s lectures, on the other hand, are probably the best introduction for the reader to whom the I Ching is a complete mystery, which probably includes 99.9% of all of us. Together, these two sets of lectures, and this book, is the first stop for anyone interested in the I Ching.

Takashi Miike is one of the most interesting directors at work in the cinema today. This movie, Lesson of the Evil, confirms his standing.Judging from the advertisement on this website, this movie from Takashi Miike appears to be a cheap rip-off of Battle Royal. After all, both movies are generally about the wholesale slaughter of Japanese high-school students. But there is where the similarity ends. While the blood and gore in Battle Royale originated from a bizarre social experiment conducted by the protagonist, the main character in Lesson of the Evil murders his students as punishment for cheating on tests and bullying. This is not a simple slasher movie. Miike abandons his typical non-linear style of story-telling to delve deep into the mind of a psychopath who manages to obtain a job as a high-school teacher. The use of flash-backs and hyperlinked segments are at a minimum. Miike produces real drama as the students are killed. It is testimony to Miike’s versatility as a director that even in telling a simple slasher movie Miike can produce a compelling story.The only downside to the movie is that it is available only in DVD regions not compatible to the US or Canada. The purchase of a region–free DVD player is justified in order to view this movie.

The Amazon website indicates that this book is unavailable. Unavailable through Amazon, that is, but available elsewhere.. This is really a shame because this is a fascinating book and well worth the effort to find, read and understand.This book consists with three parts. The first part comprises with a self-described text written in the 1930s, the Sarata-Catussatika. The Sarata-Catussatika is a short exposition of Tantric philosophy with regards tp the Sri-Vidya mandala. Hindi and English translations are provided.The second part is a follow-up, a short essay which analysizes the Sri-Vidya yantra, part by part,\.The third and last part is an essay on the mantra on the yantra of the Sri-vidya.This book is indispensable to an understanding of the Sri-Vidya. Bindu, the very center of the mandala, is the concentration of the energies and forces that surround it and are depicted in the mandala itself. The bindu is encased in a triangle. Some mandalas feature an upright triangle, some, a down turned triangle. From bindu every line and figure has meaning: • The upright triangle — in fact, any upright triangle in the mandala — signifies the masculine energy in the universe, or Siva; • the down-turned triangle signifies the feminine energy, Sakti, in the universe. The union of Siva and Sakti is the very essence of the mandala. The mandala is pregnant with meaning. Some of those elements: •  Circles in the mandala signify consciousness; • Squares signify the elements; • The lotus petals signify the principle of regeneration. All of the chakras are represented in the mandala. The mandala represents the universe as a macrocosm, and the individual psyche in macrocosm. By fully gazing upon and understanding that one is the other, liberation is achieved. This book greatly helps the sadhaka who seeks this liberation.

On the internet, there are many opportunities to purchase copper necklaces. What sets this particular necklace apart from all the others is its durability. As advertised the necklace is one-fourth of an inch wide. This produces a very strong necklace which will not break. This is a big plus.  Many of the other necklaces which can be found on this website or Ebay are fragile and weak, and will accidentally break if taken off or on. This necklace may be more expensive than the rest, but the consumer will save more in the long run by making this one purchase and not having to worry that it will have to be replaced if it breaks.

This book is an account of the development of the numbering system in ancient Indian mathematics. At first blush this may appear to be an academic, dull, dry book. Wrong. This book, while technical at times, is an engaging exposition of the scientific innovations of ancient Indian science. Some interesting facts are known, others not so well known. Those factoids include: • Ancient Indian mathematicians such as Pingala posited the concept of zero approximately at 200 B.C.E., approximately one thousand years before Western science “discovered” it. This is relevant information because up through the Middle Ages it was unthinkable in the West to speak of the concept of zero. The Indian mathematicians conceived and posited the concept of zero at least one thousand years beforehand, perhaps earlier. • Indian mathematician Baskaracarya postulated the sine function in calculus and trigonometry at least 500 years before Newton and Leibniz. • Decimal systems were used in the Harrapan civilization in the Indus valley, circa 2000 - 3000 B.C.E. The most interesting portion of the book is found in the last half. In this portion the author describes the number systems by which many of the Indian texts on mathematics and astronomy were written. A numbering system(s) were devised in which letters of the Sanskrit alphabet corresponded with different number values. These texts were in other words encrypted, giving them an entirely deeper level of meaning. This portion is actually somewhat technical and difficult to follow. This numbering system shows the extraordinary care given to these texts, and for the right reader would quite rewarding.

The memory of Alexander the Great is still alive and well in Modern Greece. There is a popular saying, O Megas Alexandros zei kai vasilevei, translated as “Alexander lives and rules,” which  is still spoken in Greece to this day. Such is the modern memory of Alexander.Much is made in this book of how Alexander ruled, to date, the largest empire and was never defeated in battle. True enough. The lessons derived from his life and manner of leadership still is able to inform modern life.This book concentrates on the military prowess of Alexander the Great. It is derived primarily from accounts given in Plutarch and Xenophon and other ancient sources.Admitted the book does not deal with the political savvy possessed by Alexander the Great. In every land he conquered he encouraged his soldiers and officers to intermarry with the local population. The conquered lands thereby became centers of Greek culture and learning. He was not concerned with mere military conquest but a true investment into the future. Alexander did not limit his activities for short-term military goals but looked ahead to the future. In this respect this is a lesson that bears repeating.The book touches upon these political aspects but does not dwell on them, emphasizing the military side of Alexander.For those looking for the military genius of Alexander this book is more than adequate.O Megas Alexandros Zei kai vasilevei!

There is no shortage of books about Robin Hood. This totally engaging book is unique becauwe it analyzes the Robin Hood myth as a historical, social, political, media and cultural phenomenon, and explains Robin Hood within his contemporary historical context. The book applies the lessons of Robin Hood to our own uncertain times.War, corruption, taxation, and internal discontent --  England at the time of Robin Hood was a very unstable country. A war with France had bankrupted England's money reserves. The money situation was made worse by corrupt government officials who looted the money reserves for their own personal gain. The central government then leaned on the common citizenry by levying more taxes. Tax collectors exacted their own set of abuses to collect the tax. There was a widespread belief among the 1% of the populace that the Magna Carta, the landmark legal document which was intended to benefit the rights of the ruling class, should apply to everyone. The local discontent was fueled by a population was increased by disaffected, disillusioned soldiers coming home from the Crusades who were skilled in the then-state-of-the-art weaponry  -- the bow and arrow.If all this sounds painfully familiar -- all except the bow and arrow bit, of course -- this explains the phenomenal popularity of the Robin Hood myth. Stealing from the rich and giving to the poor. This has always been appealing, probably more so in our times, and especially after the financial crisis of 2008.Readers will enjoy the skillful use of graphics and text which serve as interludes to the depictions of Robin Hood in movies, literature and history.

At the very heart of the crisis in the Middle East is what to do about the Palestinians dispossessed from their homeland when the State of Israel was created. Resolve this issue and the root cause of all other issues in the Middle East are or can be resolved. This book examines the legitimacy of the State of Israel in a clear-headed manner. This book is extremely relevant to issues of our times.The Idea of Israel is a mirror placed in front of the State of Israel. It is also a highly readable alternative history.This is not a book about Zionism. That topic could easily take up a separate volume.  In interviews Pappe has remarked that the idea of Israel is riddled with an inherent internal contradiction. On the one hand, a point mentioned but not fully elucidated in the book, the State of Israel was founded on the ideals of Zionism, which in turn is a product of the Western liberal tradition, and because of this shares the hallmarks of that egalitarian tradition. On the other hand, a set of justifications supporting the legitimacy of the State of Israel have developed that are in direct contradiction to the liberal origin of Zionism. These two sides are direct polar opposites and are destructive, one to the other. This book is not about the ideals of Zionism, but about these set of justifications which were promulgated when the State of Israel was established and how these justifications have evolved into what they look like now.Pappe fully discusses the merits of those justifications in full in the first one third of his book. Those justifications included: • Before 1882, the land of Palestine was an empty homeland; • From the very beginning, Palestinian terrorism was always present; • The Arab-Israeli War of 1948 was waged to prevent the total annihilation of the Jewish community living in Palestine; • In 1948, Israel was a virtual “David” facing the all-pervasive Arab “Goliath.” • Palestinians were not forced to leave their homes, but either left voluntarily or were told to leave by their leaders. • Prior to the 1948 war, Israel had agreed to the creation of a Palestinian state which was proposed by the United Nations, but this proposal was rejected by the Palestinians. • In 1948 the Arab world was determined to destroy the Jewish state.Pappe carefully analyzes the historical record and exposes these justifications for what they are: myths, misconceptions, distortions, historical inaccuracies and/or untruths, or outright lies.Pappe goes on the describe how the idea of Israel changed with relevant local and international events. The Oslo Accords in the early 1990s brought what Pappe calls the “post-Zionist” movement. It was a resilient movement and survived even the assassination of Yidzak Rabin, but could not take hold. The occurrence of the Second Intifada in the late 1990s, early 2000, created a reactionary neo-Zionist movement. The hallmarks of this movement is the legalization of an apartheid system in the State of Israel, one which applied to Palestinians, of course, but paradoxically to the so-called Arab Jews, the Seraphim and Mizrachai Jews, and other repressive measures.Good alternative histories should demonstrate that, as the Firesign Theater says, “Everything You Know is Wrong.”  This is revisionist historical analysis at its best. It is clearly and engagingly written, even though its message may not be welcomed and succeeds admirably in its task.This is required reading for anyone seeking insight into the State of Israel and its relation to its neighbors.

Martin Scorcese has made a career of movies about gangsters.The movie very much follows the themes Scorcese examined with organized crime.  His examination of criminals in movies such as Casino, Goodfellas, The Departed, informed the consequences and repercussions of the quest for and exercise of Power, power over people and manipulation of surrounding events of life.In Wolf of Wall Street Scorcese examines Greed, pure, unadulterated, naked Greed. Scorcese displays the debauched and sordid life of Belfort. This movie documents the real story of a stockbroker, Jordan Belfort, his skills as a huckster, his con man charm, his addictions to power, money, sex and drugs, and his ignoble fall from grace. The movie displays, in lurid detail, the debauchery of his sex life and the excess of his “sales meetings,” which, more often than not, resulted in spontaneous orgies.While these scenes were undoubtedly a good selling point in promoting this movie, this was not Scorcese’s point. Scorcese’s movies are all about excess. So while his hoodlums, drunk with Power, eventually spontaneously combust, Scorcese is saying in the Wolf of Wall Street that the addiction to money leads to naked Greed, which leads to other addictions, to sex, drugs, or to whatever — and left unchecked, will spontaneously combust.In his gangster movies, the spontaneous combustion is exhibited with the hoods killing each other. Here, in the Wolf of Wall Street, Belfort gets nailed by the Feds. In either instance of excess, there is a Fall from Grace, the jig is up, and all bets are off.Wolf of the Wall Street very much, then, fits the mold of Scorcese’s previous movies about Gangsters. With the advent of the Financial Meltdown of 2008, it was only a matter of time before he would make a movie about the REAL gangsters — the con men who populate Wall Street. Wolf of the Wall Street is a modern morality play born from that crisis, and behind its titillation, is a word of warning.

What can I say about a band that follows up the most satisfying album of their career with one that's just as good?If you like to describe your music in 25 words or less, these guys probably aren't for you. I refuse to label them beyond "good music." Check out the opener (and make SURE you head on over to YouTube and enjoy the beyond-strange video for it), "X-Ray Visions." It's a beautiful display of focused rage that is meaningless, but at the same time it makes perfect sense. And that beautiful interlude at mid-song..."And on the drums...Gemini. On bass guitar...presenting Pisces. On lead guitar...we have Aries. And on the microphone....SCORPIOOOOOOOOOOOOO GO!"The band doesn't take a breath as they lurch into "Firebirds!," but then it's time for a song you wouldn't call a ZZ Top "tribute"...but in may ways it's exactly that..."A Quick Death In Texas," The vocals and riffs have that unmistakable Reverend Billy G sound, including a "Please forgive me, Mister Gibbons" aside. A joy, a pure joy...at this point you should stop reading my review and BUY this, but I'm not finished.The jaw-dropper...the eye-opener here...is how they unleash all of their fury and shock and awe on the CD's closer, the 7-minute "Son of Virginia." If you've heard the latter-day Molly Hatchet, with lead singer Phil McCormick, you will know that on this track, Clutch beat those boys at their own game. It's got that swampy, menacing sound of the best that Molly Hatchet ever had to offer, and it just SMOKES.No filler, not a bad song here, easily one of the best releases of 2015.

I've read all of the Philip Marlowe novels / stories, and the one I always come back to when I'm in the mood for Raymond Chandler at his best is "Red Wind." It's a prime example of the man's craft...a couple of sentences in and you're sitting on a stool in some rat hole of a dive bar with the Santa Ana winds howling outside and Philip Marlowe sitting next to you. I'm not going to go into a deep or philosophical analysis of Chandler's work here...you can overdose on the wealth of that kind of writing with a couple of mouse clicks. Rather, I just want to say that Chandler should be a "go-to" author for the times you want to just "curl up with a good book." The characters are jaded, world-weary, "street smart," punch drunk...they'll all ring true with you. You won't feel like Chandler is "telling a story" in some cute or manipulative way. You'll feel like he's yanking you by the collar into some real-life brouhaha that's happening in the moment, live, all around you. He's the master. It's that simple.

It's impossible to dismiss anything from this period of Miles' career in the same way that it's impossible to dismiss the entire career of The Grateful Dead. A person can say they don't LIKE the music...and many have...but in 1970, Miles was on FIRE, he was NUTS, he was CHANGING music again, just as he had with "Kind Of Blue." Like it or not, Miles was, is, and will ALWAYS be the father of electric jazz / fusion, and this is the sound of the man in his laboratory, concocting that sound.This recording has been rendered somewhat obsolete by the release of "Miles at the Fillmore - Miles Davis 1970: The Bootleg Series Vol. 3" (the complete shows from which this set was drawn).In the vinyl days, critics really didn't know what to make of it, because rather than offering "songs," the four sides of the two-LP set were broken down to "Wednesday Miles," "Thursday Miles," "Friday Miles," and "Saturday Miles."The "Bootleg Series" version of the four nights has been getting 5-star reviews; it really is worth the couple of extra bucks to invest in a powerful slice of the Davis legacy.The band consisted of Miles (trumpet), Steve Grossman: (tenor and soprano sax), Chick Corea (Fender Rhodes electric piano), Keith Jarrett (electronic organ), Dave Holland (acoustic and electric bass), Jack DeJohnette (drums), and Airto Moreira (percussion). As this was the "electric" period of Miles' music and he was collaborating extensively with John McLaughlin in the studio (In A Silent Way, Jack Johnson, Bitches Brew, Big Fun, and more), Corea and Jarrett fill in the missing electric guitar dynamic. For fans of Miles & McLaughlin, the "Cellar Door Sessions" box set provides a great way for you to compare the band of this era with and without a guitarist in the mix (the box captures the Wednesday-Saturday shows, John was present for the Saturday show only). On the "Cellar Door" set, Jarrett carried the full weight of keyboard duties (Fender Rhodes electric piano, Fender Contempo organ).If your favorite Miles album is "Kind of Blue" or "Sketches Of Spain," this is probably not the album for you. While not as extreme as some of his later "noise / electric jamming" albums like "Pangaea," "Agharta," or "Dark Magus," it IS the sound of the musicians sending shards of raw, jagged sound into the night air. MANY musicians listened to this album. MANY "borrowed heavily" or just flat-out stole the concept and tried to make it their own. But that's the thing about legends...you can only learn from them and never truly make what was their shining hour into yours. Essential listening, but as i said earlier, pop for the "Bootleg" box instead.

I gave this four stars because it is the REAL Grateful Dead...no Mayer, no Anastasio, no Furthur or The Other Ones or "The Dead"...it's Jerry, Pigpen, Bob, Phil, Bill, Mickey, Keith, Donna and Brent...The Grateful Dead. The problem I have with this 4-CD set, and the reason why I am not encouraging you to buy it at the very beginning of my review, is that it is a 4-CD distillation of the 80-CD box set, 30 complete concerts. I have no idea who the "intended audience" for this one is. If you remember the "Road Trips" series, there was non-stop grousing over the fact that complete shows weren't presented. I find it very, very hard to believe that anyone other than a very casual fan of the band is going to be happy with a set that pulls ONE song from each of the 30 concerts in the 80-CD box set. Of course, that set was extremely limited (already out of print) and extremely expensive, so...unless you chase it down through alternate sources...this is the best you're going to get.I have a short list of Dead songs that are my favorites, and in a package like this, I always look for them first. Yes, there is "Bird Song." But a TEN MINUTE version of "Dark Star?" Plus no "The Other One," no "Wharf Rat," no "Stella Blue?"There are 17 songs, 2 hours and 34 minutes, from the Brent Mydland era (his first show with the band was April 22, 1979). By comparison, there are 7 songs, 58 minutes from the Pigpen era, and 7 songs, 67 minutes from the Keith & Donna years. There are NO songs from the period when Keith, Donna and Pigpen shared the stage (December 1971 to June 1972). It's a known fact that the Pigpen & Keith / Donna years are in much higher demand among fans...look at the Road Trips and Dave's Picks series of reissues if you need proof of that. So does the fact that Brent material SIGNIFICANTLY outweighs those years, does this mean this is the Brent Mydland Collection? To a degree, obviously. And that's where your "glass half empty /  glass half full" sensibilities will kick in. Two hours of Pigpen, Keith & Donna alongside 2-1/2 hours of Brent. A pleasant surprise OR a disappointment for you, depending which side of the fence you're on.I can think of a L-O-N-G list of Dead CDs I'd buy BEFORE this one...superior performances, superior song selection. Get "From The Vault III"...the Pigpen band on FIRE. Get "Road Trips Volume 1 No 2"...Summer '71, more adrenaline. Get "Road Trips Volume 3 No 2"...Austin '71. These were archive releases to get excited about. When you listen to Jerry sing "Comes A Time" on this new set, (Cal Expo Amphitheatre, Sacramento, CA 5/3/86), he sounds strained and weary. The band takes the song at "nodding off" pace. There are so many other superior versions of the song available. Other than being a collector and a completest, why would you want this one?Like I said, it's The Grateful Dead. Reading my review will with make you want it or not want it, but it's an honest review from someone who owns EVERY commercially released album by the band. I'm not a Dead Head, I have no "tapes"...but all of the "official releases" have passed through these ears and this one isn't the crème de la crème. Doesn't mean you shouldn't buy it. Just means you shouldn't expect to be knocked off your feet.

One of the ten best albums released in 2014, period. The jury may be out on the Doobie Brothers...did Michael McDonald save 'em, sink 'em, or none of the above...but this album proves what true music lovers already know...the hits this band generated are timeless, like it or not. And yeah, there are a lot of people out there who hold the band in contempt, but that's life.For my personal tastes, the single most successful track on the album is "Black Water," because it's one of their best songs, and also because Zac Brown shines here. Zac catches enough heat of his own...just like Buck Owens before him, he refuses to be pigeon-holed as a "country artist" and records what feels right, not what the public thinks he should record. There's really not a mis-step on the entire album, and yes...they brought Michael McDonald back to reprise his contributions. I love this one, so the critics can go have a cookie while the rest of us "listen to the music."

This movie is everything it intended to be, and more. You can't judge a film like "Machete Kills" or a director like Robert Rodriguez using "current box office standards." first, Rodriguez...like his "sometimes partner in film" Tarantino...does what he wants to do, follows his own vision. Both directors obviously have influences up the wazoo..."Machete Kills," like Tarantino's "Death Proof," is more about cheesy retro exploitation cinema of the 70s or 80s than it is ANYTHING going on in 2015. But these influences are utilized at will, when they serve the greater purpose of the director. It would be the same as a musician in 2015 writing a song and saying "let's put a solo in right here like Jeff Beck would have done with the Yardbirds." It doesn't mean the song has now become a "tribute" to either Beck or the Yardbirds. It simply means the artist found that specific influence to be "useful" in the moment.What can you say about a film that features Charlie Sheen (under his real name, Carlos Estevez), as the PRESIDENT, with him playing the role in a way that gleefully exploits every square inch of the tabloid fodder he himself generated? Or crazed madman Mel Gibson in a role that followed his own media inferno that presented him as...well, a crazed madman?The scorecard: Danny Trejo is everything you would want or need him to be in this role, he just nails it. Amber Heard as "Miss San Antonio" is pure evil honey, a joy to behold. Michelle Rodriguez as "Luz" is a lot of fun, and she delivers some of the best lines in the script. Sofia Vergara as "Desdemona: is playing her role in a deliberately over-the-top manner, which...for my tastes...veers close to "annoying" at points. The "La Camaleón" role is a master stroke, jointly played by Walton Goggins, Antonio Banderas (amazingly playing the opposite of his "image"), Cuba Gooding Jr, and Lady Gaga. Cuba Gooding Jr.'s take on the role is especially tasty as he is often cast as the "voice of conscience" or the "stable" member of an ensemble cast, and here he is just cold and unrepentant evil. Tom Savini is always good for a laugh when he appears in these films. Put that together with Danny, Mel and Charlie, and you have a five-star stab at reliving the past while inventing the future.

I've got to be brutally honest with you here, folks...I'm kind of shocked by the number of 5 star reviews for this one. Having followed the Dead's career from beginning to end, appreciating live performances from "The Brent Years" has always required me to develop some form of amnesia for what came before them. What you really don't want to do is listen to "The Other One" from "Dick's Picks Volume 4" (2/13 & 14 / 70, Fillmore East) and then listen to the version here, unless you're of the belief that it was ALL good, just "different." I wasn't really a Brent fan...didn't care for his songwriting contributions or vocals, and thought his keyboard style often relied too heavily on brittle synths rather than the roaring organ of Pigpen, or even the more organic "wires and wood" approach of Keith Godchaux. That said, many people found Keith to be "simplistic," and if you believe some of the behind the scenes gossip about the band, Phil (for one) became increasingly annoyed by his tendency to fall in line behind Jerry and just accent what he was playing. I'm the first to admit that Brent was easily more "adventurous"...and maybe on the tracks that never featured Pigpen or Keith, that was OK...I just found his style to be cold, machine-driven, lacking in any real fire or electricity. Also, like it or not, this was not a peak period for Jerry, either. His health was going uop and down and his vocals on what should be standout tracks like "Wharf Rat" can be a tough listen. Some have said Weir is phoning it in here...I don;t think this set is a peak for the band OR any of its individual members. Would I rather hear this than Bob, Mickey and Bill jamming with John Mayer? Yes, I would. But there's a LOT of other Dead product you can purchase BEFORE laying out the money for this set. If you're in Brent's cheering section, and if "late period" Jerry isn't an issue, go for it. Maybe not at "collectors" prices, though.

It alsmost seems foolish to write a review for an album that is SO essential, one you really need to own (and most of the people reading this probably own it anyway). It's a transitional album, the sound of the Brian Jones Stones making way for the Mick Taylor Stones. Jones and Taylor each play relatively minor roles here. Even Taylor's "baptism by fire," throwing him into the deep end of the pool for the live set "Get Yer Ya-Ya's Out," has been dwarfed by later live archive stuff like the "Official Bootleg" of "The Brussels Affair" as well as the Leeds, Marquee and Roundhouse concerts accompanying the "deluxe" reissue of "Stick Fingers." That's where the new band was fully formed, where it became a great, howling, ferocious behemoth unequalled in the history of rock & roll. Consider the famous boast that opens "Ya Ya's"..."The GREATEST rock & roll band in the world, The Rolling Stones..." It's true, you know? The Beatles were a cultural phenomenon that could hardly be contained by the label of "rock band." The Who were a force of nature, but they were never an "everyman" band unless you felt comfortable inside of Pete Townshend's head, dancing with his demons. No, it was and will always be The Stones...Keef, churning out precise, deliberate machine gun blasts of Chuck Berry riffs, Charlie holding it all together with his trademark bemused / bored stiff expression, Jagger and that rooster strut. I don't think the band fully knew where they were going during the "Let It Bleed" sessions. It was an exploration, a search for something bigger and bolder than what they had in the moment, even though they were kings of their particular hill. Compare "With The Beatles" and "Revolver"...same thing. "Let It Bleed" and what follwed was NOT "better than" anything from the Brian Jones prime years. It was different. It was a band evolving.Obviously, "Gimme Shelter," "Love In Vain," "Midnight Rambler," and "You Can't Always Get What You Want" went on to become "concert staples," with the "Ya Ya's" version of "Rambler" becoming "definitive," but as I said above, maybe left in the dust by some of the tougher performances from the Taylor era that finally saw the light of day.For my tastes, Johnny Winter took ownershiop of the title track on his "Still Alive And Well" album. He just tapped a vein of sarcasm, ennui, humor, just SOMETHING that Mick & Keith glossed over by comparison."You Got The Silver" finally saw a well-deserved rebirth in the "Shine a Light" film, and "Monkey Man" has been trotted out on stage a few times, too.There are NO "disposable" tracks on this one. All nine, all 43 minutes worth, this is as good as it gets. It's history that still rocks, still moves, still inspires.It's as essential as it gets, so...what are ya waiting for? If you own it, go listen to it, and if you don't, get it now.

This is another "common sense" book, one we shouldn't have to read because we should have everything between the covers dialed in, but for a number of reasons, we don't. The biggest reason, I guess, is that as we go through life, we let ourselves become emotionally affected by life events, and reacting emotionally to emotional situations never turns out well.It's a laundry list of things you should or should not do. You can preview the book and see the contents for yourself. Some are pretty obvious ("Quitting Too Soon," "Letting Others Control Your Life"), while others are more subtle and are probably doing more damage than you realize because they have burrowed so deep ("Acting Too Needy," "Talking When Nobody's Listening").See, the secret is to catch yourself in the act of doing these things and then put in the fix WITHOUT beating yourself up for it.That's how this book can help you. Highly recommended.

I picked three stars for this review because when you roll over the three stars the prompt you get from Amazon is "It's OK" and that is exactly hiow I remember the vinyl copy of this I bought when it was brand new...OK. Not bad. Not great. OK.There was some chatter in interviews about Eric Clapton, who obviously was the inspiration for "Blues Breaker." They dedicated it to him. Problem is that Clapton HEARD this album, and his response...I kid you not...was "These guys can't play." The track is kind of like some of Roy Buchanan's stuff...NO ONE questioned his status as a master, but SOMETIMES, his tracks would go on for what seemed like forever without actually arriving anywhere. Same thing here. "Bluesbreaker" sounds like the clips you see on YouTube of guys demoing new guitars. It lacks any kind of inspirational qualities. And if you don't need that, you might give this one four or even five stars.At the time of its release, most music fans went nuts just to have Eddie jamming on these tracks. In terms of flash, yeah...it's Eddie and Brian. In terms of ANYTHING memorable making it to 2015, let's just say that it's an artifact from 1983.

This is the way performances should be filmed. It succeeds on so many levels that it's almost not worth writing about it....just BUY it. First and foremost, it is an excellent overview of the best of Jeff's many albums. Second, he is in fine form and is very gracious toward the audience and is having a blast with his band (as they are with him). The word "joy" is the best word to describe it, and you'll also see it on the faces of Jimmy Page and Robert Plant as they sit in the audience. There are three vocal performances on the DVD, including an encore with Eric Clapton, but the interplay between the band members is so tight that when the guests come out on stage it almost seems like an intrusion. In addition to virtuoso and Zappa alum Vinnie Colaiuta on drums, you get bass phenomenon Tal Wilkenfeld and keyboardist Jason Robello. Much has been written about Tal's age and gender but I think dwelling on that does her a disservice. Yes, she was 21 at the time of this show (Beck was 64), and yes, she is a "female bass player," but so what? She more than holds her own here, especially among such heavyweights. You have to do your homework when you purchase Jeff's music...there have been hits like his "Blow By Blow" / "Wired" / "There And Back" trilogy, but there also have been some misses where things just didn't gel. In terms of what you probably want to hear from the man, this one is a 10 on a 10 scale.

I purchased this book for my laptop's Kindle today. I'm going to respectfully disagree with some of the other reviewers who dismissed this as lightweight or as a paid infomercial for some of Mark's other works. Self-promotion is OK...look at the careers of Jeffrey Gitomer and Brian Tracy. It doesn't get in the way of their best efforts, and it doesn't get in the way of what this book has to offer.For me, it's not about how much "brand new information" an author provides, because let's face it...when it comes to your mind and how it works, how it moves you forward or holds you back...a LOT has been written. It's about CONTEXT, what an author DOES with that information, how he or she presents it. The end result will either inspire you to take action, or it won't. And while it is just my opinion, I am of the firm belief that this book could inspire YOU to take some necessary steps in your life, because that's what it's done for me.The book is SO dense and fully-packed with powerful insights that I think it needs to be taken a chapter at a time. This is not a "quick read," and it probably would not serve you well to move on to the next concept before mastering the one you're on.Some of the concepts may be a little "out there" for some (like the "Fish Bowl Guided Visualization," for one) but think for a moment. What you know and how you put it all together is how you got where you are right now. If you are 100% happy with that and satisfied with every aspect of your life, why would you possibly be considering this book? New perspectives are sometimes just what the doctor ordered, even  if they may seem "offbeat" at first. Maybe everything in this book will not resonate equally for you. Name the LAST book where THAT happened.I don't want to say too much about the specific content of the book, because it would detract from the joy of your own discovery process. Suffice it to say that it's a book about mastery...mastering your thoughts, bringing discipline and focus to your actions, so that you can make progress while others are standing still.This is NOT one of those "I've read it all before" books. I'm not sure how some of the other reviewers came to that kind of conclusion but I encourage you, at minimum, to download the Kindle sample and decide for yourself. Then get the book and start taking full control of your life and your happiness.

When you click "5 stars" at the start of an Amazon review, the caption that appears is "I love it!" Let me be specific, I love 7 of the tracks, like most of the rest, and wish one hadn't been included. Still a 5-star CD, though.The David Coverdale years of Deep Purple ("Mark III" and "Mark IV") are somewhat like the "Van Hagar" years of Van Halen. While Sammy has performed a few DLR songs onstage with Eddie & Alex & Michael, You're never going to hear Roth croon "Love Walks In." Same goes for Ian Gillan...the lyrics to "Burn" will never pass his lips.It's a shame, because the "Burn" album was a downright classic. The song itself has a Ritchie Blackmore riff as catchy as "Smoke On The Water," and the songwriting on the entire album is pretty rock solid. As you know, Blackmore would snatch "Mistreated" for Rainbow set lists, and Ronnie James Dio performed it in his solo shows as well."Stormbringer" was an admirable effort to bring Deep Purple into new and uncharted realms. It was also enough to make Ritchie leave the band. "Come Taste The Band," the one album with the late Tommy Bolin, was OK...it "sounded more like Deep Purple" than "Stormbringer"...it just didn't have legs. They plodded on until April 1984, when the "Mark II" band orchestrated one of the most powerful "comeback" albums of all time, "Perfect Strangers."The Coverdale band was a mix of the singer's own sometimes Robert Plant-ish vocals and the high wails of bassist Glenn Hughes. On the studio albums, Hughes had some restraint, but on some of the live albums, listening could be a painful experience as reach exceeded grasp. The FIRST thing you will notice about "The Purple Album" is that Coverdale is often singing in lower registers than on the Purple originals, and there is no attempt made whatsoever to replicate Hughes' contributions. You get straight harmony vocals, and that's it. "Might Just Take Your Life" starts of mimicking swampy acoustic Delta blues, and then BANG, there are the electric instruments, and Coverdale struts in a very Whitesnake-ish manner throughout the song, but the Hughes segment is just painted over in the arrangement. I'm not sure how Hughes fans are going to react to this...slighted because their guy was passed over, or relieved that Coverdale didn't seek out a Hughes soundalike?The only song that makes me wince a little is "Love Child," but then again, it made me wince on "Come Taste The Band," too. If you're a fan of Kip Winger and his take on "romance," you might like it. For me, it has too much of that sleazy, leering quality to it, and while Coverdale was 24 years old when he sang it, he's 63 now, and it just doesn't feel good to hear him coo lines like "Squeeze 'n' tease me honey, When you shake your body, You move my soul...Let me be your lover, Won't you let me be your child." It's a song for a younger guy to sing, or...if you have my tastes...maybe no guy at all. Just put it out to pasture.The KEY performances...the ones where the concept is MOST effective...are "Burn," "Might Just Take Your Life," "Sail Away," "Mistreated," "The Gypsy," "Stormbringer," and "Soldier Of Fortune." The rest (minus "Love Child" are good, maybe not great.It's Coverdale's legacy, he has every right to claim it, and this is a purchase-worthy CD if there ever was one.

What works best for the Zac Brown Band can also work against them, depending on your point of view. This is not a band that you can pin down to one specific style, and you'll find the multiple personalities to be refreshing...or you won't.In 2013, I was a DJ in a small club out in the middle of the Nevada desert. In addition to all of the expected songs from Johnny Cash, Patsy Cline, Buck Owens, and all of the other legends of Country music, I mixed in a lot of current top 25 songs as well. I didn't care for much of the pop songs, and I really grew weary about guys singing about how good their baby looks in her blue jeans. The newer bands / performers who rose to the top of my favorites list...and as a result got played more often in the club...included Dierks Bentley, Justin Moore, and The Zac Brown Band. The song that was on the charts at the time was "Goodbye In Her Eyes"...which followed the release of this live album...but it was easy to tell Zac was going a few layers below skin deep when it came to the complexities of love and life.One of his major influences, which you'll find out as soon as you give him a listen, is Jimmy Buffett. Once again, glass half empty or glass half full. You'll him along and tap your fingers to a song like "Toes," or you'll skip it altogether. It's all a matter of taste.The material I like best can best be described as a mix of the pre-"Copperhead Road" Steve Earle and Bruce Hornsby & The Range, from their first album "The Way It Is." If you listen to Zac's "Highway 20 Ride," it's a kindred spirit to Hornsby's "Mandolin Rain." The other three tracks on this CD that, for my tastes, I consider to be the best are "Whatever It Is," "Colder Weather" (featuring Little Big Town), and the SUBLIME medley of "Free" and Van Morrison's "Into The Mystic." There's a clip of Zac on YouTube performing this medley live with...Jimmy Buffett. But anyone with even a casual knowledge of Jimmy's music knows there is the "Pirate Looks At 40" Jimmy, and the "Cheeseburger In Paradise" Jimmy. My tastes run to "Pirate." I'm less enthused by snappy uptempo songs about getting toasted on a boat, whether they're from Jimmy or Zac, but that's just me.There's a live version of the Marshall Tucker Band's "Can't You See" here with Kid Rock on vocals...fun, maybe not essential. But this CD is an excellent introduction to Zac's music, very highly recommended. The only caveat I can offer...and as you can see, it was not enough to keep me from giving this five stars...is that if you like albums where the tone and mood are set on the first song and stay that way until the end, this is not the album for you. Zac's an explorer, and in order to really appreciate what he's doing, you have t be willing to follow him all over the map.

This one was a GAME CHANGER. I don't know where YOU were in 1978, when this was released...but I can tell you EXACTLY where I was. I was working in a warehouse in Sunnyvale, California. We had several transistor radios strategically placed throughout our department and we went back and forth between KSJO and KOME...the two biggest FM rock stations of the day. We were at the "death rattle" days of Disco...it was no longer amusing, we hated it, Peter Frampton and The Bee Gees had jumped the shark with the "Sgt. Pepper" movie (release date,  July 24, 1978). It was OVER. And blasting out of these cheap little speakers in our warehouse was "You Really Got Me." The ARRANGEMENT sounded like The Kinks, but The Kinks never sounded that tough. WHO WAS THAT?Eddie, Alex, Mike and David came along at a time when the world hungered and thirsted for the return of ROCK, and they DELIVERED.There is really nothing you can say about this album beyond "buy it." It still holds up, the songs are still classics. I thought that each Van Halen album got progressively weaker in terms of songwriting and performance. By the time of "1984," Eddie was CLEARLY telegraphing his "Van Hagar" power ballad, keyboard-driven punches. But on THIS album, it's only rock and roll, and I STILL like it.I am even willing to forgive them for the quadruple dip (original vinyl/cassette/8-track, initial CD release, 2012 remasters, 2015 remasters). People who read my reviews know I have the most low-rent "sound system" imaginable. Is the 2015 remaster "better than" the 2012 remaster, and is THAT "better than" the original CD release? I promise you...come to my house and you won't be able to tell the difference.Just own a copy of it. I don't care about the format.JUST...OWN...A...COPY.

While Molly Hatchet has gone through more changes than most bands, they have pretty much been slammed critically from Day 1. Derided as an inferior Skynyrd knock-off, they might have gotten a bit of slack for the "Flirtin' With Disaster" album, but other than that, it's been the fans who have kept this band afloat, not critics."Locked & Loaded" is not a perfect album, and it may not be anywhere near as good as "Double Trouble Live," their first live album, with the "sort of original lineup" and Danny Joe Brown on lead vocals. But even on THAT album, they featured "Stone In Your Heart," a song that was slammed as being too pop and "not a Molly Hatchet song" and wouldn't ya just know it, they had SYNTHS on there. SYNTHS! On a "Southern Rock" song? Cue the angry villagers and their torches.Make no mistake, the Dave Hlubek / Phil McCormack edition of this band has made a few boneheaded missteps during their tenure. They are not a "perfect" band...they never have been, never will be, and once again, this goes all the way back to the Danny Joe Brown days.But when they are ON, they can ROCK. Case in point is "Saddle Tramp" from "Silent Reign Of Heroes," which may be their single most solid post-Brown track. "Devil's Canyon," from the album of the same name, is another brutal stomper. Sure, they jumped the shark with that "Southern Rock Masters" album. They completely missed any trace of irony in the Stones' "Tumblin' Dice," and apparently they think their version is a winner anyway, because it shows up here. The "core" songs which make up "Classic" Molly Hatchet..."Flirtin' With Disaster," "Bounty Hunter," "Fall Of The Peacemakers," "Whiskey Man," "Gator Country," "Beatin' The Odds," and "Dreams I'll Never See," and all here, and they're in pretty decent versions. For the record, Gregg Allman was not a fan of this band. He got pulled aside by an MTV veejay back in the day and was asked about the band's version of "Dreams," and he replied with a terse "NO COMMENT." So much for "Southern Rock Masters."This isn't a band that's going to change the world. This is a band that is going to show up at some local biker rally or state fair and play "Flirtin' With Disaster" and the crowd is going to go nuts. Music can do a lot of things, and one of them is make people happy. Nothing wrong with that, and nothing wrong with the album. As far as the sound quality is concerned, I'm listening too it as I type on my Acer laptop, which...even though it says right on it "DOLBY HOME THEATER," still has two speakers the size of quarters. When I'm not listening here, it's behind the when of my Honda Pilot, with its factory-installed sound system. If the "audiophiles" aren't delighted with "Locked & Loaded," I suggest they go complain to mama, and maybe she'll give them a cookie. Recommended for fans of the band.

King Crimson...the edition that included John Wetton, Bill Bruford, and...sometimes...David Cross and Jamie Muir, alongside founder Robert Fripp...was the one band most responsible for the "Prog Metal" sound you hear today in bands like Dream Theater. They were very similar to Mahavishnu Orchestra (the ORIGINAL "Inner Mounting Flame" / "Birds Of Fire" configuration) in that they were all virtuoso performers and all somewhat volatile when it came to the dynamics of playing in a band. One of the great highlights of the various box sets and reissues that have followed this edition of King Crimson is the ongoing peek into Robert Fripp's personal diaries. According to Fripp, this individuals in this edition of the band used to like to inch up their volume onstage, a precursor of Christopher Guest's "Nige Tufnel" remark in "This Is Spinal Tap," referring to his amp..."this one goes to 11."For YEARS following the vinyl release of USA, Fripp resisted re-releasing it or presenting the full show in its correct running order. He insisted that there were better shows, and in order to prove it, he gave us the "Great Deceiver" box set, as well as numerous "King Crimson Collectors Club" archive shows. Didn't shut people up, though...like any good collectors, they wanted USA, and the best version of it they could get.There have been MEGA-box sets of "Larks Tongues," "Starless & Bible Black," and "Red." On the "Road To Red" box set in particular, the Providence show (also offered in the "Great Deceiver" box) may be one of the toughest and tastiest gigs in this band's history.But it still...does...not...matter. USA is a piece of history. It may not be the BEST Wetton / Bruford era show captured on tape, but it is what it is. And back in 1974, prog fans went NUTS over this.No one band member is really responsible for this album's stature...they're ALL on fire. At the time, this was the album a friend used to introduce me to King Crimson (that's right, I first heard them after they'd all packed up and gone on their separate ways).I'd heard the first album, and everyone knew "21st Century Schizoid Man," but my friend dropped the needle in the groove and said "Wait till you heard THIS guy sing it). He was right, Greg Lake delivered the appropriate level of menace to Pete Sinfield's lyrics on that first album, but Wetton tore into it like a pit bull on a pork chop. Bill Bruford might be THE most ferocious drummer in the history of Prog, and I say that after having seen Phil Collins with Genesis at his peak, with Steve Hackett still on board.USA now consists of the original album plus "Fracture" and "Starless." "Fracture" is always a highlight...in the Belew era it was reborn, in a manner of speaking, as "FraKctured," and the urban myth...should you choose to believe it...is that Fripp would decide whether the band would play it or not depending on "how well behaved" the audience had been throughout the show.You can get ALL of the music on this CD (with the exception of the improv "Asbury Park") in different, perhaps "superior" versions...but this is a real time capsule artifact. You should have been there, and through the miracle of digital music, you can.

Like sales guru Jeffrey Gitomer, you will find a truckload of wisdom in ANY of his books, as well as repetition. They both have a "core message" that, after you've read a few of their works, will keep surfacing every time you read a new one. This book is considered to be one of Brian's classics, essential reading, and rightly so.You'll know what you're dealing with when you encounter the Orison Swett Marden quote at the beginning of the book:"Every great man has become great, every successful man has succeeded, in proportion as he has confined his powers to one particular channel."That's the message of "Focal Point"...pick one essential, critical goal and devote every waking moment to its pursuit as if your life depended on it......because it does.Five-star effort fro Brian.

The David Coverdale era of Deep Purple is kind of like the Sammy Hagar era of Van Halen....Dave won't perform Sammy songs in concert, and Ian won't be doing "Burn" any time soon. It's a shame, because while the Coverdale-Hughes Purple was somewhat of a different animal (so different that Ritchie Blackmore bailed after "Stormbringer"), there are some solid songs in that catalog that led up to the launch of Whitesnake. Coverdale is well aware of that...the upcoming "Purple Album" pays a long-overdue tribute to the best of his time in the band.Even casual fans probably know that this live album includes Purple drummer Ian Paice and the late, legendary Jon Lord. What makes it a 5-star album is the fact that, much like pre-Alive! KISS, the initial Whitesnake studio albums never really caught fire. Even though they had Martin Birch on hand and the aforementioned DP alums, the songwriting and studio performances didn't add up to the stuff of legends. Here, however, they STOMP, they go for the THROAT, and the result is just as good as you want it to be. If you want a rock-solid Jon Lord era document of the band, start here.

Yes, it's short (37 minutes, 5 songs, not counting the "Walk On" and 90-second "Banshee Legs Bell Hassle" interlude). Then again, so was 1994's "VROOOM," the E.P. that introduced Adrian Belew to the world of All Things Crimson (6 songs, 31 minutes, and Fripp called it a "calling "card").Here's my take on the new line-up, a mixture of my own thoughts and reactions to what others have already said:1). YES, it is great to have Tony Levin back.2). YES, the three drummers...while initially sounding like a gimmick...do play with precision and do not collide.3). YES, Jakko Jakszyk is an admirable foil / sparring partner for Fripp. While Belew excelled in the "soundscapes" and noisy dogfights, Jakszyk seems more of a perfect match for revisiting the Lake / Burrell / Wetton years of the band (as is evidenced by the choice of two tracks from "Islands" and one from "Red"). The Belew band started out as somewhat of a Robert Fripp knock-off of Talking Heads...and while Belew did sing in a "traditional" manner on songs like "Heartbeat" and "One Time," after a while...no matter how amusing or entertaining one of his performances might be...I found myself wishing he would "sing" rather than "bleat like a sheep." Jakszyk SINGS, and while his voice may be missing the warm baritone of a Greg Lake or John Wetton, he sounds pretty good here.4). YES, it is GREAT to have Mel Collins back. It was easy to forget how essential his contribution to the KC sound was after making it through the last two decades of the Belew-dominant band.5). FULL DISCLOSURE -  I did NOT hear 2011's "Scarcity Of Miracles." As such, I'm basing my reaction to this band solely on "Live At The Orpheum." They are no longer a "new" group, so what they will be able to accomplish in the studio...if they choose to record a "new" Crimson album...remains to be seen. Looks promising. Fripp is just as likely to abandon and experiment as he is to dive in head first, so time will tell.Short but tasty...recommended.

The reason I purchased the Kindle edition of this book after downloading the sample is pretty simple...I like the language as well as the direct manner in which the message is delivered.Example:"We can’t afford to lose confidence in ourselves. Keep moving forward no matter how bad we have messed up. The best time to plant a tree was twenty years ago; the next best time is today. Get back on it."(Bell, Dr. Rob (2015-02-03). NO FEAR: A Simple Guide to Mental Toughness (Kindle Locations 214-216). DRB Press. Kindle Edition.)The best advice I can give you is that there is a time for poetry and a time for the straight, unfiltered truth. While Dr. Rob may use a METAPHOR as in the example I've pasted above, this isn't a warm & fuzzy new age type of book. It's that first hot cup of coffee in the morning. It wakes you up. Dr. Rob knows what makes people tick and he wastes no words here as he encourages you to get out of your own way and get on with your life. VERY highly recommended.

Something's missing here, and it's not limited to Michael Anthony.In terms of SONG SELECTION, it's pretty much a Van Halen fan's dream come true (except for "Tattoo," but let's not go there). Eddie sounds like Eddie, which is at least half the reason why you're here, right? But Dave? The years have not been kind to Dave. The set kicks off in high gear with "Unchained," but Dave's like a lot of "power" lead singers who get the point of cheating, sort of "shout-singing" the lyrics, and a lot of the hoots and howls he uses to punctuate his vocals (long a Diamond Dave trademark) are now forced and off-key. He TALKS much of the way through "Runnin' With The Devil" and there is more of the off-key groaner stuff as well.I'm not going to get into the politics of the band and whether Wolfgang meets or exceeds Michael Anthony's bass playing but he certainly is no match for him on background vocals.As you might suspect, there are NO Sammy songs in the set. Hagar had to tackle 3 Roth songs on "Live: Right Here Right Now," but it's not reciprocated in this set."Panama" is a groaner. Because of Dave. When he hits the line "Hot shoe, burnin' down the avenue" you WILL wince. Trust me.My understanding of the original Roth-era shows was that they could be sloppy. When Sammy joined the band he said, on record, that concerts would no longer be a matter of "ripping the kids off with a clown show." In 2015, who knows what's behind Roth's motivation or in his heart (or if he even has one). Maybe he's doing his best. And with a band that based their reputation on 6 hard rock albums unleashed on a rock-hungry world (remember that the first album hit the airwaves at a tie when disco was in its final death throes), what's on this album simply isn;t good enough. Three stars and trust me, I'm being overly generous out of nostalgia.

I think your enjoyment of this series will come on one of two levels...one, you love "so bad it's GREAT" entertainment, or two, you get sucked into the vortex of this show's premise and root for the good guys (I'm not convinced there ARE any...they ALL have an agenda) and boo the bad guys (easy targets all). Personally, I don't think there are any people worth cheering for in this show because of the reasons I just named.Let's start at the top with "Maw Maw" Mabe. She gets a visit from Brandon and his fiance and says "Well, I was reading, but I GUESS I could stop." Then she tells them "Well, y'all look like you're ready to get up and leave, so...GET UP AND LEAVE!" Brandon forces a weak little "I've heard all of this before," but if you don;t have blood ties to this cantankerous woman, chances are you'll have a different expression on your face.Then there are the parents. Dad likes to rub Brandon's nose in the fact that he built up the business and just "handed it to him." And Mom is a few notches past Oedipal in her assertion that Brandon's wife-to-be Megan isn't "good enough" for him. Both parents are FIERCELY protective of the business, and that is not necessarily a bad thing. It's just the way it manifests itself. Watch the show and you'll know exactly what I'm talking about.Brandon, in the crosshairs of all of this, is part "I am going to do what's right for this family" and part wimp. To his credit, he defends Megan against the venom both parents send her way. To his discredit, all it takes is a few hard words from Mama and he's got his tail between his legs, slinking away with that "I don't know what I'm gonna do now" nonsense, even though he knows EXACTLY what he WANTS to do. He just won't cross Mama for ANY reason, and watching his struggle makes him come off weak and a bit of a sneak sometimes as his whole purpose seems to be plotting an end run around both parents before they know he's pulled it off.Megan...she whines, she's manipulative, she's paranoid and neurotic and WAY beyond insecure, and she's probably the single most entertaining member of the entire cast.Breanna..."Breezy"...the real reason why she's not on stage with the rest of the family is, to put it politely, she is homely and can't sing. That's it...she's not slick enough to join the Mabes onstage. She sees breast augmentation as the answer to her dilemma but everyone in the audience knows it's going to take a lot more than that.Denton Mabe...another whiner whose talent level is right around that of your average Saturday night karaoke barfly. He hits the right notes but anyone could fill those shoes. His dear departed dad sold out his interest in the business and Denton spends most of his time whining about how he has no "voice" in what goes on.  He also had a creepy kind of Norman Bates thing going on in the episode where he quizzed down Heather over the armloads of clothes she was bringing into her dressing room.Heather Gentry, the "new girl" brought in to give the show some youthful sex appeal that they couldn't accomplish by putting "Breezy"...a fellow Mabe...onstage, because while she is youthful, her sex appeal is non-existent. And what does Mom do? Spend most of her time trying to dampen that sex appeal.Whether you agree with me on any of these observations or not, I'm confident you'll take ONE thing away from my review. This show has a LOT going on. The people...if they are really this way "in real life" or not...can get a little loathsome and irritation but hey...isn't that what "reality TV" is all about?I have watched the entire first season, and unlike some folks, am looking forward to a second. Highly recommended with all of the caveats I've provided.

"Cold Calling"...or "Prospecting," or whatever you'd care to call it...is one of the most loathed and avoided tasks among salespeople. You've heard it said before that the salespeople who are at the top 2% of their game are there because they regularly perform all of the tasks that most salespeople avoid or simply refuse to do. Cold Calling is one of those tasks. It's a push-pull thing...unless customers are pushing down your door to get at what you've got, you MUST pull them in. The process of elimination...turning complete strangers into "suspects," turning "suspects" into "prospects," turning "prospects" into "customers"...that's a salesperson's job, the entire reason behind their receiving a paycheck, whether it's base and commission or straight commission. So if you are a salesperson and you cannot or will not make cold calls, you can start counting the days until your boss invites you to seek employment elsewhere.The fear / avoidance of Cold Calling...referred to as "Call Reluctance" in trade terms...is handled in Rosen's book better than I've seen it handled in most places. He devotes Chapter 2 ("Becoming Fearless") to this subject, but the "25 words or less" version of what he's trying to get you to understand is summed up near the end of the chapter:"Get out of your head. Once you get yourself out of your own way, you are then able to generate extraordinary results."You see, "Cold Calling techniques" are great, and there is no shortage of them in this book, but until you become comfortable with the concept of making those calls repeatedly (and making as many calls as it takes to close as many sales as you ultimately need to close), the techniques will simply teach you something that you do not want to do.So Rosen peels back the layers and helps you ask the questions you need to ask. WHAT are you afraid of? WHY are you afraid of it? WHAT benefits might you receive if you are able to "get out of your head?"Humans, in general, love to over-think and over-analyze most aspects of life. But when you are out there trying to make a living, paralysis by analysis will not serve you. You need to sit down, determine your goals, make a series of actionable steps, and go to work.If you've determined the pathway to your goals is best supported by being a salesperson, Rosen's book can...and WILL...help you.The book is about 1000% better than its title. Why he chose to label such a fine work in this manner is beyond me, but don't dwell on that. Buy it, learn from it, put it into practice, and be successful. YOU CAN! You just hhave to convince yourself first and then you'll have no trouble convincing everyone else.

I'm giving Claude four stars for this one largely due to the pragmatic nature of his approach. I am a sole proprietor...which means I am also my "sales force." There are no clients unless I go out and get them. A cornerstone of Claude's approach is making a LOT of contact with a LOT of prospects:"Phone faster.. in 1 hours time you’ll get a couple of solid appointments if you phone fast. Then you’ll say, “Wow, this works”. If you call only a few every hour, it will feel like you never get an appointment. “It doesn’t work.. I called for a whole hour!”. Phone faster."Now, the only CHALLENGE with that...if you want to use a list of pre-qualified prospects rather than the Yellow Pages shotgun approach...is that you either have to purchase the list or compile it yourself. Decent, "scrubbed" lists cost a lot of money. Do-it-yourself lists are the best, because you can be assured of their accuracy before you pick up the phone or walk in, but it takes many, many hours to come up with even the smallest of lists. That's true of what I do...Web Design. For your product or service it might take more time, it might take less.Claude doesn't really offer a solution for that obstacle, he just assumes you're reading the book on the other side of it. He does offer a few list sources, but sometimes a low budget means no budget, and when it comes to "free" list brokers, you get what you pay for. Unless you can afford the best list available, you really are better off investing the sweat equity and compiling it yourself.What I like BEST about Claude's philosophy...the source of my 4 star rating overall for the book...is his "care while not caring" principle. You have to care enough to pick up the phone or hit the streets, yes. But you have to immunize yourself against "caring" about prospects who don;t want what you have to offer. That's where most salespeople slow down or stop...they take the rejection personally, which is foolish, because it's never really a "personal" exchange with a prospect on first contact anyway, unless you're coming to them via a referral.This is a book for WORKING salespeople...he's not teaching any tricks or gimmicks here. It's more "old school" than some of the modern sales gurus like Jeffrey Gitomer. I would not say that this is the one and only book on sales that you should own. I would say that you should own it, that you should learn as much from it as you can, and add it to the well-rounded knowledge you have gained from other sources. Study the "sales dogs" like the immortal Zig Ziglar and Brian Tracy. Get a couple of Gitomer books like "The Sales Bible" and "The Little Red Selling." Add Claude's expertise to that mix and you will be one empowered individual, ready for success.

I'll admit right up front that I don't read a lot of "rock biographies." Many of them are poorly written and too one-sided (the performer must be a saint of sinner with no room in between).I place this book on similar standing with the Neil Young bio "Shakey" by Jimmy McDonough. The backsstory on that one...briefly...is that it was / is an "authorized" bio, that Neil gave McDonough unrestricted access to his "inner circle," and once he read a copy of the first draft, locked down everyone and everything. That's why it moves along at such a smooth pace and then stops on a dime...Neil stopped it because McDonough told the truth and Neil didn't like seeing it on the page.So this is not a "tabloid" book where Bockris rips Lou mercilessly to shreds, and it's also not Tiger Beat. I didn't know Lou. There's basically one person who knows how "true" the truth is in Bockris' words and that would be the late, great Lou himself. It FEELS true. If you lived through it, the albums and the backstage / offstage stories and the whole ball of wax, this book FEELS like an accurate document of who and what Lewis Allan "Lou" Reed actually WAS.You know, it is OK to tell the story of the man and still hold up the music as groundbreaking, legendary, and unforgettable.Lou had some issues.So does Neil.That happens sometimes when you're dealing with a genius.

The first thing that I liked about this book was the format. Writing a book in small, easy-to-digest in one sitting chapters has become increasingly popular...just look at the collected works of sales guru Jeffrey Gitomer. This book gives you the content of the chapter, followed by an "Action Step." The author recommends a ton of external resources. Obviously, you won't read or view all of them, but many of them will jump off the page as exactly the kind of sage wisdom you need in your life right now. I see this book as a good investment and a refresher course on replacing the attitudes and behaviors in your life that don't work with the ones that do. Highly recommended.

I first discovered Dr. Robert Anthony's books via a 12-week Sales & Management Training class I took in the late 80s. His writings were basically "The Secret" in the modern era, decades before Rhonda Byrne's 2006 book. Both Anthony and Byrne drew heavily from the turn-of-the-20th-Century books you will find collected under the covers of "The Prosperity Bible" (a five-star purchase if there ever was one), as well as the writings of Ralph Waldo Emerson and Earl Nightingale's "The Strangest Secret." Anthony delivered the "You are what you believe you are / what you think about with the most consistency and emotion" message in a modern language that eschewed much of the dated quaintness found in the "Prosperity Bible" books.
